DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lavarch Mr M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, I present the Committee's report, incorporating a dissenting report, entitled Halfway to Equal, the report of the inquiry into equal status for women in Australia, together with the minutes of proceedings and evidence received by the Committee.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the House take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to continue my remarks when the debate is resumed.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scholes The Hon G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present two reports of the Standing Committee on Procedure. One involves the completion of the Standing Orders with respect to the election of the Speaker, the election of the Chairman of Committees and other proceedings therein. The second report deals with the seconding of items in private members' time.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the reports be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the House take note of the reports.

SPEECH.PARA: The first of the two reports I have presented has to do with the completion of a series of standing orders which deal with the opening of Parliament and the election of Speaker. They are in line with matters which have already been reported to this Parliament in the past and they incorporate a proposition which was agreed to by this House in the previous Parliament, that the senior member of the Parliament should take the chair during that election, with the exception that there has been built into the new proceedings a new Deputy Chairman's position, which would be the Senior Deputy Chairman, who would be a person nominated at the commencement of the Parliament by the Speaker. That person would act, in the absence of the Speaker or the Chairman of Committees, in the Chairman of Committees' role and would normally take the chair in those circumstances where either of those persons were not present or available.

PARA.TAB: The second matter is a minor report, and I would ask the Government to give consideration to its urgent building into the sessional orders. It recommends allowing a member of this House to lodge a private member's notice and for that notice to be presented to the House, subject to the Selection Committee, without the need for the member to seek and obtain a seconder's signature in advance of lodging the notice. It is a departure from the present process but, given the circumstances in the House and given the fact that there is a filtering device in the Selection Committee, it is considered to be appropriate that a member should, on his own initiative, be able to lodge a matter of private members' business without the need to show a seconder.

The debate obviously could not proceed without a seconder once it had been introduced, but that procedure would facilitate the position of the Independents in the Parliament and would allow members to raise private matters where they did not wish to go through the party process when they did not see that as being appropriate.

TALK.START.PARA: —In accordance with sessional order 102B, the debate is adjourned. The resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, I present the Committee's report entitled Review of the Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research together with evidence received by the Committee.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade examined the effectiveness of the Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research known as ACIAR. Specifically, the Committee looked at, firstly, the effectiveness of ACIAR as an element of Australia's official development assistance program against its charter embodied in the ACIAR Act of 1982 and, secondly, the desirability or otherwise of the continued existence of the Centre as a statutory authority after the expiration of 12 years of operations, which is June 1994, the maximum length of existence specified in the current Act.

PARA.TAB: While Australia has extensive expertise in agricultural research, it was not until the creation of ACIAR in 1982 that the expertise was effectively applied to developing countries' agricultural problems. The Centre was established by the Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research Act of 1982 as a statutory authority within the Foreign Affairs and Trade portfolio. The legislation contained a sunset clause disbanding the Centre after 12 years unless its continuation was recommended by a new Act.

What was a surprise to the Committee was that ACIAR is a really good news story. Outside the field of those involved in agricultural research, the work of ACIAR is almost completely unknown. Its work has great benefit and should be much more widely publicised. Furthermore, the high level of ACIAR's performance sets an example for other statutory bodies to try to match.

The Committee has made 21 recommendations covering the areas of management and organisation, ACIAR's research program, funding, relations with other organisations, ACIAR in the future, extending ACIAR's mandate and public awareness. The first two recommendations cover management and organisation. The Centre has two governing bodies, a Policy Advisory Council and a Board of Management. The Policy Advisory Council provides advice to the Minister regarding agricultural problems of developing countries and programs and policies with respect to agricultural research for either or both of the following purposes: firstly, identifying agricultural problems of developing countries and, secondly, finding solutions to agricultural problems of developing countries.

Membership of the Council currently consists of the President, the Director of the Centre, the person for the time being occupying or performing the duties of the Director-General of the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau and not fewer than 12 nor more than 16 other members.

The Board of Management of the Centre is responsible for the conduct and control of the affairs of the Centre. It consists of the President of the Council, the Director of the Centre, the person for the time being occupying or performing the duties of the Director-General of the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau and three other members appointed by the Governor-General from among the members of the Council.

The Committee believes there is scope for a reduction in the membership of the Policy Advisory Council and that the membership of Australians and non-Australians should be equal. Furthermore, the Committee believes that there should be some degree of flexibility in AIDAB representation on both bodies. To this end our first recommendation covers an amendment to section 8(1)(c) of the ACIAR Act dealing with AIDAB representation on the ACIAR Board of Management.

Our second recommendation is that there be an amendment to section 19 dealing with the membership of the Policy Advisory Council including AIDAB representation. The size of the Council is to be reduced to 12 and half the Council members are to be residents of countries other than Australia. The Committee in its third recommendation recommends that the quorum requirement for a meeting of the Policy Advisory Committee be reduced from nine to seven and that the President have a deliberative and casting vote.

With regard to the ACIAR's research program the Committee has made four recommendations. The Committee supports ACIAR's primary focus on South East Asia and the South Pacific. However, the Committee recommends that as funding permits ACIAR should foster collaborate projects of mutual importance to other parts of the world including Africa, the Middle East and South America. North Africa and the Middle East in particular should be a priority because of Australia's expertise in dry land farming.

It is important for ACIAR and its contracted organisations to have some flexibility in determining the length of stay of Australian scientists in a country. The Committee recommends that ACIAR in conjunction with its commissioned organisations and partner institutions continue to evaluate the length of stay of Australian scientists in a country on a project by project basis.

Although ACIAR's research program activities have been successful, improvement is still possible in several areas. Project length is currently three years, but in some cases this has not been sufficient. The Committee recommends that ACIAR be more flexible in determining project length, allowing projects to be approved on a case by case basis for periods of between three and five years.

There have been some difficulties in the past relations between ACIAR research program coordinators and Australian scientists in the commissioned organisations. While most problems could be described as personality driven rather than institutional, the Committee sees merit in ACIAR setting out clear guidelines governing the relationship between ACIAR and the commissioned Australian research institutions and detailing the relevant responsibilities of each position.

The Committee looked closely at the question of the economic returns to the partner countries from the annual expenditure by ACIAR of $17m to $18m. The figures which ACIAR provided to the Committee, based on an economic assessment of the costs and returns of 12 research projects, are very impressive indeed. Based on these 12 research projects alone, ACIAR claims that for a total research cost of $27.4m—that is in 1990 dollars—the expected benefits over the next 15 to 20 years would be $816.7m, again in 1990 dollars. The Committee was rigorous in its questioning of the basis of the cost-benefit analysis but, even with a sizeable error factor built in, the Committee acknowledges that the outcome of ACIAR's research to date has, at the very least, proved cost-efficient, unlike a number of projects undertaken under the general aid program.

With regard to funding, the Committee has made three recommendations. The Committee was satisfied that the financial operations and measures to ensure accountability were sufficiently rigorous to ensure that the disposal of its funds were in keeping with the objectives for which they were appropriated. The Committee noted the Auditor-General's concern over the question of financial delegations and the related issues of payments into the trust fund and the types of financial statements required at present. The Committee recommends amendment to the ACIAR Act as a matter of urgency to rectify these technical problems.

Given the success of ACIAR's work and the fact that funding levels have remained in the range of 1.3 to 1.48 per cent of total official development assistance, the Committee believes there is room for a significant increase in the budget allocation for ACIAR. The Committee therefore recommends that ACIAR's priority within the aid budget be increased, and that by 1997 approximately 3.5 per cent of the aid budget should be allocated to ACIAR.

ACIAR does not meet the full cost of some of its activities for the Australian commissioned organisations. The Committee agrees that there need to be clear guidelines established that detail what will and will not be funded by ACIAR and therefore recommends that the ACIAR Board of Management formalise and issue a policy on the matter of overheads and cost recovery for the information and guidance of Australian collaborative institutions.

The relationship between ACIAR and AIDAB is longstanding and extensive and appears to be of mutual benefit. Similarly, relations between ACIAR and its commissioned organisations and their partner institutions are generally productive.

Although Australia contributes to the core funding of international agricultural research centres, there has been a significant decline in our contributions since 1986 and the current allocation of $7.4m is equivalent to approximately one-half of one per cent of the total aid budget. These contributions are administered by AIDAB, but ACIAR has a close working relationship with these centres.

The Committee makes two recommendations on relations with other organisations: firstly, that funding for the international agricultural research centres, together with the resources needed to administer these funds, be transferred from AIDAB to ACIAR; and, secondly, the Committee further recommends that the funding for the international agricultural research centres is to be additional to the increase in ACIAR core funding recommended earlier and that the level of international agricultural research centre core funding be increased to 1.5 per cent of total official development assistance over 5 years.

Under its terms of reference, the Committee was charged to examine the desirability or otherwise of the continued existence of the centre as a statutory authority after the expiration of 12 years of operations, the maximum length of existence specified in the current Act. The Committee was unanimous in its opinion that ACIAR should continue and that it should retain its statutory authority status within the Foreign Affairs and Trade portfolio.

While sympathetic to ACIAR's wish to have the uncertainties of the sunset clause removed, there was a strongly held view on the Committee that the existence of a sunset clause had distinct advantages. Indeed, the Committee is of the view that greater use should be made of sunset clauses to review the performance of all statutory bodies. The role of sunset clauses for statutory authorities should be the subject of examination and the Committee recommends that the appropriate parliamentary committee inquire into the role of sunset clauses for statutory authorities. As other statutory authorities do not have sunset clauses, ACIAR argued that it could see no reason why it should be treated in a totally different way from any other statutory body created.

There was a strong belief in the Committee that there was considerable benefit in retaining the sunset clause as it kept the organisation at a high level of performance with the achievement of excellent results. On equity grounds the Committee does not recommend the imposition of a further sunset clause on ACIAR. However, to ensure the continued strong performance of the organisation, the Committee does recommend that the new Act to continue ACIAR include a fundamental review every five years of ACIAR's terms of reference, including the continued existence of the organisation; it also recommends that the review of ACIAR be carried out by a parliamentary committee, as this will assist in achieving public awareness of the value of ACIAR's work, and that the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade is the appropriate body to conduct such a review.

The mandate of the centre is closely defined, with functions such as training and extension programs precluded from its activities. The Committee has made four recommendations which are, in essence, an extension of ACIAR's charter. Time precludes my going into these in very much detail, but the Committee found the ACIAR inquiry to be a positive one because the centre did such a very good job. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I endorse the remarks of my colleague the honourable member for Warringah (Mr MacKellar), because there is little doubt that what he has said identifies so much of the worthwhile work that has been undertaken by the Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research. I want to identify a number of particular matters of concern. Firstly, I do not think many of the members of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade were aware of the work undertaken by ACIAR before we undertook this inquiry, and I do not think many other people were either. For that reason, recommendation 21 suggests that ACIAR consult with AIDAB on ways to increase public awareness of the importance of ACIAR's work and its achievements in solving major agricultural problems. Indeed, annexed to the report—and I commend this to all honourable members—is a list of some of the projects in which ACIAR has been involved.

PARA.TAB: The members of the Committee thought it was remarkable that so much economic benefit had flowed from the work of Australian scientists. One of the parallel benefits of this work is that not only has it extended into overseas countries, but there has certainly been a flow-on in a number of areas in Australia. For example, with regard to the storage and handling of tropical fruits, much of the work that has been undertaken at Queensland University has as much application to our own produce as it does to the produce of the South Pacific and South East Asia.

Some of the work has involved quite extraordinary dedication. On page 86 of the report there is reference, for example, to the biological control of salvinia waterweed. This was a three-year project led by Dr Peter Room and Dr Wendy Forno from the CSIRO Division of Entomology. The extent to which the efforts by these two scientists and their assistants had brought enormous benefits to the community was quite remarkable. It related not only to the economic benefits to rice farmers and fishermen and their families and to hydro-electricity authorities, but it also had a health flow-on because of the reduced spread of disease by mosquitoes. The economic benefits have been assessed at a cost ratio of 32 : 1, which is a phenomenal figure.

I have referred to the need for a greater understanding of the work of ACIAR. I now want to refer to the excellent work that is being undertaken by the Policy Advisory Council. Professor John Dillon of the University of New England has long been associated with the ACIAR group. When I heard the recommendations of the Policy Advisory Council, I confess that I was impressed by what was a remarkable combination of representatives from Australia and overseas. To have this combination of people recommending aid programs is unusual.

In recommendation 2, some adjustments are suggested to the constitution of that board, as indeed there is to the membership of the ACIAR Board of Management. However, essentially we think the work being undertaken by ACIAR is first-rate and deserves to be extended. As my colleague has said, one of the matters of concern was whether or not the sunset clause should be extended. In fact, we have recommended that it be removed and that a five-year review program be undertaken.

One other factor which I wanted to refer to was that, obviously, because of the benefits of this type of cooperative research it needs to be examined in relation to what can be done in other fields. Therefore, in recommendation 20, we suggested that the Government should examine the possibility of establishing an organisation along the same lines as ACIAR for the purpose of providing research and development assistance to regional countries in manufacturing systems, human resource development and so on.

Last night I spent a few moments talking about AIDAB and aid programs in relation to the Asian Development Bank allocations in the Bill. It seems to me that the concept of ACIAR is one which we need to examine. It seems to bring direct benefits in that it links the academic community and the farmer or the practical requirements of government. I think it is a model which needs to be extended. I commend all those who have been involved with ACIAR. It is an outstanding program. I also commend the products of its work to honourable members. I am sure anyone who has an opportunity to see its work in practice will believe, as do the members of the Committee, that it has been a worthwhile investment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to strongly support the remarks made by the honourable member for Warringah (Mr MacKellar) and the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) because ACIAR, the Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research, is a particularly effective aid organisation. As background to my remarks, I draw honourable members' attention to a United Nations development program report, Human Development Report, which has just been published. It has on its front cover a diagram in the shape of a champagne glass which shows the global distribution of income. At the top of the champagne glass, it shows that the top 20 per cent of global income earners receive 83 per cent of global income. The bottom 20 per cent receive 1.7 per cent. It is obviously essential for a relatively wealthy country such as Australia to do what it can to influence that distribution. One of the most important contributions that I have ever come across is the work by the ACIAR. It is particularly cost-effective.

PARA.TAB: I would like to quote one example. The right honourable member for New England quoted another example. I have had a little contact with a project that the centre was involved in, the control of newcastle disease amongst chickens. Newcastle disease is the world's worst viral disease in village chicken populations. We have a very mild variety of the disease in Australia and it occurred to a couple of researchers that they could use that mild viral strain to develop a heat resistant oral vaccine which could be used to stop the disease in Asia; and they did that.

Chickens are very important, obviously, as a source of protein and of cash in low income countries. Yet newcastle disease was wiping out large populations of chickens, sometimes annually. This strain developed in Australia has been used to stop the disease in one of the states of Malaysia. It has now been adapted for use in five other South East Asian countries. An independent assessment of the benefit of this research shows that, over the six countries in which the oral vaccine is now being used, the saving is about $150m. So for a cost to Australia of $3m—that is all the project cost—there has been a saving to those six lower income countries of about $150m, a benefit-cost ratio of 25 : 1.

That is a particularly good example of the cost-effectiveness of the funds that are spent through this agricultural research organisation. That is the reason why the Committee has recommended that funding for ACIAR be increased to 3 1/2 per cent of the aid budget by 1997. In fact, that is our most important recommendation. Obviously we have to constantly review the aid program to see which parts are most effective and which parts are less effective. Clearly this is one of the most effective parts; therefore the Committee has recommended that its funding be substantially increased. I hope that the Government will accept that recommendation, because this is one of the areas where Australia, being an agricultural country, can make the greatest contribution to developing countries.
Motion (by Mr Mackellar) proposed:
That the House take note of the report.

TALK.START.PARA: —In accordance with sessional order 102B, the debate is adjourned. The resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 2 April, on motion by Mr Peter Morris:
That the House take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cadman Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report presented by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure is entitled Warehouse to Wharf and was an inquiry into the efficiency of the interface between seaports and land transport. It was a wide-ranging examination of one of the real cost factors for Australian exporters and importers.

PARA.TAB: In 1987 the Inter-State Commission presented a report on the features of costs for exporters and importers and made the remark that:

SPEECH.PARA: The costs of unreliability and uncertainty affect importers and exporters in financial terms at least as much as direct charges. The insidiousness of unreliability is that its impact is largely open ended and outside user control.

The Inter-State Commission was saying that those who should be beneficiaries of an efficient system—the exporters and importers, the factories and farmers, and the retailers and wholesalers of Australia—are those who cannot control the process of movement of goods through the seaports and land transport systems. They are the ones who pay—and ultimately the Australian consumer pays.

PARA.TAB: A myriad of reports have been presented on this area over the last 10 years. It is interesting that a committee of the Parliament has come to grips with all of the elements in land transport in relation to the export and import of goods. I pay tribute to the staff and to the Chairman of the Committee for the way in which the inquiry was conducted, and to those members of the Subcommittee who expressed a particular interest in this issue.

Regarding figures produced by the Bureau of Transport Economics on the cost of shore based shipping costs, it is interesting to note the movement of those costs over the last five or six years. In most areas there appears to have been a decrease in costs, although in some instances costs have increased. These costs are attributable to ports and their related charges, to stevedoring, customs brokers, transport to and from wharf, packing and unpacking, and transport to and from a depot when necessary.

On the scale used by the Bureau of Transport Economics, it is interesting to note that between 1985 and 1991 the cost of less-than-container loads declined from a figure of 2,392 to 1,972. It is a ratio, not a figure, and is a measure used as an economic measuring model. Despite that decline, there are areas in the system where costs have increased. Those areas where costs have increased include customs brokers and transport to and from wharf, the area examined by this Committee. Those costs have significantly increased while many other costs have tended to decline over the six-year period.

If one is to take seriously the statement of the Inter-State Commission, then Australians are paying multimillion dollars for the inefficiencies in the movement of goods between factories and farms and the wharf, or from the wharf into the shops. There is a complex arrangement and cross-matching of transport arrangements that the Committee examined and set out in tables in the report. These tables cover pages of the requirements and processes in the transport system.

The report shows that the responsibilities for people in the transport system are so complex that one becomes aware that the transport system and the movement of goods is an industry in itself, an industry which is not responsible to the users of that system and in which the users cannot control the prices.

The Committee has come forward with recommendations for the establishment of an interface efficiency council. It could, in fact, in my view, prove to be not as valuable as the Committee first thought it might be. This Committee report is a wonderful compromise, with the Australian Labor Party not wanting to go as fast in some areas as the coalition and the coalition forcing the pace with changes to workplace relationships and many other areas where we see a sense of urgency.

The Committee worked very smoothly and came to the best agreement possible in the circumstances. There has been no dissenting report to this final report because people have agreed with the results and the recommendations. However, in some instances, what flows from this report on the part of the Government is a reluctance to move as fast as the Opposition would want things to move in this critical area where there is a need for absolute urgency if we are to remain competitive and to boost our export effectiveness and the return to Australian producers and manufacturers and where those who are importing need to retain a minimal cost.

The establishment of an efficiency council would look at things such as desirable changes in the system, the frustrations and inefficiencies that occur, the lack of coordination and the documentation problems. I have mentioned the myriad of processes in the import and export chain in the transport mode but when one comes to look at the documentation required for the movement of credit or cash it is hardly less complex, with a system of checking and cross-checking that is understandable but which is complex.

One of the interesting recommendations, and many submissions were received, was on the prospect of electronic data interchange and the need for Australia to establish a comprehensive process that could be accessed by all importers and exporters so that the information for ordering, times for arrival of ships and exact description of goods or cargo can be done quickly, can be done efficiently and can be done in such a way that all users—importers, exporters, customs agents and government departments—can access the information. The process appears to be moving slowly and it appears that in every sense there will be a commercial gain from the process. It is time that Australians understood that we are in a very competitive world and if Australia is going to succeed then the need to establish an efficient electronic data interchange as a matter of absolute priority cannot be overstressed. Australia must take a lead in this area if we are going to be successful in the drive to export efficiently and to have our imports come in at minimal costs.

The report itself, as I have mentioned, is a compromise; many of the recommendations, in my view, are softer than they need be and there appears to be a lack of urgency about the report. I am not being critical of my colleagues or taking a partisan view; it is a personal point of view. I do not think that Australians at large understand how critical this area is for the future of our nation. The complexity of the transport processes in the export and import of goods is not understood; it has become an industry in itself. It is becoming an industry which is self-perpetuating and lacks real competition. There is a need to change the whole approach to this industry if we are going to be effective and competitive.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to speak to the report of the Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure, Warehouse to Wharf. No area is subject to such emotion as the Australian waterfront, and no area—except maybe the flag—suffers more by the distortion and ignorance of most of its critics.

PARA.TAB: Of course, it is very convenient, either intentionally or unintentionally, to confuse the Australian waterfront with the Australian Waterside Workers Union. The waterside workers are only one link in a whole chain of operators on the waterfront. The Opposition can, in the unlikely event that it becomes the Government, put the troops on the waterfront. But unless those opposite are prepared to tackle all of the options, it will be an expensive, divisive gesture of futility.

The Committee and the Subcommittee of which I was a member tried to look at all aspects of the movement of containers and cargo through Australia's major ports. I believe that we have come up with a report containing recommendations that will, if accepted, correct many of the problems plaguing the interface between seaports and land transport. The thrust of the report is to generate a better understanding of the needs of all who are involved in the whole interface, including users of those services, and a better understanding of how we can make the system work more effectively for the benefit of the whole nation.

It was therefore disappointing that on the release of our report, the shadow Minister, the honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Sharp), put out a press release criticising the report in which he says that the report is a soft option report. It is clear that he does not understand the operations of the interface between the warehouse and the waterfront. It is also clear that he does not understand industrial relations on the waterfront. He did not make a submission to the inquiry. He did not appear before the Committee, which was open for him to do. He did not attend any Committee hearing as the Opposition spokesperson on shipping. He wanted to go on a union bashing exercise; but the Committee, over a period of 18 months, tried to dispel the `us versus them' adversarial theme. All the members of the Committee tried to develop in its place a spirit of cooperation, of getting people to understand the complexities of each other's tasks, responsibilities and needs, and of making the whole interface work better for the benefit of the nation.

The Committee found that the waterfront has been a sorry saga of lost opportunities. Too many people have been prepared to put all the blame on the Waterside Workers Federation. This is a smokescreen behind which many of the most vocal critics hide their own inefficiencies and unwillingness to change; but change they must if Australia is to become competitive. Responsibility for the failure to act rests squarely on the shoulders of importers, exporters, transport chain participants and their respective industry organisation. The inquiry has revealed an appalling apathy, ignorance and inertia on the part of users of waterfront services.

Participants along the chain have each operated within their own discrete worlds, without regard to the impact of their actions on the overall efficiency of the chain. Much of the evidence presented to the Committee had been heard before by either the Webber Committee on Shore Based Shipping Costs in 1984-86 or the Inter-State Commission from 1986-89.

One reason for the apathy could be the unpreparedness for, or unawareness of, the individual cost components of the services utilised. This arises from the lack of a direct commercial relationship between importers and exporters and the service providers. Alternatively, it may be that, despite all the rhetoric from some industry organisations, individual firms have not seen the waterfront costs as a priority.

The inquiry found a prevalent attitude among participants of blaming each other for the inefficiencies, expense and failing of interface services. It was a case of, `It was always someone else's fault'. It is clear that if participants in the chain from the warehouse to the wharf started talking to each other rather than about each other, Australia's trade effort would greatly benefit. The waterfront is not an `it', it is not a single entity; it is the sum of many players.

Of course, as the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Anderson) said on its presentation and the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman) said this morning, the report was a compromise. Some members wanted to go stronger on some recommendations; but they were discussed, and we came up with a unanimous report that was agreed on all sides. I thought that that was good.

Of course, when there were half a dozen people in the room, each having different points of view, each of us would have put greater emphasis on some area. For example, in my own case, I would have liked to see more credit go to the waterside workers who, despite what we hear in this place, have reformed their industry. But of course, willing as I always am to compromise, I did not want too much praise to go to the Waterside Workers Federation. Indeed, I was in agreement that, where a critical comment was deserved, it should be included in the report.

The waterfront exemplifies one of our national shortcomings. Australians have always been loath to face up to responsibility. We always find it easier to blame others rather than to look at improving our own performance. As is known, the waterfront produces nothing. The waterfront reacts. It makes nothing at all. It does not build anything. But it does provide a service. People bring cargo to the waterfront by sea and take it away by land, or vice versa. The timetables are very much determined by those who use the waterfront, whether by sea or by land. That is not done by the waterfront.

All aspects of our port system were comprehensively reviewed with the aim of achieving substantial improvements in efficiency and productivity. One area that I would like to stress is the importance of what is called the `paper chain' on the waterfront. This is one area where improvement could be made, and this may come with electronic data information flow. It has been estimated that some 40 million documents—imagine it—are generated annually in Australia, related to the transport of import and export cargo. Around 100 separate pieces of paper can be required in the import process alone. The reduction in paperwork, repetitive data processing and keeping tabs on cargo is estimated to produce savings of between 3 and 5 per cent of the value of our traded goods. This represents a saving of between $100m and $200m per annum, just by cutting out the paperwork.

Comparing the current complexity of paperwork with the intricacies of our system for payment of cargo, the current reliance on the antiquated bill of lading and letter of credit systems is causing unnecessary delays at the sea and land transport interface. This was illustrated in evidence from the Committee's Western Australian hearing that ship borne cargo may arrive prior to the bill of lading. Steaming time from Singapore might be only four days, but it might be seven days before the documentation arrives. Cargo would not be able to be unloaded until the bill of lading arrived. This is clearly an unsatisfactory situation and urgent reform is needed in this area. Again, the increased use of electronic data interchange and electronic funds transfer will assist in simplifying and streamlining the process.

The spotlight must now turn to the interface between our ports and our land transport. I see this report acting as a catalyst to speed up the process of trade and ensure that it spreads along the whole of the transport chain. That is what we have got to do. They cannot be isolated, and the whole of the users of the waterfront have got to start talking to each other. They have got to start acting as a single entity. It is no good, any longer, each blaming the other. Each group has got to take responsibility for its own actions. If we are serious—and if they are serious—about bringing real and significant change and reform on the waterfront, it is up to them. We can set the guidelines, but it is up to them to act.

In conclusion, I would like to pay tribute to the Chairman, the honourable member for Shortland (Mr Peter Morris) for the excellent work he did; to the Deputy Chairman, the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman), and all the members of the Committee, who worked very hard; and especially to the staff, Chris Patterson and June Murphy, without whose diligence and assistance we would not have been able to bring down this report, which I think is one of the most important reports that will come before this Federal Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report of the Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure entitled Warehouse to Wharf is my first experience of a Federal parliamentary inquiry and, like the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis), I must say I am particularly impressed with the operation of the Committee and I can only express admiration for the tremendous amount of work done by the Chairman, the honourable member for Shortland (Mr Peter Morris). I can also appreciate the efforts of the Committee staff and the officers of the Department of Transport and Communications.

PARA.TAB: Within the terms of reference of the inquiry, that is, an examination of the interface between seaport and land transport, I think the report is a major contribution to waterfront reform. It is obvious, however, from the many inspections and public hearings that the Subcommittee made around Australia, that a great deal still remains to be done to improve the total transport chain from factory or farm to the point of sale.

The report, and the many submissions, clearly show that, while labour reform has certainly been necessary and great improvements have in fact been made, the almost exclusive concentration on this aspect of the waterfront over the last decade has obscured not only the need to reform the whole transport chain, but also the wider factors which determine waterfront efficiency. I refer to the excessive number of container ports in Australia; the inherent difficulties of scheduling ship arrivals, given long distances; and the distorting effects of the pan-Australia freight rate. As well, there are the massive distortion of transport costs and the distortions of the relativities between road and rail, which after all not only determine the mode of transport but the infrastructure at the ports. Finally, of course, there is the parochialism of States and the political factors that have been evident in port funding for many years, in the provision of infrastructure. In fact, the more you look at the whole situation, the more it is apparent that it really would not matter if every port was manned by just one wharf labourer and he was paid at Bangladesh wage levels—our ports in Australia would still be hopelessly inefficient.

The Alice in Wonderland chain of industry participants between the importer and the exporter, at all container ports, is an almost impossible burden. The list includes the shipping companies, the stevedores, the container depots, the freight forwarders, the customs brokers, the banks, the road transport operators, the railways, the port authorities and the Federal regulatory agencies. Virtually none of these industry participants has any real incentive to improve the overall efficiency of the transport chain. In many cases, it is exactly the opposite. The incentive is for each participant to expand their area of activity and entrench themselves, and simply to pass on costs. The whole transport chain is collectively a sort of cost-plus system. Every operator has every reason to just obfuscate reasons for delay. Exporters and importers appear to have no control whatsoever, faced with the fragmentation of this transport chain.

It is all in sharp contrast, of course, to our bulk handling ports, which are efficient by any standards. The coal port at Newcastle has a complete absence of any middlemen. The terminal control is by the importers and exporters, and you can see why it is such an efficient port. In contrast, all the major container ports are inherently inefficient with their plethora of middlemen and their historic locations on the edges of large urban areas, which create ever-increasing transport difficulties.

It is very fortunate in one sense that most of our exports are large bulk goods and our imports are in containers. Our balance of payments would be far worse if the reverse situation applied. It is a wonder that we have not been accused of using container ports as a form of import restriction. The only thing we could do more effectively in this regard would be to restrict the issue of import licences to an office at Chambers Pillar manned by my colleague, the honourable member for Wills (Mr Cleary).

Seriously, I think manufacturing and container exports have little hope unless industry addresses the problems and the directions set out in this report, and government comes to grips with the wider causes of port inefficiency. The pan-Australia freight rate is a major distorter of costs and infrastructure spending on ports. It is certain that without it we would have quite a different arrangement in Australia.

For years we have been constantly told of the unfavourable comparisons between Australian ports and Singapore and major European ports. But how could we ever hope to be as efficient as those ports when Singapore alone handles three times the total containers of all Australian ports? How can we ever compete with Singapore when our multiplicity of ports get the dregs of the world's shipping; when our stevedores have got to sort through a relative handful of containers to unload them?

There is little doubt that we could get a dramatic increase in efficiency with fewer container ports. From the evidence given to the Committee, it seems that the direction in which we should be heading is maybe two container ports at Fremantle and Brisbane. I think evidence has been given that, even with the distortion of transport costs, containers can arrive into the suburbs of Sydney from Fremantle quicker by rail than if they stay on the boat. We were given evidence of large importers who have withdrawn business from Port Botany. In the case of Nissan cars, the importers now have them delivered through the port of Brisbane. I think a similar situation will arise at Melbourne.

It is an irony that so much funding has gone into abandoning what was the best port in Australia from a shipping point of view, that is, Sydney Harbour, to construct a much inferior and exposed Port Botany, which is often subject to weather delays. This decision, of course, was facilitated by the distortion in transport costs and the shift of containers from rail to road. Economic rationalists seem to have no trouble in relentlessly crushing people in the car or clothing manufacturing sectors but seem to regard road operators as untouchable.

I think the intellectual dishonesty of the Opposition in this matter is appalling, not only in its refusal to address transport subsidies, but also in its policy even to increase them in its Fightback package. But I suppose the National Party would never support the GST unless such a bribe were being offered.

The efficiency of our ports and the provision of infrastructure are fundamentally based on a transport system. While ever we build railways with loans, and roads with grants, and ignore external road costs, and refuse even to address the problem in any rational manner, we can never begin to approach port efficiency. The initiatives such as those contained in the One Nation package are also going to be largely wasted unless we address this matter.

Every inspection the Committee made, at Fremantle, Adelaide, Melbourne, Sydney and Brisbane, showed enormous amounts of wasted infrastructure spending. We saw disused wharves, disused equipment and disused railway lines. Much of that, of course, was a result of the parochialism of State governments and their fantasies around election time. While the Committee, I think, acknowledges that State government is responsible for land transport and port operation, the significance of the ports to the national economy shows that we really do have to look at the matter in a much wider national perspective. I think all port authorities showed a narrow and mostly unrealistic view of their operations, and I could see no alternative to stronger Commonwealth control on State infrastructure spending and port development. Nothing, but nothing, can be achieved until the economic distortions between rail and road are removed.

I think this report will be a catalyst for reform in the ports themselves. As the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Anderson) said, `It is only a beginning'. It is a worthwhile beginning, but we have got to realise that it is only the tip of the iceberg.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me first compliment the other members of the subcommittee of the Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure—the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Anderson), the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis), the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Mack), and also the Chairman, the honourable member for Shortland (Mr Peter Morris)—for the commitment and the work that they put into the production of the report titled Efficiency of the Interface between Seaports and Land Transport `Warehouse to Wharf'. Of course, the support of the members of the full Committee was also of great assistance. The on-site inspections were well attended, as were all the meetings by honourable members and also the public hearings. The assistance also of the secretariat, Chris Paterson, Les Dunn and June Murphy, as well as that of the advisers, John Jenkins, Malcolm Aldons and Martin Cotton, was invaluable.

PARA.TAB: There is no doubt that great inefficiencies are present in the way in which Australian ports operate. The Committee's efforts to gain information were often hampered by a hesitancy on the part of those giving evidence to see the bigger picture, the picture of the whole transport chain and its relevance to their own operation. There was also a tendency, where we went on on-site inspections, to show the Committee the sites rather than to divulge the real problems that exist. There was much conflicting evidence on which area had the inefficiencies and where those inefficiencies were present, and it was often usual for the Committee to be told that the fault lay in other parts of the chain, rather than the organisations seeing faults in their own operation.

The sorts of problems that are apparent really are a symptom, a reflection, of the more deep-seated, traditional ways of doing business in the transport chain. It is still an industry that is based very much on a cost-plus mentality. The real costs and savings are not passed through the chain so that the efficiencies of importers and exporters are reflected in their own costs.

There are some examples of this. The mismatch of working hours exemplifies this sort of problem. Terminal operators say they are able to operate 24 hours a day but warehouses will accept or send out their containers in a very narrow few hours each day, even then perhaps on only a few days a week. Of course, warehouse operators are driven by their own costs. But their stance raises the costs and inefficiencies that are apparent at the terminal. A warehouse that may be prepared to accept deliveries outside normal hours has the potential of increasing the efficiency at the terminal. That warehouse would not, however, share in the cost savings that the terminal could then generate.

The cost to terminal operators of the equipment needed on the wharf is great. Container handling equipment and other machinery on a wharf, if it is to be modern and state of the art, is very expensive. If that investment can be utilised for more hours of the day then there are efficiencies to be gained. There is no system of encouraging the transport operators and warehouses to increase their hours. In other words, warehouse and transport operators who were willing to increase the hours would be effectively subsidising those who were not. There should be a cost encouragement for them to do this.

The hours of operation create many problems. Those hours often coincide with peak traffic hours in cities and at times result in truck queues and a reduction of efficiency. The road transport part of the operation is often operating at the most inappropriate time.

Another instance of the whole chain not reflecting real costs is the traditional method of the pan-Australia charging for shipping of containers to Australia. Under this practice there is agreement between shippers that containers coming to Australian ports are charged the same regardless of which Australian port those containers are landed in. It is apparent that this cannot reflect the real costs of importers and exporters in handling those containers. This practice could result in the inability of individual ports to expand and take advantage of economies of scale. It could result in the retardation in the growth of our land based transport systems, particularly rail.

Considering the great cost of equipment in equipping container terminals and looking at overseas examples, it may be that fewer major ports would develop if the pan-Australia charge were not there but those that would develop would, by handling greater quantities, operate more efficiently because of economies of scale and be more likely to be better equipped. If real shipping costs are reflected port to port it will encourage other methods of land based transport—rail, perhaps—to once again operate more efficiently. This, of course, would fit in nicely with plans for an improved single gauge railway from Brisbane to Perth and drive development of that.

The practice of allowing free storage days for import containers at terminals encourages delay in picking up containers, as costs do not need to be paid until they are picked up. The result is greater peaking and troughing at terminals, together with greater costs and inefficiencies for those terminals. At the other end, in exporting containers, latitude is afforded by terminal operators to exporters beyond cut-off times for delivery of containers to terminals. This, once again, increases the cost to terminals.

In both these cases, whether the containers are going out or coming in, although the practices increase the costs those costs are not passed on to those people who take advantage of these practices. The conclusion is that those exporters who are complementing and adding to the efficient operation of the terminal are once again subsidising those who are reducing the efficiency and increasing the costs of the terminal. The charges made by terminal operators should reflect those costs so as to encourage and drive the industry towards efficiency.

Those three examples really do reflect one of the major issues that the Committee found needed to be addressed, which is that there needs to be an attitudinal change by the whole chain of participants in the interface area. They need to examine their own efficiencies in relation to the whole, and they need to introduce charges that reflect the real costs involved in the transport of containers to individual importers and exporters.With a policy of differential charging, in that way those participants can lead the improvements in the correct direction. It is worth looking at how these inefficiencies that seem so deep seated in this industry really came into being and how they have not been fixed to any great extent as yet.

It is my view that to a large extent the manner in which Australian industry operated, especially in the postwar era, has a lot to do with the practices that now seem so wrong. Under the protection policies of those years, it was very easy to pass on costs. Real competition did not exist. The quality and prices of overseas products were not competing with Australian goods. Australian manufacturers supplying only the domestic market were able to pass on those costs without a problem and with no thought to the fact that many of those costs were brought about by inefficient transport.

Now the need of Australian industry is to become competitive in all ways with the best that the world can offer. An integral part of that ability to become efficient and competitive is transport. Australia can no longer afford to pay more than the real cost without the inefficiencies for the carriage of goods to and from Australia. There is a real need to improve our performance.

There have been marked improvements in productivity on our wharfs which have seen gains in efficiencies. Since 1988-89 the turnaround time for grain vessels at Australian ports has been halved. Terminal operators report significant reductions in manning levels, with many of those being attained through multiskilling and restructuring of the work force. The challenge now is very much about structuring business, about encouraging an atmosphere of real competition where end customers can see that the cost of transport can be driven by them and the choices they make. Those choices must be available to them. Those customers—and every other link in the chain—must see the costs much more transparently and must see that by changing their practices they can influence their own costs. As I said earlier, this can only be achieved when there is differential charging that reflects those real costs.

The changes to attitude can be greatly assisted by a concerted effort at greater communication between all levels of participants in the chain. I note the recommendation of the Committee that interface efficiency councils be established to facilitate the efficient movement of cargo to and from ports, initially Sydney and Melbourne, and to formulate policy in relation to the port interface. It is my view that such a committee, properly put together and with the right aims, could do a great deal in creating the attitudinal changes that the Committee sees are so necessary and also it could encourage the acceleration and the coordination of effective electronic data interchange. (Time expired)

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Standing Committee for Long Term Strategies

TALK.START.PARA: —I have already tabled the paper. In its short life, the Standing Committee for Long Term Strategies has been active in a range of inquiries. It has already published two reports on the evolution of Australia as an information society and the policy implications that follow from it.

PARA.TAB: Now for something completely different: a survey of the implications of demographic change in Australia and, specifically, an analysis of what has been called the greying of Australia in the report Expectations of Life: Increasing the Options for the 21st Century. In keeping with the Committee's name, the report takes a long term view of the issues, looking past the next election and past the turn of the century to population projections for the year 2030 and beyond. Later speakers will deal with specific aspects of the report and outline its main recommendations. I will consider its philosophical thrust and mention only its most important recommendation, which is essentially a plea to the Government, the media and society as a whole to change their attitude to the aged.

Unlike other committees, the Long Term Strategies Committee is able to determine its own terms of reference. We decided to inquire into and report on the factors that will be the central determinants, the changing expectations, of life into the twenty-first century, with reference to the elements that determine the variations in longevity.

The elements include: occupation, gender, education, class, place of residence, ethnicity and race, consumption patterns, wealth and other factors; we also acknowledge the need to develop policies which recognise and encourage the redefining of `time-use value', that is, validating non-work experience, given that increasing longevity will coincide with declining labour input. In the face of the changing population structure, there is the need for maintenance of most productive use of human resources for the nation, the maintenance of individual quality of life into old age, developing policies for stimulating creative time use and developing policies to meet and anticipate changes in population structure in the areas of education, training and employment practices.

Our most important recommendation is that the Commonwealth Government recognise, first, that the changing demographic structure of the population requires reassessment of the value on importance, both socially and economically, of life outside traditional work. The capacity of people to confer value, that is, value without a dollar equivalent, on their own labour time use, will be increasingly significant when expectation of far longer active life coincides with a likely reduction in the length of the paid work life, especially physical work; second, that the increasing absolute and relative numbers of the elderly in Australian society do not impose a burden on the economy or threaten the viability of the health and welfare system; and that such demographic changes raise questions about social practices and institutions that need to be solved in a rational and consensual manner.

The justification for these propositions, and particularly the second, is contained in the report, which also considers many of the other challenges posed by the shifting demographic contours of our community: health and medical treatment; fitness and recreation; education, culture and the arts; transport, housing and urban planning; employment and social welfare. I name only the most obvious, all of which are considered in detail in this report.

One major challenge is the reallocation of resources as the proportions of young and old change. But the biggest challenge, one that cannot be met by legislation or funding, is how to change attitudes to ageing and the aged. If society sees the ageing population as a problem, to which solutions, even a final solution, must be found, it will be reflecting the negative attitudes towards the aged, so often found within the community, when none need exist. The challenge is to recognise the opportunities offered by the developing social structure and to devise policies to make use of the vast resources of energy, competence, wisdom and skill found, all too often neglected, within the aged community.

Like most industrial countries, Australia has experienced a considerable rise in life expectancy over the past century and is currently experiencing a significant rise in the proportion of those who remain vigorous well past the customary or even statutory retirement age. In Australia the rise in the proportion of older people, usually those defined as those over 60—the `chronologically gifted', as the neologism has it—is due partly to increased longevity and partly to the fact that the baby boom of the 1950s and 1960s was followed by a sharp fall in the birth rate.

Another important development is that, as life expectancy is increased, the age of retirement has tended to decrease. The result is that retirement, for the first time in human history, has become a definite and significant phase in most people's lives. People who retire today at 55 may look forward to at least another 20 years of active life.

These facts are well-known. What is less well-known and often wilfully obscured in the more alarmist reports on the coming aged boom, is that these trends will not continue indefinitely. Demographers project that the rise in the number of old people should level off around the middle of next century and that the proportion of those over 60 should stabilise at not more than 25 per cent. Future social planning does not need to assume an ever increasing aged segment, only that such people will come to constitute about a quarter of the population.

Similarly there is the likelihood that full employment, as we experienced it from World War II until 1974, will not be seen again—or the term will need radical redefinition—because we have the phenomenon of a change in the labour force as a result of an increasing proportion of women, historically very high participation rates, but a loss of employment opportunities for many people who were traditionally in work.

But the trend to early retirement has slowed down because of the increasingly manifest desire of older employees to continue working. The main demand from older citizens these days is not for the chance to retire early, but for the right to continue working beyond the normal retirement age, a reversal of the demand by working people and their unions in the nineteenth and most of the twentieth century. Strangely, the predominant response to increased life expectancy and the substantial period of free time following the end of formal employment, the third age as it has often been called, has not been excitement and joy.

Instead of welcoming the opportunities and challenges offered by this new stage of life, we have heard, in the mainstream media at least, little but expressions of fear and alarm at the burden which the increasing numbers of the aged are supposed to be imposing on the rest of society. Most of the evidence examined during my Committee's inquiry was aimed directly against such negative views. The message we received was that if there is a problem with the ageing of the population, the problem is not the aged but the myths about and hostile attitudes towards them.

Media alarmism about the greying of Australia—and even statements by government leaders—commonly recycles inaccurate or irrelevant figures and various journalistic cliches about Australia's demographic future. In particular, there is the fear that population ageing is a time bomb that threatens to blow the economy to pieces. Much of this fear is based on the strain that the aged population is expected to place on the age pension system. But close examination of the figures shows that while there is a need for careful planning and finely judged policies, there is no occasion for alarm. An important chapter in the Committee's report makes a critical analysis of this issue.

It is very important that we as a community move away from adopting the heresy that all values have dollar equivalents—indeed, that value means money value; loss of income means loss of value and recognition; and that unpaid work may have no significance in validating human activity. That would be tragic. The Committee draws attention to the importance of volunteer work, in which large numbers of Australians are involved and on which many important community services are increasingly dependent. We also urge the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services (Mr Howe) to initiate a review of national health spending, to compare expenditure on preventative medicine, which is rather low, to that on curative—after disease—medicine.

On behalf of the Committee I express my thanks to the Secretary of the Committee and our faithful staff members Kelly Fitzsimmons and Tracy Cumberland. A special tribute is due to Dr Robert Darby, who, as Secretary from June 1991, worked with extraordinary dedication and intellectual penetration in mastering and collating the large amount of material submitted to the Committee. We are very much in his debt. As Chairman I want to thank my Deputy Chairman and other Committee members for their hard work and their contribution to the report.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Deputy Chairman of the Standing Committee on Long Term Strategies, I would like to add my remarks to those made by the Chairman, the honourable member for Lalor (Mr Barry Jones). In November 1990 the Committee adopted its terms of reference and it was decided that the conduct of this particular inquiry should take place principally by means of research. It was decided on this occasion that a seminar would be held where a range of speakers would come and address the Committee on a range of relevant topics. I believe that this was quite a successful way of going about things.

PARA.TAB: The inquiry received up to 60 separate submissions after advertising in newspapers at the beginning of the inquiry. While my colleague the honourable member for Lalor has discussed the more philosophical aspects of the inquiry I would like now to take a little of the House's time to address some of the recommendations of the report.

Australia, together with the rest of the developed world, is undergoing significant demographic changes. It has experienced a rise in the proportion of elderly people in its population. While we still have, and will continue to have, a relatively young population in comparison with other industrialised countries, the trend is undoubtedly there, and it is one that the Government cannot afford to ignore.

The report has come up with some very specific recommendations, a good many of them aimed at changes in Commonwealth Government legislation. It has, for example, recommended that the Commonwealth Government introduce legislation along the lines of that covering sex, race and disability to make discrimination on the basis of age also unlawful. The words `racist' and `sexist' are now part of our daily vernacular—it probably will not be long before we add the word `ageist' to this list. It is a very appropriate term because, I believe, we are probably quite ageist in many of our attitudes or else we might ourselves be victims of ageist prejudices.

Perhaps I should mention at this stage that, to use the words of my respected Chairman, the honourable member for Lalor, I have already reached the `chronologically gifted' age, and I suppose I am well and truly into the third age group.

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps the honourable member should read my speech. The health state, longevity and consequently life expectancy of our population have undergone unprecedented improvement over the course of the past two decades. Not only are our people living longer, they are leading active and constructive lives to a much greater degree than in previous generations. I can certainly agree with that. It is important that governments begin to take cognisance of this factor and this report is an important step in this direction.

PARA.TAB: Other specific recommendations in the report include the abolition of compulsory age rated retirement in the Australian Public Service and other Commonwealth employment areas. It is also recommended that the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Beazley) look specifically at ways in which opportunities might be created for older people to participate in retraining or re-skilling and ensure that their access to and participation in the labour market are not diminished.

I should mention here that it is already coalition policy to see that those who wish to retire may retire, but those who do not should have the opportunity to stay on while they can contribute and be stimulated by their activities. This makes perfect sense when you consider that, with greater longevity in our community, there will be an increased number of individuals in the future whose period of retirement or post-employment will last as long as 20 years. This represents a savage waste of any nation's human resources if all this capacity, skill and experience were to be shut out of the economy through compulsory retirement.

The report also deals with other aspects of the lives of the elderly in our society, as my colleague the honourable member for Lalor stated in his introduction to the report. Richer people, the better educated and those with intellectually or physically demanding interests have greater flexibility in dealing with the vagaries of everyday life. The report, in its recommendations, seeks to ensure that older people live valuable lives for as long as possible, and I say amen to that.

It has dealt with the health and medical issues facing older Australians with some very specific recommendations to the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services and the Commonwealth Government. It has also touched upon the issues of physical fitness for older Australians and, quite significantly, their role in education, culture and the arts. A person, no matter what age, does not stop learning, and in this context the report also makes specific recommendations to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training.

The report also addresses the changing demographics of our nation in terms of housing and our urban environment. This is a significant factor, in that our cities have changed quite dramatically from relatively high density living to the monstrous suburbanisation of our living space. This has quite an effect on older people's lives.

Time does not permit me to elaborate any further, so in my closing remarks I would like to once again thank my colleague the honourable member for Lalor for his exemplary chairmanship and the members of the Long Term Strategies Committee, the Committee secretary, Mr Ian Dundas, and the support staff, Mrs Margaret Swieringa, Ms Kelly Fitzsimmons and Miss Tracy Cumberland, and especially Dr Robert Darby, who joined the inquiry from June 1991 and who I understand was responsible for most of the writing and administrative groundwork in putting this particular inquiry together. I commend the report to all members of the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, you and I and all the rest of us here, and probably most of the people up in the gallery, if we are lucky, will grow old. In fact, it is something we look forward to and yet, when one looks at the age situation in Australia, we need the recommendations of this report to be implemented; we really do. We need to end discrimination on the basis of age, and we need particularly to amend industrial relations legislation. We do need to abolish compulsory retirement in the Australian Public Service, for a start, and the New South Wales Government has given us a lead in this matter already. I just cannot understand how we as a society can automatically say that when you reach a certain age, you are finished, you are on the scrap heap, and all that accumulated knowledge and wisdom is no longer of any value. Of course, this is absolutely wrong.

PARA.TAB: I am delighted that the Committee has brought down this report. I commend those of my colleagues who have been heavily involved with it and the secretariat and staff of the Committee. I believe it is one of the most significant reports this Parliament has seen for some time.

I would like to make a point on growing old—if one is lucky—particularly as the Minister at the table, the Minister for Aboriginal and Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner), is involved in the matter I am raising. It is that we are lucky if we happen not to be Aboriginals. This needs to be highlighted. Most people do not realise that in 1988 the life expectancy figure for you and me, Mr Deputy Speaker, was 73.1 years and for our wives, 79.5 years. But for Aboriginals born in the Northern Territory in 1985, the life expectancy for males is only 53 years—20 years less than for males in the rest of society—and for females only 63 years, compared with 79.5 years for other women.

We are talking about discrimination on age, but these figures highlight an area where the expectations of life should be broadcast more. I make that point because while I believe—as the Minister at the table well knows—that we should provide for Australian people on the basis of need and not on the basis of race, I think the figures illustrate that Aboriginal people are greatly in need.

I also applaud the recommendation of the Committee that the Government should investigate phased retirement and make the employment of older people more flexible. The proposal for the modification of the age pension to encourage older people to re-enter the work force and use their skills and knowledge is highly commendable. The proposal is that they might retain a percentage of the pension depending on the number of hours worked.

I agree most strongly with the recommendation that there should be increased local involvement in assessing Department of Social Security benefits, in order to encourage a maximum sense of community and to use local knowledge.

I totally endorse the proposition that we should acknowledge the work done voluntarily by people throughout our society. I know from the very many organisations in my electorate and elsewhere in Australia of the value to society—as the honourable member for Lalor (Mr Barry Jones) said, you cannot put a dollar value on it—of voluntary workers. The voluntary care they provide is absolutely incredible.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is essential.

—As the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite) says, it is absolutely essential. In the brief time remaining to me I want to focus on the health section in appendix 6. I believe it is extraordinarily important that we should undertake an education program which is going to make older people realise that they can be fit and that they do not have to sit around. It is difficult if older people have a purely physical problem where they cannot improve themselves, but education, health care and fitness are all important.
