SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In November 1989 I presented a draft Bill to Parliament proposing amendments to the Disability Services Act of 1986. In November 1990, I presented a private member's Bill proposing similar amendments. In September last I re-presented this Bill, again proposing the same amendments, but no opportunity has been given by the Government for its fuller debate and acceptance.

PARA.TAB: For almost three years, on behalf of people with disabilities, parents and service providers, the coalition has been pressing the Government to accept the fact that the 1986 Act was not immutable, that change was needed and that a greater degree of certainty and compassion is required in the administration of the Act. It is intolerable that the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services (Mr Howe) has allowed so many people with disabilities and their carers to suffer the stress of not knowing whether services will continue after June 1992 and what guidelines of services will follow. As the architect of the Act, the former Senator Don Grimes, said as recently as February this year:

The principles and objectives that were set out in the disability services legislation in 1986 are as clear and as sensible as can be found in most places. But I must remind those involved, as I used to at that time, that they are but standards and

SPEECH.PARA: guidelines to help in the development of programs to assist people to fill their developments in society. They are no more than that.
But the Government, the Minister and the bureaucracy have set their own agenda, creating uncertainty and risking the lifestyles of many disabled Australians.

PARA.TAB: I have continually urged the Government to amend the Act to provide more flexibility and more certainty to people with disabilities, their families and their service providers. The coalition proposed that guidelines be formulated and brought before Parliament for debate, and amendment if necessary, so that the criteria for funding of services would be clearly laid down.

The Bill also proposes that the transition date, the period in which financial assistance for prescribed services and for upgrading prescribed services is payable, be extended to give existing services more time to adapt to the requirements of the Disability Services Act. The amendments also provide for security of contracts between the Government and service providers, and an appeals procedures.

Last November the Minister outlined his blueprint for action for disability services. He stated that he would amend the Disability Services Act. He told the ACROD conference that the transition date of 1992 would be removed but that he would require services—all types of services, including sheltered workshops, activity therapy centres and larger accommodation services—to meet certain standards by 1995 in order to continue to be eligible for funding. The Minister also stated that he would formulate and table section 5 guidelines.

I re-present this Bill to keep these matters before the House, to keep the Minister to his word and to keep him honest. I remind him that there are only two months left before the transition date expires. I now remind the Minister of his Government's commitment to social justice and to the family. Very little of that commitment is evident in his actions to date.

Despite clear acceptance of the role of the family members and the life of a person with disabilities in numerous circulars issued by the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services, in the Commonwealth-State Disability Agreement, in parliamentary Acts, in last year's Australian Health Ministers conference communique, and in the Office of Disability resource kit, a review of an accommodation service in New South Wales by the State branch of the Department has formally documented that handicapped people must, firstly, be encouraged to identify an advocate, non-family, of their own choice; secondly, not be able to be removed from the service by the request of a parent—a guardian is acceptable; thirdly, accept that a parent cannot give consent to the development of a plan for their advancement; and, fourthly, accept that only a guardian, again non-parent, can nominate change of physician. The list goes on with exclusions of any reference to the family. This is interesting after what we have just been told about the aged and the ageing of Australia.

This is absolutely in conflict with stated pronouncements, with the Act, and is contrary to the interests of the handicapped who greatly need stability and non-conflict in their lives. It is also contrary to the Government's so-called vision of social justice as restated by the Minister at the Aged and Disability Expo in March this year, where he said:

The Government's vision of social justice recognises that governments must be in partnership with individuals, families and communities to improve the quality of life for all Australians. Only in partnership together can the best be realised.

SPEECH.PARA: It is very easy for the Minister to talk about social justice, but it has not been put into practice in this regard. (Time expired)

PARA.TAB: Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gibson Mr G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That this House:

SPEECH.PARA: (1)expresses its support for the actions of the Government of France in suspending the testing of nuclear weapons in the South Pacific;
(2)calls on the French Government to convert the twelve month suspension of testing into a permanent cessation of all testing, development, production and deployment of nuclear weapons by France;
(3)calls on other Governments around the world to also cease all testing, development and production of nuclear weapons; and
(4)requests the Australian Government to actively pursue international negotiations to achieve an immediate and permanent cessation of nuclear testing throughout the world.

The break up of the Soviet Union and the collapse of the Cold War provides the peoples of the world with an historic opportunity to fundamentally redirect their energies and incomes towards social and humanitarian programs. The international community now faces a clear choice: to choose between nuclear disarmament and the protection of the environment through new mechanisms of common security; or to continue with the nuclear arms race, with nuclear proliferation, the threat of nuclear weapons and their devastating impact, and a deepening of the environmental crisis.

PARA.TAB: The dramatic change in the security map of Europe and the world has resulted in much discussion about the future of nuclear weapons in the new Europe. The gains by the Greens in recent regional elections in France have caused the French Government to rethink its position on the issue of the nuclear deterrent and testing of weapons in the South Pacific. Like many others in this House, earlier this month I welcomed the French Government's decision to suspend further nuclear testing in the South Pacific in 1992.

The issue of nuclear testing has been one of great and continuing interest to the people and governments of Australia. Australia's regional opposition to French testing has always been abundantly clear and has not wavered. The most obvious and concrete expression of that opposition is the Treaty of Rarotonga, which bans all testing from the area of the South Pacific zone.

Our opposition to French nuclear testing is over 20 years old. The Whitlam Government was very strong in its opposition to the French tests, and in fact exercised that opposition by taking France to the International Court of Justice. The Fraser Government was similarly inclined and very strongly opposed, and the Hawke and Keating governments have continued with this policy. Australia has been unflagging in its opposition. Each time a test takes place, the Government protests strongly to the French Government. We have also regularly raised the issue in the United Nations and in various forums within that body.

Australia is one of the strongest proponents of a nuclear test ban treaty in the international arena and has, over the years, been at the forefront of initiatives to hasten the conclusion of a comprehensive nuclear test ban treaty. Last year the annual resolution at the United Nations, which is jointly sponsored by Australia, New Zealand and Mexico, gained record support. Only two countries voted against the resolution for a comprehensive test ban treaty—the United States and France—while four abstained. This is a clear indication that the overwhelming majority of members of the United Nations agree with and support the constructive and pragmatic approach to the negotiation of a comprehensive nuclear test ban treaty, which that resolution recommends to the Conference on Disarmament, which is the single multi-lateral disarmament negotiating forum.

Although we welcome the French Government's suspension of testing, we must be ever vigilant. We cannot sit back and think that we have won the issue. More than 10 years ago, in May of 1981, there were reports that the French Government was to suspend its nuclear testing program at Mururoa, pending a review of its nuclear weapons programs. The then Australian Foreign Minister, Tony Street, said:

SPEECH.PARA: He hoped the reported review by the French Government would lead to a complete cessation of nuclear testing in the South Pacific Region.

That was more than 10 years ago. Unfortunately, that cessation did not occur. We must act now to ensure that we maintain our pressure on the French Government so that it is not tempted to resume testing as it did in 1981.

PARA.TAB: France is not the only nation still testing nuclear weapons—or until recently still testing. The United Kingdom, the United States and the People's Republic of China are all still testing nuclear weapons. The Australian Government is disappointed that the three countries eligible to sign the protocols of the Treaty of Rarotonga—the United States, the United Kingdom and France—have not yet signed the Treaty. Both France and the United States have most recently been urged to do so at prime ministerial and foreign ministerial level.

There are major health, environmental and other risks associated with the testing of nuclear weapons. Despite the fact that testing is underground, Greenpeace reports that there have been major leaks of radioactivity at the United States and British testing sites and at both sites in the former Soviet Union. In effect, each of these test sites is a nuclear waste dump which we are leaving to the future generations to clean up.

Continued testing of nuclear weapons by the UK, US and China sends a disturbing signal to the world. Testing gives credence to the myth that the possession of nuclear weapons leads to a more secure world. The ending of the Cold War should have been the signal for the nuclear superpowers to move towards a more mature negotiating position for resolving conflicts. The continued testing of weapons and the implied threat of use of those weapons have no place in the present world.

Further, nuclear weapons testing is used as an excuse for a number of other countries, such as India and Israel, to justify their own secretive programs. The haves continue the military expansion of the have-nots.

The French have said that they see their moratorium as a small step towards disarmament. This step needs to be expanded upon and adopted by all other nuclear powers. It is clear testing causes environmental devastation, it kills people and it adds to global instability. France's nuclear test sites in the South Pacific are at the coral atolls of Mururoa and Fangataufu in French Polynesia. More than 40 atmospheric tests and 130 underground tests have been carried out there, under the guidance of the French Atomic Energy Commissariat.

This testing has caused fracturing and fissuring of the atolls and there are fears that radioactivity is leaking into the marine environment. Continued testing on the damaged atolls further threatens the geology of the area and could lead to radioactivity from the more than 130 tests leaking into the Pacific Ocean. An independent health study of French Polynesia has never been undertaken and military health records of the personnel from the site have not been released. No follow-up program has been undertaken to monitor workers once they have left the site.

A recent modelling study in the Marine Pollution Bulletin has indicated that if major leakage of radioactivity occurred from Mururoa and Fangataufu, either through a single discharge or through constant release, the entire marine environment of French Polynesia would be contaminated. In a worst case scenario, the marine environment of most South Pacific countries would be contaminated; radiation levels above normal would be found as far away as north-west New Zealand.

The environmental safety of testing programs is suspect. Action must be taken before further serious harm is done to the environment. The French Government should move to extend its moratorium past the end of this year and cease all further testing. France should also sign the 1963 partial test ban treaty banning atmospheric tests and begin negotiating an international and verifiable comprehensive nuclear test ban treaty. France should sign and/or ratify without reservation all major international and regional treaties relating to nuclear testing and nuclear proliferation.

The test sites at Mururoa and Fangataufu should be closed down and alternative strategies identified and implemented to develop the economy of French Polynesia. The rest of the world should expand on France's lead and end testing, end production and end deployment of nuclear weapons. Our leaders should seize this historic moment offered by the ending of the East-West tensions and commence a major demilitarisation of the world.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Nehl)—Is there a seconder for the motion?

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ronaldson Mr M.J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The first thing I want to say in relation to this matter is that I congratulate the mover of the motion and particularly the mover of the amended motion.

PARA.TAB: There is one thing that I have found disconcerting and not amusing in my two years here. It seems that some people, and that includes the left wing of the Labor Party and the Greens and the Democrats, believe that they have exclusive rights to this concern for the future of the planet. Can I say to the House and to those who are listening that that is very far from the truth. From a personal point of view and from a party viewpoint can I say that we are desperately concerned about the future of this planet and we will be doing everything to ensure its survival by not only supporting such motions as this but also by undertaking our own advances in that regard.

I know the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Gibson) is himself a family man who has young children. I go home on those rare occasions when members of parliament actually have time to sit down with their families. I look at my two-year-old and my five-year-old and my six-year-old and I remain totally convinced that we have to work damn hard to ensure that they indeed have a future.

Just so that this is on the public record I would like to read a press release from my colleague, the shadow Minister for foreign affairs, Senator Robert Hill, which he put out following the French nuclear testing decision. It supports the second part of the motion of the honourable member in calling for a permanent cessation of the testing. This is the press release of 9 April in which he says:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . welcomed France's decision to suspend nuclear testing in the Pacific to the end of the year, but urged the French to permanently end testing in the region.
`France's unexpected announcement should be welcomed. . .
Indeed it was unexpected. I know that both Mr Gibson and I certainly did not expect it.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. J.D.M. Dobie)—Order! The honourable member will refer to the member by his electorate.

TALK.START.PARA: —The press release goes on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: `The Federal Opposition has consistently opposed France's use of the Pacific as a nuclear test site.
`We have questioned France's need for an `independent nuclear deterrent', believing that this policy has not helped to encourage an environment of global nuclear non-proliferation.

`France's overnight decision follows concerted pressure over many years from governments—particularly those in the South Pacific—and international organisations justifiably concerned about the effects of French testing in the Pacific.
`But it also reflects the changing global security environment of the past few years.
`The end of the Cold War has forced states to reassess traditional security frameworks and question the need for weapons of mass destruction.
`The Opposition now hopes that France might follow the lead of the United States and the former Soviet Union in reducing the size of its nuclear force.
`In the meantime, it is vital that France extends its 1992 suspension to a permanent end to nuclear weapons testing in the Pacific.

So in relation to paragraphs one and two of the motion, we do very strongly support them. In relations to paragraphs three and four, I think there are two questions. We support the general thrust of those motions but our emphasis has always been on the reduction of nuclear arsenals which is now happening, and we are pleased to note especially the efforts of the US and Russia, but we would like to emphasise the reduction aspect over the test ban. What the coalition is saying is that while we also support a comprehensive nuclear test ban, we believe that it should be on two conditions. The first is that a proper verification regime should be in place. Over the last few years a lot of work has been done on developing verification regimes which could be adopted to suit a test ban situation. The second is that progress on a comprehensive test ban should be linked to advances in the reduction of strategic and conventional arms.

PARA.TAB: I think it is always very difficult to prioritise this question but I believe the reduction question should be given greater emphasis. There are a number of reasons for this. The first one is that so many countries have actually got past the testing and development stage that the weapons are both produced and are available. Therefore any ban on testing and development is potentially irrelevant. Indeed, the technology which built the early nuclear weapons is readily accessible and nuclear weapons these days can be built without testing.

Many countries have deployed nuclear weapons. I am sorry the mover of the motion is not in the House because I question why deployment is referred to in No. 2 of the motion but not in No. 3, and I really cannot understand why that is the situation. I would have been far happier if words similar to those in paragraph 2 had been used in paragraph 3 to ensure that the deployment question was raised not only in relation to France, but also in relation to governments of other countries. I think that that paragraph should have read: `calls on other Governments around the world to also cease all testing, development, production and deployment of nuclear weapons' and that that addition would have greatly strengthened the motion itself.

If you look at the reduction question rather than the testing question, there is no doubt that there are enormous arsenals of weapons of mass destruction. That should be of enormous concern to everyone in this House, as I am sure it is to everyone in the gallery, to everyone who is listening today, to the Australian community and indeed to the world community. The need for the world community to control the proliferation of these weapons of mass destruction is the number one issue that we have to face because it has the potential to impact not only on ourselves but, I believe of far greater importance, directly on our children and our grandchildren.

The Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons, 1968, has 140 signatures. Although it is useful it is still unable to control the development of nuclear weapons by those states with the determination and the technological sophistication to do so. It is fair to say, however, that it is the most widely adhered to of the arms control treaties, but there are a number of states which either possess nuclear weapons or have a suspected nuclear weapons capability and which have not acceded to the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty.

It is extremely unfortunate that there was a lack of agreement on the final document of the fourth Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty Review Conference held in September 1990. When that is reviewed in 1995 it will be an absolute necessity to resolve some areas in which the Treaty is inadequate, in particular its discriminatory treatment of nuclear weapons in a non-nuclear weapons state.

As I said, the question of the testing is one, the reduction is the other. As I also said before, the capability is already there. Whilst I am pleased from an environmental point of view that the French have stopped testing, and while I am extremely anxious from an environmental point of view for the rest of the world to stop the testing, I believe that the ultimate threat to the Australian community and the world community is the matter of reduction rather than of testing. That has got to be the focus.

I am also deeply concerned about the proliferation of chemical and biological weapons and about the need to control the proliferation of ballistic missile technology. Although negotiations on disarmament aiming towards a global banning of the manufacture, production, transfer, acquisition, stockpiling use of chemical weapons are ongoing, the reality is that years of accessibility of chemical materials, the established global chemical industry and the verification problems make it extremely difficult to achieve such a convention.

Undoubtedly, we have made enormous progress since the end of the Cold War—enormous progress—and I very much applaud the steps that have been taken towards that. But as the mover of the motion said, we have a damn long way to go, because this is, in my view, the question of this century and indeed the next century. We have got to aim for world peace. That has got to be the focus of the world community and I believe that the question of world peace, the reduction in nuclear arms, the reduction in those weapons of mass destruction, must even take precedence—I do not say this lightly—over the question of the global economy. That is our number one challenge. I support the motion; I support the mover of the motion; and I hope that the House will adopt it.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a delight to speak in a debate where there is so much agreement between the Opposition and the Government. I was glad to hear the speech of the honourable member for Ballarat (Mr Ronaldson) and I am pleased to support what he has said. I particularly applaud the initiative of the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Gibson) in moving this motion. It is striking that, since it was first moved, the purpose of the motion has been achieved. After so many years, the 20 years or so that France has been testing nuclear weapons in the South Pacific, at last the French Government has agreed to cease testing. At this stage it is only a temporary cessation of testing, but of course one hopes that that will become a permanent cessation of testing as the global security environment improves.

PARA.TAB: It was striking, too, that this decision was announced by Prime Minister Beregovoy in the first speech he made after having been appointed Prime Minister. I have had some contact with Prime Minister Beregovoy and am impressed by him. I was delighted to see his appointment and particularly pleased that a decision of this level of importance and a principled decision of this kind was amongst the first things he announced. That may give a signal of the quality of his Government.

The motion is important because it not only calls on France to make its suspension of nuclear testing a permanent one but also calls on all governments to cease nuclear testing, and not only testing but development and production. As the honourable member for Ballarat mentioned, it should also emphasise deployment. It also calls on the Australian Government to pursue those goals.

Of course, the Australian Government has been pursuing those goals for many years. We have in fact been one of the leading nations in the conference on disarmament in Geneva. Our initiatives have been important in the progress that has been made on chemical weapons. We have continuously urged the nuclear powers to cease their testing and I am sure the Government will continue to do that. Nuclear testing is damaging, because it allows perpetual technological improvement in the complexity of nuclear weapons and the damage that they can do. So stopping nuclear testing is a necessary condition for stopping the technological advances in the global arms race.

In the last couple of years, we have been through a dramatic and, to most people, unpredictable change in the global security environment. The Cold War is over; it is strikingly over. It was over before the internal collapse of the Soviet Union but that has made the end of the Cold War even more readily apparent. The result of that is that all nuclear powers, and many non-nuclear powers too, are cutting back on their military expenditure. That is an essential condition, in my view, to demonstrating the end to the military threat in most parts of the world. There are still regional threats, but the global strategic environment has enormously improved. With that improvement, it is important that we seize the opportunity to make the decisions that will be of permanent benefit to improving security. One of those decisions which are crying out to be made is the decision to stop further nuclear testing.

The country that is holding out against that most strongly, I regret to say, is the United States. The United States continues to say that it needs to maintain its nuclear testing in order to maintain the reliability and to improve the accuracy of its nuclear weapons. But when it is no longer threatened in the way that it was before, it would be quite possible for the US to responsibly have a suspension of nuclear testing in order to test the change that that would cause, to use that as a bargaining lever for the reductions in nuclear armaments that must happen from the Commonwealth of Independent States—to continue, in other words, the momentum for disarmament that is currently under way. So I hope that the French example will be an influence on the United States and that it too will agree to suspension of nuclear testing. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gallus Mrs C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to add my voice to those of the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Gibson), the honourable member for Ballarat (Mr Ronaldson) and the honourable member for Fraser (Mr Langmore) in the debate on this motion concerning the testing of nuclear weapons. I want to commend its mover for bringing it before the House.

PARA.TAB: The honourable member for Fraser has referred to the United States as the key to the problem of nuclear testing, and indeed it is. In the last resolution before the United Nations which New Zealand and Australia sponsored, there was a hold-out by three countries—the three main countries in the use of nuclear testing—and they were the United States, France and Britain. It was interesting that in the last vote Britain did abstain, having gone along with the United States and France in previous votes. In the last vote it was only the United States and France which stood out against the resolution that there be a stop to nuclear testing. France now has declared a one-year moratorium, which makes the United States the last remaining country supporting the continuation of the testing of nuclear arms.

A number of reasons have been given by the United States for that and it is quite interesting that they vary according to who is giving the reasons. The United States has always claimed that it is for national security, that it needs this testing because of the deterrent effect of nuclear arms. Yet today, as at no time since the Second World War, we have this unique time, in the absence of the Cold War, when we could actually look at stopping nuclear testing.

But the US has provided three other reasons why it wishes to continue testing and I will mention them briefly. The first is that it is impossible to verify a complete ban, and the honourable member for Ballarat made reference to that. However, the ability to check whether nuclear explosions are occurring has become much more sophisticated in the last 10 years and it is now possible to detect seismic disturbances. Previously there was always the danger of confusing them with an earthquake or some quarrying or explosions in mines. That is no longer the case. I believe that scientific reports say that nuclear explosions can now be detected. So much for the first reason.

The second reason is the desire of the United States to develop the third generation of nuclear weapons. As honourable members would remember, the first generation was the fission bombs, followed by hydrogen bombs. The third generation now is the directed energy devices whereby X-ray lasers are used to focus the energy of a nuclear explosion into a beam of destruction.

The third reason is that the United States claims, as France has done in the past, that the nuclear stockpile needs to be tested for its safety. There is a feeling that over time there is a dangerous degradation of the pile and the devices themselves need to be exploded to see that they are continuing to be safe to stockpile. That is one of the most peculiar reasons I have ever heard for keeping a nuclear stockpile and testing it to make sure that it is safe. In fact, there is no reason why the elements of the nuclear stockpile cannot be take apart separately—not in a nuclear explosion—and the individual elements tested to see whether they have retained their safety.

They are the three major reasons the United States has given for not complying with the other countries that wish to have a complete ban. I have some quotes here but unfortunately I do not have time to read out all of them. However, I want to read out one which I find rather chilling. It is from Dr Lawrence Ferderber of the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory in California. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: We're in the midst of a renaissance, a period of growth in the quality and sophistication of our work.

That was a comment on building up the nuclear arsenal in the United States. The Americans have been very clear that, despite what other countries have said, they are in no way going to stop their nuclear program.

PARA.TAB: Very briefly I want to go over some facts regarding the number of nuclear tests. There have been 1,818 tests since 1945: 921 by the US; 643 by the Soviet Union; 177 by France; 42 by the UK; 31 by China, and one by India.

Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. J.D.M. Dobie)—Order! The debate is adjourned as the time allotted has expired. The resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday. The honourable member will have leave to continue her speech when the debate is resumed.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts: Proposed Relocation of Coode Island Chemical Facilities

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scholes The Hon G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this House refers to the Standing Committee on the Environment, Recreation and the Arts, for full inquiry and report, the matter of current proposals to relocate the Coode Island chemical facilities to the Point Wilson area of Port Phillip Bay, including in the terms of reference:

SPEECH.PARA: (a)investigation of:

PARA.TAB: (i)the effects on Port Phillip Bay of any failure or accident in an area with little tidal movement;
(ii)the size of chemical and petroleum facilities in a small area between North Geelong and the Avalon Airfield;

(iii)the danger of any failure in containing volatile, explosive, inflammable and toxic substances to the population of Northern Geelong, Corio and Lara as well as areas in Central and Eastern Geelong and the Bellarine Peninsula;
(iv)the need for a full environmental impact statement; and

(v)whether the proposed development could reverse the process of cleaning up Corio Bay and the areas south of the Werribee River which has taken place since the disclosure of the toxic nature of these waters in 1973; and

SPEECH.PARA: (b)urgent treatment of the report.

In the short time that I have available I will not be able to go into detail on what I consider to be a very defective report by a review panel. That review panel was made up of Melbourne based people and it made no serious attempt to establish the environmental or social suitability of the site it ultimately recommended. This is not the first occasion on which I have moved a motion in this House for reference to the Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts of the proposal to build chemical storages and other such things in the area just south of the Werribee sewerage farm at the Avalon airfield.

PARA.TAB: In 1981 the Victorian EPA announced that a site for an intractable wastes incinerator in a similar area only a few miles from the area mentioned in this announcement was quite safe and sound. Subsequently, an inquiry found that the EPA was not even aware that the area was subject to regular water flooding, and yet a clay based safety provision was going to be built in this storage. At that time, the House of Representatives Committee recommended against it and it did not go ahead.

I believe that the whole process is unsatisfactory. Every local government body in the Geelong area opposes it. The Corio Shire, which is the shire in which it is to be built, proposes to spend a very large amount, about $200,000, to seek to have the site changed, and that must be a serious consideration. I wrote to Mr Landy during the hearings and indicated that I believed that no site at Point Wilson should be selected unless there was proper public consultation and adequate environmental and other safety checks. Neither of those took place.

Under the EES provisions of the Victorian Parliament, the site is not subject to query in the subsequent examination of the announced relocation. The EES proposal only deals with how the site can be made suitable and what is required for it to be suitable. If it were found that it was not suitable, it is not able to report on it. It is controlled by the Victorian Department for Planning and Environment, which is hardly the appropriate place for such an inquiry to take place as it has a vested interest before it starts.

There are two clear situations where concerns exist. Firstly, the site is much closer, especially with prevailing winds, to the urban area of Geelong. It is across Corio Bay. Any spillages will not move out of the area because there is virtually no tidal flow. There will be something in the order of 100 transports a day travelling over 50 kilometres on a 100 kilometre per hour divided road to Melbourne. It is not taken into account in the report, but the Melbourne to Werribee section is incapable of carrying that increased traffic without a greatly increased risk. The report writes down the dangers of road transport, virtually dismissing them. The fact is that the day that the announcement was made a chemical accident on the Hume Highway blocked that highway for seven hours. We are going to have 200 times that potential on the Geelong road without any adequate alternative roads.

We also have an additional problem in that there are very important nature reserves immediately adjacent to the site. It is not good enough to say that we are going to look at what our World Heritage obligations are in the wetlands and the migratory birds treaties that we have signed, and that we are going to look at how we can make it safe. We should be looking at whether it is safe, whether those areas will be affected, and whether our treaty obligations can be complied with. I do not blame the people of Footscray for wanting to get rid of the thing. I think the people of Geelong do too. I do not think any of these things are ever going to be very safe. In fact, this week the people of Britain are complaining about Australian waste being shipped over there to be destroyed.

The facts are that there has to be an adequate environmental and social impact study and there have to be proper studies into whether or not every motorist who drives between Geelong and Melbourne, and between Werribee and Melbourne in particular, is going to have his life placed at risk for a political decision which is not adequately considered and has not adequately been studied. I hope that the House will refer this. This is not altogether a Commonwealth issue, but the Commonwealth does have responsibilities in the area. I believe that, as in the case of the intractable waste incinerator in 1981, we should repeat that process.(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

—The honourable member for Corio (Mr Scholes) in this motion wants the matter of the proposed relocation of the Coode Island facility referred to the Standing Committee on the Environment, Recreation and the Arts. However, since the August 1991 fire, the whole question of the location and storage of industrial chemicals has been the subject of wide ranging public debate in the inquiry. Since the 1991 fire, the matter has been investigated in great detail and many groups and individuals have had the opportunity to raise their concerns.

PARA.TAB: In these circumstances, any proposal which would subject the industry to a further investigation is quite unnecessary. It represents a huge cost which would be imposed on the chemical industry—an industry which has already spent a fortune on the State investigation. I therefore oppose any further investigation into the relocation of the Coode Island facility.

There are a number of important points to consider in this matter: first, the safety aspect, which must, of course, be paramount; secondly, the cost aspect, where it does not impinge on safety. I return to the question of safety. The industry operating at Coode Island has done so for the past 30 years, virtually without major incident until the August 1991 fire. It is, therefore, important to discuss the consequences of the recent fires in an appropriate context.

Despite the toxic smoke, the worst recorded injury was a broken finger, and pollution levels were about the same as those caused by the traffic on Geelong Road over two days. The industry, I believe, would prefer to stay at the Coode Island site. Moreover, I understand the metropolitan fire brigade favours the retention of the facility of the Coode Island site, and the honourable member is correct in his statement about the 50 vehicles using the Geelong Road per day and the dangers involved. I also understand that the Coode Island site has environmental advantages. The disadvantages are that Coode Island is relatively close to housing and relatively close to the Melbourne business district.

Obviously, it has to be a judgment on the safety and environmental aspects of Coode Island. The inquiry carried out in Victoria concluded that the facility should be relocated. On the information from the fire brigade and the chemical industry itself, the facility should stay where it is. Both the fire brigade and the industry itself surely know the dangers and hazards associated with storage facilities of this kind.

In my view, there is no doubt that the chemical industry should remain at Coode Island. It is obviously the safest and, coincidentally, the most economical site available. But the potential for Point Wilson should not be ignored. It is an ideal location for industrial expansion and the development so badly needed in the broke State of Victoria. This development is absolutely essential if we are to downstream much of our raw materials and add value to our exports. Most chemical plants rely on a number of basic elements—the supply of raw materials, such as salt or LPG, which Australia has in abundance; ample supplies of fuel and power which, again, we have in abundance, and a favourable economic and industrial environment, which we certainly do not have.

Such a favourable economic environment would include a number of factors, for example, the availability of a suitable location for a chemical plant and industrial expansion generally: in my view, the site at Point Wilson represents an excellent opportunity for this type of development. It needs a taxation system which offers realistic depreciation rates; chemical plants are very capital intensive. It needs the availability of investment finance at reasonable rates: our overdraft rates at 12 to 14 per cent do not look good alongside investment capital at 3 and 4 per cent available overseas. It requires a new deal on industrial relations, which includes the abolition of compulsory unionism, optional arbitration and enterprise bargaining. It requires a government which, to paraphrase a former President of the United States, Calvin Coolidge, believes that the business of Australia is business, and which, having established some basic rules of corporate behaviour, will get out of the way of business.
There is no doubt that Australians are capable of building huge chemical plants and processing plants. Just look at what we have done in the past.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the motion moved by the honourable member for Corio (Mr Scholes). The central fallacy of the Coode Island review panel's report, inevitable given its term of reference, was to recommend concentration on a single remote location for the hazardous chemicals involved, thus maximising road usage, instead of recommending several locations close to the users. For example, there could have been a modified and reduced central facility for inner Melbourne at Coode Island, and a facility at Crib Point to service Dandenong, Clayton and other users in the eastern metropolitan area.

PARA.TAB: I express some concern at the lack of balance in the report. From my perspective, two major issues had to be addressed in considering the relocation of the Coode Island chemical facility. The two issues were, first, containment and, second, distribution transportation. The report itself is 266 pages long, with 76 pages of appendices. The examinations of transport and distribution account for only 10 pages of the total document, less than 3 per cent of the total. Even appendix 6.3 confesses the inadequacy of the transport treatment. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: The effect of storing new hazardous materials (such as LPG or VCM) at the relocated terminal have not been considered . . . A full, detailed transport safety and risk study would take several months to perform. Although it will be required for final project approvals (probably within the ambit of a complete EIS), the duration and costs rule out conclusion of such a study within the scope of Task 2.4.—
this section on transport risk issues continues with a broad-based discussion of the comparative risk of transport by road, rail and pipeline—
A detailed study of transport risks would take several months, as illustrated by the recent ACDS report which took more than five years to prepare for just four dangerous materials.

That is not a very comprehensive treatment. I declare my undying fealty to the Premier, I think she is doing an excellent job, but I express concern that in her news release of 7 April on the relocation of the Coode Island facility only one of 24 paragraphs refers to the question of transport. The paragraph says in full:

We wish to ensure that transport from the new facility will be safe and have committed funds for road upgrading in conjunction with the Federal Government in order to add a third lane to the Geelong Road.

Of course, that is referred to in the immortal One Nation package. Further, in the Premier's statement, `Coode Island Review Panel', of 23 paragraphs, not one paragraph refers to the issue of transport.

PARA.TAB: I am concerned about that. Obviously the Coode Island review panel and the Victorian Government face a painful dilemma: the choice of a centralised facility with risk to an established densely populated area, or a distant facility, relatively remote from population, where risk is part of the lengthened transport links. If you take, for example, the distance between Coode Island and Footscray, where many of the users would be, and West Point Wilson and Footscray, it would be fair to estimate something like a tenfold increase in distance, and something like a tenfold increase in exposure to risk.

If you go further, more or less in the direction of the honourable member for Dunkley (Mr Ford) but more in the direction of my colleague the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy), the distance from Coode Island to Dandenong would be of the order of 40 kilometres. The distance from West Point Wilson to Dandenong would be more of the order of 100 kilometres. So that is a matter of some concern.

The motion moved by the honourable member for Corio (Mr Scholes) is mild in its language but appropriate. A parliamentary committee ought to look at the relocation of Coode Island facilities as a matter of urgency. I agree with the honourable member for Dunkley that the matter should not be allowed to drag on. There are important issues involved. But from the perspective of the west, and I speak as the member for Lalor, there is the concern that for too long the west has been seen as the area where a facility is dumped that no one else wants—historically sewerage, later intractable waste and then medical incineration. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to speak on the motion of the honourable member for Corio (Mr Scholes) that the proposals for the relocation of the Coode Island chemical facilities be referred to the Standing Committee on the Environment, Recreation and the Arts. It is a very important issue for all Victorians and it is appropriate that it be considered by Federal Parliament. Honourable members will be aware that on 7 April 1992 the Victorian Government announced that it would implement the recommendations of the Coode Island review panel for a new storage facility and that the Government had accepted the panel's recommendation that the new site be located at West Point Wilson on the western shores of Port Phillip Bay. The recommendation of West Point Wilson as the new site was one of 57 in the Coode Island review panel's sixth and final report. The recommendation of the Coode Island review panel—the Landy review panel as it is commonly known—that Coode Island be shut down and that another site be developed has been welcomed by both the Victorian Labor Government and the coalition Opposition. As far back as 19 October 1990, with the release of its Coode Island closure strategy, the Victorian Opposition drew attention to the massive environmental threat posed by the Coode Island chemical facility. The fires which occurred at Coode Island on 21 and 22 August 1991 were testament to the Victorian Opposition's warnings.

PARA.TAB: On 10 December 1991, the Victorian coalition parties attacked the Kirner Government for senselessly delaying the inevitable decision to progressively close Coode Island. The shadow Minister for Conservation and Environment, the honourable Mark Birrell, called on the State Government to stop wasting time and to work with industry and the EPA to identify and facilitate the use of alternative, safe chemical storage sites. Four months later, the Landy review panel released its report and West Point Wilson is the recommended new site at a cost of $200m.

I fully understand that the honourable member for Corio would be very concerned about the proposal to locate the new site within the boundaries of his electorate. However, the reality is that an exhaustive investigation has already occurred. The review panel was established by the honourable member's State Labor colleagues, and the recommendations of the panel have now been accepted by the Kirner Government. There is not time for further delay. Coode Island remains a significant risk to the safety of workers at the site and nearby residents; there is no time for further referral. The time for action is now.

The Coode Island facility has proved to be an environmental and health time bomb for Victorians. Stating the obvious, we cannot contemplate a repeat of the disaster which occurred at Coode Island on 21 and 22 August 1991. An alternative site must be found and in full operation as soon as possible. To that end, we welcome the recommendations of the Landy review panel for a new facility to commence in 1996.

For the benefit of honourable members who may not be fully aware of the final recommendations of the Landy review panel, I will briefly summarise them. The panel recommended that a new bulk liquid port facility be built at West Point Wilson on the western shores of Port Phillip Bay, about 50 kilometres south-west of Melbourne and 15 kilometres north-east of Geelong. The report said that the site at West Point Wilson, which is about five kilometres from the nearest housing, offered substantial buffer zones, of up to two kilometres, which would guarantee protection for the community; a long-term viable future for the chemical industry; the possible relocation of bulk hazardous chemicals currently imported through Geelong and Williamstown, and increased safety in the transport of hazardous chemicals.

The site was also chosen because of the need to take a long term view of up to 50 years and the main alternative, the upgrading of Coode Island, would continue to be a subject of controversy and review as the city developed. I also note that the review panel recommended that an environmental effects statement be conducted for the proposed facility in conjunction with the Commonwealth and that a consultative committee, representing key interest groups, guide the statement's preparation. I stated earlier that I fully appreciate the sentiments behind the motion. However, the time for review and investigation has passed. The time for action is now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous Dr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —This motion reads as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: That the House:
(1)calls upon the State Law and Order Restoration Council (SLORC) of Burma to cede legal authority to a civilian government as mandated by the Burmese people in the elections of May 1990;
(2)condemns the arrest and detention of Burmese citizens for the peaceful expression of their political views;
(3)condemns the SLORC's disregard of human rights and fundamental freedoms; and
(4)urges the Australian Government to:

PARA.TAB: (a)call upon the UN Human Rights Commission to continue and expand its scrutiny and action over the human rights situation in Burma;
(b)affirm its support for the resettlement of genuine Burmese asylum seekers who are without other safe and reasonable alternatives; and
(c)call upon the Government of Thailand to accord Burmese refugees temporary safe haven and access to procedures for third country resettlement.

SPEECH.PARA: I have pleasure in supporting this motion, although in doing so I want to say that it is rather sad that we have to continue with a motion like this in this House because of the dreadful circumstances of human rights in Burma. In fact, since this motion was last debated on 27 February, no evidence has arisen that indicates that the Burmese State Law and Order Restoration Council, the SLORC, has ceased its extreme violations of human rights. The scale of abuse is far worse than the violations by China in Tiananmen Square. Amnesty International, in various reports, has described Burma as the worst offender of human rights abuses in the region. A recent international report described Burma as `a prison without bars'. There are also 2,000 political prisoners behind bars.

PARA.TAB: The release of 11 political prisoners yesterday, which takes the total to 38 who have been released, is insignificant when one thinks of the remaining 1,072 political prisoners at least. It is well known that these prisoners are kept in inhuman conditions, and now the UN Human Rights Commission is investigating brutal mistreatment of political prisoners. Australia must ensure that pressure is maintained on Burma until the National League for Democracy, which has a democratically attained mandate to govern, is allowed to do so. The token gestures of the SLORC in recent days should not be perceived as evidence of real change. The release of some political prisoners is a mere token. A total of 38 have been released out of the 2,000 that have been detained.

The 1991 Nobel Peace Prize winner, Aung San Suu Kyi, remains in detention, and, while the military regime announced some reforms, it has not agreed that she will be released. The announcement that Aung San Suu Kyi can meet briefly with her family must be placed in the context of her being the leader of the National League for Democracy, which has won a democratic election and which has not been allowed to govern. These people think that they are being generous in allowing the family of the leader of the party that won the election to see her for the first time for quite some time. I agree with Senator Evans, who said on 26 March that Aung San Suu Kyi's expulsion from Burma, rather than her release, would not be acceptable.

Political, economic and ethnic refugees continue to leave Burma at a greater rate than ever before. Thousands are leaving through every possible means—through the Bangladesh border and the Thai border. Even China has agreed `out of humanitarian considerations' to accord temporary settlement to refugees. Japan has granted for the first time refugee status to Burmese anti-Government activists.

A group of Asian lawyers have released a report on the conditions within the refugee camps. Men and women have been captured and used as porters for the Burmese Army; they serve as human mine detectors. The Thai-Burma border camps have grown even larger and the conditions are disgusting. I saw similar camps during my visit to the Thai-Kampuchea border and have seen the suffering that occurs in these camps. Australia's role in moves towards a peaceful resolution in Cambodia has shown that Australia is important in the region and must therefore speak out on the human rights abuses in Burma.

Despite the military government's firm maintenance of power, it is now coming under increasing international pressure and Australia has a vital role to play in maintaining that pressure.The European Parliament has passed a motion to call for sanctions and to recommend that the UN Security Council investigate abuses of human rights in Burma.

On 10 April, the European Parliament suggested multilateral trade sanctions on Burma and the delaying of aid programs. Australia has an important role to play to support, reinforce and extend these suggestions from Europe within this region. There is evidence that much of the foreign aid in the past has gone to strengthening the Burmese Army rather than where it was intended, that is, to the Burmese people. This is an important region to Australia and Burma provides a potential source of regional instability if these matters are not dealt with.

In early 1988, there was an escalation of protest and civilian rioting which was brutally quelled by the Burmese police under the instruction of the SLORC. The strength of these attacks was said to be far greater than anything we have seen in our region. The repression of the pro-democracy movement in Burma was justified on the grounds that it was maintaining law and order. There was no threat to law and order; there was only a threat to the entrenched and privileged position of the armed forces and those who rely on the armed forces for the maintenance and continuity of that position.

In the run-up to the election of 27 May 1990, there was clear evidence that the SLORC used military pressure to influence election results and control potential insurgencies. Nevertheless, the election was won by Aung San Suu Kyi and her party and everyone expected that the military would do the right thing. The SLORC did not want to call the election, but was forced by international pressure to do so; it then attempted to intimidate people during the election. Having resoundingly lost the election, one would have thought that it might have given up and realised that the Burmese people did not want it. Instead, what happened? It imprisoned the leader of the democratic forces, Aung San Suu Kyi, and continued with its brutal regime. That is the situation that we have been facing. It is clear that unless the international community isolates Burma and makes it perfectly clear to the ruling clique in Burma that it will not accept this sort of behaviour, progress will not be reached.

It is about time that all of the countries of the region took seriously this very unstable situation in Burma which is creating tensions in the whole region and the suffering of all of those Burmese people that have clearly expressed a desire for democracy and for an alternative government. It is about time that we acted much more firmly in relation to the Burmese situation. I support this motion.

I want to say something about the personal courage of Aung San Suu Kyi. On a number of occasions she was offered safe escort out of Burma to be released. But she decided to stay with her people and to continue the struggle for democracy, even though this has resulted in her imprisonment.

She obviously is a worthy winner of the Nobel Peace Prize and has set a very good example concerning the struggle for democracy not only in Burma but in international circles. She has set an example for many leaders around the world that sometimes there is a very high price to pay for democracy. Our thoughts are with her and her people in supporting this motion. Let us hope that action will be carried out very soon by the international community to secure democracy, human rights and basic freedoms for the people of Burma.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Filing Mr P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I follow on from the comments of the honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous). It is clear that the human rights abuses in Burma have been well documented and are reminiscent of the atrocities committed by the Pol Pot regime in Cambodia. Amnesty International has documented the horrific abuses of human rights, including rape, pillage, torture and murder. Early this year Amnesty International identified more than 1,500 political prisoners of conscience and 600 people arrested for carrying out anti-government activities in the first seven months of 1991.

PARA.TAB: According to a January 1992 Amnesty report, over 100 people have been sentenced to death in Burma since July 1989 by military tribunals and civilian courts. Amazingly, although the courts continue to hand down these death sentences, the Burmese Government—ironically known as the State Law and Order Restoration Committee or SLORC—refuses to admit to the killings.

The SLORC seized military control of Burma in 1988 after pro-democracy demonstrations led to the resignation of the authoritarian military ruler, Ne Win, who came to power in 1962. The SLORC has subsequently undertaken a major crackdown on Burmese citizens who expressed a desire for democracy and has continued to repress critics and opponents of the military regime. Despite these obvious uprisings against the ruling military junta, the SLORC continues to refuse a transfer of power to the National League for Democracy party which was democratically elected in 1990, the leader of which is the Nobel Peace Prize laureate and detainee Daw Aung San Suu Kyi. The award of the Nobel Peace Prize to Aung San Suu Kyi highlighted to the world the plight of the people of Burma and the gross violations of human rights and political freedoms which have occurred in that country. Of the 392 members of parliament elected in 1990, 111 have been gaoled or have fled the country. The rest are too terrified to speak out against the SLORC.

However, these facts are nothing new. What represents a radical and significant change in the matters concerning the human rights situation in Burma is the change in policy of the international community regarding Burma, one which in my view and I am sure the view of many of my colleagues should have happened a lot sooner. Until recently the response of the international community on the whole to the countrywide repression and persecution of minorities in Burma has been ad hoc and ineffectual. The events that have occurred in the last few days and weeks surely represent the most significant signs from the international community that the oppressive tactics by the SLORC will no longer be tolerated.

Since this motion was moved in February of this year the essence of its decree remains legitimate. The human rights abuses in Burma are indefensible and we must do all we can to see that a stop is put to them. However, as a country that has little to do with the Burmese Government, we can only urge our international counterparts to adopt a similar position to our condemnation of human rights abuses in Burma. This is becoming a trend. No longer is the international community prepared to take a blinkered view of events in Burma; it is speaking out.

Human rights abuses in Burma continue. United Nations Secretary-General Boutros Boutros-Ghali's decision to send the Under Secretary-General for Humanitarian Affairs, Jan Eliasson, to Burma in early April is a sure sign that the United Nations is prepared to become actively involved in putting an end to these violations and supporting a peaceful transition to democracy in Burma.

For the first time, ASEAN countries, who were previously prepared to overlook human rights violations in Burma, are taking a stand. Each of the six nations making up ASEAN—Thailand, the Philippines, Malaysia, Indonesia, Brunei and Singapore—have publicly called on the Burmese Government to exercise restraint. Pakistan has urged Burma to allow tens of thousands of its Muslim citizens from the state of Arakan fleeing to Bangladesh to return home. Up to 210,000 Arakanese Muslims, known as Rohingyas, have entered Bangladesh in the last four months, pleading sanctuary from the raping, killing, looting and burning which the Burmese Government has been party to.

Until recently, the SLORC claimed that most of the people who fled to Bangladesh were not Burmese citizens, although their ancestors lived in the isolated Burmese western province of Arakan for centuries. In March of this year the 46-nation Organisation of Islamic Conference denounced the Burmese Government for the persecution and repression that have been conducted against the local Arakanese Muslim community.

SPEECH.PARA: The United Nations Human Rights Commission made an unprecedented unanimous ruling in censuring the SLORC for serious human rights violations and sent a special rapporteur to investigate these circumstances. The office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees has admitted that the movement of refugees into neighbouring countries was reaching dramatic proportions, with between 5,000 and 7,000 people fleeing Burma daily.

PARA.TAB: This month, the European Parliament adopted a resolution on human rights violations in the persecution of minorities in Burma. The resolution proposed that the European Parliament call on its members of the United Nations Security Council—namely, France and the United Kingdom—to propose an embargo on arms deliveries to Burma and possibly trade sanctions against that country.

These significant changes in stance by the international community occurred as a result of the sustained campaign against human rights abuses, of which campaign Australia has been one of the most ardent supporters. Significant catalysts for this more hard line approach include the SLORC's systematic campaign to force Muslims in Arakan to flee to neighbouring countries, the sacking of 150 Rangoon university teachers as a result of their suspect political loyalties, and the castigating of students, politicians and monks who had political views other than that of the military junta.

The SLORC has attempted to justify its military oppression as necessary to maintaining control over ethnic insurgencies. However, these groups in recent years have posed little threat to the country's heavily populated urban centres. No longer can the SLORC stand by this argument. The increasing refugee exodus to neighbouring countries, brought on by military oppression and social and economic problems, has led to a well-recognised international problem.

There has also been the problem of narcotics trafficking, in which the SLORC has been directly involved. The flow of heroin from Burma to the neighbouring countries, as well as to North America, has led to catastrophic results. Drug addiction is on the rise in Burma and surrounding countries. So is AIDS, which is directly linked to drug addiction. Burma and Thailand have the highest incidence of HIV infection in Asia, and AIDS has spread from Burma to India and China.

Finances from the sale of huge logging concessions to foreign firms, in particular to those in Thailand, have been used to buy military equipment which has been used against the citizens of Burma. The wanton destruction of rainforest areas due to logging could have long term ecological effects for the region. Ultimately it is the people of Burma who are suffering and will continue to suffer under the rule of the SLORC. However, only last weekend, in clear recognition of the international community's demands, we heard news of the Burmese Government's decision to allow Aung San Suu Kyi to see her husband, British academic Michael Aris, and their two sons. Being under house arrest in Rangoon since July 1989, she has not been able to see her family for more than two years.

Only yesterday, Burma's military junta signalled the release of 11 political prisoners. This brings the number of political prisoners released to 38 since last week. The turning point in this recognition of the repression conducted by the Burmese Government is the succession of General Than Shwe to the position of Prime Minister that occurred only last week. Last Friday, the SLORC pledged to free all political prisoners, except those who posed a threat to national security. It also agreed to take back many of the 210,000 Muslim refugees who have sought political asylum in Bangladesh.

While the SLORC has said that it will take back all refugees who had valid national registration or other documents to support their identity, the fact is that the Burmese army seized citizenship papers of many refugees leaving the country, leaving them with no proof of residency or citizenship. The Government has also allegedly called off the military offensive against the Karen rebels on Burma's eastern border. However, last Tuesday night it was reported that Burmese Government forces shelled Karen rebel positions, despite its statement that the attacks had been suspended.

While the latest measures by the Burmese Government are a step in the right direction, it remains to be seen whether they are, in fact, a change in policy or are merely designed to appease international opinion. It is now more crucial than ever that the international community and Australia maintain their pressure on Burma to end the fighting and repression and begin a dialogue for the formation of a new democratic government. Action must be taken as soon as possible to ensure that the people of Burma have their rights and freedoms restored to them.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to join with the previous speaker, the honourable member for Moore (Mr Filing), in supporting the motion which was put forward by the Opposition Whip, the honourable member for Casey (Mr Halverson). In doing that I have to say that those of us who are concerned about human rights and the promotion of multiparty democracies around the world can be glad that we live in a time when that concept is spreading to an increasing number of countries.

PARA.TAB: I believe the crucial moment was the development of a free trade union movement in Poland. It was the first of the Eastern bloc countries to do so. It ultimately resulted in a clamp down and a revival of multiparty democracy in not only Poland but also other countries in eastern Europe. I think that played a crucial role in multiparty democracy spreading to the Soviet Union. The collapse of communist totalitarianism in the Soviet Union has now meant that multiparty democracy is starting to emerge in places such as Africa and other parts of the world where it is long overdue.

In our part of the world sometimes it is more difficult to see multiparty democracy growing and developing with the speed and strength that many of us would like to see. In Burma, as the honourable member for Moore and the honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous) pointed out, there is one crucial fact: the party led by Aung San Suu Kyi won over 80 per cent of the seats in the national assembly in May 1990. On that basis alone she should form a government, her party should form a government and they should rule in Burma.

As previous speakers have pointed out that, of course, was not something that appealed to the military dictatorship that has run Burma for many years. Its actions have been condemned not only by members of this Parliament but also by the United Nations General Assembly. The Human Rights Commission has expressed concern about violations in Burma. The European Parliament, as mentioned by the honourable member for Moore, has carried resolutions calling for sanctions to be imposed. Members of ASEAN have taken the extraordinary step of suggesting that action needs to be considered to ensure that these human rights violations do not continue.

That is an unusual step for ASEAN. In the past ASEAN has been reluctant to get involved in the internal affairs of neighbouring countries. The fact that countries such as Malaysia, Indonesia and Singapore are raising human rights issues is a progressive step and something which I hope will develop in other ways in years to come.

For Australia, our Government, through our Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans), I think with the support of the Opposition parties, has applied an arms embargo to sales of military equipment to Burma. We have made it clear that there will be no resumption of development assistance to Burma while these human rights violations continue. Australia has provided more than a quarter of a million dollars to clothe and feed some of the refugees that are now living in the camps in Bangladesh.

The two countries which I think have the greatest contribution to make in improving human rights in Burma right now are Japan and China. Japan is the biggest aid donor to Burma. I think Japan can play a very constructive role in protecting the human rights of the people of Burma. China is the largest arms supplier to Burma. I believe it could take a very strong step in improving its human rights record by applying an arms embargo to sales to Burma until the current dictatorship in Burma hands over to the Government which was freely elected in May 1990.

I obtained a few examples of human rights violations in Burma. Given that time is short, I will not go into them this afternoon, other than to say that it is very clear that prisoners of conscience have in some cases been tortured and raped in Burma. There have been examples quoted where prisoners have been used as minesweepers to walk ahead of soldiers to clear mine areas in the military incursions that have taken place. There have also been allegations that former prostitutes who have HIV have been put to death. For these and other reasons, I support the motion before the House. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to be able to support the motion moved by the honourable member for Casey (Mr Halverson), which in part condemns the State Law and Order Restoration Council's disregard of human rights and fundamental freedoms in Burma. Previous speakers—today and on the two previous occasions on which this debate has taken place—have outlined at length the history of the present situation. However, the debate today is all the more timely because of recent developments in Burma; they have been alluded to this morning.

PARA.TAB: It is fitting that we should debate this issue. Although for many people Burma is a little known country, our histories have been intertwined and we have cause to be interested in Burma's future. The security and stability of our region, which the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) tells us is where our future lies, is of concern to us. Incidentally, the Prime Minister may be correct in that observation, but the way he has gone about making that particular point has angered and disgusted many Australians.

In this broad context we reflect also that Burma was the focus of attention in the events leading up to the fall of Singapore in February 1942. The Prime Minister's contribution in respect of that particular issue also went down like a lead balloon. His deliberate and malicious misinterpretation of the history of that time offended many British and Australian citizens.

At that time the Australian and British governments jointly decided that the priority was to ensure the security of Malaya. This was considered to be in the best interests of the defence of Australia, India and Burma. Ultimately, at the end of the war or shortly after, Burma became independent. But back in the early 1940s it was the focus of a major dispute between the then Australian Prime Minister, John Curtin, and the British Prime Minister, Churchill. Churchill's attempt to divert the Australian convoy which was en route from the Middle East to Burma led to a dramatic change in the relationship between Australia and Britain. The historic `Australia looks to America' call was made by Curtin at that time.

Burma gained independence in 1947. In 1962 a coup led to the repressive rule of the military under General Ne Win. That military rule continues despite the 1990 election, which clearly indicated that people wanted a return to a civilian democracy as a form of government rather than a military government.

We should rightly condemn the actions of the supreme State Law and Order Restoration Council. Other speakers have outlined the extent of the atrocities which have been committed against the people of Burma, and I do not wish to dwell on those. However, while we are discussing human rights abuses in Burma, it seems appropriate that we should be reminded that there remains on the Notice Paper the motion of the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Gibson) which also highlights the actions of the Indonesian Government in East Timor. Debate on this motion has been conspicuously quiet in recent weeks. I ought to say in fairness that the honourable member tells me that he is to have further discussions with the Prime Minister on that matter.

There is a contrast here, but I do not believe that we can continue to overlook the fact that six Australians and perhaps as many as 200,000 East Timorese have been murdered by Indonesian forces in East Timor. This is not a game of one-upmanship in terms of which regimes are the most repressive in the world. It is a great pity that we have regimes such as these in any parts of the world. So I do not intend to contrast the situation in Burma with that in Indonesia. But we should not overlook or excuse the actions of the Indonesian military in East Timor any more than we want in this debate this morning to overlook or diminish the horrific activities of the military regime which continues to exist in Burma. I was interested to read in this morning's edition of the Australian—(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Every nation who joined forces in the Gulf just over a year ago in the name of a new world order should now employ the strongest non-combat measures open to them to cleanse the human rights blot which is Burma today. Every leader, every military strategist and every citizen who believed that the taking up of arms was justified by the atrocities being perpetrated in oil rich Kuwait should now support tough trade sanctions to combat the prolonged and methodical torturous killing of the men, women and children of Karen in one of the world's poorest nations.

PARA.TAB: I join today honourable members on both sides of the House in strong support of the motion before the House. With them, I stand in sympathy with the victims of the Burmese atrocities and in outrage that these atrocities are continuing in our world, our region. I join also with those who call on the severing of Australian trade links with the perpetrators of these atrocities, should the ruling junta's concessions to international outrage prove inadequate—not that I believe that an entirely negative stand should be adopted in the face of the first, though minimal, evidence that the military junta is sensitive to the world's condemnation.

Observer nations would do well to pause and to watch, but they should also make it clear that they have no intention of allowing the momentum of their campaign for full lifting of the unacceptable yoke of the Karen people to lapse. In this context, I agree with Senator Evans's judgment: while in recent weeks he has been reconsidering the question of economic sanctions to strengthen those measures that Australia has already taken, he thinks it appropriate to put any further diplomatic action on hold until it becomes clear whether the junta's actions are a watershed or simply cosmetic.

But the accusation of the All Burma Students Democratic Front that the oppressors are merely trying to divert international attention from Burma's affairs and to deceive the people accurately represents a wider concern that tactics such as those used in the past by a South African government striving to shield its atrocities from the eye of the world are being employed in Burma. There is reason for this concern. International pressure must be maintained; in this context, I agree that China and Japan have major roles to play.

Australia has a proud record as a defender of the victims of human rights abuse, an honest broker in discussions and strategies towards non-combat solutions, often in conjunction with the United Nations in places such as Namibia, South Africa and Cambodia. Our desire to intervene where we can do so effectively to release those in bondage, often in poorer nations, must go unquestioned. But we must not fall into the ego trap of prematurely bringing out our biggest guns—and in Burma, in a non-combat sense, these must be strong trade sanctions and participation in a comprehensive UN endorsed arms embargo against Burma—in order to prove our credentials as defenders of the oppressed; to do so would be to prolong the agony of those very people.

For now we must wait, giving the junta the opportunity to build on the minimal concessions to human rights which it has made, but we must not wait too long.
