For the people of Karen, the wait for relief has already been far too long. It is 3 1/2 years since SLORC seized power. Human rights abuses were recorded then. But, since the election of 1990, in particular, the persecution of the people has grown beyond human endurance, reflecting Adolf Hitler's crime against the Jewish people during World War II.

As is the case in oppression and war, women are doubly the losers. There has been broad reporting of the atrocities endured by the Karen people. Nicholas Cumming-Bruce's commentary in the Age on 16 February 1992 encapsulates the human face of military oppression. In referring to the infamous press-ganging of civilians by the military in Burma, he gave an eyewitness report of a farmer, aged 65, who was reduced to `a beaten, half-starved beast of burden', conscious of the fate of the so-called porters who are worked to exhaustion on the front line as beasts of burden who, when they collapse from hunger and sickness, are killed by the soldiers or are left to die. But for women, the nightmare is extended. Also utilised as porters, the women must endure barbaric rape. (Time expired).

Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. M.J.R. MacKellar)—Order! It being 12.30 p.m. the debate is interrupted in accordance with sessional order 104B. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday.
Question proposed:
That grievances be noted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Atkinson Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take this opportunity to place on record my disappointment and annoyance at the current campaign to change Australia's national flag. This campaign is being conducted by a vocal minority and there is little sympathy for this campaign amongst the vast majority of ordinary Australians. I am not surprised that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has now called for a new flag. This gives him yet another opportunity to divert attention from the appalling state of the Australian economy and his Government's continuing mismanagement of national affairs.

PARA.TAB: I was shocked, however, that the Prime Minister would have the audacity and temerity to denigrate his national flag whilst on foreign soil. Never before have I been so embarrassed by or ashamed of the actions of an Australian Prime Minister. One can be certain that the Prime Minister's predecessor, Bob Hawke, would never have humiliated or insulted his own nation in such a manner. I agree totally with Professor Geoffrey Blainey, who earlier this week wrote:

SPEECH.PARA: The Prime Minister, Mr Keating, has failed in that simplest test of leadership—loyalty to the nation he leads. Nothing was more degrading than his rejection of the Australian flag while officially representing Australia on Indonesian soil. He marks himself as unfit to lead when he positively uses his position as national leader to deride the national flag.

This Prime Minister is determined to destroy our history and our heritage. He has a manic desire to rewrite Australia's history without any reference to the facts. We earlier witnessed his attack on Australia's traditional ties with Great Britain and the monarchy and his bizarre interpretation of Australian-British relations during World War II.

PARA.TAB: Now, as a nation, we must be saddled with this Prime Minister's hatred for our flag simply because it has the Union Jack in the upper left-hand corner. Since assuming the role of Prime Minister, he has embarked on a most amazing attack on Australia's Anglo-Celtic traditions and heritage. I can see no reason why the Prime Minister's utterings should not be labelled as anti-British racism. The Labor Party should be ashamed that it elected this man to the high office of Prime Minister.

The campaign for a new flag has been largely led by a Sydney based organisation calling itself Ausflag Ltd. In late 1991, this organisation wrote to all Federal members of parliament arguing the case for changing Australia's flag and I wish to take this opportunity to place on record my response. The letter, dated 5 November 1991, is addressed to the Executive Director of Ausflag, Mr Harold Scruby, and I quote:

SPEECH.PARA: Dear Mr Scruby
I refer to your letter dated 10 October, 1991, regarding AUSFLAG'S campaign to change Australia's national flag.

I have carefully read your letter and I remain far from convinced that there is a need to change our flag. I do not understand your statement `it is vital in these times that Australia has its own flag`. Australia does have its own flag and I believe that it is supported by the vast majority of Australians. The fact that Europe will have a new flag in 1992 is irrelevant to the present argument in Australia and I dispute your claim that the European flag will be superior in status to the British, French and German flags. I would not wish to be the person to have to tell an Englishman, a Frenchman or a German that his flag has been lowered in status.

Your statement that a change of flag requires only an Act of Parliament and not a change to the Constitution is most interesting. Certainly, Federal Parliament has the power to enact legislation to change the flag but there is certainly an argument that the question should be placed before the Australian people by way of referendum. This is the policy of the Coalition. The national flag should only be changed with majority support from all Australians and not by the whim of politicians. Your organisation should not be attempting to take the short route—the issue is too important.

The comparison with Canada's change of flag is not legitimate. It is well known that Canada's history is very different to Australia's and this fact is referred to by the Canadian Consul in his letter to you dated 21 April, 1986. You make no mention of this argument in your letter.

To assert that there is doubt whether Australia is still a colony of Great Britain is ludicrous. Who has these doubts? Who believes that Australia is not a sovereign independent nation with our own identity? Your letter contains some very bold statements but very few facts to support them.

Your claim that Australia's flag is confusing to the rest of the world is without evidence. It is similar in design only to the national flag of New Zealand—if this worries the New Zealanders then let them change their flag. The claim that our flag promotes Great Britain is laughable—do the flags of the Republic of South Africa and the State of Hawaii (both include the Union Jack) promote Great Britain as well? I challenge you to take a close look at the range of national flags and you will quickly see that many are similar. The Netherlands flag could be confused with the French flag, the Soviet Union flag resembles the flag of the People's Republic of China, the flag of Belgium has the same colours as the flag of Germany, the flags of Indonesia and Monaco are identical and both are similar to the Polish flag. Italy's flag is easily confused with Hungary's and Ethiopia and Bolivia have identical national flags. These are but a few examples. The similarities between the Australian flag and the New Zealand flag are far less than the examples just offered and yet your organisation uses this `similarity' to promote the case for a new flag.

Your final assertion that change is inevitable is quite wrong. The Coalition, along with the overwhelming majority of Australians, supports the retention of the current flag. Your organisation's ambition to impose a change of flag upon the Australian people will not be realised.

Finally, I am annoyed at your use of Banjo Patterson's poem `Our Own Flag'. This poem was written in 1900, one year before Federation and BEFORE the current Australian flag was chosen from a competition attracting nearly 33,000 entries.

At a time when Australia is faced with enormous economic hurdles and the consequent economic and social hardships, I believe that your energies and the energy of your organisation could be better channelled.
That concludes my letter to Ausflag but, for the benefit of the Prime Minister, I will repeat the message contained in the final paragraph:

At a time when Australia is faced with enormous economic hurdles and the consequent economic and social hardships, I believe that your energies and the energy of your organisation could be better channelled.

I am only one of three members of the current Australian Parliament who have served in war under the current Australian flag. Last Saturday, Anzac Day, Australians in every city and town across Australia displayed their affection and support for the national flag. Despite the claims of the Prime Minister, Australian service men and women have fought for this country under the current flag in two world wars, the Korean war, the Vietnam war and, most recently, the Gulf war in 1991.

PARA.TAB: When one sees such expressions of support for the flag, and when one remembers the sacrifices made by Australian service men and women throughout this century, how could one seriously contemplate such an important change to such an integral part of our history and heritage? What is more, if we change now we establish a very dangerous precedent. Any future Prime Minister who is faced with serious domestic problems may attempt to reopen the flag debate and we will never settle the issue. We will be the only nation in the world which embroils itself in a constant debate about its national symbols. The Prime Minister has already embarrassed this country in the international arena by denigrating his own national flag, and that must never be allowed to happen again.

Finally, I wish to place on record my total contempt for the hypocrisy of the Labor Party on the issue of the Australian flag. The Labor Party's symbol, used in all Federal and State elections for the past decade, has boldly and conveniently included the current flag. The Labor Party has held election rally after election rally with the Australian flag emblazoned across the stage. What a pack of hypocrites. My message to the Prime Minister is simple: leave our flag and heritage alone and direct your attention to the crucial economic and social issues facing Australia in 1992. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I enter this debate to highlight a number of concerns I hold regarding the marketing and pricing policies of Australia Post. I do this with some reservations because of the very great respect I have for the hundreds of thousands of people who have worked for Australia Post and those many thousands who still work for Australia Post across this country and who provide a high quality service to consumers, and also because of the working relationship I have had with middle and upper level management of Australia Post. I do not want to denigrate any of the employees or those who have had to make some of these decisions but to target some of the policies—and I know that many of the people who now work for Australia Post agree with me, particularly in my concerns over the closure of Australia Post centres, the franchising and transfer pricing arrangements and other aspects.

PARA.TAB: I accept that Australia Post has played a vital role in being the communications network, as one might put it, across this nation for decades. It has played a commendable historic role in improving the quality of life of people. Regardless of where they live in this nation—whether they live in Dirranbandi, in the outback, in Bourke, or in the capital cities—Australia Post has been there providing a communications system. It has been a vital means of personal communication. It has been an excellent vehicle for the delivery and dissemination of information, and that has been taken up by all sorts of publishing organisations over the decades. Australia Post has been an equaliser in the provision of services to non-metropolitan Australians. It does not matter where one lives; services have been equalised so that those in country areas can gain just as much as others.

I, like many others, have applauded the role that Australia Post has played in providing a community oriented service. It years ago cast aside the idea of user pays. It has always had a national interest test and has been willing to cross-subsidise the cost of delivering a product in country areas by offsetting the profits that have been made in the larger metropolitan areas.

This history goes back to 1984 when Australia Post was given the right to bring about its own changes; it was given that independence. It was allowed to take on what one might call a corporate mentality. It could set its own charges except in two areas: standard letters and registered publications. A role is supposed to be played by the Prices Surveillance Authority in those two categories.

Over the last couple of years we have seen major changes. There has been a targeting for greater efficiency, higher productivity, reduction of costs, and improvement in the quality and variety of postal products and, at the same time, the maximisation of profits. There is no doubt that Australia Post has achieved the last target because it reached $144.1m in profit in 1990-91. I do not blame it for that; I welcome the fact that it has made this profit but it ought not to be maximising profit to the detriment of people generally. Profit should not be maximised at the expense of quality of service to all Australians. It should not be at the expense of Australia Post's community service obligation. It should not be at the expense of Australian jobs and the publishing industry.

We are now seeing a major change in impact on those areas. We note the changes that have taken place, firstly, in the registered post area and, secondly, in the new system of print post. They are the issues I want to target. I have major concerns that relate to delivery times, the closure of post offices, and the postal charges for standard letters, but I want to stress the issues of print post and registered post. Those other matters will be taken up by a special committee of Government members next Monday when we meet with senior Australia Post officers in this Parliament. I am going to restrict comments for the moment to the areas where the real changes have occurred.

The changes have come about because Australia Post says that it has lost something like $20m in print post. I suspect that that is creative accounting. I think the time has come for us to look at the figures that Australia Post has used because over the last 18 months it has massively increased its mailing charges for most magazines. Some of these increases have been as high as 223 per cent. To post a magazine or publication weighing up to 500 grams, one now has to pay $1.52; originally it was only 47c. Previously the profits made on the cost of delivering a standard letter or a magazine in the city areas offset the costs of country delivery; that is no longer so. The system has been changed. There are two categories of weight: from 125 grams to 250 grams, then from 250 grams to 500 grams. Then there are geographical categories—posted from within the same city as the destination, from a city in one State to a city or metropolitan area in another State, such as from Sydney to Brisbane, from a city to the country, or from a country area to a country area—and it is the country people who are suffering massively.

In August 1990, if a letter was posted and delivered within the same city, the cost was 47c. That has been increased to 87c, an increase of 85 per cent. In country areas it originally cost 47c—which was the same as for cities—but today it costs $1.52, a 223 per cent increase.

I believe that Australia Post has abandoned its service obligation to the community. Motivated by the cash register, it has denied its historic obligation and responsibility to be the provider of a communications service to all Australians, irrespective of where they live and who they might be. Whilst the country and provincial consumers are being forced to pay extra, there is a major effect not only on the consumers but also on the publishers.

There are some 12,000 publications across this nation—there is some argument about whether it is 10,000 or 12,000—produced by about 1,000 publishers. They employ tens of thousands of people as photographers, journalists, printers, clerical staff. Those jobs are now in jeopardy because Australia Post has changed the rules. It has cast aside its community obligations. It has thrown off the obligation and responsibility that it had to country people. It is now attacking jobs in this country, attacking small business and attacking consumers. It is not good enough.

The ones affected are the churches, charitable groups, sporting groups, recreational and cultural organisations—the community bodies and societies. There are tens of thousands of these across the nation, all of whom have depended on Australia Post to communicate with their members outside of meeting times. There have been so many items, so many units of material, posted through Australia Post and that process is now under threat not only because of cost but also because of a new rule that, unless one has more than 500 articles to post, one has to pay the ordinary rate. The 47c has been increased to $1.52. If one has only 496 articles to post, one now pays $2.65. Imagine what this will do to the cycling clubs, tennis clubs, coin clubs and other recreational groups across this nation. They will simply not be able to afford that. It will mean a major breakdown in that freedom of information, that distribution of information that is so important to quality of life.

There is another rule: if the cover price of a magazine is over $5, it cannot even come within the print post rules. What has the cover price to do with the costs incurred by Australia Post in delivering a magazine? I would suggest that it has nothing to do with it. The cover price relates to the quality of that magazine; it ought not to have anything to do with the cost of delivery by Australia Post.

My concern is that these rules, which will be in force by 1994—they started on all new magazines from January this year—are going to affect the sorts of groups I have talked about; the religious groups that have periodicals, the community groups and their reports, the Country Women's Association, the trade unions, the welfare groups and the benevolent organisations. These rules are going to restrict them from communicating with their membership. They are going to deter country people from subscribing to magazines—and they depend on magazines on such subjects as fishing, cycling, home gardening, hobbies, and high-tech electronics. They depend on those 10,000 to 12,000 publications for information. They are going to wipe out at least 1,000 small businesses and cause massive losses in jobs.

The changes are going to mean a shift in the producers of publications for this country. Previously, the offshore publishers were not able to get at this special registered post exemption. They were not able to send their magazines at 47c. They had to pay the ordinary rate. Now they can go in there, with a low cost of production, and be equal when it comes to delivery price. They can compete against and wipe out a lot of Australian magazine publishers and get their magazines off the shelves.

I think we ought to do something about it. It is going to have an enormous impact on those people who live outside the metropolitan areas. We need to postpone these changes. Whilst we have given Australia Post some statutory freedom, this Parliament ought to have a say in this matter. It ought to say, `No. No. No' to these changes. It ought to say it is not good enough, when we have an inflation rate of zero per cent, to have increases in Australia Post's prices of five and 10 times—that is setting aside the special example where some items have gone up by 223 per cent in just two years. I believe the whole issue ought to be the subject of a special study by the Prices Surveillance Authority and also by the Federal Consumer Affairs Bureau. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bailey Mrs F.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today I wish to bring to the attention of this House a subject which should concern us all, yet it is a subject that many feel uncomfortable with and choose to ignore. I am speaking about domestic violence. Contrary to popular belief, and most women's fears, women are at greater risk of personal harm and danger at home than they are in the street. In Australia today, family violence accounts for the largest category of homicides. To put a precise figure on the level of domestic violence in Australia is difficult because many cases are unreported, and many of the agencies which deal with victims of violence do not keep records of contact, while the police statistics reflect only the extent of family violence which is actually reported. However, it is accurate to say that domestic violence is widespread and increasing.

PARA.TAB: The report by the New South Wales Domestic Violence Committee released in July 1991 estimated that more than 100,000 women in New South Wales alone are victims of domestic violence. That is one in every 10 women in that State. Those statistics are only an indication of the level of domestic violence in our society—a level which is alarmingly high. Demand for services at Melbourne's five sexual assault crisis centres has doubled over the past year.

The New South Wales study estimated that domestic violence costs the community about $1.5 billion each year, resulting from income that victims must forgo while recovering from assaults, employers' loss through absenteeism and costs carried by the Federal and State governments. That estimate, however, does not include the cost borne by the community for death, serious injury and disabilities caused by domestic violence—which in one case was over $1m.

Violence against women is not solely physical. It often involves threats to harm children, denying social contact with friends and verbal abuse which, while not visible or easily measured, can be just as devastating as physical or sexual abuse. There is no doubt that the psychological effects of violence are devastating. Repeated acts of violence erode a woman's self-esteem and her sense of having any rights or choices. The humiliation and submission, which are at the root of all domestic violence, often leave the woman feeling worthless and helpless, and often reduced to a state of complete despair from which escape is viewed as impossible.

Women experience enormous difficulties in leaving a violent relationship; so much so, that most in fact do not leave. For many women the fear of their partners if they leave, and the lack of police protection, means that they are pressured to stay with their violent partner. In fact, the fear of future violence often becomes the batterer's most powerful weapon to be used against his victim. A woman's fear of her partner is well justified. Homicide studies indicate that threatening to leave or actually leaving an abusive partner is the most dangerous time for victims of domestic violence.

Other factors which prevent women escaping from such violent relationships are concern for their children and having no money, no transport, no housing, no social support and no employment. Many women view escape from violence as a step towards poverty and homelessness for themselves and their children.

The recent case in South Australia, where a jury acquitted a woman of murdering her de facto husband after hearing details of the violence she had endured for years at his hand, has established not only a legal precedent, but also a social precedent as the difficulties that battered women face in leaving a relationship become more widely understood. However, there is still a long way to go. The problems that victims of domestic violence face are often exacerbated for women from non-English speaking backgrounds, Aboriginal women and rural women. Language barriers, lack of appropriate services, lack of information about services, religious and cultural constraints and a lack of understanding on the part of those providing support services all work together to make it exceedingly difficult for migrant and Aboriginal women to escape from a violent relationship.

A study by Lyla Coorey of why rural women do not leave a violent relationship revealed that the structures created by isolation and distance, the employment situation and the financial arrangements between couples make it more difficult for women on the land to leave a violent relationship than for women who live in town. The 1988 Federal Government report Life has never been easy found that those women who live in rural Australia have been deprived of equal access to the education, training and social support freely available to their city counterparts. In some cases this was compensated for by the closer support networks that exist in country communities. However, when it comes to dealing with domestic violence, the country network often fails, with the issue being largely ignored by the community. Lyla Coorey's study found that the attitude in the community towards domestic violence was unsympathetic, as revealed in the community's reluctance to get involved.

It is not only the women who suffer from living in a violent partnership, but their children as well. The causes of domestic violence are far more complex than the commonly purported simplistic causes of alcohol consumption, stress, emotional trauma, conflict or provocation by the victim. Such explanations merely serve as excuses which are used to justify the man's violent behaviour.

It is now understood that violence against women is a product of a set of traditions, habits or beliefs, which permit some men to assume dominance and control over women and to assume the right to use violence as a means of exercising that dominance and control. Mr Allen Fugler—a clinical forensic psychologist who gave evidence at the recent trial in South Australia I previously mentioned—said:

SPEECH.PARA: Men who terrorise and beat women are riddled with insecurities and use aggression to try to control a partner whom they believe has more personal skills than they do.

PARA.TAB: Victims of domestic violence are vulnerable and look to the Government, our judicial system, our police and our society to provide them with support and assistance. In most cases, the Government, the police, the judiciary and society fail to adequately assist and support battered women. The New South Wales Domestic Violence Committee report found that many women do not have access to accurate and confidential information about their rights. This is perpetuated by the fact that police and legal responses to domestic violence are frequently characterised by inconsistency and inaction.

Arrests in this area are rare, despite the fact that domestic violence is a criminal offence. A report on domestic violence by the Australian Institute of Criminology found that police remained reluctant to become involved with what they saw as a private, family matter, and as such were slow to take up their power to arrest offenders.

Domestic violence is not a private matter. It is a community matter which must be addressed by governments and individuals alike. However, except for a number of token efforts in this area, the issue is being largely ignored and hidden. An indication of this is that a major report on the status of women which was tabled in this House just this morning does not contain one recommendation regarding domestic violence. The solution to the problem of domestic violence lies not just with helping victims get out of violent relationships, but with changing society's attitudes towards the treatment of women, changing the attitudes of the police force and a realisation that domestic violence is a crime which is punishable.

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot begin my grievance today without first congratulating the honourable member for McEwen (Mrs Bailey) on a very timely and excellent speech. More and more of us have to raise the issue of domestic violence publicly.

PARA.TAB: My grievance is about the popular misconception that job losses are an inevitable result of environmental protection policies. This is something about which I feel very deeply indeed and on which I hope to speak many times in this place and in other places. The attitude that in the public I am talking about is typified by the increasingly common bumper sticker one see which reads, `Greenies cost jobs'. Too often, the debate about the environment is seen as a juxtaposition between the two, ignoring the fact that, in meeting environmental standards and developing cleaner, energy efficient industries and production processes, significant job growth will occur. Not only do greenies not cost jobs; greenies can create jobs.

I have often spoken on the issue of uranium mining, and when I have opposed uranium mining I have been accused of preventing job creation in Australia. Of course, it has always been very easy to demonstrate how few jobs are created in that particular form of mining. But I will go further now and say that the area of energy generation is an excellent illustration of the way in which clean technologies will not only help us meet essential environmental standards but will also create significantly more jobs than conventional methods.

The primary reason for this is that clean energy technologies are not only more cost effective but, of course, more labour intensive. For example, the generation of 1,000 gigawatt hours of electricity per year in a coal-fired power plant requires an estimated 116 workers. In a solar-thermal facility, to create the same amount of electricity requires 248 workers, while a wind farm needs 542 workers—or shall we put it another way and say that it provides 542 jobs?

Honourable members may feel that wind farms are a pretty fantastic proposition and that I am indeed tilting at windmills—as I am often accused of doing—but I draw honourable members' attention to the Danish experience. Using a temporary subsidy, and I stress that it was temporary, the Danish Government created 3,000 jobs in wind farm manufacturing. That subsidy was repaid threefold in reduced dole payments and increased income tax. By the year 2000, Denmark will have 10 per cent of its electricity supplied by wind. In answer to those who worry about labour costs, I suggest that they keep in mind that those costs are offset by the much lower levels of investment and capital needed in these industries and that investment in capital can then be redirected to more productive areas.

Australia is well placed to repeat the Danish success. The Western Australian, Victorian, Tasmanian and South Australian coastlines have great potential and the Danish figure of 10 per cent could be achieved here by 2005. This would create 8,000 direct and permanent jobs, which is equal to the entire work force employed by the pulp and paper industry, with thousands of additional jobs in the manufacturing phase.

Australia could also gain enormous employment benefit from developing and exporting solar power generated electricity. Australia already leads the world in solar research and development, with several solar manufacturers already exporting a significant proportion of their production.

The international demand for photovoltaic systems is increasing by 25 to 35 per cent annually. Again, we are world leaders in this technology. This market could be ours. A CSIRO study further found that the establishment of a solar power generation industry would create many manufacturing jobs in Australia, as the production of solar-thermal and photovoltaics routes is well within the capabilities of Australian industry. Conventional coal and gas power stations, however, require engineering development beyond these capabilities and that, of course, necessitates imports. A massive export market with a potential for widespread job creation is slipping through our fingers. A familiar story indeed!

The markets, both international and internal, that are being created by environmental policies should not be underestimated. According to the Worldwatch Institute, millions of jobs will be created in energy conservation, recycling and pollution control. In the United States, for example, there are twice as many people employed in the recycling of aluminium as there are in the actual primary production of it. Recycling may already be a bigger employer than coalmining. And the investment by North American companies in pollution control was estimated to have created 166,000 jobs in 1985 in the US alone.

On a global scale, the market for environmental products and services by the year 2000 is expected to be between $US300 billion and $US400 billion. Just think of the employment generation that could involve. Yet the Australian Trade Commission estimates that our share of that market will be 0.1 per cent. We must target government assistance to develop local products which can get a bite of what will be a very jobs-rich cherry. In many cases, Australia has the technology and the potential in the area of environmental products and services just as it has in solar power.

In the field of waste minimisation and toxic waste control, which has created so many jobs in the United States, Australia has produced a number of initiatives. These include Sirofloc, which is used in sewage treatment; the CSIRO plasma furnace; membrane technology for liquid waste treatment; and waste recycling and destruction technologies being developed by Neutralite and CSIRO-Siddons Ramsett. I mention also Memtec, the magnificent Australian company which is involved in the purification of water. It announced yesterday that it is now recognised as the world leader in the area. Let us hope that we keep Memtec in Australia and let us hope that we can use its wonderful work.

Outside of manufacturing and construction, there are many other areas in which our environment could be preserved while offering employment possibilities. A major one is tourism, particularly eco-tourism. Tourism is the largest industry in the world, achieving a growth rate of 8 per cent. Opening Tourism House in Canberra on 29 April this year, the Minister for Tourism (Mr Griffiths) praised the role of tourism saying, `Tourism is now recognised as a key industry, a "fair dinkum" industry and a strong contributor to the national economy'.

Eco-tourism is growing at an even more impressive rate—a massive 30 per cent per annum. It has the potential to be an even greater contributor. Australia, with its famous natural wonders, could become a major eco-tourist destination. Some areas have already shown how beneficial it can be. The Resource Assessment Commission detailed how protected rainforests in the New England region attract 200,000 visitors a year, providing the community with $1.7m a year and supporting 58 full time jobs.

A familiar cry is that meeting international requirements in areas such as the cutting of greenhouse gas emissions will cost jobs when exactly the opposite is true. A recent study in Victoria showed that using clean and efficient energy to achieve a 20 per cent reduction in greenhouse gas emissions by the year 2005 will lead to the creation of 17,300 jobs by that date.

The development of public transport and the upgrading of rail systems would undoubtedly be of environmental benefit due to a reduction in CO(2) emissions. One can imagine the number of jobs that would be provided, both in the creation of infrastructure and in permanent jobs such as those for drivers and conductors.

On the other side of the coin, the job growth of many traditional industries is vastly overrated. When one considers the claims by those proposing the pulp and paper mill in Tasmania, one would think that they were offering the answer to Australia's employment problem. Yet those mills using conventional kraft chlorine bleaching processes are capital intensive, computer automated operations. The number of jobs will significantly decrease very quickly in the years ahead.

While employment in conventional pulp and paper mills can only decrease, the 8,000 workers in wind farms that I referred to earlier could account for only 10 per cent of our electricity needs. Honourable members can see the potential. I do not have the time to go into the many other areas in which jobs are created, but I hope that I have given honourable members reason to think that it is not a question of jobs versus the environment. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to grieve today about the effect of this Federal Labor Government on the inner west of Sydney, which I am honoured to represent. It has one of the proudest and richest histories of any community in Australia. Unfortunately, due to this Federal Labor Government, the reality of the inner west is a sad comparison with its history.

PARA.TAB: No-one in the inner west has been untouched by the horrible legacy of this Labor Government. Our pensioners and our self-funded retirees are ignored and forced to count their pennies. Our families cannot get affordable child-care. Scores of young people are turned away from university and TAFE. Hundreds queue for care at local public hospitals, such as Western Suburbs Hospital, which have been subject to massive Federal underfunding. This is Labor's legacy to the inner west.

But most tragically, more than 10,000 inner west residents are jobless and rely on the dole for their daily bread. In recent months, the inner west dole queues have continued to grow. It is sad but starkly true that in the inner west we are being forced into a dole culture. Young people go straight from their high school graduation to social security registration. If this horrible situation continues, which we cannot allow it to do, hundreds of the inner west's young people will not have jobs until the end of this decade.

Each resident of the inner west knows at least one person who cannot find a job due to Labor's homemade recession. Each resident of the inner west can see in the early morning neighbours waiting for help outside St Vincent de Paul's on Burwood Road or outside the Uniting Church in Ashfield, overflowing with homeless people.

These people are the hardest hit by the recession. But in a sense, we are all victims—victims of a Labor Government which is more concerned with preserving its own power than improving the economy. Labor mates have grown comfy in Canberra, assigned themselves all sorts of perks and closeted themselves from the suffering that is the real Labor legacy—the real 100th birthday gift from the Labor Party to all Australians—namely, the worst recession in 60 years.

The human costs in the inner west of the cruel, cold-blooded economics of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and his mates cannot be measured. The Prime Minister cannot measure the tragedy of a family that splits up because dad cannot cope with the pressures of being out of work for months. The Prime Minister cannot put a meter on the shattered dreams of a bright young person cheated of an education because of Federal Labor Government quotas. The Prime Minister cannot count up the frustration of a talented young mum who cannot work because child-care is beyond her means. The Prime Minister cannot make a statistic of the pain of the aged pensioner who is forced to wait for months or years on a public hospital waiting list for a hip replacement or cataract surgery.

Indeed, I challenge the Prime Minister and his colleagues to get out from behind their Canberra desks, put down their computer print-outs and calculators and come to the inner west to see the real suffering that the Labor policies have inflicted upon a real community in a real world. If a Labor Prime Minister came to the inner west he would realise the total failure of Labor in the inner west where one in three young people is out of work. The Prime Minister would see that Labor has done nothing to create jobs in the midst of Australia's worst recession in 60 years. Or perhaps the Prime Minister could blow the cobwebs off his deputy and send him along to our community. After all, the inner west has been unfairly subjected to untold health system blunders by the Deputy Prime Minister, the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services (Mr Howe).

Hospital funding in New South Wales is down by hundreds of millions of dollars. The Minister has rejected, without even a moment's consideration, my proposal for a new high-tech hospital for the inner west and consigned our residents to outdated health services. In addition, the Minister's bureaucrats will not allow Homebush West to have its own pharmacy; they are content to have senior citizens walk across desolate industrial yards for their scripts.

The fact is that politicians must listen to ordinary people and come up with commonsense solutions for unemployment and the huge taxes every Australian is forced to pay. As every community group meeting tells me, we must cut the taxes of people in the inner west and give them an opportunity to save and to spend. More saving and investing means more jobs. Fightback gets rid of seven separate taxes and takes a huge chunk out of personal income tax. It will put more money in the pockets of people in the inner west and more people in the inner west into jobs. Fightback delivers in this.

Fightback could have been designed specifically for the inner west's specific needs. It will help the inner west's families by making child-care affordable again through increased family allowance. It will help our children with more spending on education. It will give the inner west's senior citizens dignity through increased pensions, better superannuations and rebates for taking out private health insurance. It will discard the old, tried, traditional methods of Labor—the endless spending, the waste, the lust for power, the backroom deals, the mates and the bully boy tactics. We, as a community in the inner west, will fight for our future.

I also take this opportunity to commend some outstanding individuals and groups in the inner west who do a wonderful job in and greatly benefit our community. Their efforts are tireless and serve as a wonderful example to us all. I first mention part of the electorate which has been redistributed into Lowe, Haberfield. Father Frank Meachem of St Joan of Arc in Haberfield is a tireless community worker in both a spiritual and pastoral sense.

TALK.START.PARA: —He is a great man.

—He is a wonderful man. As I say, he is in a part of my electorate which is new. I look forward to sharing with him his great work, great diligence and a commonsense with which he has guarded and guided his parishioners. I am sure that he will continue to do so. I look forward very much to working closely with him for the benefit of the people in this area.

PARA.TAB: My friends at CO.AS.IT, Mary Colinelli and Joe Fin, do so much outstanding work for the Italian community, as does Mr Felice Montrone of the Puglian Association. They especially look after the pensioners, the elderly and the disadvantaged. They do a wonderful job for those who cannot speak English as their mother tongue. They also do a great job in looking after their community. They should be warmly commended.

Let me also mention Reverend Bill Crews and his team at the Ashfield Uniting Church. This has become one of the great centres for caring for the homeless, in particular the homeless youth, in our community. It is the largest centre of its type in the inner west. It has a number of programs that keep kids away from the drug culture, that give them some chance of a start in life. Without them, a lot of kids in our community would be even worse than they are now. I thank God for their care, involvement and hard work. Let me take this opportunity to welcome the Reverend Mautofu Fuimaono-Samuelu to our community. He is a recently inducted minister at that church. I am sure that, as a representative of the fine Samoan community, he will continue to maintain the fine tradition of that church.

Recently, some visitors came out from the Ukraine, children who were affected by the events in Chernobyl. Members of the Russian community organised the visit. In particular, I would like to commend Irina Thorogood, Nick Perch and other members of the Russian community who really took a lot of time and trouble to assist youngsters who were severely affected by radiation. I was delighted to be of some small assistance to the organisation of that trip. I look forward to being of assistance in future trips which are being organised by those in similar groups.

In the inner west we are very honoured to have a number of very effective and very good Combined Pensioners Association branches. I would like to commend, in particular, Jack Spicer of the Ashfield Combined Pensioners Association and Lilian White of the Five Dock Combined Pensioners and Superannuants Association because they do a very spectacular job in looking after the needs of that group. This is a group which in many ways has been neglected by the Government. I am delighted to say that in Fightback they will get many benefits which will indicate the true concern that we, on this side of the House, have for their benefits and welfare—not least of these is the improved health system which they will get under a coalition government. I commend the groups and, in particular, those two members of those groups.

In Five Dock we have a very active Salvation Army Corps—what we might call Christianity with its sleeve rolled up. The leading member of that organisation is Russell Marsh. He is a pillar of the local community. He is what we would call a very decent bloke. We cannot go to any function, organisation or event, without Russell being there. He is always there behind the scenes—working away, making sure it works, looking after those who need a bit of help. Without Russell, our community would be a lot poorer than it is now. I congratulate Russell and his colleagues for the great work that they do there.

The St Vincent de Paul Society all around the country does a wonderful job—that is equally true in the inner west. It is sad to see the queues outside St Vincent de Paul branches, but let me say that Ron Hanlon and the western regional office of the St Vincent de Paul Society do a great job.

In the child-care area, we have some outstanding individuals and organisations. There is Mary Farr of the Concord Family and Child Care Co-operative and Mrs Murray from the Infants Home in Ashfield, which has one of the most ethnic mixes of children in any infants home in Australia. They do a wonderful, loving, caring job for an enormous number of children who are, by and large, very disadvantaged.

I also mention Vera Shaw and her colleagues at the Blind Citizens Association. They do a wonderful job for their particular community. I also mention, in particular, Ron Peak of the Croydon Park Ex-servicemen's Club. Ron is a good bloke. He runs a great club and it is largely through his efforts that the club is so good. The club has a lot of good blokes in it, a lot of members. I think most of them vote Labor, but they are good blokes and they have built up a beaut little club. It is a great pleasure to visit. They look after their mates when their mates are in trouble and I must say it is always a great pleasure to have an association with that club. But I am sure that I speak for them when I say that they were appalled, as I was, at the Prime Minister's cynical denigration of our Australian flag for selfish, political ends. The Prime Minister clearly would stop at nothing and abuse anything or anybody in his lust for power. I also mention the wonderful RSL clubs and, in particular, the Five Dock club with Sam Sleeman and Gordon Hill. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Today is Holocaust Remembrance Day. Those members of parliament who have visited Israel will know that the Holocaust museum, Yad Vashem, commemorates the terrible events surrounding the Jewish Holocaust. There is also a museum in the Jewish Centre of my electorate that commemorates those horrific events. On this day names of Holocaust victims will be read out. That will take place at the Forrest Plaza in Perth today.

PARA.TAB: I believe it is appropriate that we do not lose our sense of perspective and vigilance in relation to the sufferings of the Jewish community. I also note that there is clearly now a campaign by the Australian League of Rights to deny the circumstances of the Holocaust. Unfortunately, I see that this is also being linked with the movement towards the view about one world government—this new order—which I find very unfortunate because at the base one cannot deny the suffering of the Jewish people. Some people now begin to see the world in terms of Jewish conspiracies and also try to deny some historical facts that surround the horrible experience of the Jews under the Nazis during World War II. As I note, the Australian League of Rights is again moving in the Australian community. I find that very unfortunate because at the base its members are, among many things, anti-semitic.

It also gives me the opportunity to mention that the sheikh of the Lakemba Mosque in Sydney, Sheikh Imam Hilaly, did make some remarks in the past that were seen by the Jewish community as anti-Jewish, anti-Zionist and racist. I will not go to the full text because it is not the purpose of this speech to raise the heat on the issue, but rather to say that I believe the time has arisen when it would be appropriate for Imam Hilaly to seek a reconciliation with the Jewish people through the form of an apology for the remarks that are in that speech.

I do so because it is interesting to note that on 30 March of this year was the 500th anniversary of the edict of Isabella and Ferdinand of Spain that expelled the Jewish people from Spain. On the 500th anniversary, the King and Queen of Spain for the first time attended a synagogue. That was clearly an exercise in reconciliation. I believe that we in Australia would benefit from an exercise in reconciliation between the Jewish people and Imam Hilaly. I believe the Imam Hilaly will at one stage wish to attain Australian citizenship. I would have thought that Australian citizenship should be based upon a recognition that one ought not to be a racist. I hope and feel that he would want to disown the remarks that he made in 1988. But I do have to say on behalf of the Jewish community that I believe an apology for those remarks would be very helpful for healing relations between the Jewish community and the members of the Imam's community.

I move now to another matter, the question of television rights. Those who come from the State of New South Wales would be very familiar with the fact that Channel 9 obtained, as a result of many changes, the rights to television coverage of rugby league. In fact it is clearly on the record that its coverage of that has been quite inadequate and quite deficient.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear! It needs to be a lot better. It is atrocious.
—Yes.

—It was much better under Channel 10 and certainly much better under Channel 2. I thank my colleagues for their remarks. Why should it be that a television station can acquire the rights to a sporting event and then not properly exercise those rights. We find that it is terrible in country areas. We had this trouble in the past when people were actually denied access to the Melbourne Cup coverage. In the old days when the ABC had some money, it used to provide the coverage of those sporting events and so we found that people in country as well as metropolitan areas got coverage. We find that those rights are now being purchased, but not exercised.

PARA.TAB: Honourable members may remember a time when they could stay at home and watch on television world title fights involving people such as Jeff Fenech. But no more, because now, if we choose to watch such fights, we have to take our families to somewhere like the Burswood Casino in Perth to watch a fight of that nature or to watch some other major event. I believe that we ought to make it a condition of sporting rights that when those rights are acquired, if they are not exercised they are forfeited and that those rights ought to be made available at a residual price to another television network so that the public at large can still be able to enjoy the benefits of that sporting coverage.

The reason I make this speech is because we are now on the verge of looking at pay television. If the same thing happened with pay television and a channel acquired the rights and decided that it would show, for example, the New South Wales Rugby League Grand Final or the State of Origin games or the AFL grand final at some late hour of the night, the public at large would have no recourse and there would be very little opportunity to exact a market penalty. I believe that we need to write in provisions that where those rights are not exercised, those rights are forfeited.

In Perth, there was a very considerable coverage of rugby league by Channel 10—and certainly Channel 2 continues to provide an excellent coverage—but now it has virtually disappeared off the television screen. The industry is suffering because the rights being held by Channel 9 are not being properly exercised. Frankly, when I have raised this issue its responses have been quite inadequate. I believe that ought to be the position we take.

I also wish to raise another issue that I previously raised in this place and that is this program on Channel 10 called Studs. It is simply a salacious, cheap exploitation of women. It ought not to be on television. It is a disgraceful program. I do not say that because I am particularly morally offended by it; I just find it is cheap. The fact that it comes from the United States means it has absolutely no redeeming quality because there is no employment generated for Australians even so. But it is just a cheap, salacious exploitation of women and it is on at prime time.

If it were buried away like some of the other grubby pieces of television late at night, I would not feel so concerned. But at prime time I believe it to be a cheap, salacious exploitation of women. I say to Channel 10, `It is time that you took it off the air. If this is what your financial difficulties have created, then we really have to wonder where Channel 10 is headed'. The Australian public is not served by a program that is so degrading of women. It is time for this to be dealt with.

I turn now to one other matter that is on the horizon; that is, the likelihood of some Chinese refugees coming to Australia. We are informed that there is a boatload of people heading towards the north-west coast of Western Australia. The current predicament with the Cambodian refugees causes me great concern. It has been a lawyers' field day. The Australian community is impatient with it.

The Australian community believes, as members in this Parliament believe, that there are opportunities for people to come to Australia through the orderly process. There are cases of genuine refugee hardship in which the Australian community—and this is a bipartisan matter—says, `You, as members of Parliament, should have a refugee program'. But to have people engaging in what is now a process of exploiting the Australian system—and the legal aid system—is unacceptable. When I heard the latest news item, my first response was, `I wonder who the lawyers are going to be to represent these people when they land in Australia?'.

One does not want to be inhumane about the issue, but I want to say, on behalf of the Australian community, that it is unacceptable that we have a process which is so longwinded and allows people to take advantage of what turns out to be our hospitality in the name of refugees, when there would be many other refugees around the world with very genuine cases to put before us. We need to be much more vigilant about this.

I do not believe that we should be simply open armed in being prepared to accept these people into Australia. In this case, the Indonesians have said they should send the refugees on their way. I do not believe that we ought to fall into the same trap as we did with the Cambodian refugees. We need to be very vigilant about this. These are issues that we need to be addressing in relation to the refugee problem.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cobb Mr M.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The great rural industries of Australia, most of which are represented in my electorate, are in a desperate financial position. Much of this is due to Federal Government policy. Australia, as a whole, is in an economic mess. The overseas debt has blown out sixfold during the term of this Government from $23 billion to $145 billion net. We have one million people unemployed. While we may welcome an inflation figure of 1.7 per cent annually, it is flat only because the economy is flat. If

SPEECH.PARA: and when the economy moves up, that figure will probably, unfortunately, move up too. Farms and small businesses are shutting down in my electorate almost every day. This is largely due to bad economic management. The rest of the world is starting to get its act into order. I believe Australia is lagging behind. It seems that every wealth creating enterprise in this country is forced to persist with antiquated practices and methods that put us at a disadvantage to the rest of world.

PARA.TAB: There is no better example of this than the wage on-costs that we have to bear in Australia. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a table showing these wage on-costs.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. This table highlights how detrimental these costs are. If one compares an Australian wool carpet manufacturer with a New Zealand wool carpet manufacturer, the table shows that, on just about every indicator one can look at—whether it be annual leave, public holidays, sick leave, rostered days off, annual leave loading of 17 1/2 per cent, shift premiums, long service leave, payroll tax, workers compensation, productivity superannuation and so on—New Zealand has a lower figure, or a zero figure. For example, New Zealand does not have payroll tax. The wage on-costs in Australia for a wool carpet manufacturer are 51.5 per cent; in New Zealand, the figure is 13.6 per cent. In other words, New Zealand wool carpet manufacturers are working at an advantage over us of 300 or 400 per cent on their wage on-costs. That translates into costs to the employer of about $4,500 per employee per year. How can we compete against that?

PARA.TAB: The upshot of all of this is that it raises the cost of living within Australia, which means ultimately a lower standard of living for us all. It makes Australia uncompetitive with the rest of world. Other countries can, in effect, produce their goods cheaper than us and undercut us. For example, in China textile factories pay wages of $1,000 to $1,500 a year. Employees are prepared to work 12 hours a day, six days a week in some cases. If they can get their machinery to a half decent level—because productivity is what it is all about—they can undercut us.

I am alarmed to hear that the textile side of Pacific Dunlop Ltd is thinking of moving to China. Unfortunately, the Government seems oblivious to this. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) was overseas tugging his forelock in Indonesia recently. He came back to Australia and immediately started tugging his forelock to the ACTU and Bill Kelty, instead of dealing with these sorts of problems.

Compare a First World country such as New Zealand with Australia. There is a firm in New Zealand called Feltex, which is owned by BTR Nylex. In many cases, its employees are working three shifts a day seven days a week, compared with our employees, who are working one shift a day five days a week. Feltex is now substantially undercutting Australian firms. On top of that, we have a $A1 to $NZ1.40 exchange rate to compete with, as well as the wage on-costs differences which I have already highlighted, that makes it very difficult.

Under the CER agreement between Australia and New Zealand, which I strongly support, there is not a 32.5 per cent tariff on carpets. So the Australian carpet manufacturers are really up against it. I am in favour of that tariff being abolished, but these other things must be pulled into line too so that our manufacturers can compete.

Feltex New Zealand is making a major thrust into Australia. I will highlight three instances, one of which we can see before us. The contract to lay 70,000 square metres of carpet in this Parliament back in 1985-86 was worth $4.8m and involved the use of 150,000 kilograms of wool. Apart from Australian made carpet for the Prime Minister's suite and a couple of other token areas, Feltex New Zealand was successful in getting that contract, and Australian producers and firms were denied the opportunity to supply our very own Parliament with Australia's number one product. I believe the committee was advised that Australian manufacturers did not have the quantity or the right price for the job, which I believe is nonsense. I am looking into that.

I am told that some significant sections of the carpet in Parliament House have to be replaced. If that information is correct, I will do everything I can to ensure that it is replaced with Australian carpet.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—I acknowledge the support of the honourable member for Franklin. The Sydney International Airport carpeting contract was let in February of this year. That $2.7m contract was for 55,000 square metres of carpet and involved 100,000 kilograms of wool. Feltex New Zealand was successful again against Australian tenderers. The Melbourne International Airport requires 14,000 square metres of carpet, 36,000 kilograms of wool, worth $0.7m . The early indications are that Feltex will probably be the successful supplier again. Australia is losing out.

PARA.TAB: I would like to discuss briefly how the carpet wool manufacturing industry and the wool growers are missing out because of this. We have got 80 to 90 manufacturers in Australia. Most of them are very small. I will highlight nine of the major firms, eight of which are vertically integrated. We have Tascot Templeton Carpets in Tasmania, for example, which is one of three weavers of carpets in Australia. It produces superior quality carpets and has a high patterning capability—it can integrate 42 colours. It has done such projects as the Sheraton Wentworth in Sydney, Wrest Point at Hobart, Adelaide Airport, Changi Airport in Singapore and so on. It is a great company.

TALK.START.PARA: —All from Tasmania.

—It is all from Tasmania, as the honourable member says. Australia has carpet manufacturers such as Invicta, Godfrey Hirst, United Carpet Mills, Minster, Homfray Hycraft, Victoria Carpet Co., Brintons and Pacific Textiles. I will highlight one of the tufted carpet manufacturers, the Victoria Carpet Company. Ninety-five per cent of Australian carpet manufactured is tufted carpet. It is low in labour cost. The Victoria Carpet Co. uses about 100,000 kilograms of wool a month. It sources its wool product from Albany in Western Australia, Geelong and New Zealand—New Zealand wool is becoming more competitive. Wool spinning is very labour intensive. With these on-cost advantages that I was talking about earlier, New Zealand is starting to undercut the Australian mills and that is a great shame indeed.

PARA.TAB: The growers are also affected. We have 30,000 woolgrowers in Australia who produce crossbred type wool from 25 to 40 microns, who produce wool suitable for interior textile design in carpets, bedding products, doonas, bats, upholstery, fabrics, curtains and so on. Each grower has an average size clip of only 17 bales compared with the merino grower's 110 bales, but it is, nevertheless, a significant industry. If that wool is sold in Australia for use in Australia it helps put a floor in the market in this country. Instead, we have the finished product coming from overseas and that is a loss to Australia in raw sales and value adding, which the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) is very keen on.

What is the coalition going to do about this? We intend to help the Australian manufacturers, which in turn will help the Australian woolgrower and help Australia. One firm of weavers that I was talking to yesterday uses 500,000 kilograms of wool a year. It employs 210 people. Its payroll tax cost alone is $400,000 to $450,000. We are going to remove that tax totally in our Fightback package. That is what we are going to do for that one particular company; that will help make it viable. The Victoria Carpet Co. that I spoke of earlier employs 135 people and has a payroll tax burden of $230,000.

The coalition, if we attain government at the next election, is going to abolish that impost. Also, the sales tax of 10 per cent that companies have to pay as a capital outlay will be rebated for business purposes, which will be of great use to them.

Do honourable members realise that the second highest cost this company has after wages is actually freight? It costs this company $850,000 a year to lug its carpets around Australia and deliver them. Of course, the Opposition is abolishing the fuel excise, sales tax on parts and so on. This will lower the freight costs that that company is presently burdened with.

The GST Fightback package also delivers industrial relations reform, which will help us to greatly reduce oncosts, for example by abolishing the 17 1/2 per cent leave loadings, if companies want to do that, and rearrange the working hours, on top of suitable practices. The Opposition is offering a lot; the Government is offering nothing. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —In the three minutes that are left I want to talk very briefly about the benefits of the zero inflation rate that was announced yesterday. That is really quite a remarkable achievement at a time when the whole world has an inflation problem. It is remarkable that Australia's position has moved to the point where in the first three months of this year there was no average movement in prices at all.

PARA.TAB: There are great benefits from that zero inflation rate. The most obvious is that people have a greater sense of security. One of the goals of the Government's economic policy is stable prices. People want the security of knowing when they go to shops or when they buy petrol or whatever that they will have a predictable price to pay. Zero inflation does not mean that every price is stable; it just means that on average there has been no upward or downward movement.

That is of benefit in creating a sense of security. Perhaps more importantly than that, it is of great benefit to us as we try to build up our exports. Prices in most of the rest of the world are rising, sometimes quite strongly. If we can keep our inflation rate stable then the price of our exports will not be going up and that means that we will have a greater capacity to export effectively. In other words, Australia's economy becomes a more competitive economy.

There are good reasons why prices are stable. The principal reason is not that there is a recession but that for the last seven or eight years there has been an extraordinary level of wage restraint. The prices and incomes policy, the Accord, has been effective in restraining wages in an unprecedented way in Australia. That has gradually fed through into prices, so that prices too are now stable. It is also partly due to the fact that the economy is recessed and therefore the demand is not as high for commodities. There is no doubt that the principal influence has been the restraint on wages.

Another benefit is that this allows the Government greater scope for expansionary policies in the Budget. It is essential that, at a time of high unemployment, fiscal policy be as expansionary as possible. With stable prices there is greater scope for stimulatory policies which will lead on to faster growth of employment.

I thought I would resurrect a poem that I wrote in 1985. I thought it was good. A lot of people do not agree with me but that is their prerogative.
