SPEECH.PARA: KEEP OUR FLAG
Australians all please make a vow
To keep the flag that we have now.
It's been our emblem over the years
- It represents our joys and tears.
Our heritage is strong and true—
Why should we change to please the few
Who would turn from all it represents
For the ego of "Would-be" Presidents?
Let's never forget the men so brave
Who sacrificed their lives to save
Australia and its freedom.
Lest we forget their reason for dying
- Let's keep their proud flag ever flying.

While I am at it, every week I usually give the Greens a bit of a brush up, but I am pleased to say that it got so cold down at the Picton River that they decided to give up their protest and give the honest people of Tasmania an opportunity to work. If Dr Bob Brown wants another combat on the 7.30 Report, I am ready for him at any given time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wonder whether many Australians are aware of the shoddy treatment the British Government gives to so many British residents in this country. The question I raise, of course, is the lack of indexation of the British social security retirement pensions paid to United Kingdom pensioners resident in Australia.

PARA.TAB: If indexation on British 1990 estimates were paid, an additional #141m or over $330m would be coming into this country. Not only would this have a positive effect on the balance of payments; it would also have a marked effect on Budget revenue and expenditure. There would be reductions in Australian income support, payments made and also the benefits from higher income tax receipts. It is obvious that Britain is not only ripping off its former residents; it is also ripping off the people of Australia. At least half of that $330m would have gone into the public purse.

Let me give the House some facts about a particular 75-year-old British retirement pensioner. At present he receives #28 per week, when in fact he should be getting #52. If that person went on holiday in the United Kingdom he would immediately get the higher rate each week. This means that the United Kingdom is retaining #1,248 or around $3,000 per year from a person aged 75 who paid for a full pension over a period of 40 years or more. That is very poor show indeed, as you, Mr Speaker, would no doubt agree. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —On foreign soil the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has announced that the Australian flag will be altered. The Australian Labor Party presently uses this fine symbol of Australia's nationhood as a backdrop for its conferences.

PARA.TAB: At the last Federal election, the former Prime Minister, the former honourable member for Wills, stood in front of a large Australian flag. The ALP's current platform, adopted in 1990, features the ALP logo with the flag again showing. A distinctive Australian flag on a coloured background was used by the ALP on its how to vote cards at the election to convince voters that they should support Labor. Therefore, the ALP strategists think that the Australian flag has vote winning potential for the Labor Party. The ALP's market research must suggest that both hard core ALP, as well as swinging voters, view the present flag with some respect.

Countless presentations of our proud flag have been made by current ALP members and senators to hundreds of community groups throughout the community. With members of the ALP having for many years draped themselves in the glory of the Australian flag, what ideas would the Prime Minister have in designing a new flag for the use of the ALP. Could I suggest the Prime Minister might like to adopt for the ALP a flag depicting a combination of Japanese, Malaysian and Thai flags around the edges, with the centre featuring a large representation of the Indonesian flag to symbolise the Prime Minister's new found interest in Asia. Or perhaps the Prime Minister could adopt an ALP flag with a combination of American, German and British flags to show Australia's growing—(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am glad we are talking about the flag. I want to use this opportunity to call upon the Leader of the National Party (Mr Tim Fischer) to endorse the enlightened views of a Queensland National Party State MP on changing the Australian flag. The National Party endorsed candidate for the seat of Kennedy and State MP, Bob Katter, yesterday told Mount Isa's daily paper, the North West Star, `It was ridiculous to have someone else's flag taking up a quarter of your own flag'.

PARA.TAB: For once, I agree with Mr Katter. I hope that he does not get rolled on this issue as he did in relation to the sugar tariff issue. He stuck with zero tariffs without any consultation with the industry. I think that it is very important that he has made these comments. The Leader of the National Party should stop pontificating over the flag issue and endorse Mr Katter's view that we should dispense with the Union Jack on the Australian national emblem. In fact, I will be writing to Mr Katter shortly and inviting him to co-sponsor a Kennedy electorate campaign competition to design a new Australian flag. I will certainly welcome his participation in that.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation: Coverage of Anzac Day Marches and Services

TALK.START.PARA: —Last Saturday, thousands of ex-service men and women participated in Anzac Day marches and services in cities and towns throughout Australia. Thousands more veterans—for a variety of very good reasons—were unable to march or attend the special commemorative services. These old and not so old soldiers, along with hundreds of thousands of other Australians of all ages and backgrounds, tuned their television sets to the ABC in order to watch the marches and services taking place in capital cities of this nation.

PARA.TAB: But this year, the ABC decided that Anzac Day marches and services were not deserving of the complete coverage they had previously enjoyed and undoubtedly deserved. At about 12 o'clock viewers in Victoria were unceremoniously advised that the telecast of the Anzac march and service in Melbourne was about to be interrupted to permit a repeat screening of a program in the Opening Learning series. I understand that the same outrageous and inexcusable situation occurred in some other States.

Anzac Day is a sacred day—a day of national significance. The decision of management of the ABC to curtail its direct coverage this year was heartless, insulting and inexcusable. It is not good enough. If the present ABC powers that be cannot see their way clear to allow sufficient time to cover the Anzac Day marches and services in their entirety, they should be replaced by others who have a better understanding of the debt we owe to those who sacrificed so much in the defence of this very great nation. Lest we forget.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rightfully, the sugar industry is recently attracting a lot of attention. The General Manager of the Australian Cane Farmer's Association, Mr Joe Farley, has come out and said that the leader of the coalition has demonstrated a lack of knowledge regarding the operation of the sugar industry and that, indeed, his attitude is harming world trade. I do concur with Joe, but I would like to point out that the Opposition is saying that Fightback is going to help the sugar industry. The yuppies over there do not understand that cane farmers do not pay payroll tax. The Opposition is going to abolish petroleum excise. Cane farmers do not use petrol. They actually use diesel in their tractors and harvesters, and have done so for 30 years.

PARA.TAB: The Opposition wants to exempt wholesale sales tax. We have done it. The Opposition cannot exempt something that has already been exempted. It wants to have a scorched earth policy of zero, to adopt the IC recommendations without any qualifications whatsoever, and then lump a 15 per cent GST on top of it. The Opposition then wonders why Senator Macdonald got chucked out of the cane growers meeting last week and was perceived as being a fool.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am forced to my feet by the absurd remarks of the honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Courtice). Fancy suggesting that cane growers do not pay payroll tax or that cane farmers, because they consume diesel and not fuel, are in some way not affected by the Fightback package. Who does the honourable member for Hinkler imagine pays for the diesel that is used by all the trains that are used to cart the crane to the factory, that is consumed by the factory, or pays the payroll tax incurred by the mill workers? Of course, the sugar industry carries the cost. The Fightback package will distinctly service and assist the sugar industry, just as it will service all primary industries, as the honourable member for Hinkler is well aware.

PARA.TAB: Any suggestion that the stand by this party on the question of tariff reform has, in any sense, adversely affected export markets for the sugar industry has to be nonsense. The sugar industry knows where we stand; it knows where the honourable member for Hinkler stands. He would do well to acknowledge the support his Government has had from the Opposition in spite of the difficulty the Opposition has faced. He would be much more gracious if he were to acknowledge that rather than pour a bucket on the Opposition from some self-righteous stance that he has chosen to take.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to report to the general community most interested in reform of disability programs on the expansion of funding for disability programs by this Government. In 1983, the Commonwealth was providing $29.9m, assisting 13,000 people with a disability. By 1991, the support had grown to $64.16m, assisting some 24,000 people with a disability.

PARA.TAB: The four-year expansion package announced in the 1990 Budget increased this support even further. By 1995, the DSP will provide almost $100m in 1990 dollars to directly assist over 30,000 people with a disability with such services. In addition, an extra 12,700 people with a disability will be assisted through DEET and CRS programs, bringing the number of people assisted to 21,700. While much more needs to be done, I am very pleased to make this announcement of expansion on behalf of our Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Taylor Mr W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to read to the House part of an Anzac Day address on the Australian ethos given in Toowoomba last Tuesday by a local World War II veteran, Colonel Malcolm Stuart. He said, in part:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . it is our duty, those of us who are still alive and capable, to work for the political, social and national unity which is so lacking today to ensure that when and if they do have to go to war our soldiers will not have to be looking over their shoulders and their efforts and sacrifice will not be in vain.
He also said:
Could they be sure that the cohesion of our social structure can give them the vitally loyal support they must have if they are to protect their country against an enemy?

Can they trust and rely on their political leaders of all parties to ensure that the country will not be divided, that the political loyalty will not be given to external institutions as is sometimes the case now?
He said:
Can they be sure that every permanent resident is . . . without political loyalties to a foreign, and possibly hostile, country?
Finally—and this is particularly for the ears of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating)—Colonel Stuart went on to say:
Or that our symbol of unity, our flag, will not be abused either in Australia, or a foreign country, by our political leaders?

TALK.START.PARA: —Both the Government and the Opposition can be blamed if the resource security legislation fails to pass the Senate. I have to shaft a few of my colleagues and illiberal people in the Opposition. It is stupid that legislation was shoved aside over a title. The action will not stop me from working for resource security for the timber industry. In the end, the legislation was accepted by both sides, but after picky examination the Liberal and National parties demanded a change in the title of the legislation.

PARA.TAB: This time, some of my colleagues decided that they would keep the legislation out under any pretext and they were quite happy to dump on their colleagues in the country. They will not succeed. The pettiness of the major parties over this issue is another shovel full of dirt in the hole of the grave for party politics. I acknowledge that Federal and State management for sawmills is separate and could proceed smoothly with good will. Even pulp mills could be dealt with separately and given the guarantees needed, but this will be far more cumbersome for the industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you for the opportunity to speak today on the Australian flag. It looks as though Victoria is to have an Australian flag led recovery. My office has been inundated with calls for supply of the Australian flag as it stands today. I draw to the attention of the House the fact that, in 1984, the Australian Labor Party's glossy brochure for re-election—in shiny first-use paper—had emblazoned upon it the Australian flag. Written across the top of it were the words: `Australian Labor Party'.

PARA.TAB: The Government was saying to Australia, `Here is what we stand for; here is the Australian flag'. It was emblazoned on every piece of literature the Labor Party had for the 1984 election, the 1987 election and the 1990 election. What did the Labor Party put up behind its leader when he spoke at each election campaign speech? It was the Australian flag, with the Union Jack proudly emblazoned in the corner.

In my electorate of Corinella—all the way from beautiful Phillip Island up to Wonthaggi and into the heart of Dandenong—the Australian flag now stands, and will stand until the next election. We will then see what the Government will put up behind its leader. It will be the Australian flag behind the Prime Minister. The Government will say, `Here we are'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 2 p.m., in accordance with sessional order 106A, the time for members' statements has concluded.

—Will the Prime Minister confirm that he has received a letter from the National President of the RSL advising him that the Prime Minister `confused and misled the House on Tuesday over the issue of the Australian flag'? Did the RSL President, a man whose own father, Major Garland, died as a result of service at Kokoda and was buried under the Australian flag in 1945, advise that the Prime Minister was wrong when he asserted that Australian forces at Kokoda had fought under the Red Ensign, not the Australian flag? Does the Prime Minister have the common decency now to admit that he was wrong or will he continue to distort our history for his own shabby, political ends?

—I noticed RSL spokesmen making statements about the flag and its use in certain theatres of war over a period of weeks, and often erroneously. I took my advice from the Australian War Memorial and other advisings. Let us be clear. The principal fact is that in the First World War particularly the Union Jack was the principal flag.
—You cannot even get that right.
—Order!

—Let us make this totally clear: when Prime Minister Menzies said that the Australian flag could be flown, and in 1947 Prime Minister Chifley said by press release that the Australian flag could be flown, they were making a concession against the flying of the Union Jack. It took the Prime Minister to put a press statement out saying, `You may, as a concession, fly the Australian flag'. Two concessions by Prime Minister Menzies and by Prime Minister Chifley. That was the sort of attitude: that you could only fly the Union Jack in this country—the flag of another nation. The concession was, Mr Speaker—

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!

—You do not like this because, like all conservatives, you have always got to be dragged screaming. As I said the other day, when someone turns up the Hansard of these debates he will chuckle and giggle and guffaw at the obscurantism of you lot opposite.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The House will come to order.
—Mr Speaker—
—Do you have a point of order?
—On a point of order: I was wondering if I could ask the Prime Minister to table the letter from the President of the RSL; if not, can I table it on his behalf?
—Order! That is not a point of order. The Leader of the Opposition should not use those sorts of stratagems.

—Has the Treasurer's attention been drawn to claims that for Australia to become `genuinely internationally competitive' there is a requirement for `an entire generational change' and that Australia jettison the `20 lost years of bad policy, bad attitudes and bad values by just about everyone'? Can the Treasurer tell the House whether Government analysis of those claims provides justification?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did notice the comments of the Leader of the Opposition when he went to New Zealand to disparage his country. He has got himself into this habit of constantly attacking this country both here and abroad, denigrating it, running it down, pretending it does not have the strengths that it does, and not being prepared to recognise the great strengths which have been emerging, and will continue to emerge, from the hard work of Australian working men and women who recognise the challenge which Australia faces in becoming competitive and who have decided to work cooperatively to try to achieve a greater level of competitiveness.

PARA.TAB: What do they hear from the Leader of the Opposition? They hear this constant, nagging, narking criticism and abuse from him as he goes around the country and as he visits other countries in the world. This was particularly the case when he went to New Zealand the other day. The Minister for Social Security referred to another of his observations, which I will get to in a moment.

In all of these criticisms the Leader of the Opposition simply ignores the normal standards of analysis and the normal standards of arithmetic accuracy. This is becoming a constant theme and a constant shortcoming of the Leader of the Opposition, despite his much flaunted education and his much flaunted claim of competency in these things.
We recall, of course, the observation made by the now Minister for Trade and Overseas Development when he referred to a speech by the Leader of the Opposition in Brisbane last year, in which he said:

ANSWER.PARA: On the Treasury's own index of competitiveness today we are 15 per cent less competitive than we were in 1982-83 when the Hawke Government came to office.

As the then Treasurer pointed out to the Leader of the Opposition, to his eternal embarrassment and shame, a reduction in the index of competitiveness is, of course, an increase in the competitive position of Australia. A fall in that index denotes an improvement in competitiveness. What happened was, of course, that the Leader of the Opposition simply got the graph upside down; he was incapable of the normal standards of analysis and arithmetic accuracy which one would expect from anyone who makes such searingly critical comments about Australia and Australians.

PARA.TAB: The other day the Minister for Social Security pointed out another observation of the Leader of the Opposition when he was in New Zealand and when he said:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . over 80 cents in every taxpayer's dollar goes to social security and welfare in Australia. That is, 80 cents of what you pay in tax goes to look after somebody else's family before you look after your own.
The Minister for Social Security pointed out the absurdity of that particular proposition, to which the Leader of the Opposition put out an immediate riposte. He said:

If Dr Blewett was numerate he would understand that outlays on social security and welfare totalled $30 1/2 billion in 1990-91. In that same year net PAYE revenue was $37.6 billion. The former as a percentage of the latter is 81 per cent.
And he goes on to say:
Is that the best Dr Blewett can manage?

This is an astonishing piece of fiscal analysis on the part of the Leader of the Opposition, because he assumes that the only funds going into social security and welfare are those which come from PAYE taxpayers—nothing from fuel tax, nothing from company tax and nothing from any of the other revenues which come into the Federal Budget.

PARA.TAB: However, it is even more absurd than that when you apply a bit of Fightback analysis to this arithmetic. On page 14 of Fightback it says:

ANSWER.PARA: We will reduce PAYE tax by $13 billion in two phases.
And:
. . . we will reduce expenditure in social security by $228m.

So let us apply a bit of Hewson arithmetic to this new equation. First of all, under Fightback we have social security and welfare outlays of $30 billion and net PAYE revenue of $24,000m. So what does this mean? It does not mean that we are spending 80c in the dollar on social security and welfare; we are spending $1.23 out of every dollar on social security and welfare!

PARA.TAB: So this is the way in which the Leader of the Opposition intends to reduce the dependence of individuals on the welfare sector, by in fact increasing, on his own arithmetic absurdity, the amount coming from PAYE from 80c in the dollar to 123c in the dollar as a result of that. Of course, it is no wonder—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order.
—Order! Honourable members on my right will cease interjecting.

—The Minister has now been speaking for some eight minutes in respect of this question and answer. Mr Speaker, I know that your job is difficult, but it is made increasingly difficult by those lengths of answers. I ask you to apply the convention and ask the Minister to come to the conclusion of his answer.

—It is no wonder that, when this man is in control of the calculator on the other side, there is a $3.9 billion hole in the GST package. How ridiculous and absurd it is for him to disparage the arithmetic of the Minister for Social Security by saying `if Dr Blewett was numerate'. I can say one thing: when Dr Blewett decided to abandon his academic career and come into Parliament that was a great loss to academia in Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members—Ha, ha!

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!

—But when the Leader of the Opposition decided to abandon his teaching profession at the University of New South Wales and come into Parliament, I might say that that was a great boon for the teaching of economics in Australia. That was a great boon for all economists in Australia.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The House will come to order.

Why has not the Minister been stood down?

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Richardson did not seek to rescue a relative at all. What he said in his press statement—

—I will read his press statement:

ANSWER.PARA: After checking with the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Gareth Evans, to ensure that I was not acting improperly, I rang Mr Kabua, the President of the Marshall Islands. In introducing myself, I made it clear I was not ringing in my official ministerial capacity.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The House will come to order. Honourable members on my left will cease interjecting.
—This is remarkable.
—So you approve?

—Order! The honourable member for Kooyong.

—What he sought was that his relative be given access to documents held in Australia to prepare his defence and to give appropriate assurances and undertakings that he would return to the Marshall Islands to have the matter heard. Senator Evans had this to say in the Senate:

ANSWER.PARA: I understood that Senator Richardson himself had no intention of making any suggestion that the charge be dropped, and I thought that was wise. I said, `Finally I did not see any objection in principle in making the call as long as he did not hold himself out in doing so as acting on behalf of the Australian Government'.
Which he did not do. He rang as a private citizen seeking only—

TALK.START.PARA: —Who paid for the call?
—Order! The House will come to order.
—A Minister can never divorce himself or herself from the fact that he or she is a private citizen in certain circumstances.
—Did he use a public phone?
—Order! The Leader of the National Party.
—Therefore, he did not seek to, as the Leader of the National Party has said, rescue a relative.
—Who paid for the call?
—You do not want to start about private calls and government expense, do you?
—My word I do.
—Do you?
—My Oath!
—I would not if I were you, Andrew.
—I will take you on any time.
—Order! The House will come to order.
—And your tax.
—Order! The honourable member for Kooyong!
—Or any of you, frankly. In that sense, he was seeking only that this person have his passport returned so he could prepare a case for his defence.

—My question is also addressed to the Prime Minister. Can the Prime Minister advise the House whether yesterday's excellent inflation result was simply a result of the recession? What will the Government do to ensure that low inflation is preserved as economic recovery proceeds?

—The short answer is no. Yesterday's result of zero inflation for March was not simply a result of the recession, which is a line being run by the doom and gloom merchants opposite, particularly the shadow Treasurer. Yesterday he said, `You always get low inflation in a recession'.
—That is right, he says. Well, how come we got 11 1/2 per cent in 1982-83?

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The House will come to order.
—God, you are a case!
—Order! The Deputy Leader of the Opposition will cease interjecting.

—After the 1974-75 slowdown, we had double digit inflation as well. Today's inflation result came about principally because of the Government's incomes policy. In the boom which was the forerunner to the recession, we beat, for the first time, the dismal legacy of double digit inflation, coming from double digit wage increases, with wage explosion reacting to very high levels of demand in the economy.

PARA.TAB: Accord mark VI held wages at around 6 per cent in that boom when wage increases on offer were of the order of 12 to 15 per cent. So instead of entering the recessionary period off an inflation base of 10 or 11 per cent, we entered it with an inflation base of around 6 to 7 per cent. As a result of that and the sensible operation of monetary policy, we saw inflation decline.

In fact, if we look at the CPI underlying rate from 1985 to 1991, we see that there is a trend decline right through the whole period. Anybody trying to suggest, as the Deputy Leader does, that this is a sort of one-off fluky thing that came from the recession, has got to deny the whole trend line down and, as well as that, the trend not only in inflation but also in inflationary expectations which has accompanied it, which was never there in 1982-83 or 1974-75.

TALK.START.PARA: —Look at the unemployment queues.
—Order! The honourable member for Ballarat!

—Inflationary expectations never shifted in either of those slowdowns in that recession, but have tracked inflation down for the first time since inflation became a long term problem for Australia over the period from the middle 1980s.

PARA.TAB: The Government can claim that it alone was able to break the back of Australia's inflation. The conservative parties, despite nearly a decade of living with double digit inflation, were not able to deal with it, and would not be able to deal with it in the future; but, not only that, they would compound the problem. As the Australian Financial Review said today, a tremendous gain has been produced in this country. The Opposition would put that asunder, would sabotage it, by adding five to seven percentage points to the price system from a consumption tax, without any mechanisms for removing that surge in inflation, that surge in wages, from the ongoing inflation rate and then would ask the central bank to jack up interest rates to such levels as to pull that inflation from 7 per cent or 6 per cent down to zero.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Dundas will cease interjecting.

—That is the reality of the Opposition's policies in relation to inflation, whereas the reality of the Government's policies is that we are now sitting on an annual inflation rate of 1.7 per cent, a quarterly rate of zero and an underlying rate of 3 per cent, with low interest rates and with a wages policy intact. As the Australian Financial Review reports today, `Hewson wants "big bang" labour reform'. The big bang will be a big bang in inflation, a big bang in interest rates and a big bang for the economy a minute later as it hits the wall, as we see a recovery nipped in the bud, smashed by rising interest rates.

PARA.TAB: The fact is that, in this key area of competitiveness, the inflation rate upon which interest rates and investment sit, and our capacity to trade and be competitive, it is the Opposition which threatens this policy, this outcome, with its consumption tax, and it has no mechanisms whatsoever to take it out of the ongoing inflation rate and no mechanism to get inflation down, other than by instructing the central bank to operate a vicious and draconian monetary policy on the economy.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Smith Mr W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. It relates to the Minister for Transport and Communications. I refer the Prime Minister to an article which appeared in this morning's Sydney Morning Herald by Tom Burton entitled `PM falls down in first test of Govt integrity'. The article states:

QUESTION.PARA: There were probably a dozen issues which Cabinet considered over the period ranging from deregulation of the radio industry in December 1990 to changing the cross media rules for radio in August 1991. . . which clearly had some impact on the radio station he was duty bound to promote. . . he also had access to key confidential data and Government plans for the radio industry by way of Cabinet submissions

Can the Prime Minister inform the House which Cabinet meetings the Minister attended during this period and what documents and Cabinet submissions pertaining to radio broadcasting the Minister received during the period?

TALK.START.PARA: —It was common knowledge among the Ministry that Senator Richardson was a director of radio station 2HD and he was not present at last year's Cabinet and ERC meetings which decided television and radio licence fees. That is the first point. Secondly, he assures me that while he was a director he did not participate in any other Cabinet discussions that could have affected 2HD. That is the principal point at issue.

PARA.TAB: The other point at issue here is that Senator Richardson did not make a declaration. This charge comes from a party which opposed all declarations in the House of Representatives and has opposed them and succeeded in preventing senators from lodging declarations in the Senate to this day. As a test of the veracity of the Opposition's position on this, I will have the Government reintroduce the regulations into the Senate and we can then see whether the Leader of the Opposition will instruct his Party to vote for those declarations in the Senate—in other words, we will see whether the Opposition will continue to try to hide—

TALK.START.PARA: —You talk about hide; you ran away yesterday.
—Order! The honourable member for Chisholm will cease interjecting.
—and hide behind its numbers in the Senate—

PARA.TAB: Mr Ruddock interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I warn the honourable member for Dundas!

—as the Liberal and National parties sought to hide their interests in here by voting in the House of Representatives against the declaration of MPs' interests. So from the parties which have voted against—
—That is right.
—Order! The honourable member for O'Connor will cease interjecting.
—Well if that is right, do not ask any questions about other people.
—Well, it is and yet you—
—Order! I warn the honourable member for O'Connor!

—My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Is the Minister able to inform the House of any recent initiatives taken by the Government in relation to the future of the dairy industry?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Crean The Hon S.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can indicate that, as a result of deliberations by Cabinet last night and further consultations with the Australian Dairy Industry Council this morning, I have today announced details of a new plan for the dairy industry and legislation will be brought to Parliament shortly. This plan builds on the success of the Kerin plan and, most importantly—

—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. This Minister has now been caught red-handed announcing Government policy by his own words at the commencement of his answer. A question was asked about the dairy industry. Standing order 144(b) says very clearly that he cannot announce Government policy and here he is announcing Government policy and confirming that he is announcing Government policy. He should be asked to resume his seat.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The House will come to order. The Standing Orders allow Ministers to answer questions on their portfolios and on matters of government administration and matters within their purview. The Standing Orders—

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Standing Orders do not allow Ministers to announce policy and the Minister should not announce policy matters.
—Mr Speaker, I should indicate that the policy was announced—

—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. In light of the ruling you have just given, how does that relate to the anticipation of parliamentary debate? There is already a standing order which says that a matter which is about to come before the House cannot be debated. At the opening of his response, the Minister suggested that legislation would come before the House shortly. I put it to you that, if he is not announcing Government policy, he is certainly anticipating debate.

—Order! The right honourable member for New England is drawing the longest possible bow I have ever heard drawn in this place. He knows as well as I do that the Standing Orders about anticipation of debate relate to matters that are before the House. The matter is not before the House—as he well knows if he takes any interest in the dairy industry, which I knows he does—and there is no point of order.
—He has only been here 70 years.
—I thank the House, Mr Speaker. As I say, these proposals were announced before Question Time—
—The Minister for Resources will not interject like that any more.

—and they go to a continuation of the plans for the dairy industry which, as I say, follow up from the Kerin plan. I must say that I am surprised by the members of the National Party trying to stop this information being brought to the House, because they have been the ones who have been calling for us to actually say something about it.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!

—Let me say this, Mr Speaker: the important thing about this announcement is that it reflects the active consultation with the industry. That is the important difference between our approach and the Opposition's in terms of addressing industry development.

PARA.TAB: The details of the announcements go to both assistance and market development. It is proposed that there be a moratorium for a further 12 months on any reduction in market support. That is particularly to assist the situation in Victoria and Tasmania, which have been hard hit. There will be a phase-down in market support to the year 2000 in equal instalments, taking the market support equivalent protection from 22 per cent above export parity to 10 per cent above export parity. I should point out that this 10 per cent above export parity is the equivalent of and is consistent with the tariff target of 5 per cent for manufacturing industry. Importantly, it is a figure that has been achieved with the agreement of the industry. It is not a figure that was advocated by the IC, which the Opposition was locked into. Underwriting has been abolished, but the cheese tariff quota remains. The comfort clause has been abolished and there will be a further review and reorientation of structures to give this industry a more effective market development orientation.

I want to give praise to the industry with whom I have negotiated this package of reforms. The ADIC represents both producers as well as processors and therefore is an important body because it involves more than just the grower end of the market. It had to negotiate this in difficult circumstances. Not only did the ADIC have an IC report which it could not live with—members of the coalition could because they were committed to introducing it—but also it had to cope with the disciplines associated with our position in the GATT and a constituency that was arguing for the retention of the status quo. But against that background, I challenged it to come forward with a forward looking strategy that would secure the industry and make it grow. The ADIC has responded. I sat down with it and we negotiated.

So the outcome does demonstrate what can be achieved through consultation—against the background, perhaps, of an IC report but where the outcome is reached in consultation with the industry. It is the same commitment I have made earlier this week in this House in relation to the sugar industry, and it is one behind which this Government firmly stands. But the point that also needs to be underscored is that this outcome for the industry could not have been achieved by the coalition, because it is locked into Fightback which proposes the elimination of tariffs and the adoption of the IC report. There is no flexibility in the Opposition's position at all, and that is why the National Party, in particular, has found itself in such great difficulties within its own constituency.

We hear a lot of mock concern from the National Party in this House about a constituency which it claims to be concerned about. The other day a press release from the Deputy Leader of the National Party said he was worried about the time that was being taken to settle the dairy industry package because it would not allow time for debate here. The reality is that the real debate takes place with industry, not with you mob in this place, because so far as the industry is concerned—

TALK.START.PARA: —So Parliament does not count?

—No, Parliament does count, but Parliament counts in terms of trying to give effect to good policy based on consultation with industry—something that the Opposition does not understand. Little wonder that in response to that press release the Victorian President of the United Dairyfarmers Association, John Watson, effectively said, `Get on with making a constructive contribution rather than just being negative'. I concur with those comments.

PARA.TAB: Mr Lloyd interjecting—
Mr Tim Fischer interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Deputy Leader of the National Party and his Leader will cease interjecting.

—The reality is that the Nationals will say one thing in the bush and do another thing here, whether it is blind support for the Fightback package, to shore up support for the Leader of the coalition or whether it is the failure to vote by those very strong people who were carrying themselves around the bush promoting the fact that they were going to take their party on. When it came to a vote in the Parliament and the concern that the Leader of the National Party has about the use of the proper forms for these issues to be debated, they would not even turn up. They have raised expectations and they cannot deliver.
—They are gutless.
—Order! The honourable member for the Northern Territory!

—I should also say that I was interested in a comment in today's Australian Financial Review, where the Deputy Leader of the National Party tried to say that there was not really a serious division within the National Party on the question of tariff protection and industry policy. There is this little quote under the by-line of Robert Garran:

PARA.TAB: The deputy leader of the National Party, Mr Lloyd, disputed claims by some National Party sources about the level of opposition to tariff cuts in Monday's party-room debate.
Mr Lloyd denied that the numbers were 10-to-9 in favour of supporting the July 1 cut. He said 8-to-11 was more likely.

ANSWER.PARA: That is a great margin and great leadership. I conclude by simply making this point: there is a stark difference to our approach to sensible industry development for key industries in this country to grow in the future. It is one that involves consultation; it will have regard to the economic rigour, but it will have sensible regard. It will not be driven by the ideological fervour that the Opposition has been locked into—the National Party in particular now reluctantly realising that it has been locked into it. We will take every opportunity to expose that hypocrisy and lack of representation on its part.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister and concerns the Minister for Transport and Communications. Can the Prime Minister assure the House that the Minister for Transport and Communications never received any expenses from radio station 2HD, or its holding company, and that a credit card was never issued to the Minister by radio station 2HD, or its holding company, whilst he was a Minister or a member of parliament?

—I am not aware of what emoluments directors are paid. But if the allegation is that to protect a credit card Senator Richardson would skew public policy, that is an outrageous allegation—an outrageous and petty, spiteful allegation—and not only that: arising from that, not that he does not have a right to sit in the Cabinet, but that he had not declared the interest, and this from the Party which opposes declarations. You have double standards. You are total hypocrites about this.

PARA.TAB: Mr Tim Fisher interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Leader of the National Party will cease interjecting.
—I will have the regulations introduced in the Senate to declare senators' interests. You go and vote for them.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. The Minister will be aware of concerns expressed by the Premiers of Victoria and South Australia regarding the loss of employment in Victoria and South Australia attributed to accelerated tariff reductions announced last year. The Minister will also be aware that the Geelong area has had heavy losses in the TCF area, including those caused by the withdrawal of Pacific Dunlop Ltd to offshore locations. I ask: will the Government consult with the Premiers about these very real concerns in order to seek an answer to the job losses which are now of a very high order?

—Senator Button and I are both aware of the concerns of the Victorian and South Australian Premiers. The Government is already in constant contact with the governments of both Victoria and South Australia on these issues. For example, Mrs Kirner has organised a meeting in Melbourne tomorrow to discuss the future of the textiles, clothing and footwear industries.
—Look at Gerry.
—Gerry knows.
—Order! The honourable member for Higgins and the honourable member for Bruce will cease interjecting.
—I understand that the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce has arranged for the Chief Executive of the Textile, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority to attend that meeting.
—Just look at Gerry.
—I warn the honourable member for Higgins.

—The Government recognised the special needs of these industries in the One Nation statement of 26 February this year. As TCF firms come to terms with increasing competition, the Government is providing targeted adjustment assistance. One Nation announced additional funding of $51m to the Textile, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority to promote industry adjustment. This brings total funding to $130m to 1994-95.

PARA.TAB: The Government's TCF industries development strategy gives a high priority to helping existing firms to restructure. For example, those programs provide support for updating of equipment, work force training, value adding, advice on better management and production techniques, and restructuring.

The honourable member for Corio referred to job losses in Geelong caused by the relocation offshore of some TCF factories. Labour costs in some Asian countries are much lower than they are in Australia. We would not be competitive, in labour terms, whatever level of protection was provided. In the restructuring process it is important that TCF firms focus on areas or sectors in which we can compete—sectors in which fashion, market responsiveness and design, for example, can give us a competitive edge. In Geelong there are future opportunities, for example, for manufacturers of carpet using Australian raw materials and focusing on export as well as on domestic markets.

The Government has always acknowledged that the restructuring of the TCF industries will result in a smaller work force, but the jobs that remain in these restructured industries will be better, in terms of training and skills levels, and more secure. The phase-down in tariff protection announced in March last year will end with tariffs for TCF ranging from 10 to 25 per cent. As I am sure the honourable member for Corio will acknowledge, the Government's tariff regime will allow these industries the opportunity to restructure, unlike the zero tariffs to which the ideologues of the Opposition remain blindly committed.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reith Mr P.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Prime Minister to his admission yesterday that the Minister for Transport and Communications failed to disclose his directorship of radio station 2HD in his Minister's interests statement, and also that the Minister participated in a number of Cabinet decisions impacting on the radio industry while he was such a director. Firstly, I ask the Prime Minister to answer the question from the honourable member for Bass, which he ignored, which was in these terms:

QUESTION.PARA: did the Minister receive any Cabinet decisions, documents or briefing notes pertaining to the radio broadcasting industry from September 1990 to January 1992? Secondly, will the Prime Minister give the Parliament an unqualified assurance that no financial or other gain accrued to Labor radio station 2HD as a consequence of these Cabinet decisions in which Minister Richardson participated?

TALK.START.PARA: —I said before that Senator Richardson assured me he did not participate in any Cabinet discussion which affected 2HD while he was a director. As for Cabinet documentation, as a Minister he is entitled to receive it, particularly when other Ministers have a clear knowledge of his interests and his long term interest in radio station 2HD. In fact, I myself was a chairman of that radio station—the voice of the Hunter, 2HD. We pioneered over twenty-fives and under fifties rock. Senator Richardson has made a great contribution not only to the Hunter but also to Australian radio.
—Indeed. I know.
—The Minister for Land Transport was a colleague at the time. Senator Richardson has had a 15-year or 20-year association with this station.
—You declare it.
—Order!

—The notion that some Cabinet document relevant to the interests of radio in some way is something for which he should be accountable or disqualifies him is a nonsense. Is that to say that all of the members of coalition Cabinets who were farmers should never have seen a document on primary industry? When did a coalition Minister ever declare an interest? When did they ever declare their interests?

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course you never did and it is a nonsense.

—My question is directed to the Treasurer. Can the Treasurer explain to the House what is meant by the term `the black economy'? Has the Government been persuaded that introducing a value added tax on consumption provides the best answer to the problem of the so-called black economy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a question which has received a fair amount of attention as Opposition members go around the country with distorted claims about the benefits of their particular proposals in relation to means of dealing with the so-called black economy. The term `black economy' is usually understood to mean that part of economic activity in a country which is not recorded in the national accounts because it is based on transactions which are concealed from the authorities. The concealment can be because those transactions themselves are illegal, such as the trafficking in illegal drugs, or so as to avoid or evade taxation.

PARA.TAB: When it comes to the question of evasion and avoidance of taxation, we need to go to no-one other than the honourable member for Bennelong in terms of his sorry experience during the period that he was Treasurer. It was during that period that we saw the integrity of the Australian taxation system fall about the place as every month and every week we saw a new scheme devised in order to avoid and evade taxation in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —The bottom of the sandpit scheme, wasn't it?
—Order! The honourable member for MacKellar!
—We had the wet and dry slutzkin schemes, the cherry picker schemes—
—The bottom of the sandpit scheme!
—Order! I warn the honourable member for MacKellar.

—and the bottom of the harbour schemes, if you like. It took some belated action on the part of the honourable member for Bennelong and a consistent attempt by this Government to try to bring back and restore the integrity of the taxation system.

PARA.TAB: It is worth reminding ourselves that, as we endeavoured to improve the integrity of the taxation system, almost every measure was opposed by those opposite. They opposed our early attempts, which were mostly successful, to close off those tax avoidance opportunities; they opposed the introduction of the fringe benefits tax; they opposed the introduction of the capital gains tax; and only very reluctantly and belatedly did they support the introduction of the tax file number system in order to provide for greater integrity in the system.

Now these people, who not only oversaw the damage done to the taxation system but then resisted our attempts to restore its integrity, are now pretending to be the champions of the elimination of the black economy. Indeed, they even claim in their proposals that there will be a net benefit to revenue of some hundreds of millions of dollars. They have squirmed and complained when the Taxation Office has said that that is a fallacious claim and that that amount of money should not be included in the arithmetic—in any event their inaccurate arithmetic—of their particular proposals.

Why is it that the Tax Office and the Treasury have said that this is a fallacious claim? It is because there is a wealth of expert advice to suggest that the GST can do nothing to deal with the alleged problem that the Opposition is trying to deal with. As Professor Head said last year:

ANSWER.PARA: In basic structural terms the GST simply fails to address the black economy issue. The same tax-evading tradesmen who fall outside the income tax net would likewise evade GST.
Similarly, the IMF, which has been a prime advocate of GSTs and VATs in its pronouncements, said this in 1991:
In general terms neither the RST (Retail Sales Tax) nor the VAT can tax the unofficial or black economy.
The Opposition's own documents include a paper from the Victorian Employers Federation which states:
Both systems (a Retail Sales Tax and a Value-Added Tax) miss the cash, underground or black economy. Both the RST and VAT are subject to some tax evasion and avoidance.

What we would actually see as a result of this great money laundering scheme which the Opposition proposes to introduce—this $40 billion switch in relation to revenue—is a massive distraction for the Australian Taxation Office. It would be distracted from its legitimate task of systematically closing off those remaining opportunities which might exist in the tax system. Indeed, in Mrs Thatcher's own experience, during the period when she was introducing a value added tax the black economy—

TALK.START.PARA: —She did not introduce that.
—During the time of her changes to the scheme—

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The House will come to order.
—Are they saying that Mrs Thatcher did not improve the value added tax in Britain?
—You said she introduced it.
—Order! The honourable member will cease interjecting.
—You are a dishonest man.
—Order! If the honourable member for Mayo interjects again, I will deal with him.

—She introduced some extensions to cover the building industry and, as the Prime Minister reminds me, she also increased the rate, which is something you would have in mind if ever you had the chance. During that period, of course, the extent of black economy operations actually increased in Britain.

PARA.TAB: We will not leave the matter there, because even in the Fightback document Opposition members record the international experience of the black economy in a number of economies around the world. In this very revealing document where they try to portray some relationship between the existence of a value added tax and the size of the black economy, we actually find that in the two economies where the black economy is allegedly least or smallest—that is, in Switzerland and the United States—there is no VAT, yet in Belgium, where there is a value added tax, we find the largest black economy.

So even on the basis of the Opposition's own documentation the Victorian Employers Federation says that a GST cannot eliminate the black economy, and in terms of the Opposition's international comparisons, it has not been done. This is just another example of the fallacious and deceptive claims which are being portrayed by the Leader of the Opposition and his ilk as they go around and try to deceive the people of Australia. It is no wonder that there is a perception abroad that not only is this man dull and boring, but also he cannot be believed and cannot be understood. No-one knows what he stands for, because he is essentially on about the deception of the Australian people as he makes claims about his particular tax proposals.
Opposition members—Oh, sit down!

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The House will come to order.

—The way to deal with these questions is the way in which this Government has pursued them—with persistent legislative action and by the persistent activity of the Australian Tax Office, one of the many organisations which the Opposition constantly disparages.

—My question is to the Prime Minister. I refer him to his previous answer to a question about Senator Richardson's telephone call to the President of the Marshall Islands. I remind the Prime Minister that in that answer he suggested that Senator Richardson was operating as a private citizen. I therefore ask the Prime Minister how he sees that statement as consistent with a statement that Senator Richardson himself made on 28 April in a doorstop interview when he said, `Now, just remember this is a person who is a friend of mine for 25 years. I believe I can use my position for any legitimate purpose'.

—Senator Richardson made clear that in his telephone call he was calling as a private citizen and a relative. Seeking what? To be able to recover his relative's documents and passport to prepare documentation back in Australia for his defence. No matters relating to the charges against him, or the defence, were raised by Senator Richardson. That is the assurance he gave Senator Gareth Evans and me—and that, I think, is that.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Resources. It concerns the automotive LPG industry. What is the attitude of the Government to the use of LPG as an alternative fuel for vehicles, and what are the prospects for industry growth?

—Over the last decade the Government has consistently supported the use of LPG as an alternative transport fuel by ensuring that LPG was not subject to product excise. This has meant that LPG has sold for about half the price of petrol and has therefore been an attractive alternative fuel for motorists in this country. As a result of this approach, the industry has grown by 15 per cent a year over the last decade, so that it now accounts for over 4 per cent of vehicle fuel needs.

PARA.TAB: Well over 100,000 Australians use LPG in their vehicles and there are over 1,200 outlets for LPG supply. There are, of course, many hundreds of small businesses prospering by converting vehicles to use LPG. Accordingly, a thriving industry has been created under Labor, using wholly locally produced product and, in the process, replacing the need to import some $130m worth of oil every year.

In addition, of course, it probably goes without saying that there are considerable environmental benefits from the use of LPG, particularly in our major urban centres, as a consequence of reduced emissions of greenhouse gases. This consistent and long term approach, which, I might say, included the very successful deregulation of LPG last year, stands in stark contrast to the Opposition's approach.

I would think that, in terms of the goods and services tax package, the Opposition's policy had not been thought through, because what will pertain in the unlikely event of these policies being implemented is that the relative differential between LPG and petrol will be abolished.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why are you opposed to lower petrol prices?
—Order! The honourable member for Maranoa!

—Accordingly, the advantages of converting to LPG—costing some $2,000 on average—or using LPG will overnight be obliterated. The LPG Users Association of Australia has indicated to me that in its view the industry would last `24 hours' if the GST package were implemented. Just the threat of these policy changes has seen a significant reduction in the use of LPG conversion facilities and, of course, indicates a potential reduction in the use of LPG. So the Opposition has the dubious distinction of actually wiping out jobs by outlining a policy prescription—
—Oh, come on.
—This is a fact; it is not an assertion by me. There has been a dramatic reduction in the number of conversions, and the consequence of that is obvious.
—What about your recession?
—Ask the people involved.
—Order!
—They know.
—Order! The honourable member for Bendigo!

—Those opposite interject. They assert by their interjections implicitly that this proposition I am putting is incorrect. They are not unanimous on this. If the Leader of the Opposition has sufficient regard for the former shadow Minister for trade, and now shadow Minister for the defence of the realm, the honourable member for Mayo, he must have some regard for his judgment. What is the honourable member for Mayo's view about this policy? When asked on radio in Adelaide recently whether the industry would be snuffed out by the GST, the honourable member for Mayo said, `That would be right'. He also said, `Anyone converting to LPG under the Opposition would be "crazy"'. In terms of the problems that would be created, he went on to say, just to top it off—and I must say that I checked the transcript because even I did not believe a shadow Minister would have responded in this way—`We haven't made up our minds how to do it'.

PARA.TAB: In summation, there will be a clear and adverse impact on the LPG industry, particularly the converting component of it. The representative organisations argue that the GST policy will wipe out the industry overnight with the adverse implications, environmental and economic, and also in terms of our trade position. The Opposition has encouraged a policy that is conceded by one of its now senior front bench members to be a `crazy' policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. I refer to the Prime Minister's claim that it was common knowledge that Senator Richardson was a director of 2HD when he participated in broadcasting discussions and decisions of the Cabinet. Was this statement by the Prime Minister not just an expression of personal opinion, or has the Prime Minister been personally assured by all Ministers present at the Cabinet discussions that they knew of Senator Richardson's directorship? Is it not, therefore, the case that unless the Parliament is satisfactorily assured that Senator Richardson either disclosed his interest as a director of the radio station whenever he participated in Cabinet discussions or decisions on broadcasting matters—and not just those relating to licence fees, but all broadcasting matters—or, alternatively, absented himself from those discussions, he must, in accordance with accepted Cabinet practice, resign from the Ministry and in default you ought to remove him?

—The second point is that this is about declarations which you stand opposed to. So the fact is, Mr Speaker—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The House will come to order!

—I won't be sitting down for a debating point.

—Mr Speaker, on a point of order—
—Mr Speaker, the Opposition persists in taking non-procedural points of order—
—The Prime Minister will resume his seat. The Leader of the National Party on a point of order.

If the Leader of the National Party is asking me to take action against anyone who asks me to do something in the chamber, I think that the first person on my list would be the Leader of the National Party who is asking me to ask Ministers to sit down and stand up and truncate answers, et cetera.
—That lot on the other side of the House are unbelievable. They are up every five minutes on these points. They require the Speaker to do things all the time.
—Order!

—I was here 23 years ago when Jack McEwen used to have the big boots on. I know all about the Opposition, so its members should not tell me about the practice of the House of Representatives, or Question Time, or the conventions, or the protocols. I know them back to front because I have seen the Opposition with the boot on the other foot for so long.

PARA.TAB: The fact is that the Liberal Party of New South Wales has used the public purse to procure a seat in Parliament. If the honourable member for Bennelong, at his unctuous best, wishes to give any advice about impropriety, I invite him to give Nick Greiner a phone call this afternoon and pull him into line.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Bruce!

—My question is directed to the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services. I ask: in the light of comments that the Minister has made recently on this issue, can the Minister tell the House whether, in fact, he supports the privatisation of public hospitals? Could he explain what the consequences of the privatisation of public hospitals might be?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: DEPUTY PRIME MINISTER; HEALTH, HOUSING AND COMMUNITY SERVICES

TALK.START.PARA: —With respect to that question, it would seem that the New South Wales Government, in particular, is very anxious to include public hospitals within its privatisation program. The people of Port Macquarie are the first to experience the threat that that involves. However, this is not an isolated example.
—Any integrity left?
—Order! The honourable member for Lowe will cease interjecting.

—Other examples that propose similar action include Maitland, Albury, Coffs Harbour and other country communities. The New South Wales Government's version of privatisation is not based on not for profit organisations and their takeover control of public hospitals; rather it involves the control or handing over of control to private groups accountable to investors and not to patients. Any attempt to privatise a public hospital should be assessed on the basis of three essential principles: firstly, that Australians are provided with the highest quality of health services—
—They are not getting it now.
—Secondly, that those services are provided as efficiently and effectively as possible—
—You cannot call them efficient!
—Order! If the honourable member for Lowe interjects again, I will name him.

—Thirdly, that there is quality of access to health services. The honourable member for Lowe would have a particular interest because, as those with a political memory around this House will recall, prior to the last election the then Health Minister of New South Wales, Mr Collins, visited Port Macquarie and promised a public hospital at a cost of an estimated $80m. Subsequently, he was replaced by a different Minister and that Minister has effectively replaced that commitment from an $80m public hospital to a private hospital.

PARA.TAB: The honourable member for Lowe, in terms of his electorate, is currently campaigning for, and circulating a petition to construct, a high technology public hospital in an area which is already heavily overburdened. The implication is quite clearly that the honourable member for Lowe has in mind that, if there should be such a hospital, it would involve private capital for profit and the closure of public beds in that electorate. In terms of what we are speaking about, the honourable member for Lowe has a very keen interest.

It is very doubtful that transferring public hospitals to the private sector involves any benefit in relation to the principles that I have referred to. What is obvious is that private operators base decisions on the profit motive and there is no control over service quality or the necessity of treatment. The bottom line of profits is hardly the basis on which health decisions should be made. Experience elsewhere shows that high-tech specialist services in these circumstances flourish at the expense of services such as maternity and casualty, which are far less profitable.

Public access can be assured only by giving private proprietors very generous deals. The New South Wales Government deal in Port Macquarie is a testament to this. Although New South Wales will not release full details of the deal, it is clear that it will cost taxpayers at least 10 per cent more than any other public hospital service in New South Wales. I remind honourable members that the cost of a public hospital bed in New South Wales is substantially higher than that in any other State. These beds, subsidised effectively by the public sector, will turn out to be the most expensive beds in Australia.

One ought not to have any illusions about the course of privatisation. It is essentially about the subsidisation of private profits. It means less accountability in terms of public money. It means a poorer quality service. It means, for those who are sick or potentially ill, insecurity where currently there is security.

I thank the honourable member for Phillip for her question. I understand the concern, particularly in rural areas in New South Wales, and I indicate in terms of this Government's approach that we certainly will not be subsidising private profits in terms of health services. We are about client services and accountability. The honourable member for Lowe says that I am obsessed with costs. What he is concerned about is pork-barrelling in his own electorate where, ultimately, taxpayers would pay for private services.

—Mr Speaker, my question to you relates to the length of answers given by Ministers at Question Time. You will be aware that during the period of the Fraser Government the average number of questions asked per day exceeded 16 and the average length of answers given was approximately three minutes. Up to 6 March in the calendar year 1992 approximately 10.5 questions have been asked and answered each day and Ministers are taking approximately 5.4 minutes on average to answer those questions.

PARA.TAB: On 31 March I asked you, Mr Speaker, in response to your repeated assertion that you do not have the power under the Standing Orders to require Ministers to limit the length of their answers to questions, whether Mr A.R. Browning, when Clerk of the House, advised you that the Speaker has unlimited power if the Standing Orders and the practices of the House as to the power of the Speaker at Question Time were silent. On that occasion you undertook to look at whether Mr Browning did advise you along those lines. I wonder whether you are now in a position to give advice to the House in regard to that matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not aware that I did get any advice such as that from Mr Browning. But I must say that I do not think the honourable member for Hume would suggest that it would be a sensible precedent for the Speaker to start opening his files of correspondence from members or from officials. I might say to the honourable member for Hume that in the House the Clerks can offer advice, but the House is the final arbiter of these things.

PARA.TAB: On two occasions in recent years honourable members have put forward propositions that we should limit the time of answers. The honourable member for Dawson did, as did the former honourable member for Oxley, Mr Hayden. On both occasions, under separate governments, the House did not debate or deal with those two propositions. I also recall that there is a report from the Standing Committee on Procedure, which also suggests a mechanism for Question Time which has also not been dealt with by the House. The only advice the Speaker can draw from the opinions of the House is that it does not wish to have those limitations.

Both I and my predecessors have frequently said—it does not matter how often the honourable member for Hume gets up to try to coerce me differently—that, unless the House makes some other determination, the Speaker is not really in a position to be able to put time limits on Ministers' answers. Often some Ministers give answers that are too long, in the view of some people; other people may find some considerable interest in those answers. The honourable member for Hume can raise this point frequently—I am sure he will.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will.

—The honourable member for Hume may even wish to put a proposition before the House and test it with the House. If he does that, I will be happy to abide by whatever decision the House makes. As the honourable member for Hume knows—and my predecessors from both sides have had the experience of dealing with it—he is really suggesting to me that I should advise him and the House how long a piece of string is. I do not think he knows the answer to that, either.
