DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Major National Research Facilities: A National Program

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Free The Hon R.V.

TALKER.NAME: Mr FREE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Technology)

TALK.START.PARA: —For the information of honourable members, I present a report by the Australian Science and Technology Council entitled Major National Research Facilities: A National Program. I seek leave to make a ministerial statement relating to the report.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —A significant component of any nation's science and technology base is its system of major national research facilities. Australia currently has six such research facilities, including the Australian Telescope, the Oceanographic Research Vessel Franklin, and the Australian Animal Health Laboratory.

PARA.TAB: Major advances in science and technology increasingly depend on research workers having access to the type of complex and expensive equipment contained in these facilities. However, their high cost in terms of both establishment and maintenance is often beyond the resources of individual institutions. In response to a request from the then Prime Minister, ASTEC investigated this issue and produced what is a very important report. Major National Research Facilities: A National Program recommends that a program of major national research facilities be established. This would provide for the consideration of new major research facilities proposals, phasing-out of facilities that no longer satisfy national needs and priorities, and access to major research facilities overseas where such access is an appropriate alternative to the creation of an Australia-based facility.

As part of its report, ASTEC established assessment criteria to enable proposals for funding to be judged in terms of their benefits to science and technology and to the nation. Using the Council's criteria, the report lists some 15 likely candidates for major facilities over the next five to 10 years. Among these proposed facilities is an upgrade of the Australia Telescope, a new marine geoscience research vessel, a mining materials research facility and a tropical marine research network. The ASTEC report notes that a further process of rigorous evaluation will be necessary before any decision can be made to proceed with any of these. I must emphasise this point. Any hasty decisions on new facilities would be inimical to the spirit of the report.

In particular, honourable members will note that one of the facilities recommended for further investigation is a new hi-flux research reactor to replace the existing reactor at Lucas Heights. No decision will be taken on the establishment of such a facility without an inquiry process consistent with the decision of last year's ALP National Conference.

Major National Research Facilities: A National Program is in many ways a landmark report. It recognises that major national research facilities are too important for decisions to be made on an ad hoc basis. It recognises that Australia's future need for national research facilities must be planned as an integral part of our national research and technology priority setting process. ASTEC has produced a valuable report which will enable us to establish procedures for assessing the relative benefits to Australia of proposals for major national research facilities. I urge all honourable members to give consideration to the report, and I present the following papers:

SPEECH.PARA: Major National Research Facilities: A National Program—Report and Ministerial Statement, 30 April 1992.

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Mr Beazley) proposed:
That the House take note of the papers.
Debate (on motion by Mr Fife) adjourned.

Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Ronald Edwards)—Mr Speaker has received a letter from the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:
The Government's failure to save jobs by delivering genuine cost-cutting reform and effective resource security.

PROCTEXT.PARA: I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

TAB.EMPHASIS: More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hewson Dr J.R.

TALKER.NAME: Dr HEWSON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition raises this matter today out of very genuine concern about the fact that almost through the entire period since our Prime Minister (Mr Keating) assumed that office he has run one diversionary tactic after another in order to divert attention from the very real pain and hardship that are being suffered and will continue to be suffered under his policies as a result of the recession that he inflicted on this country and his inability to develop an effective policy response to what is the deepest recession in Australia in 60 years. This has particularly come to light in recent days as major government decisions go by and opportunities are lost, as in relation to resource security, to actually get genuine development in the form of a pulp mill in northern Tasmania; or, as was in the news today, the major closures of three plants by the Edgell-Birds Eye group, which is going to result in the loss of hundreds of jobs, both full and part time jobs, again, as we see from the announcements of that company, due to the failure of his Government to put in place the appropriate policies.

PARA.TAB: One of the things that flabbergast most Australians, the one thing that they probably find harder to understand at the present time than almost anything else, is why Australia imports food when it is wealthy in terms of its agricultural capabilities and its range of agricultural products. That is the most amazing thing to most Australians when they go to the shelves in the shops and stores. It is not just in the canned goods area but right across the board. More recently we have seen it in terms of items as basic as tomatoes. They cannot understand why these items are dumped into this country to the detriment of our industry. It is a tragedy in particular, I believe, because if we had to pick an industry which really has enormous potential in Australia and can really get up and go and contribute hundreds and thousands of jobs and billions of dollars of exports and so on, it is the food processing industry. The average Australian has considerable trouble not only understanding why the Prime Minister runs around belting the Brits, manhandling the Queen, attacking the flag, distorting our history and so on, but also understanding why he cannot put in place a basic set of policies which would allow us to become a major exporter in processed food, as we should, of course, in view of the capability that is there.

It is most instructive, if we look, for example, at the work of the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce and its estimate that the processed food deficit could reach as high as $2 billion through the period to the year 2002 under the sorts of policies that this Government is following. There could be further significant losses in investment as businesses are moved offshore and markets are lost offshore and we could end up with a $2 billion deficit by the year 2002 under the sorts of policies that this Government is pursuing. Yet, if we were to put our house in order, if we were to make the policy changes that are identified in Fightback, we could see that industry boom and we could have a $4.5 billion surplus in processed food by the year 2002.

So the choice is, under this Government, a deficit, on its numbers, of about $2 billion, or a surplus of approximately $4.5 billion if we take the potential that is there just in the Asia-Pacific region to develop an effective food processing industry. It is interesting to note that the growth rate of processed food consumption in Asia has averaged 22.2 per cent in nominal terms and 18 per cent in real terms. There has been an 18 per cent growth in real terms in the consumption of food in Asia in the last four years. On that basis, the market for Australia—which is presently $20 billion—could go to $150 billion in the period to the year 2002. That is a 700- or 800-percentage point increase in the size of that market, if the right policies are put in place.

Australian exports of highly processed foods grew at only 7 1/2 per cent in nominal terms over the past decade, compared with over 13 per cent growth in manufactured exports across the board. If between now and the year 2002 we could achieve that 18 per cent growth that we have seen in the Asian area in recent years—if we could just match the growth in demand—an industry that under this Government's policies will go into deficit by $2 billion could contribute a $2 1/2 billion surplus as a result of its development. That is the tragedy surrounding the people at Edgell in Cowra and the other places where those plants are closing. They cannot understand how their plant has to shrink in an industry with phenomenal potential. The answer is very simple: this Government cannot deliver—it will not even contemplate delivering—the reforms that are necessary to give that industry a fair chance.

I thought some of the material that was released by Pacific Dunlop, which is responsible for the Edgell group, was particularly instructive. The Boston Consulting Group, which has done a careful study of the competitive problems of the Australian food processing industry, has presented some pretty alarming details of just how uncompetitive that industry, with all its potential, has become under this Government's policies.

Let us look, for example, at the cost of raw materials—that is, the price into the factory—in the food processing industry. For potatoes, costs in Australia are 100 per cent higher than those in the United States. For tomatoes and green peas, our costs are 65 per cent higher than those in New Zealand. For sweet corn, they are 50 per cent higher than those in the United States and New Zealand. That is just on the input costs. We can see the tremendous advantage of a goods and services tax in its being able to reduce the input costs of a major industry such as the food processing industry.

A number of other major cost disadvantages in Australia have been identified at the manufacturing stage of the food processing industry: obsolete technology, inadequate product development, plant commonly operating at only 30 per cent of capacity, a poor industrial record, outdated work practices, and shift penalties that make more than one or two shifts totally uneconomic. This study provides some very detailed information on some of those disadvantages, such as the cost of Saturday and Sunday work. The loadings paid for additional work in Australia are unbelievable compared with the loadings that are paid in the same industry in other parts of the world. We can see the tremendous benefits of our labour market reform policy for genuine enterprise bargaining to eliminate those labour market cost disadvantages.

Packaging is another element of cost. In the food processing industry in Australia, a can costs 40 per cent more than it does in Europe. In Australia, board costs—that is, packaging, or cardboard, costs—are 44 per cent higher than they are in the United States. There are massive cost disadvantages as we package the product and try to get it out to market. Then we have domestic transportation costs. For example, grain transport costs in Australia—that is, internal transport costs—are double those in the United States and the United Kingdom for the same distance. We can see the tremendous cost advantages that would flow to domestic transport and the food processing industry from the abolition of petrol tax under the Fightback package.

To take our goods offshore, international freight costs are involved. In the food processing industry, for example, shipping costs to Tokyo from Sydney are 22 per cent higher than those over a comparable distance to Tokyo from the United States. From Tasmania they are 68 per cent higher. Why? It is because we have this process of cabotage on the waterfront. We have to put the goods on an overmanned, cost-inefficient domestic ship to bring them from Tasmania to Sydney and then transfer them to an international ship. We are paying away all the cost advantages that we ought to have in an industry such as the food processing industry in Australia.

If we look at ship turnaround times in Australian ports, it takes three times as long to turn a ship around than it does in Osaka, as an example in relation to the food processing industry. Container dwell times—that is, the time a container sits on the waterfront—are 20 times longer in Melbourne than in Singapore. The Government talks about waterfront reform. In comparison, look at the advantages that would flow out of the Fightback package for shipping and waterfront reform in terms of baseline cost advantages to this particular industry.

The study also looks at government regulations, and the cost impacts of those, which are identified. It also looks at other things such as the differences in health standards and inefficient anti-dumping procedures, all of which are very important. But the bottom line conclusion is also very important:

SPEECH.PARA: Tariffs on imported goods are not the solution. They will not help overcome the competitive problems identified here.

Here is an industry that has enormous potential. The food processing industry is an industry that a lot of people have focused on as having phenomenal potential. All those elements of cost are the result of either failed government policies, government taxes and charges or government intervention in this country that is stopping that industry from reaching its potential.

PARA.TAB: The people who have just lost their jobs up in Cowra and other parts of Australia as those plants have been closed down have absolutely no idea why the Prime Minister wanders all over the place denigrating their flag instead of looking after their jobs and dealing with those basic cost disadvantages.
Opposition members—Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —It was most instructive when one of the Asian leaders, Lee Kuan Yew from Singapore—someone who has no visible hang-ups, unlike our Prime Minister when he travels internationally, and who is very sure of his position and his country's position in the world—visited Australia in March last year. He did an interview with the Australian newspaper and the article on this interview states:

SPEECH.PARA: But he believes there are certain industries where Australia has a natural advantage because of access to raw materials which would be viable if our industries became competitive.
He gives one particular example:

PARA.TAB: `Your food processing industries are another area of comparative advantage. If you want to go in for it in a big way, you should not just export frozen meat, but processed foodstuffs like TV dinners and lunches ready for the microwave, and made to Asian tastes.

SPEECH.PARA: Outside leaders can come and spend a few hours in Australia and readily identify—knowing their own experience internationally—the tremendous potential that exists for our food processing industry in their area. As Lee Kuan Yew is wont to do, he goes on and boasts:

PARA.TAB: `All these things are possible . . . Of all places, Singapore is doing this. Our companies prepare Chinese, Malay and Indian cuisine either canned or frozen.

SPEECH.PARA: They are hitting the market. They are filling the gap that we have lost but for which we have got all the potential. If one goes to Singapore, which is only about 20 miles long, one sees that there is not a lot of agricultural product there and that one would be struggling to find much that one could turn into a food processing industry as a base. Here we are, with the natural advantage of agriculture, the tremendous need in this nation to develop value adding activities so that we can actually start to pay our way in the world, reduce our international debt and create the million jobs that have been lost under this Government—and Singapore is taking our market away from us without any of those natural advantages.

PARA.TAB: Why is that? It is because Singapore goes out and deals with the problem. If it has a major problem in shipping costs, it builds not just a port but the most cost-effective port in the world. That is really what Fightback offers the Australian people. It offers in each of the areas that are identified in this document from Boston Consulting, and a range of others, a genuine basis on which an Australian industry such as food processing can become genuinely internationally competitive. There is no other way.

One hears all this nonsense that we have heard in recent days about the tariff debate and how we have to have tariffs to grow up, to make the grade and all that sort of thing. I was also interested in another comment of Lee Kuan Yew:

"There is no other choice. It is the only way forward. The idea that Australians can hide behind a protective barrier, build up industrial muscle and compete against the world is an illusion", he says,
"You will build up muscle when you have to compete, not when you are training to compete.

SPEECH.PARA: Others understand the issue and they have a way of jamming it down our throats that I personally find offensive when they come to Australia. But these guys over here are not worried; they are interested only in one job—the Prime Minister's job. They will do anything, say anything, misrepresent anything and undermine anything to keep that job. They will run one diversion after another—including attacking our flag—rather than putting into place policies that would give the food processing industry, and a host of others right across the board, the real chance to reach its full potential and to create the one million jobs that have been lost under this Government's unbelievably irresponsible approach to policy and to the Australian nation. The Prime Minister claims to be a nationalist. He claims to be an internationalist. He knows our place in the world. He has not even begun to understand. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Griffiths The Hon A.G.

TALKER.NAME: Mr GRIFFITHS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Tourism and Minister for Resources)

TALK.START.PARA: —The contribution of the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) was what we have come to expect in that, by the sin of omission, he commits the sin of potentially misleading people. I will take just one example. We are talking about reducing the cost on food inputs. There is not an economist in this country who argues other than that the Fightback package, the GST, will contribute to our inflation outcome. Those opposite should stay there for a moment, because we should have a bit of a discussion about resource security legislation. The Leader of the Opposition is turning his back, like the coward he is, on this issue.
—Make him withdraw.
—Order!

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I withdraw, Mr Deputy Speaker. Let me give one indication of the cost on food inputs. Every one percentage change in the inflation rate costs each farmer approximately $1,200. Across agriculture as a whole—and we are, after all, talking about the food sector—one percentage increase in inflation costs that sector $200m. Surely that was a germane issue to put before the House in terms of the Leader of the Opposition's contribution? As I say, the sin of omission has the potential, if not the actual impact, of misleading people. But we would not want that, would we?

PARA.TAB: It is accepted that the total impact of the GST on our international competitiveness will add in the order of 5 per cent to our inflation rate. We should remember that one percentage increase in inflation costs each farmer $1,200. When we multiply that by five, the result is $6,000 per farmer. For the total agricultural sector, if we multiply $200m by five, we are talking about big bickies. What has that got to do with competitiveness?

The Leader of the Opposition talked about the waterfront. I will not go into great detail on the waterfront as I have addressed that issue here on other occasions. Let me give one example: in a press statement issued on 4 November the Australian Wheat Board described the improvements evidenced on the waterfront in this country as `spectacular'. Surely that is an organisation which can be accepted by members of this chamber as an independent arbiter or umpire, or as a commentator which does not have the tag of partisan political comment attached to its observations. The Australian Wheat Board was referring to turnaround times, and that is what the Leader of the Opposition adverted to in his comments. In quoting them as `spectacular', the Australian Wheat Board noted that since 1988-89 the time taken to turn grain vessels around at Australian ports had dropped from an average of 4.52 days to 2.4 days—almost a 50 per cent reduction. Importantly, that represents some $10m of savings.

I could go on and make further comments about that, but I will make just one observation. In terms of the Opposition policy for the waterfront, again the Opposition is on public record as indicating that it would call in the Army to resolve industrial relations disputes on the waterfront. For goodness sake! In the 1990s we are talking in this country about a fixed bayonet approach to industrial relations. That is going to get those opposite a long way indeed. Then of course the shadow Minister for industrial relations, the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) talked about a `big bang' theory of industrial relations. Before the next election people in Australia will have the opportunity of reflecting upon precisely what that terminology implies.

What it implies of course is that the award protection system in this country will overnight be abolished. The theory is quite clear: strip away from everyone—the workers in this building, in factories, in the Public Service, in the shops, on the waterfront, in the aviation sector, in the hospitality industry—the legal award coverage that they have had in this country, in effect, since Federation. It is then `catch as catch can'.

What is being proposed by the Opposition under the heading of industrial relations reform is to so turn around the power relationships between employees and employers as to effectively strip away any protection that employees have. A week or so ago I was in New Zealand, perchance on the same day as the Leader of the Opposition visited New Zealand. The situation in New Zealand is instructive I think for anyone in this country. I spoke to a young man who I happened to pick up, believe it or not, hitchhiking. I asked him what industry he worked in, he told me, I asked him how long he had worked in it, he said, `About six months'. I asked, `Are you covered by a trade union?'. He said, `No. It is a bit risky. I would be sacked on the spot'. I said, `What terms and conditions of employment do you enjoy?'. He said, `I am not sure. I signed a piece of paper. I am not sure what was on it'.

When I tested him on this, he indicated to me the totally illogical position, from his view, of not signing the document, because in the absence of that no job would be offered. He had no protection. But the interesting thing about him was that he said he would stay in that employment for only as long as it took to find better alternative employment. That indicates the sort of approach that we are going to have from the Opposition. It is not the approach from the Government. It never will be because, in this Government's approach, we have something that is very important, that is, respect for employees. We do not take what Doug Anthony, a former National Party Leader, has described as a very pig-headed—he does not use the term `pig-headed', but he talked about—

TALK.START.PARA: —He is a former member of the honourable member's own Party. The import of his article in the Australian on 27 April is that there is a great difference between stubbornness and leadership. There is no future for a political party that shows an incapacity to be flexible in its policy positions.
—He tells the truth, you mean?

—I am observing his comments about your side of Parliament, you fool. The honourable member's interjection, quite frankly, ought to be restrained to the extent that he is not supposed to give me an advantage in the debate. The comments I am referring to are by a former National Party Leader; they are talking about the Party of the honourable member—

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Ronald Edwards)—The Minister should withdraw his comment about the honourable member for Moore.

TALK.START.PARA: —I withdraw.
—And the honourable member for Moore should not interject.

—I thank the honourable member for Moore for his interjection. In relation to the other matter that was raised by the Leader of the Opposition, that is, the resource security legislation, this is not an academic matter. We are not here talking about the possibility of there being some sort of significant reform for an industry and consequent employment opportunities arising out of that; we are talking about a policy jurisdiction where Australia suffers the disadvantage of some 10 per cent of our trade deficit being in timber and paper products.

PARA.TAB: This is a difficult policy jurisdiction, in large measure because the Federal Government's constitutional writ does not necessarily run that far. But the Federal Government, by the process of exhaustive consultation with the States, with industry, with unions, within the Government itself and more latterly—I might say unsuccessfully—with the Opposition, has sought not to embrace the particular views put by any particular lobby or interest group but to strike an appropriate balance in the public interest. So the Government has developed legislation to address the issue of forest conservation and development. In so doing, it has committed itself to that important part of our economy. It has committed itself to ensuring that investment takes place and that jobs are created.

What do we have here from the Leader of the Opposition, who waxed lyrical about the need for reform, the need for job creation, the need to provide opportunities to Australians to be world competitive? What is the man who only a few weeks ago said, `I am yet to get up to speed on this issue', that is, the Leader of the National Party (Mr Tim Fischer), who only a few short weeks ago did not understand the issues, doing? He is being very firm; he has indicated that in the Senate his National Party and Liberal Party colleagues will block the legislation proposed by the Government.

At the end of the day, in a democracy—and I think it was Churchill who said, `A democracy is the worst system in the world except all the others'—people are, of course, entitled to their view. The difference in this issue is that a large part of the Opposition Caucus believes that this legislation should be passed, and at this point there are no substantive differences between the Government and the Opposition. There are differences—of course there are differences—and there is nothing unusual in that in this chamber, in the other place, or in relation to a whole spectrum of policy issues.

What is the difference between the Government and the Opposition in relation to this matter? Essentially, the Opposition requires a change in the name and not the content of the Bill; that is, it requires a change from Forest Conservation and Development Bill to Forest Conservation and Major Projects Bill. As Shakespeare would have it:

SPEECH.PARA: What's in a name? that which we call a rose
By any other name would smell as sweet.

It seems to me to be an extraordinary position that we have now reached, where the Opposition will apparently vote against this legislation in the Senate as a response to the Government not being prepared at this point to change the title of the Bill.

PARA.TAB: It would be a sin of omission on my part were I not also to say that there are differences in terms of the Opposition's desire to see the Government embrace, in a written instrument to itself, undertakings relating to the ongoing monitoring of the legislation and, in the event of the legislation being found wanting, indicating a preparedness to review within a reasonable time frame any shortcomings in the legislation. As a mirror image of that policy position, I might say the same thing in relation to enhanced inter-governmental agreement processes.
I am quite happy to indicate in this chamber, on the record, that any legislation for which I have responsibility either as Minister for Resources or, for that matter, as Minister

SPEECH.PARA: for Tourism would, in the normal course of events, be subject to such ongoing monitoring and review. There is no legislation for which I have responsibility that I would not review in the event of shortcomings being established. So if we have now a position—

TALK.START.PARA: —Just do it, then.
—I have just given an undertaking in the national Parliament.
—Order! The honourable member for Mitchell!

—So presumably that strips away the Opposition's requirement to have, by way of correspondence, the identical undertaking. The undertaking is there, as I indicated to the Opposition in our discussions—they were not negotiations. I might say that some licence has been taken with the content of those discussions but, in any event, as I have indicated here, that ongoing monitoring and review process is the norm as far as I am concerned.

PARA.TAB: For example, in relation to petroleum resource rent tax legislation that I brought in a year or so ago, I have currently on my desk a number of possible amendments which will be considered on their merits. So the review, the monitoring process, is normal and to be expected, and I am happy to give an undertaking in relation to that. That leaves the Opposition with one issue: the title of the legislation. Changing the title of the legislation will make no difference, of course, to the content of the legislation. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALKER.NAME: Mr LLOYD
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Resources (Mr Griffiths) made much of what he claimed were the improvements in productivity on the waterfront, and he quoted the Wheat Board. What he did not say was that there have been reductions in the manning levels on the waterfront for the loading of wheat, but all those people, who were not made redundant as they should have been so that there could have been some reduction in cost in total on the waterfront, were moved over to the general labour pool on the waterfront and have just added to the costs of everybody else on the waterfront. Today we have the situation on the waterfront where there is more surplus labour than ever before and no reductions in costs in general.

PARA.TAB: The Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) spelt out the situation very clearly on this matter of public importance:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's failure to save jobs by delivering genuine cost-cutting reform and effective resource security.

He quoted from Boston Consulting and even from the Government's own DITAC in relation to Australia's inability to capitalise on the tremendous opportunities for us with processed food and value adding, particularly in the Asian area, if we can only get our act together. He cited all of the problems we face, and I will cite a couple more because my electorate has 16 major food processing factories. With our goods and services tax, contrary to what the Minister has said, every farmer who supplies those food processing factories will on average be $8,000 a year better off in savings because of the abolition of payroll tax, fuel tax and sales tax. Also, the Minister might have learned when he was in New Zealand that another plus of the GST is that it will remove an export tax. That is helping New Zealand farmers and exporters generally against ours. This export tax adds close to $2 billion at the present time. When talking to some of the processing people recently, it was interesting to learn that the abolition of payroll tax alone will save them many millions of dollars.

PARA.TAB: The case of SPC, with its 30 per cent productivity lift, which is only half of what it could have achieved had it been allowed to do what it wanted to do but was restricted by this Government from doing, shows what can be done. But SPC is one of the very few food processing factories in Australia that works on weekends. For most of them the added costs of those shifts would mean that they would lose money. If a product goes into a cannery, or whatever factory it is, at an equal price in Victoria, or in Australia, it comes out between 20 and 40 per cent more expensive because of those points made by the Leader of the Opposition.

What about abattoirs? It is 2 1/2 times more expensive to process a steer in most parts of Australia than in the United States—and three times more expensive in Victoria, if one can actually find somebody to process it. It is interesting that an Australian meat tripartite overseas mission recently reported back—and this was the Government's own mission, full of good unionists and public servants—that in the three countries it went to, the United States, Germany and Denmark, every abattoir it visited had an enterprise agreement. There were no strikes. Every one had double shifts—there are only four abattoirs in Australia which have double shifts—and they all had higher production.

Finally, there is the Edgell situation with tomatoes. The Leader of the Opposition made the point that, according to Edgell's own statement, the closing down of Cowra and Bairnsdale had nothing to do with tariffs but a lot to do with those higher costs and lousy dumping and countervailing policies against unfair, subsidised imports. That tomato case took two years, and in that time up to 40 per cent of the market was lost. It took four months from the application to a provisional duty—we will do it in under half that time—and almost five months for final duty. That is the sort of area where we have positive policies to assist.

The resource security legislation has had a painful birth and will have a painful death unless the Government honours its agreement. I give the Minister credit because I believe he is genuine and decent with regard to resource security—

TALK.START.PARA: —But he got rolled.
—He has been terribly frustrated, and he has been rolled by the Left. If one likes, he has been left by the Left. For example the Canberra Times on 2 March 1991 said:

SPEECH.PARA: Kelly scorns resource legislation.
The Australian today said:
Resource security deal killed by Kelly.

There is a certain similarity, is there not? The Left, as a short term political tactic, for preferences and for deals, will do anything to prevent genuine resource security and the genuine creation of jobs in this country. At Question Time today the subject of phone bills came up. I bet there will be a good bill between Kuala Lumpur and Parliament House for the last few days as the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories (Mrs Kelly) has been phoning in and marshalling all the lefties to make sure that the agreement that was reached between the industry, the Government and the Opposition could not be fulfilled—

TALK.START.PARA: —It was torpedoed.

—It was torpedoed, and without it there is no legislation. Even if the Government's legislation had passed, we have consistently said that it really would not achieve what it was out to achieve because of the influence of the Left. It is a `no win' Bill. It does not provide major project legislation, on the one hand, for pulp mills, et cetera, and it is not a broad Bill with genuine resource security to pick up those 1,200 sawmills around Australia with all of the smaller investments that they want to make. If one likes, it could be said that it is a mule of a Bill. We all know what a mule is: it is stubborn and it will not work.

PARA.TAB: We can work through all of the debate that has gone on for some months on this very important legislation. There is $5 billion to $7 billion of investment at stake and thousands of jobs in regional Australia with the saw mills and where the pulp mills will be. There is, as the Minister said, 10 per cent of the trade deficit with regard to the wood and paper products that now come in.

The Government could not do one thing or the other, so what happened? I give credit to NAFI and to Dr Bain, who—even though it meant they would not achieve the legislation that all of their timber mill members wanted—agreed to a proposal which basically turned the Bill into a major projects Bill. That is what that heading was for. In the legislation, 10.1 becomes project specific—that is, a particular project is named by the Minister. So we were really prepared to turn what should have been a Bill for all forestry industry in Australia into a project specific Bill by that application. That would have meant that the industry would not have got what it deserved to get, but it had faith.

The Minister did not mention this, but I think it was an oversight: the other point was, of course, the fact that there were to be discussions and negotiations through the national forest strategy to get something to provide, on a regional or industry basis around Australia, genuine resource security for all the others in the industry in Australia. That, certainly, is what we will do in government. We will provide genuine resource security so that there is this investment and so that there are these jobs.

The Minister knows, I know and the industry knows that there was an agreement and that it had four elements. The Minister mentioned three of them and I picked up the other one. I say to the Minister that we were prepared, in spite of our reservations about the weaknesses of the Bill, to go along with it in the Senate so that any major projects—whether in northern Tasmania, Victoria or Western Australia—could get under way.

In the dying stages of the debate in the Senate, we still say that all the Government has to do is honour the agreement that the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories sabotaged from Kuala Lumpur through the means of the Prime Minister because of the deal that was made to get him elected as leader, and to hell with what it has meant to the jobs and investment around Australia and the efforts of this Minister. If the Government honours that agreement, that legislation will be passed. If the Government cannot get the Act right in the food processing industry, we can at least start to make progress with the forestry industry in this country.

PARA.TAB: Right at this moment, I understand that our legislation on the resource security is being debated in the Senate. It will probably fail because ultimately the Opposition does not wish it to succeed. There have been genuine and lengthy negotiations on both sides to ensure the success of this legislation. We know the conflict over forest resources has been a debilitating debate. I guess it has been a debilitating debate because over the last 10 years there has been a shift in community attitude over the question of conservation and the use of our forests.

Regrettably, the forest industry itself has really given up the fight on intelligent investment in this country. It has asked the Government to legislate for what we call resource security. The Government was always reluctant to take that legislative course. But we went down that track hoping that a decent Opposition would support the legislation to ensure that there would be a pulp mill in northern Tasmania, and perhaps in Maryvale in Victoria, and that the rest of the industry would invest in value adding ventures. We arrived at that sort of decent legislation. It is a legislation that I want to run over again to ensure that we are—

TALK.START.PARA: —I will interrupt the Parliamentary Secretary, as I am about to leave the chair. There was a matter raised involving the honourable member for Ballarat who left the chamber. I think, in fairness to the honourable member for Ballarat, I should ask that he consult with me outside the chamber as to whether or not the remarks were made. —I appreciate that course of action. People appreciate that the legislation that we were putting forward was our attempt—and a very decent attempt—to strike a balance over this divisive debate, otherwise the debate over the use of our forests would never end. In the next couple of hours it looks as though we are going to be back in that camp, back into the old fights that we have been having for the last decade.

PARA.TAB: Our legislation sought to manage this conflict between the States rights over land use and the Commonwealth's legislative control over exports, the environment and national estate issues, Aboriginal matters and World Heritage matters. In the interests of good government, we have tried to put the issue above politics, but we may well have failed to do that.

Our legislation would ensure the development of a pulp mill in northern Tasmania as the first of many potential projects identified by the forest industries themselves. If the Opposition and the Democrats work together in the Senate today to defeat our legislation, in effect, they will be voting against balanced development in this country and, in the Opposition's case, it will be throwing out the baby with the bath water. In effect, they will be voting against future prosperity for Australia and Australians, especially in northern Tasmania.

Let me make it clear that this legislation now being debated in the Senate represents only one, but a key, element of a package that has previously been debated in this House. The legislation will be complemented by enhanced intergovernment agreements for forest industry developments which cannot now meet the eligibility criteria under the legislation. The package represents a major reform by any measure which will create long term jobs for the people of Australia. I would have thought that investment and job creation would be a priority for the Opposition, as it is for us. But I seem to be wrong.

The objectives of that legislation being debated and the complementary enhanced intergovernment agreements are to provide security and certainty to both the forest industry and its community; to provide security and certainty to industry so that it can make significant long term investments with confidence and so that the governments of the future will not prevent or obstruct the investment's productive outcomes; and to provide security and certainty to the community so that all of its interests, whether they be for values that are environmental, cultural, heritage, social or economic—both for the current and future generations—are adequately and comprehensively safeguarded. This legislation was designed to shift the industry towards export oriented value adding activities and to facilitate large projects of the kind that we have already described.

We have also accepted that projects made up of integrated activities should be eligible under the legislation. I would have thought that this was a breakthrough for the Opposition in a sense. This was a key part of the debate a month or more ago. We argued, along with the Opposition, that such a proposal about integrated activities might involve—but would not be limited to—a large scale sawmill, a veneer plant, a flitch mill, a woodchip plant to process the residues, and the establishment of plantations as a further resource base. So it had a very wide range of activities that it would pick up under this Bill. I cannot, to this moment, understand why the Opposition refuses to pass this legislation in the Senate.

The Government also recognises the need to encourage investment in commercial plantations. Such investment for export of woodchips, providing resource for downstream processing or both will be eligible for consideration for resource security under the legislation now proposed. Where the plantation proposal is to export woodchips, we would need to be satisfied that they would be surplus to domestic requirements; that is, surplus to the needs of downstream processing operations in Australia. The initiative should provide a significant boost to the development of eucalypt plantations in the country, particularly, I note, in Western Australia.

Our legislation focuses on investments of national significance. We are saying to the industry, `We, the Government of Australia, are conducting a comprehensive, integrated assessment and we are satisfying ourselves that certain obligations have been entered into by the enterprise and the State Government that we tie ourselves by legislation not to use our statutory powers other than in exceptional circumstances'.

As I say, I enter the debate more in sorrow than anger. We have done our very best to ensure decent future investment in this industry. I do not know the reasons why Opposition members will not be in it. But we will find out in the Senate in the next couple of the hours why Opposition members are prepared to stuff the economy of this country.

SPEECH.PARA: The States Grants (TAFE Assistance) Amendment Bill 1992 provides for supplementation for 1992 recurrent grants to reflect increases in price levels and also to appropriate funds for the increases for TAFE announced in the Government's November 1991 statement on the economy and employment.The Bill gives effect to the Government's decision announced in the November statement to provide an additional $115m for post-secondary education in 1992. This is the initial stage of the response to overcoming the problems highlighted in the Finn report on post-compulsory education and training.

PARA.TAB: Whilst the proportion of young people remaining to the end of secondary school has virtually doubled in a decade, and student numbers at our universities have risen by over 50 per cent, this is not the case for TAFE. While student demand for TAFE and training has continued to increase strongly there has not been the growth experienced in the other sectors. The budgetary priorities of State governments, which have responsibility in this area, together with labour market conditions have limited training opportunities in the TAFE sector. Discussions between the States and the Commonwealth on the funding issues raised by the Finn report are still in progress but this funding initiative, when taken together with other funding initiatives announced in the Prime Minister's One Nation statement, will contribute markedly towards setting funding for vocational education and training on a proper basis.

The Commonwealth is extending its original offer to the States and Territories on TAFE funding and is offering to take full funding responsibility for the development of a new and expanded system of institutes of vocational education. In the context of this offer, the Commonwealth will provide an additional $720m over the 1993-1995 triennium to fund growth in the system. However, this Bill is confined to additional 1992 funding and further legislation will be introduced in the budget session.

The effect of the changes is that the Bill provides for an additional $98.904m in recurrent funding and an additional $3.490m in capital funding taking the total funds available in 1992 to $475.307m. I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill and commend the Bill to the House.

Bill presented by Mr Beazley, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BEAZLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: The training guarantee scheme was established by legislation introduced into this House on 18 May 1990, and it came into effect on 1 July 1990. It requires employers to spend a minimum amount on training, broadly defined.

PARA.TAB: The scheme was introduced as part of the Government's policy over the last several years to develop the appropriate environment in which Australian industry can become more competitive internationally. A fundamental step in this process is the development of a highly skilled work force which can adapt quickly to major changes in the economy.

The scheme is an additional mechanism to stimulate industry's commitment to training. It aims to increase the skills of the work force by expanding employer investment in training and distributing more equitably the training effort among employers. We must prepare for an inevitable increase in demand for skilled people, as the economic recovery strengthens, by ensuring that our commitment to training in this country is maintained and increased. The training guarantee provides an important underpinning to achieving the necessary skilled work force.

This Bill amends the principal Act to give effect to a recommendation made in the report, the Finn report, of the Australian Education Council Review Committee entitled Young People's Participation in Post-Compulsory Education and Training. It also makes some minor technical amendments and a clarification. The Finn report was commissioned by Australia's Ministers for education and training to report on the future development of post-compulsory education and training in Australia. The report has provided new directions for the vocational education of young people whilst recognising the increasing convergence of vocational and general education.

In line with one of the Finn report recommendations, the Bill provides for work experience and practice for students and teachers to be included in an eligible training program of an employer. This further provision in the training guarantee will provide a strong incentive for employers to provide work experience and practice opportunities. Work experience and practice are key ingredients to education and training. This prepares young people for entry into the work force and strengthens the competencies of teachers in helping students meet industry requirements.

The Bill targets full time students at or above the level of year 10 or its equivalent who are under 21 years of age. This is consistent with the Finn report's emphasis on young people. Provision is made for students undertaking courses in schools and education and training institutions including institutions which are registered under a State or Territory law. In some cases these may be a private sector institution.The student must be full time in order to avoid inappropriate use of the provisions, such as employers releasing their employees for part time study and being able to claim their employee costs as eligible expenditure.

In regard to teachers, provision is made for teachers in schools and institutions of the kind applying to students. Unlike full time teachers, part time teachers generally will be already gaining some work experience, or at least have the opportunity to gain such experience. Accordingly, the provision applies to full time teachers only.

The Bill also specifies that there is an agreement between the teacher and the training institution, and the training institution and the provider of work experience, which includes the terms and conditions under which the teacher may undertake work experience. This is to ensure that only genuine and formal work experience arrangements apply to full time teachers. This is consistent with the aim of encouraging teachers to acquire industry experience and knowledge so they can pass this on to students when they return to the teaching institution.

The Bill inserts a provision that goods and services are to be provided within 13 months from the time the expenditure is incurred. This gives added force to the intent of the legislation that expenditure is not an end in itself and that the actual provision of training is the central purpose of such expenditure. However, the Bill makes provision for the Commissioner of Taxation to extend the time limit, should he decide it is appropriate to do so.

Finally, the Bill also inserts provisions for an employer to use a standard cost per kilometre for expenditure incurred on prescribed vehicle travel to enable an employee or other person to attend an eligible training program. A regulation will be tabled as soon as possible to give effect to this.

In summary, this Bill introduces some new aspects to the training guarantee in response to the Finn report. It also makes amendments to current provisions to assist employers and facilitate the administration of the training guarantee. I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill and commend the Bill to the House.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill, which is to commence on 1 July 1992, will make consequential amendments to various tax Acts, the Occupational Superannuation Standards Act 1987 and certain defence Acts as a result of the introduction of the Superannuation Guarantee Administration) Bill 1992 and the Superannuation Guarantee Charge Bill 1992 on 2 April 1992.

PARA.TAB: The Bill will amend the Income Tax Assessment Act to make the superannuation guarantee charge non-deductible for income tax purposes. This amendment is in accordance with the policy outlined in the December information paper on the superannuation guarantee charge. The Bill will also amend the Act to ensure that payments of the `shortfall component' of the superannuation guarantee charge made to a complying superannuation fund are treated as taxable contributions in the hands of the fund. The final amendment will ensure that the arrangements for obtaining tax file numbers apply to facilitate the administration of the superannuation guarantee scheme.

The Taxation Administration Act contains offences and prosecution provisions which create a number of offences of general application to the various Commonwealth tax laws and makes provision for their prosecution. It also contains provisions dealing with objections, reviews and appeals. The Bill proposes amendments to extend the list of provisions of taxation laws contained in that Act to include references to the corresponding provisions in the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Bill 1992.

The proposed amendment will ensure that decisions of the Commissioner of Taxation relating to liability for superannuation guarantee charge are not reviewable under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act but are reviewable instead under the separate objection, review and appeal provisions contained in part 4 of the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Bill.

The Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act provides criminal sanctions against persons who engage in transactions designed to ensure that a company or trust is rendered incapable of paying income tax, sales tax and certain other taxes or charges. Such schemes are commonly known as bottom of the harbour schemes. The proposed amendments will also make it a criminal offence to enter into an arrangement with a purpose of securing that a company or trustee will be unable to pay the superannuation guarantee charge.

An amendment will be made to the secrecy provisions in section 18 of the Occupational Superannuation Standards Act to allow the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner to publish a list of complying superannuation fund names and business addresses. This amendment will allow those employers and members of the public who wish to contribute to complying superannuation funds for purposes of the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Bill 1992 to have access to details which will enable them to contact the funds direct.

The amendments will amend the Defence Act 1903, the Defence Force Retirement and Death Benefits Act 1973 and the Military Superannuation and Benefits Act 1991 to ensure that the superannuation benefits for members of the Defence Force are consistent with the benefits required by the superannuation guarantee scheme.

The amendments to the tax Acts and the Occupational Superannuation Standards Act are not expected to have a significant financial impact on the revenue. The estimated impact of the additional benefits for members of the Defence Force provided as a result of the amendments proposed in this Bill will be approximately $6.9m over the next nine years.
I present the explanatory memorandum, which contains more detailed explanations of the provisions of the Bill, and I commend the Bill to the House.

DEBATE.TITLE: AVIATION FUEL REVENUES (SPECIAL APPROPRIATION) AMENDMENT BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Bill presented by Mr Snowdon, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snowdon The Hon W.E.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SNOWDON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport and Communications)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill makes technical amendments to the Aviation Fuel Revenues (Special Appropriation) Act to enable reductions to be made to the avgas excise and customs duty rate while preserving the Civil Aviation Authority's revenue entitlement under the Act. The purpose of the amendments is to permit the phasing out of the collection of that proportion of avgas duty that is directly attributed to the Department of Transport and Communication's aerodrome cost recovery program.

PARA.TAB: In August 1990 the Government announced its intention to transfer the remaining Commonwealth-owned aerodromes to full local ownership and to encourage aerodrome owners who are receiving funding under the aerodrome local ownership plan (ALOP) to accept full financial responsibility for their aerodromes.

As the number of aerodromes financially supported by the Government is reduced there is a corresponding reduction in government outlays. The Government has given a commitment to the aviation industry to pass on savings through the progressive reduction of the rate of excise and customs duty on avgas. This Bill will enable this commitment to be implemented.

The current rate of duty on avgas is 27.480c/litre of which 3.010c is attributable to aerodrome cost recovery purposes. The balance of the duty is attributable to cost recovering aviation functions carried out by the Civil Aviation Authority.

This Bill enables the 3.010c to be phased out while retaining the existing level of revenue entitlements that the Civil Aviation Authority has under the present Act. At the same time the amendments enable the Civil Aviation Authority with the agreement of the Minister to vary the amount of revenue it receives for cost recovery purposes from the duty. This preserves the intent of the arrangements under the present Act.

The Bill will allow immediate amendment of the customs and excise tariffs to provide a one cent reduction in the avgas duty. A further one cent reduction in the avgas duty will take place when the combined number of Commonwealth aerodromes and ALOP aerodromes is reduced to 100. The final component of duty attributable to the aerodrome cost recovery program is scheduled to be removed in June 1993 when the aerodrome transfer and withdrawal process is anticipated to be completed.

This Bill is a reflection of the tangible benefits which are flowing to the general aviation industry from the Government's aviation reforms, in particular its policies on aerodrome local ownership. I commend the Bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum for the Bill.
