Bill presented by Mr Willis, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALKER.NAME: Mr WILLIS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Finance)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill proposes amendments to the Commonwealth Employees Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 1988, the CERC Act, and the Occupational Health and Safety (Commonwealth Employment) Act 1991, the OH&S Act. It also proposes technical, drafting and consequential amendments to other Acts. The provisions of the Bill are explained in the explanatory memorandum. I propose therefore to confine my comments to the major amendments.

PARA.TAB: The main focus of the Bill is to continue the reform of Commonwealth employees' compensation arrangements in line with the recommendations of the Brown review of the Comcare program. In this, it fulfils an undertaking given by the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) that this would be done in the present sittings.

The Commission for the Safety, Rehabilitation and Compensation of Commonwealth employees—the Commission—which operated as Comcare, was established under the CERC Act. Its purpose was effectively to manage the Commonwealth public sector workers' compensation system. The Commission's role in the prevention of workplace injury and disease through improved occupational health and safety practices and the rehabilitation of injured workers was emphasised.

In December 1990 Mr Ron Brown, a management consultant, was commissioned to carry out a comprehensive review of the Comcare program. The Brown review involved consideration of the effectiveness of the Comcare scheme and recommendation of policy and legislative changes needed to better achieve the Government's objectives. The review acknowledged the success of improvements in workers compensation arrangements and policy achieved by the Commission since its establishment under this Government. Nevertheless, it targeted additional areas where effectiveness could be enhanced.

In December 1991, the first step in implementing the Brown review's recommendations was taken. The Commission was restructured as a regulatory body distinct from Comcare and with a separate chairperson. It is responsible for regulatory functions associated with the CERC Act and the OH&S Act. This includes determining compensation premiums. Comcare was restructured as a service delivery body, headed by its chief executive officer. It is responsible for commercial administrative and service functions under the legislation, including providing support to the Commission.

This Bill deals with two important measures designed to implement other important recommendations of the Brown review. The Bill covers the licensing of Commonwealth authorities to perform certain functions under the CERC Act in respect of their own employees under the supervision of the Commission; and improvements in relation to Comcare's financial arrangements.

I turn to the proposed regime for the licensing of Commonwealth authorities. In the CERC Act in 1988 provision was made for both Australia Post and Telecom to become self-administrators of the Commonwealth workers compensation scheme. This was for a two-year trial period. Under these arrangements the two organisations were responsible for all aspects of the administration of the CERC Act for their employees. The Brown review recommended that these self-administration arrangements should end and be replaced with a system of licences for self-insurance and in-house claims management.

The Bill provides for the implementation of that recommendation. It does so in a way that is consistent with preserving flexibility and increasing efficiency in the operation of the Commonwealth's employee compensation arrangements. But, at the same time, it will ensure that the licensed authorities operate under an appropriate system of regulation by the Commission. That system of regulation will, among other things, ensure consistency of practice between Comcare and the licensed authorities. Commonwealth authorities will be able to apply to the Commission for licences under the Act. The Commission will have the power to grant or refuse applications, based on their consideration against criteria set out in the legislation. An application fee will need to be paid.

The new arrangements will allow the Commission to issue three classes of licence. A class 1 licence will allow an authority to operate as a self-insurer. The licence will transfer to the licensed authority all or part of Comcare's obligation to compensate its employees.A class 2 licence will allow an authority to determine its own claims. The licence will transfer to the licensed authority, wholly or in part, Comcare's function of determining its employees' claims under the CERC Act. A class 3 licence will allow an authority to self-insure and determine the claims of its employees.

SPEECH.PARA: Licences are to be subject to a system of conditions set out in the CERC Act, as well as other conditions imposed on a case-by-case basis by the Commission.

PARA.TAB: The principal statutory conditions are to be requirements that licensed authorities comply with the CERC Act and pay their annual licence fees. The conditions able to be set by the Commission will include conditions limiting the maximum liability for which a licensed authority may self-insure, or in respect of which it may make a determination. If a limit is imposed by way of a condition then, once exceeded, liability to make payments or to determine a claim, or both, will revert to Comcare, depending on the class of licence. Another possible condition to which a self-insurance licence may be made subject is a requirement that the licensed authority obtain specified bank or other guarantees or other specified securities.

The Government recognises that consistency, equality and independence of decision-making are of paramount importance in these processes, particularly at the review stage. Accordingly, the Commission will be able to impose a condition on a licence that the reconsideration of claims determined by a class 2 or class 3 licence holder be carried out by Comcare or another authority. To ensure consistency and equality of decision making, licence holders will be obliged to comply with guidelines issued by the Commission. In addition, the Commission will be able to give a direction to a licensed authority, either generally or in respect of a particular matter or class of matters. Licensed authorities are to be required by the CERC Act to comply with such directions.

It is anticipated that, exercising its powers, the Commission will set performance standards to be achieved and maintained by license holders. Because a licensed authority will be bound as a condition of its licence to comply with the Act, a failure to comply with guidelines or directions of the Commission will involve a breach of that condition. The Commission will be able to suspend a class 2 or class 3 licence or revoke a licence of any class for breach of any condition. It will also be able to direct a licensed authority to comply with conditions of the licence. The provisions of the Bill also detail the effects of a suspension or revocation. Under the Bill's provisions, the current self-administering authorities—Australia Post and Telecom—will hold class 3 licences.

The second group of amendments proposed by the Bill, linked to the implementation of the Brown review, concerns the financial arrangements under the CERC Act. Comcare will be allowed to enter into arrangements under which it will provide and charge fees for agreed services related to the performance by Comcare of its functions under the CERC Act. Also included are provisions under which Comcare will collect premiums under the CERC Act on behalf of the Commonwealth.

The Bill aims at simplifying the operation of the CERC Act by including a special or standing appropriation. There will be payable to Comcare the moneys necessary to meet undischarged liabilities for claims under the previous compensation arrangements. In addition, Comcare will also be paid amounts equal to the administrative costs attributable to these claims. There will also be payable to Comcare the moneys necessary to discharge its liabilities for claims under the CERC Act and to cover administrative costs associated with those claims.

The amounts available to Comcare under this second head are limited to the amounts of premiums it has collected together with notional interest on such of those premiums as have not from time to time been paid out, less previous payments. The Minister for Finance may determine the opening balances for the special appropriations and the rate of notional interest to be applied to the balance from time to time in the Consolidated Revenue Fund.

Part 5 of this Bill provides for the introduction of recovery of the costs of administration of the Occupational Health and Safety (Commonwealth Employment) Act 1991. These proposals have two aspects: fees for certain services and general contributions. The Commission will be able to enter into arrangements with departments and authorities under which it will provide and charge for agreed services. Comcare is to be given a similar power under the CERC Act.

The Commission will also be able to estimate contributions that are to be payable by all departments and authorities covered by the OH&S Act. In this way, each department and authority will contribute to the cost of administering the Act based on its own occupational health and safety record and having regard to other specified matters. This will provide departments and authorities with a financial incentive to improve occupational health and safety programs, and will assist in ensuring a safe and healthy working environment for Commonwealth employees.

A two-stage process of review of estimated contribution will be available. Estimates will be reviewed first by the Commission and then, if the Department or authority concerned wishes it, by the Minister. Departments and authorities will be required to provide relevant information and to pay interest on late payments.

This Bill represents an important stage in the successful implementation of changes to the workers compensation system based on the recent Brown review of the Comcare program. The Bill represents substantial progress in the Government's continuing reform of the Commonwealth employees compensation scheme.

The amendments proposed in the Bill are not expected to have a significant financial impact. The costs of licensing and of regulation of licensed authorities under the CERC Act are to be recovered from those authorities through application and annual fees. The standing or special appropriations proposed to be inserted in the CERC Act will take the place of annual appropriations and are limited in their scope. The cost recovery arrangements proposed for the OH&S Act may result in some savings in annual appropriations to the extent that costs are recovered from non-Budget dependent agencies. Costs or savings in respect of Budget dependent agencies are dependent upon the annual Budget process and cannot be quantified. I commend the Bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.
Debate (on motion by Mr Peacock) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: COAL MINING INDUSTRY (LONG SERVICE LEAVE FUNDING) BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Bill presented by Mr Willis, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALKER.NAME: Mr WILLIS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Finance)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: These Bills form an important part of the Government's coal industry reform package. They provide for the amendment and, ultimately, the repeal of the States Grants (Coal Mining Industry Long Service Leave) Act 1949 which, together with complementary State legislation, establishes the present scheme for the funding of long service leave in the black coalmining industry in New South Wales, Queensland, Western Australia and Tasmania.

PARA.TAB: The current scheme is funded by way of an excise on coal production levied at 20c per tonne. Under the proposed arrangements, long service leave will be funded by a levy on payroll. The new scheme has been agreed to by the relevant States and all elements in the industry affected have been consulted in relation to the proposed reforms.

On 2 December 1991, the Government announced a range of initiatives in relation to the coal industry. These were announced in the Government's coal industry policy statement jointly issued by the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) and the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean). The statement presents the most far-reaching changes to coal industry policy since the immediate post-war period. Reform of the industry's long service leave arrangements is part of those initiatives.

The policy statement followed a review of long service leave funding undertaken by Mr L. J. Willett, then chairperson of the Superannuation Fund Investment Trust, and was delivered to the Minister for Industrial Relations in November 1990. The report recommended changes to the present funding scheme. It also proposed that the scheme should be fully funded so as to facilitate the portability of long service leave in the industry and to ensure the preservation of benefits in the event of companies going out of business.

The Government agrees with the general thrust of Mr Willett's report and believes that responsibility for administering the fund should be returned to the industry. It recognises, however, that in the short run this may impose significant cost burdens on sections of the industry.

Existing arrangements have operated on a `pay as you go' basis, and a substantial unfunded liability for long service leave has accrued. Moreover, large scale, highly productive producers—largely represented by the Queensland Mining Council—raised concerns that they presently cross-subsidise the operations of more labour-intensive mines, predominantly the underground coalmining industry in New South Wales.

In commenting on the Willett report's recommendations, industry parties and State governments agreed that outstanding liabilities and future accruals should be funded on a more equitable and rational basis related to employment costs. The Government believes that the new arrangements safeguard the public interest in maintaining a viable coalmining industry whilst representing an appropriate balance between the principles of efficiency and equity and the interests of the disparate parties.

The Bills terminate the present excise funding arrangement and implement a new industry managed, fully funded scheme. With the co-operation of the States, it is envisaged that the new funding arrangements will become fully operational from 1 January 1993.

The principal features of the scheme are as follows: there is to be a single national scheme under Commonwealth legislation, and its management is to be the responsibility of a board of directors made up of employer and union representatives. The legislation will establish a Coal Mining Industry (Long Service Leave Funding) Corporation. The Corporation will be wholly self-financing and will have two functions. The first will be to manage the coalmining industry long service leave trust fund for the purpose of reimbursing participating companies for long service leave taken by coalminers and other eligible employees. The second will be to collect levies from companies for the purpose of funding long service leave and meeting the costs of the Corporation.

The Corporation will be constituted by a board of six directors whom the Minister for Industrial Relations will appoint and who will hold office on a part time basis. The Minister will appoint two of the directors to represent the companies engaged in black coalmining in New South Wales, Queensland and Tasmania, and one director to represent companies engaged in black coalmining in Western Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister will appoint one director to represent the United Mine Workers Division of the Construction, Forestry and Mining Employees Union, and one director to represent: the Electrical Trades Union of Australia; the Federated Engine Drivers and Firemen's Association of Australia; and the Metals and Engineering Workers Union. Another director is to represent: the Australian Collieries Staff Association; the Colliery Officials Association of New South Wales; and the New South Wales Mine Managers Association.

PARA.TAB: In the first instance, the Minister will appoint one of the directors to be chairperson of the board and another to be deputy chairperson. Subsequent appointments of chairperson and deputy chairperson will be made by the board. The directors' remuneration will be determined by the Remuneration Tribunal.

The Corporation will have all powers necessary to carry out the functions I have described. It will have the power to enter into contracts, including contracts with other organisations to collect levies, manage funds and make payments in relation to long service leave on behalf of the Corporation. It will have the power to invest moneys so as to maximise the return on funds in the interests of contributors, to borrow moneys subject to ministerial approval, and to employ staff and engage consultants under terms and conditions determined by the board. The scheme is to be independently reviewed at regular intervals and once it is fully funded responsibility for its operation will be devolved to the industry.

Assets and liabilities of the existing fund are to be transferred to the new scheme and the legislation provides that the rate of levy is to be prescribed by the Minister acting on the advice of the board. The levy is to be collected from participating companies only, with the formula for reimbursement set to reflect national minimum industry standards in respect of long service leave. Claims for reimbursement may be made in relation to all award based entitlements payable during long service leave, including production related bonuses. Where such payments are made arising out of an obligation under a recognised enterprise or workplace agreement reimbursement may also be claimed.

For constitutional reasons it has not been possible to cover certain non-award based entitlements payable in certain States or by individual firms by tailoring the rate of levy to the circumstances in each participating State. There is nothing, however, in the scheme to prevent firms paying higher long service leave benefits where they see fit. In such cases they will not be able to claim reimbursement from the fund for payments in excess of normal entitlements.

It is envisaged that the scheme is to be fully funded over a period of 10 years, including the unfunded liability for leave accrued prior to 1 January 1993. Presently, it is estimated the initial levy will be in the vicinity of 6 per cent of payroll. The actual rate of levy will be precisely determined by an actuarial review conducted under the auspices of the Corporation. As I have already indicated, there are compelling reasons for continuing government involvement through a statutory corporation.

First, the new arrangements will substantially increase long service leave funding costs for many companies, especially by reason of the requirement to fully fund accrued liabilities. The formation of a statutory corporation, rather than a private company, has enabled company income tax deductibility of contributions to the fund. The rates of payroll levy that are required to finance ongoing accruals of long service leave and to fund the accrued liability will impose significantly increased cost burdens on the industry. These rates of levy will, for some companies, equate to a cost of about 60c or 70c per tonne compared with the present 20c per tonne. The burden will fall most heavily on relatively labour-intensive mines.

In view of the potential cost impact of the new arrangements on sections of the industry, particularly the requirement to achieve full funding, it is appropriate that the tax treatment of levy contributions to the new scheme should be as favourable as the tax treatment of payments under the current excise funding arrangements. As excise payments are deductible for company income tax purposes it is anticipated that there will be no additional cost to revenue.

The provision of tax deductibility for levy contributions also recognises that, unlike most other employers, coal companies are being compelled to contribute to a long service leave fund. Other employers who make provision for their long service leave liabilities in the normal way retain the funds so provided as internal working capital. Deductibility of contributions will help offset the cost of replacing that working capital.

Secondly, the new long service leave scheme removes the inefficiencies and inequities associated with the present arrangements, and its full funding will ensure the portability and preservation of benefits. It is an important complementary component of the Government's coal industry policy reforms, which are designed to respond to changed circumstances and help secure the industry's future into the next century.

Thirdly, continuing Commonwealth involvement provides a guarantee of continuity and for a smooth transition to the privately funded scheme or schemes with a minimum of industrial friction. I commend the Bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum.
Debate (on motion by Mr Peacock) adjourned.

PARA.TAB: Bill presented by Mr Willis, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALKER.NAME: Mr WILLIS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Finance)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: The States Grants (Coal Mining Industry Long Service Leave) Amendment Bill forms part of a package of measures already outlined in my second reading speech in relation to the Coal Mining Industry (Long Service Leave Funding) Bill 1992.

PARA.TAB: As a result of the reduction in the levels of excise payable under the present scheme, it is necessary, as an interim measure, to amend the States Grants (Coal Mining Industry Long Service Leave) Act 1949. The Bill, therefore, amends the principal Act by providing for the whole of the excise raised under the existing scheme to be paid from the Consolidated Revenue Fund to the existing coalmining industry long service leave fund.
