Bill presented by Mr Crean, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crean The Hon S.F.

TALKER.NAME: Mr CREAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of the Coal Industry Amendment Bill is to reform the functions and activities of the Joint Coal Board. This reform measure is part of a package of major policy reform measures for the coal sector announced by this Government on 2 December 1991. The aims of the reform package are to promote growth, employment and investment in the industry through the removal of unnecessary impediments to growth and change. The other reform measures to be considered by Parliament are:
.a new industry-based coal research and development arrangement;
.a new national scheme for coalminers' long service leave; and
.abolition of the coal export duty.

PARA.TAB: This Bill will give effect to the Government's decision to refocus the functions and activities of the board. The board was established under Commonwealth and New South Wales coal industry Acts of 1946. The New South Wales Government will be introducing its parallel Bill to the State Parliament in the current parliamentary session.

At the time that it was established, the board was given extensive powers over industry development, mining, employment, and marketing to ensure adequate coal supplies in the postwar reconstruction era. Many of these powers have long since been unnecessary and unused. The New South Wales coal industry has undergone extensive changes since 1947, moving from a domestic oriented industry to a premier coal exporter.

In October 1990, the Commonwealth and New South Wales governments engaged Mr Bryan Kelman to undertake an independent review of the powers, functions and activities of the Board. Based on Mr Kelman's review and subsequent consultations with industry parties and the Construction, Forestry and Mining Employees Union, both the Commonwealth and New South Wales governments agreed that the board's functions and activities would be rationalised and refocused to concentrate on those areas where it has a demonstrated record of performance.

The decision to refocus the board's powers and role in the industry will remove unnecessary duplication of functions between the board and the State department responsible for mining matters. The Bill provides for the board to continue its powers, functions and activities in the following areas:

SPEECH.PARA: .administration of the coal industry workers compensation scheme;
.provision of coalminers occupational health and rehabilitation services, including the provision of preventive medical services, monitoring workers' health and investigating related health matters;
.promotion of the welfare of current and former workers in the industry, their families and communities in the coalmining areas;
.collection, collation and dissemination of accident and other statistics related to the health and welfare of workers engaged in the coal industry;
.provision of advice and information to Ministers and others on coalminers health and welfare;
.report to Ministers and the chief inspector of coalmines as it thinks fit on matters of safety;
.provision of international training and educational courses in coal under the auspices of the Australian aid program and international development agencies; and
.collection of industry statistics until such time as both the Commonwealth and State Ministers otherwise direct.

PARA.TAB: The board will also continue its provision of training activities to mineworkers until such time as effective alternative arrangements are operating to the satisfaction of the industry parties.

Both governments have recognised the very valuable work which the board has done in relation to coalminers' health and welfare. The board will therefore continue to monitor dust levels until the industry parties can satisfy Ministers with portfolio responsibility that there are suitable and effective alternative arrangements which may warrant a transfer of this function.

The effect of the Bill is to remove unnecessary duplication of functions between the board and the State, and to bring to an end the board's powers, functions and activities in a number of areas, namely:

SPEECH.PARA: .control over the rate of development of the coal industry in New South Wales, particularly attempts to match supply and demand; and
.coal resource utilisation, mining, marketing and management issues within the State.

Future board membership will formalise the current arrangement, which is an independent chairperson, a union representative and a company representative. However, the terms of appointment will be changed. The Act provides for a maximum term of appointment of seven years on a full time basis for all board members. The Bill will amend this to a maximum of three years on either a full time or part time basis.

PARA.TAB: As it stands now, policy direction to the board can only be issued from the Prime Minister in agreement with the Premier of New South Wales. The Bill will place the board under the direct control of both Commonwealth and State portfolio Ministers responsible for the coal industry. Provisions have been made in the Bill to improve the board's standards of accountability in line with contemporary practice.

From 1992-93, the board will become largely self-funding for its continuing operations. The workers compensation insurance, health, and welfare activities will be funded from existing resources accumulated by the board and from future premium and other income. The other functions will be operated on a cost recovery basis. In 1991-92, the Commonwealth share for the board's operations is $2.463m. This includes funding for the Coal Industry Tribunal of $570,000 which has previously been provided through the board. Funding for the Coal Industry Tribunal will continue.

The reforms to the Joint Coal Board embodied in this Bill ensure continuation of its high standard of delivery of services to employees in the New South Wales coal industry. The health and welfare of industry employees will in no way be compromised by this reform. Both governments believe that the elimination of overlap with State activities and bringing the operations of the board into sharper focus will assist the efficient operation of the State's most important export industry.
I commend the Bill to the House and I present the explanatory memorandum.
Debate (on motion by Dr Kemp) adjourned.
Bill presented by Mr Crean, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crean The Hon S.F.

TALKER.NAME: Mr CREAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of this Bill is to transfer responsibility for coal research and development in Australia from a Commonwealth Government run system to an industry funded and managed scheme. This new arrangement was announced by the Government on 2 December 1991 as part of a major package of institutional reform in the coal industry.

PARA.TAB: The principal Commonwealth Government mechanism for directing and coordinating energy research and development has been the National Energy Research, Development and Demonstration Council (NERDDC). Coal research has been funded through NERDDC by the Coal Research Trust Account, which was established by the Coal Research Assistance Act 1977. Current funding arrangements for the Coal Research Trust Account is through the collection of a 5c per tonne excise on black coal production by the Excise Tariff Act 1921.

The new coal research and development (R&D) arrangements had their origins following a review of all Commonwealth funded research arrangements within the Department of Primary Industries and Energy conducted in 1989. The aim of the review was to define improvements which could be made to ensure that research programs continued to produce results that are relevant to industry requirements. A statutory research and development corporation model was chosen and has been adopted in most cases; however, the coal industry opted to administer its own research and development.
There have been a number of disadvantages associated with the existing Government imposed arrangements:

SPEECH.PARA: . the levy rate has tended to be regarded by some firms as a ceiling on research and development investments, rather than a minimum guaranteed level;
. opportunities for firm-specific competitive advantage which might otherwise have been pursued through research and development have been obscured;
. some firms have expressed a feeling of disenfranchisement from their R&D; and
. management's responsibility for each firm's R&D has been implicitly transferred to external authorities, making R&D less relevant in day-to-day business decisions.

Agreement has been reached with the coal industry, through the Australian Coal Association, to transfer responsibility for coal research and development from NERDDC and the Coal Research Trust Account to a new Coal Research Council to be run by the Australian Coal Association through the incorporated company Australian Coal Research Ltd. This will involve Australian Coal Research Ltd assuming all financial and contractual assets and liabilities and obligations associated with the Coal Research Trust Account.

PARA.TAB: A detailed memorandum of understanding has been signed between the Australian Coal Association and the Commonwealth to provide for the industry to fund and manage its own research. In the MOU the Australian Coal Association undertakes:

SPEECH.PARA: (a)to maintain the total level of collective research funding in the coal industry at the same level per tonne as would have been collected each year under the current coal industry research levy of 5c per tonne produced;

(b)in raising this level of research funds, to take every measure to ensure that moneys raised are not substituted for specific company funded research expenditures. The research expenditures will be additional to those outlays undertaken by individual companies;
(c)to allocate research funds so raised, including interest earned, exclusively for the administration and execution of coal research and development activities;
(d)to administer funds in accordance with commercially acceptable and prudent practices, including provision of an annual audit by a certified public accountancy firm;

(e)to establish a body with the appropriate legal status, now the Australian Coal Research Ltd, to assume from the Commonwealth all financial and contractual assets and liabilities associated with the Coal Research Trust Account, including responsibility for unfunded commitments; and

(f)to liaise with other relevant research administrative bodies, such as the Energy Research and Development Corporation, to ensure suitable collaboration and a reduction in unnecessary duplication where this arises. This may also result in joint funding of projects and sharing of results where appropriate.
The aim of the amendments to the Coal Research Assistance Act 1977 is to put into effect the transfer of coal R&D from the Commonwealth to the coal industry. These amendments involve:
.transferring to Australian Coal Research Ltd the moneys, assets, liabilities and commitments—including unfunded commitments—associated with the Coal Research Trust Account;
.the transfer of existing research grant agreements and those completed projects for which there remain obligations including associated intellectual property rights; and
.providing for the Commonwealth to take back responsibility for coal R&D in the unlikely event that, for some reason or other, the industry is unable to fulfil its obligations.

PARA.TAB: In relation to the financial impact of the transfer, this involves the transfer of:

SPEECH.PARA: -the balance of the coal research trust account of around $8m, with the coal industry taking responsibility for outstanding commitments of around $17.2m of which about $9.2m will be met from future revenues collected from the coal industry by Australian Coal Research Ltd;

-Commonwealth-owned equipment used by grantees until the completion of research contracts—this is then sold and the moneys earned are reinvested in further research. Based on initial purchase price this equipment cost around $7.2m;
-computer equipment, database and software, valued at around $35,000, currently used in grants administration.

PARA.TAB: The Commonwealth excise of 5c per tonne of coal produced, which funded the coal research trust account to the value of around $8m per year, is being suspended through consequential amendments to the Excise Tariff Act 1921. I would like to say how pleased I am to see such productive cooperation between the coal industry and the Government in organising the transfer of coal R&D from government control to self-management by the coal industry. This type of cooperation is another example of where the Government can encourage positive research in industry. I look forward to working together with the coal industry and to seeing the implementation of commercialisation of R&D in the industry.

The national energy research development and demonstration program has done very good work in the past and this new legislation will add to the effectiveness of its work. I believe this legislation sets the basis for collaborative industry-government approaches for the future. I commend the Bill to honourable members and present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
Debate (on motion by Dr Kemp) adjourned.
Bill presented by Mr Crean, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crean The Hon S.F.

TALKER.NAME: Mr CREAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of this Bill is to repeal the Customs Tariff (Coal Export Duty) Act 1975 and to amend the Excise Tariff Act 1921 which will put in place the reform measures for the coal sector announced by this Government on 2 December 1991. One of the reform measures announced by the Government is the abolition of the coal export duty. The duty was originally introduced in the early 1970s as a tax on windfall profits. Over the years the duty was modified and, at present, coal which remains dutiable is high quality coking coal mined from depths no greater than 60 metres in open-cut mines which were in production before 30 June 1980. In practice, the duty affects six open-cut mines in Queensland operated by BHP Australia Coal Ltd. This Government acknowledges that the duty is an anomaly in the current coal industry tax system.

PARA.TAB: The Government has therefore agreed to repeal the coal export duty in return for BHP's commitment to invest $248m in new capital expenditure, enhanced research and development and additional coal mine rehabilitation activities over the next five years. The program of commitments by BHP will have significant efficiency gains, improve regional employment opportunities and provide environmental benefits for Queensland.

The commitments will also add to the competitiveness of export operations of Australian coal at a time when Australia needs to explore all avenues of improved export performance. This Government's decision to abolish the duty as part of a package of micro-economic reform for the Australian coal industry underpins the facilitating role this Government is prepared to play in working with industry to overcome sectoral impediments and promote industry development. This Bill also amends the Excise Tariff Act 1921 to give effect to the Government's decision to reform the coal research and development arrangements and coalminers' long service leave arrangements.

The Commonwealth excise of 5c per tonne on coal produced which currently funds the Coal Research Trust Account to the value of around $8m, will be suspended. The remaining Commonwealth excise of 20c per tonne on coal produced, which currently funds coalminers' long service leave will continue until a new payroll levy based scheme comes into effect.

There is a potential loss of gross revenue from abolition of the coal export duty of $44.8m in 1992-93 and $40.5m in 1993-94. Suspension of the levy for research and development and the ultimate abolition of the long service leave levy will reduce Commonwealth receipts. Legislation providing for the establishment of an industry-based coal research and development arrangement and a new national scheme for coalminers long service leave have been introduced into the House of Representatives today as part of the Government's coal industry policy reform package. I commend the Bill to honourable members and I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
Debate (on motion by Dr Kemp) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: STATES AND NORTHERN TERRITORY GRANTS (RURAL ADJUSTMENT) AMENDMENT BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Bill presented by Mr Crean, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crean The Hon S.F.

TALKER.NAME: Mr CREAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill amends several of the provisions of the current rural adjustment scheme, RAS, which was introduced in January 1989 following an extensive review. At the time of setting up this revised scheme it was envisaged that it would operate in a more flexible and innovative way to address more adequately the changing structural adjustment forces acting in the Australian agricultural sector and to more closely match the requirements for assistance of individual farmers.

PARA.TAB: In the first years of the revised scheme, the rural economy was generally buoyant but towards the end of 1990 it had become apparent that the sector was experiencing the beginning of a severe downturn and that a number of farmers were facing financial difficulties as a result of depressed commodity prices. This was to be the first real test of the adequacy of the scheme. In Queensland and northern New South Wales the severe drought in 1991 exacerbated the difficulties being faced by farmers in those areas.

My Department undertook assessments in April and October 1991 to determine whether the assistance measures available under the scheme were adequate to meet the pressures placed on individual farming families. It became apparent as a result of these assessments that additional measures would need to be introduced to assist farmers with long term prospects, but in financial difficulties, as a result of the downturn.

The resultant changes to the scheme augmented the existing measures which would assist in maintaining the basis for an internationally competitive rural base. Funding was progressively increased from $62.45m in 1990-91 to $193.91m for 1991-92 and at present some 10,000 farmers are receiving RAS assistance. These variations, in conjunction with other initiatives, such as the modification of hardship provisions under the Social Security Act, have provided a safety net for those farmers facing severe financial difficulties.

There is provision under the agreement to amend the terms and provisions available under the scheme provided that the concurrence is sought from State and Territory Ministers. This provision has been particularly useful as it has allowed access to the assistance without delay. The first two amendments have been made by agreement between the Commonwealth and the States and the Northern Territory. It is now appropriate to bring these amendments before the Commonwealth Parliament.

The third amendment being introduced at this time is to formally extend the scheme to the Australian Capital Territory, ACT. Following self-government, the Territory has assumed responsibility for program delivery. There has been very little demand for assistance under the scheme by the Territory's farmers as there are only 230 farmers in the ACT, of which approximately 25 per cent would be assessed as being bona fide farmers under the criteria laid out in the agreement. Under the current arrangements, New South Wales has been acting as an agent for the administration of the scheme where there has been a need for assistance for ACT farmers. While there has been little demand to date, it is only equitable that those few genuine farmers in the ACT should also have access to the RAS.

The first initiative to be introduced was the new measure available under part A of the scheme entitled `Debt Restructuring with Interest Subsidies' or DRIS. Farmers, who have long term prospects in farming, but due to various reasons, including low incomes, are not able to obtain further finance from their creditors, may be eligible for an interest subsidy on their existing debts. This measure was designed to improve farmers' cash flows. This provision has been applied with other measures available under the RAS, such as the support to obtain carry-on finance to meet the individual needs of farmers.

Following the economic statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in February 1992, additional funds were provided which will assist some farmers to plant broadacre and sugar crops in the 1992 winter and 1992-93 summer crop planting seasons. The crop planting scheme is designed to support the provision of working capital for crop plantings and raise confidence in the broadacre industries. For this purpose broadacre crops have been defined as cereals, coarse grains, oilseeds, peanuts and grain legumes. Needy producers in the sugar industry are also included. These industries are in need of working capital.

Assistance for crop planting has been available since March 1992 under part B of the scheme. Support is in the form of a 75 per cent interest subsidy on their commercial crop planting loans. Under the terms and provisions that have been agreed with the States, to be eligible for assistance, the farm enterprise should be profitable in the long term, but unable to obtain sufficient commercial carry-on finance to undertake normal cropping programs. Assistance will be limited to a maximum $10,000 subsidy and can be used for normal crop planting expenses such as wages, seed, fertiliser, fuel and repairs.

In the development of a national drought policy, the provision of relief for farmers affected by dry seasonal conditions is provided under part B of the scheme. This component supports farmers in financial difficulties through causes beyond their control, to obtain carry-on finance through the provision of interest subsidies on commercial borrowings.

Part B assistance was activated in 1991 primarily because of the severe financial hardship being suffered by many farmers as a result of the low commodity prices, but this situation was compounded in Queensland and northern New South Wales by the severe drought conditions in the latter part of the year. Under the arrangements for the current scheme, funding for part B has been shared equally by the Commonwealth and the States. In recognition of the difficulty of some States to provide matching funds, the Commonwealth agreed in October 1991 to alter the funding contribution. Under the revised funding arrangements for part B, the Commonwealth will provide two dollars for each dollar provided by the States.

The scheme has, in general, withstood the considerable pressures exerted by the downturn and drought. The new measures have contributed significantly to the effectiveness of the scheme. They have complemented the measures already available under the scheme as well as a number of other Commonwealth and State programs that have also been under similar pressure to support the rural sector through this crisis. Evidence suggests that 1991-92 will prove to be the lowest point of the adverse conditions in the sector and that 1992-93 will see a recovery.

The scheme is currently being evaluated in line with Government policy of regularly reviewing the effectiveness of its programs. I will be reporting on the outcome of the review to the next meeting of the Agricultural Council of Australian and New Zealand at the end of July. The evaluation may recommend the need to further modify the scheme in order to meet the primary objective of ensuring structural adjustment in the industry. The manner in which the scheme has coped through the downturn will be closely scrutinised, in particular its effectiveness in assisting to modify the effects of future downturns in farming in Australia. I commend the Bill to honourable members and present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.
Debate (on motion by Dr Kemp) adjourned.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Suspension of Standing and Sessional Orders

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Mr Crean)—by leave—agreed to:

That so much of the Standing and Sessional Orders be suspended as would prevent the order of the day, committee and delegation reports, for the resumption of debate on the report of the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs entitled Halfway to Equal: Equal oportunity and equal status for women in Australia, being called forthwith.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —This morning I tabled in this House the report of the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs on its inquiry into equal opportunity and equal status for Australian women. This report is entitled Half Way to Equal. I believe that title in many ways summarises the vast bulk of the evidence which the Committee has received. This afternoon I will talk to a small extent about the nature of this inquiry, its history and its form because I think they are important in our understanding of the development of the committee system in this place.

PARA.TAB: I will also speak about a few of the recommendations. Time will permit me to canvass that only very briefly. The report contains some 79 recommendations. It would need a lot greater time than we have available to do it much justice. I understand my colleagues, the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman) and the honourable member for McEwen (Mrs Bailey), will also be addressing the report and they will expand a little more fully on recommendations which are of particular interest to them.

This inquiry commenced late in the life of the last Parliament after the terms of reference were referred by the then Attorney-General, Lionel Bowen. The Committee started late in the life of the last Parliament and, with the Christmas period and the subsequent election, it really did not get under way to any great extent until the beginning of this Parliament. In essence, the inquiry has lasted for around two years, which is a long time for a parliamentary inquiry. If members take the opportunity to go through the report and get some idea of the evidence which this Committee received, they will understand why the Committee took so long in gathering evidence.

There has been a monumental attempt by this Committee to consult as widely as possible and to gain evidence as widely as possible on the Committee's terms of reference. Essentially, the Committee was asked to conduct a stock take on the position of Australian women in the 1990s. That meant gaining evidence from all walks of life: from many individuals; governments, both State and Federal; business; voluntary organisations; many academics; universities and community groups. At the final cut-off date for consideration of the evidence, the Committee had received some 634 written submissions. Given that a standard inquiry might expect to receive from 60 to 100 submissions, one can see that this did attract a lot of interest.

Over and above that, the Committee held public hearings in each of the Australian capitals and in some of the major regional centres and heard from a further 181 witnesses at these public hearings. We received over 170 further exhibits of previously published material. To involve the women of Australia plus other interested groups and government departments, in one case with the Royal Australian Institute of Public Administration, in another the Australian Sports Commission, in another the Department of Employment, Education and Training and in another the Office of the Status of Women, we co-hosted four seminars which in themselves attracted over 1,000 participants. I think that gives the House some idea as to the amount of evidence this Committee has received.

I shall refer to some of the statistics which led the Committee to reach its conclusion and make its recommendations. Some of this evidence is quite startling and bears repeating. For instance, women's wages in Australia currently on average are only 87 per cent of average male wages and women make up only 13 per cent of government representatives in Australia. Since the inception of the Australian honours system in 1975 women have received only 24 per cent of all awards and most of them have been in the lower orders.

In Olympic competitions between 1948 and 1988 women have won 42 per cent of the medals which have been won by Australians, and this is despite the fact that they have made up only 19 per cent of all team members and have been able to compete in only 22 per cent of events.

More than half of the women in the paid work force in Australia earn less than $21,000 per year, while two-thirds of men have incomes greater than this figure. Australia's senior business managers, public servants and professionals are five to 10 times more likely to be men than women. I think that gives the House some indication that, if there is a myth abroad or a community perception that the battle has been won for Australian women—that is, that they do enjoy full opportunity and status for their contributions to Australian society—it is indeed a myth, and it is a myth which should be challenged. I think it is very successfully challenged by the very compelling evidence which this report details.

Apart from the pure factual data that this evidence provides, I think the House would be impressed by the quality of the evidence. In many instances, obviously a great deal of effort and time has gone into the writing of submissions for this inquiry. A great deal of commitment, of true passion, and unfortunately in many cases a degree of disillusionment, concerning the position of Australian women has been shown.

It is easy enough, I suppose, to go through the exercise, to collect this data and to portray a picture of contemporary Australian women. Where the exercise becomes far more difficult is in deciding why it is that this has occurred, why it is that this inequality persists and what can be done to overcome it.

In response to that challenge the Committee has put together some 79 recommendations. They are very broad ranging in their coverage and, I am pleased to say, in the vast majority of cases they have been agreed by all members of the Committee. There is a dissenting report on some recommendations, particularly those dealing with the operation of the Sex Discrimination Act and the affirmative action legislation and no doubt my colleagues will point to those particular points of disagreement.

I would like to concentrate on the matters of agreement, which form the vast majority of the Committee's recommendations. I think we found that there is no one answer; I do not think we expected to find one answer. There certainly is no one answer or solution to the problems and the difficulties that we have identified. Sure, there have been very big changes in the role of Australian women, most obviously in terms of their participation in paid work. That has altered quite dramatically, even over the last two decades. More than 50 per cent of Australian women are now in paid employment, and if one pays regard to the number of women under the age of 15 or 16 and the number of women over the age of 60, one will find that women of working age, women of pre-retirement age, constitute a very large proportion of Australian women in paid work.

Despite that change, there has been very little change in the role of Australian men. Women still continue to bear the brunt of responsibilities in the home and are the primary care givers; they carry the responsibilities for the maintenance of families and for extended family ties. They continue to play their traditional role. While this is a matter of choice and not to be attacked by any means, one can point to the fact that whilst women continue to carry this double burden, the range of opportunities available to them, and their ability to participate in other aspects of society, can be greatly hampered.

The Committee has focused on the position of women in paid employment. There are a number of recommendations which deal with the industrial system. We have also focused on recognition for unpaid work. That is an important part of this report, and I think it is time that this Parliament gave some close consideration to the recognition of unpaid and voluntary work. It is essential for the well-being of our community that this work not be taken for granted, as has so often been the case.

There is discussion on the position of Australian women in sport and leisure, and there are recommendations which flow from there; a brief preview of the position in training and education; and also mention of women with special needs—Aboriginal women, women from non-English speaking backgrounds, women with disabilities and women who live in remote and rural communities.

I will say no more about the report, but I would like to pay some tributes and give some thanks for the work that has gone into it. Firstly, I mention the staff of the Committee. A legion of staff has been involved in this report over the two years, but I will pay special tribute to the Committee Secretary, Kathy Townsend, who has put in enormous effort, through her own personal commitment, to the report. The previous Committee Secretary, Jon Stanhope, who was instrumental in gaining terms of reference and had a deep personal commitment to the inquiry, should be acknowledged. The other staff members who contributed their valuable time are Grant Harrison, Donna Christophers, Louise Carney, Ann Hazelton, Lorraine Ball, Sue Moreton and Margaret McCormack.

We have also had considerable help from people outside our staff and I would like to pay particular tribute to Dr Marion Sawer, who helped enormously in the preparation of some of the discussion papers and in making sure that the reports were accurate and on line. Also, Libby Darlinson contributed heavily to the discussion paper on the issue of women in sport.

Finally, I wish to thank my colleagues on the Committee. This inquiry went for a bit longer than two years. Throughout its great length it was conducted in a very good bipartisan spirit, and I very much welcome the cooperation which was forthcoming from my colleagues. I mention in particular the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman), the honourable member for McEwen (Mrs Bailey) and the honourable member for Forde (Ms Crawford), who were probably involved in most of the seminars, most of the public hearings and in the sub-committee deliberations. I thank my colleagues for their support and assistance in this invaluable work.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cadman Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to thank the Chairman of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, the honourable member for Fisher (Mr Lavarch), for his introductory remarks. There is much in what he said with which I would wish to identify myself. In fact, as he said, the report has proved to be largely bipartisan but in some areas there are differences.

PARA.TAB: In examining this subject, the Committee endeavoured to gain evidence and submissions from over half of the Australian population. As the Chairman said, there were over 600 submissions to the Committee and, as with all inquiries of this type and even with such a large number of submissions, one cannot be completely sure that one has covered the whole ground.

As well, as could be expected, much evidence came from those employed in the area of equal opportunity or affirmative action agencies. Regrettably, the sifting of evidence is most difficult when we are confronted by those who, for many reasons, feel that our society has let them down or been unfair. Many statements were subjective or even bitter; many of the complaints of discrimination or perceived unfair treatment could apply equally to men or women. The terms of reference, however, prevented us from looking at it in a broad sense, and maybe I felt at times that a broad look at unfair treatment of people by our society could have produced more substantial recommendations.

The objective of the Sex Discrimination Act 1984 is, in part, to alter attitudes in regard to women by making certain practices unlawful. Discrimination and harassment are the cornerstones of the Act. The title of the report, Half Way to Equal, implies that the Committee may have considered that Australian women are half equal to men. I reject that assumption and I believe that the majority of the Committee, if it had given proper attention to the title, would reject that also.

Equality of opportunity for men and women is an important ideal for Australians. Many steps have been taken over the past century to implement this ideal; yet in some areas it remains unfulfilled. Many issues were examined by the Committee and, in the great majority of recommendations, as the Chairman has said, there was agreement amongst the members. However, there was disagreement in a number of the most significant areas. The final draft of the report was considered by only four members of the Government and five members of the coalition.

In my view, the hasty processes of final consideration were most detrimental to reaching balanced conclusions and to making recommendations which are of lasting value to women in Australia. In my view, the processes adopted in the closing stages of the inquiry could be viewed as being detrimental to the advancement of Australian women. In some ways, in fact, this is a minority report, as only four members of the Government and five members of the Opposition were present at the last meeting. Whilst the Committee investigated many areas, of particular note are the findings with regard to unpaid voluntary, part time and casual work.

The huge contribution of women who are, as it was termed in the inquiry, `the administrators and managers of home affairs and future generations' has been largely ignored by feminist action groups. The activities of these women in our society have never been evaluated. It is time for those who extend care, support and assistance to their fellows to be recognised. For far too long—and this has often been encouraged by government funding—women in the unpaid work force have felt discriminated against compared with women who are in the paid work force.

In this desperate economic climate, the impact of women being forced out of their area of unpaid work into the paid work force can impose severe strains on the well-being of our community. Community organisations and homes, and employers of casual and part time workers, all suffer because women are forced, in many instances against their wishes, into full time paid work. The preferences of women to make their maximum contribution to our society is overlooked.

The Bureau of Statistics survey, which covered a large number of women, indicated that only 4 per cent of women prefer to work in full time paid work whilst their children are of school age and that 69 per cent prefer not to work at all whilst the children are of that age. In fact, of all the women who work, only 17.8 per cent are in full time paid jobs. But that number is increasing. In many instances, their decisions are not those of preference. Discrimination against women in unpaid work was, for me, one of most significant features of the inquiry. Organisations such as the Australian Family Association should be complimented for their thoughtful and factual contribution.

I come now to the dissenting report which was written by me and my colleagues the honourable member for Menzies (Mr Andrews), the honourable member for McEwen (Mrs Bailey), the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Costello), the honourable member for Ballarat (Mr Ronaldson) and the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair). The conclusion that we reached was:

SPEECH.PARA: Equality of opportunity and status for all Australians, including women, remains our objective. However, this objective will not be achieved by opinion, wishful thinking, preconceived notions of women's wishes, inadequate analysis of developments, or insufficient attention to the consequences of proposals. While the conduct of this inquiry has afforded a review of women in Australian society it remains incomplete and inadequate.

The main features of the dissenting report relates to the recommendations to change the Sex Discrimination Act and to some recommendations relating to the workplace. In our view, a series of recommendations to change the Act would lead to a significant codification and legalisation of the processes currently being used to resolve matters of discrimination and harassment. It was proffered by Government members that part of the grounds for unlawful acts would encompass the removal of the test of an action being not reasonable. In its place, it is proposed in the report to substitute as the definition the course of action which is the least discriminating in the circumstances. It sounds to be a play on words. Two examples easily demonstrate the need to retain the reasonable approach; for instance, a male counsellor on breastfeeding may not be acceptable to some women or a male pool attendant may not be acceptable to Islamic women. The least discriminatory course of action can, in these instances, completely cut across the intention of the recommendations. So we have dissented to that recommendation.

PARA.TAB: If this recommendation is linked with the recommendation that determination by the Human Rights Commission should become an enforceable order of the Federal Court in the absence of an appeal, this proposal will ensure that only those with legal representation will be courageous enough to go to the Commission. Nothing could be more daunting to anyone—let alone someone who may have been subject to demeaning discrimination—than to face the cross-examination or minute discovery of every aspect of a case.

We have rejected that course of action in favour of the current conciliation process. This process has produced settlement in 95 to 97 per cent of the cases. No thought seems to have been given to the women who have experienced discrimination or harassment nor to the high level of success that the conciliatory model achieves. The Opposition members have also completely rejected the recommendation that educational institutions established for religious purposes should now be subject to the provisions of the Act. This concept is an old one for socialists. Most of the world has decided where the boundaries to religious freedom lie. Here we see the ancient wish to interfere with the employment practices of non-government schools brought under the control of the State. Nothing could be a greater anathema to the freedom loving Australians. They have rejected these policies time and again.

In addition to the existing grounds of sex and marital status, we support the extension of discrimination within the Act to apply to those with family responsibilities and to the prospect of pregnancy. The report contains so much material relating to women in sport, education and the opportunities for girls and young women to expand their horizons in career prospects. So much of value has been done, but so much more could have been done if we had been a little more determined and timely in the closing stages of the inquiry.

At times during this inquiry, I must confess that I felt a deep sympathy for the many women who exhibited hurt and bitterness over the way in which life had dealt with them. One could not help feeling sad for the scarred and discouraged lives. I hope that Australian men and the institutions which serve our society will understand the implications for them. Regrettably, families suffer when economic and social pressures place excessive strain on the members of families. Women so often carry an inordinate share of the pressure. Commitment, care and unselfishness so often underlie the answer to resolving the problems that have been raised. Those attributes cannot be attained by legislation, but only by changes in personal attitudes, good role models and education.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the very few minutes that I have left here today, I would firstly like to commend the Chairman of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee, the honourable member for Fisher (Mr Lavarch), and other members of the Committee, for the effort that has been put into this inquiry over the last two years, which resulted in the Chairman tabling this report here today. I would also like to acknowledge the work of the secretariat, in particular in the latter stages of the inquiry and in the compilation of the report, of Ms Kathy Townsend and all of her staff.

PARA.TAB: As the Chairman and the previous speaker, the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman), have said, this report makes 79 recommendations covering women at work in both the paid and unpaid work force; women with special requirements, such as those who live in rural areas; women from non-English backgrounds; Aboriginal women; women in sport; women in our education and training systems; and recognition of women, to name just a few. To produce a report of this magnitude and in the time frame available to us is an indication of the degree of cooperation and goodwill among members of the Committee.

While supporting the majority of recommendations, as the Chairman has mentioned, the Opposition has included a dissenting report. We believe, and have grave concern, that some of the recommendations proposed could actually have the result of discriminating against women. In particular, I refer, though briefly because of time constraints, to recommendation 67 that the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission determinations be registrable in the Federal Court of Australia and that, in the absence of an appeal, they automatically become an enforceable order of the court. We believe this is moving away from the conciliation and educative model of the Commission, would work against women and would be very expensive.

It is not a comfortable process now for women to come forward to make a complaint of being sexually discriminated against. If that process were to move towards a more litigious system, we believe that could deter women from accessing the complaint process. Although there was some conflicting evidence disputing the claim by the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission that 97 per cent of cases are successfully conciliated or not proceeded with, there was overwhelming evidence pointing not only to the effectiveness of the conciliation model in settling complaints but also to the fact that the conciliation method, rather than an adversarial approach, is more likely to achieve more lasting results, especially in an employment context where parties, of necessity, have to maintain an ongoing relationship. We believe that the only people who will be advantaged by this recommendation will be the lawyers.

Another area of concern for us relates to the recommendations expanding affirmative action to include small business and the voluntary sector. We do not believe that this Committee can, or should, make such recommendations when it did not take comprehensive evidence on these subjects. In supporting that the Affirmative Action Agency be resourced to undertake qualitative assessment of reports received, we believe that it would be more appropriate to research these areas thoroughly and to evaluate the impact of such recommendations before recommending any action. The inquiry and evidence that this report is based on did not provide the necessary information on which to make such recommendations.

However, in the brief time available, I highlight some of the areas in this report that we believe have long needed attention and, hopefully, as a result of this report will receive the attention they deserve. The first of these is the superb work done by women as volunteers. The fabric of our society would be threadbare without it, but it is often undervalued and unrecognised. In reality, voluntary work makes a very significant contribution to the economic and social life of the nation, and many rural communities in particular would cease to function without it.

For these reasons we believe it is important to undertake a study to determine the nature and extent of voluntary work as well as to gather information concerning those who give their time and labour voluntarily and the skills that women gain from voluntary work in organisation, management and communication. These could be recognised as appropriate training skills in the paid work force.

I would particularly like to draw the attention of the House to a group of women who are frequently overlooked and omitted from studies: rural women. I am very pleased to see that they were not overlooked in this study. Almost 2 1/2 million women live outside urban areas. While the percentage of farms has been decreasing, the number of women who are farmers in their own right or who manage farms has been increasing. Rural women frequently have workloads equivalent to two or three full time jobs, but are often described as not having a job. Many describe their occupation as home duties when there is clear evidence that they undertake an enormous range of voluntary community work and often describe farm work, which can range from driving the tractor, dipping sheep or doing the books, as home duties. The most recent estimate of the contribution that rural women make to the national economy was the 1986 estimate by the National Farmer magazine of $6m annually. Hopefully, the recommendations contained in this report, in particular a revision of the agricultural census, will remedy this situation and will achieve for rural women the recognition they deserve.

I would also like to mention our strong support for the recommendations relating to superannuation, specifically those provisions relating to the interrupted work patterns of women in the paid work force and investigating the possibility of accessing a proportion of superannuation savings towards the purchase of accommodation. I must add that, while this report makes these recommendations, the coalition's Fightback program has already led the way and adopted these measures as policy. In fact, the Fightback program goes further for women, particularly for women at home in the unpaid work force, by allowing spouses and partners to make superannuation contributions on their behalf. That is positive recognition of the value of women's work in the unpaid work force.

For women in both the paid and unpaid work force child-care is a critical issue, particularly for women and children with disabilities. We particularly want to commend the Committee for recommending the elimination of duplication between all three levels of government and for recommending that the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services needs to reassess its fee relief structure. We believe that there should be no discrimination between women in the paid work force and those at home in the unpaid work force. Any two-tiered approach to fee relief for child-care would make women in the unpaid work force second-class citizens—and we will never support that.

I reiterate that we support the majority of the recommendations in this report, apart from the main areas that both my colleague and I have mentioned. However, we would add that, in spite of the diversity of public opinion sought, it is disappointing that there are not more recommendations for older women, as they are an increasing percentage of our population, and that there is no recommendation concerning women involved in domestic violence. Although domestic violence has been increasing at an alarming rate, it is continually ignored by all levels of government, the judiciary, the police and society at large. There is nothing more debilitating, nothing that reduces a woman's self-esteem more and nothing that reduces her choices more, than being the victim of domestic violence.

In conclusion, it is our hope that the recommendations contained in this report do not become entangled in political theory and ideology, but are able to be translated into fair and practical measures that will benefit not only the highly educated and articulate women but the lives of all women.
Debate (on motion by Mr Lindsay) adjourned.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade I present a report entitled Report on the Visit of the Defence Sub-Committee of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade to Nurrungar-Woomera and Northern Territory, October 1991, and I seek leave of the House to make a short statement in connection with the report.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Defence Subcommittee has a long tradition of inspecting defence establishments and units across Australia. In line with this tradition, last October the Defence Subcommittee inspected the joint defence facilities at Nurrungar and Pine Gap and several defence establishments in the Northern Territory. The decision by the Defence Subcommittee to visit northern Australia reflects the recent focus of defence planners on the north. In August last year the Subcommittee conducted the first phase of its inspections of northern defence establishments when it visited north Queensland and the Torres Strait. This report describes the second phase of the Subcommittee's inspections in the north.

PARA.TAB: This visit coincided with the final stages of the Subcommittee's inquiry into the Australian Defence Force reserves. The inquiry benefited from the opportunity given to the Subcommittee to inspect the Reserve force called Norforce, which is one of three regional force surveillance units located in northern Australia. Norforce was raised on 1 July 1981 to provide a tactical ground surveillance capability in the Top End. It is on 28 days notice to move for operations.

The Subcommittee inspected soldiers of the Darwin Squadron, Norforce, based on Melville and Bathurst islands. Members were impressed by both the high calibre of the Reserve soldiers and the high standard of the unit. The inspections of Norforce resulted in members of the Subcommittee gaining a wider appreciation of Reserve operations in the difficult conditions of the north.

The visit to the Northern Territory provided opportunities for the Subcommittee to inspect RAAF bases Tindal and Darwin. We were briefed on the respective roles of these two bases. Some concern was expressed to the Subcommittee that some projects had been delayed as a result of uncertainty about the future of RAAF Base Darwin in the light of the role ascribed to Tindal. The view was put to the Subcommittee that RAAF Base Darwin can only be defended from Darwin and that this cannot be done effectively from Tindal. The Subcommittee was made aware that some concerns are held, firstly, about the impact of civilianisation in the particular situation of the Darwin base in a cyclone and, secondly, about the impact of defence regional support review on operational readiness at Darwin.

Given the expansion of the defence presence in northern Australia, the Subcommittee was briefed on recent developments in the north by the Commander Northern Command, Brigadier Frank Hickling. We were told about the impact of the force structure review on the northern area with respect to the continuing build-up of defence strength, particularly through the relocation of 2 Cavalry Regiment to the Darwin area.

The briefing given by the Naval Officer Commanding Northern Australia, Captain Tim Lewis, complemented the briefings on surveillance of the northern coastline provided during the Subcommittee's earlier trip to north Queensland. The Subcommittee gained an appreciation of some of the difficulties encountered in patrolling northern waters, and the ease with which fishing boats could be camouflaged successfully in the mangroves of estuarine waters was clearly demonstrated to us.

The Subcommittee's itinerary included the joint facilities at Nurrungar and Pine Gap. While members appreciated the opportunity to see facilities at first hand, it should be noted that the Subcommittee received an unclassified briefing. The Subcommittee was very concerned to find that publicly available printed knowledge of the joint facilities exceeded the information which was made available to the Subcommittee during the briefing. Indeed, the Subcommittee noted that information appearing on the congressional record of the United States is not made officially available to Australian members of parliament.

I led that Subcommittee visit as Chairman of the Defence Subcommittee. I was accompanied by Senator MacGibbon, the Deputy Chairman; Senator Brownhill from New South Wales; the honourable member for Berowra (Dr Harry Edwards); the honourable member for Hunter (Mr Fitzgibbon); the honourable member for Casey (Mr Halverson), a former RAAF senior officer; the honourable member for Riverina-Darling (Mr Hicks); the honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore), a former Minister; and the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair), a former Minister for Defence. We received an unclassified briefing.

One may very well wonder in what light the members of the Subcommittee are regarded. As members of this Parliament, are they regarded as being trustworthy by the defence establishment and capable of receiving a classified briefing? Whereas members of the United States Congress and Senate are able to receive a briefing, members of our own Parliament and members of the Defence Subcommittee are unable to receive one. I find it totally unacceptable that this situation should obtain.

TALK.START.PARA: —Outrageous.

—It is outrageous, as the honourable member has said. At Nurrungar, the Subcommittee was told that a significant change had been made to the position of the deputy commander, who is the Government of Australia representative. The deputy commander is now fully briefed and therefore in a position to take over fully the joint defence facility at Nurrungar. The Subcommittee observed, however, that the change in the position of the Government of Australia representative was not reflected in the relationship which exists between the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) and the media with respect to public disclosure of information. Information which is publicly available in Australia does not parallel that which is publicly available in the United States.

PARA.TAB: Nonetheless, the Subcommittee is appreciative of the efforts made by all concerned in the arrangements for the inspections and for the opportunities provided for informal discussions. Subcommittee members are also grateful to the Minister for Defence for making the special purpose aircraft available to the Subcommittee. It greatly assisted members of the Subcommittee in carrying out this visit. I commend the report to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I wish to make a few observations about the report entitled Report on the Visit of the Defence Sub-Committee of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade to Nurrungar-Woomera and Northern Territory, October 1991, to which the honourable member for Herbert (Mr Lindsay) has just referred. I will start by commenting on the matter to which he referred in respect of the joint facilities.

PARA.TAB: I found it a little embarrassing, as one who is fully briefed on the joint facilities—as is my colleague the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock)—in that my colleagues were advised so little about the nature of the activities of the facilities. I find it even more embarrassing that those who are members of the United States Congress are given a far more comprehensive briefing than is available to any member of the Australian Parliament—other than those who are in the small category of the Ministry and, as I understand it, a few in the Opposition. There may be a few others but, if there are, I am not aware of them.

I want to say three things about this. Firstly, it is totally unacceptable, in a joint facility, for a greater measure of disclosure to be available to the American partner and its parliamentary representatives than to the Australian partner. It is no use explaining that the United States Congress has a different responsibility. As far as the Australian people are concerned, we are in a direct line—having been elected to represent them—to the same measure as the members of the United States Congress represent the American people.

Although the United States has a different constitutional structure, it should not be in the transcripts of congressional committees that we read of the nature and activities of those joint facilities. Indeed, it has been remarkable that over the years men such as Professor Ball have been able to produce and publish in Australia almost all of the information they had on the facilities using the congressional record. It is something which I believe the Government needs to address.

The second point is that it is important for people to understand that in this post-Cold War era the nature and character of the obligations of those joint facilities are changing. It is even more important that there is within the Australian Parliament—certainly for the Defence Subcommittee, for a select number of other people, and certainly for those who are representatives of the Senate and the House of Representatives—an opportunity to receive some briefings on the changed direction.

The third point that worries me equally is that we are told that there is to be a greater measure of Australian involvement. That means that this Parliament has a greater obligation as to the funds which are directed there. As this report comments, it is surprising that the financial contribution at the moment goes to the Alice Springs area. For example, we have referred to the fact that about 20 per cent of the input of the whole Pine Gap facility goes into the Alice Springs area. That represents $28.5m in salaries, local contracting at a value of $17m, local purchasing of supplies in the region of $7m, rentals at $42.2m, and donations amounting to $250,000. All of us who have been to Alice Springs understand this. It even has one of the best baseball diamonds in Australia, and it is all because of the American involvement. But let us be realistic; if the Government wishes to change the nature of the Australian involvement, it is even more critical that we should be briefed on the subject.

It is important that we pay tribute to the work being undertaken by Norforce. All those northern surveillance, reconnaissance and patrol units—the 51st Far North Queensland Rifles, the Pilbara regiment and Norforce are three—operate in a magnificent way with the local people. I have now been fortunate to see each of them in action on a number of occasions.

The work they do needs to be commended. They virtually have the same role in war as they have in peace, and I am told that much of the work they do has as much relevance to civilian requirements and surveillance as it does to military requirements in time of war. We have worries about boat people landing in the north, and it should be said that in many ways Norforce and its parallel units are very much the eyes and ears of the people of the north. The observations they make of the activities of people in the region are of enormous value. They are very fine elements of the Australian Defence Force and I would like to pay particular tribute to them.

There are, of course, other aspects of the report which I would like to mention but cannot address now. However I should comment—and the honourable member for Kooyong is in the House—that the decision the coalition Government took concerning the establishment of the main RAAF base at Tindal is one of which I remain inordinately proud. More than anything else that decision gave momentum to the further development of the RAAF's presence in northern Australia. It has enabled a base squadron to operate from there and to ensure that the other bare bases that operate in Western Australia, the Northern Territory and in future in the northern tip of Cape York are going to be able to provide the air cover that is very much a complementary part of the defence assessment that is commonly accepted by both sides of this Parliament.
