DEBATE.TITLE: CRIMES (TRAFFIC IN NARCOTIC DRUGS AND PSYCHOTROPIC SUBSTANCES) AMENDMENT BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 5 March, on motion by Mr Duncan:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last night when the adjournment motion was moved I was part heard on the Crimes (Traffic in Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances) Amendment Bill 1992 and the Opposition's response to it. I had indicated that we were not opposing the Bill, but that we had three concerns. We had one particular and deep concern about proposed section 8A. I was indicating the depth of our concern and detailing many of the authorities behind the factors that I was raising. I was saying that, given the net cast by the provisions of the principal Act in terms of offences relating to dealings with drugs is extremely wide, it is wholly inappropriate, as the Gibbs committee recognised, for the requisite mental element of such offences as are covered by this Bill to be anything less than recklessness.

PARA.TAB: To give an example, provision is made for an offence of manufacturing, transporting or distributing any substance, equipment or material with the knowledge that such articles may be used for a purpose relating to a dealing in drugs. If the test in proposed section 8A were adopted, that is without qualification, innocent persons could be prosecuted in circumstances where they had no actual knowledge that, first, the article in question was within their control and, second, the relevant article was to be used for such an illegal purpose.

Such a result would be contrary to the position taken by the High Court in the 1985 decision of He Kaw Teh v. the Queen. In that case it was held that, for the purposes of a prosecution under the Customs Act, it must be established that the defendant knew of the existence of the prohibited imports in whatever receptacle he was carrying them. In contrast, if proposed section 8A became law—and again I emphasise if it became law without qualification—the prosecution would need to prove only that the defendant ought to have known of the existence of the prohibited imports. I cannot overemphasise the importance of the fundamental principle that criminal intent can never be imputed; it must always be established firmly and unequivocally by the prosecution.

Those are the factors behind the concern that we have in relation to proposed section 8A. I said last night that we support the Bill, that we support strong measures against drugs. The Crimes (Traffic in Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances) Amendment Bill is the sort of measure that ought be supported, notwithstanding our concerns. I emphasise the depth of our concern regarding the question of presumptions and assumptions of knowledge.

It is important for the sake of the record that our concerns be noted and that the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) or his representative—I see the Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney General (Mr Duncan) is here—address the matters that I raised last night in summing up the debate. In passing measures designed to deter and properly punish criminal activity, the Parliament must never lose sight of the ultimate objective—the preservation of individual liberty. Any proposed legislation which may weaken the safeguards for ensuring that every individual receives a fair and proper trial in accordance with the traditions of our common law must be subjected to the most vigorous scrutiny.

TALK.START.PARA: —On February 14 1989 Australia signed the 1988 United Nations Convention Against Illicit Traffic in Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances. The purpose of the United Nations convention is to encourage and develop international cooperation in a wide range of measures designed to stamp out the illicit drug trade. The European Economic Community and about 55 countries have ratified the convention. However, before Australia can ratify the convention it must ensure that its laws and administrative practices are established so as to give effect to its obligations under the convention. This Bill is designed to fill the so-called gaps in State and Territory legislation and thereby satisfy the various obligations under the drug trafficking convention until appropriate State and Territory legislation has been put into effect.

PARA.TAB: I understand that there has been international pressure on Australia to ratify the convention as soon as possible. I know the Federal Government is keen to ratify the convention. It should also be said that if Australia is to encourage other countries to accept the convention, particularly in Latin America, Asia and the Pacific, it would be in a more persuasive position if it had ratified the drug trafficking convention.

Furthermore, ratification of the convention is one of the recommendations of the financial action task force on money laundering. Australia is a strong supporter of the financial action task force. Indeed, the new Chairman of the National Crime Authority, Mr Tom Sherman, is to become chairman of the task force during 1992-93. The financial action task force will meet in Australia in September this year under his chairmanship. In addition, Australia is currently the subject of a financial action task force evaluation as to what progress Australia has made in implementing the recommendations of the task force—and one of those, as I said earlier, was ratification of the convention. A task force team was recently in Australia to examine these matters. The task force will consider the team's report on Australia's progress on this issue on 14 May. It need hardly be said that Australia could be subject to valid criticism if Australia does not ratify the drug trafficking convention.

Obligations prescribed by the convention which come within Commonwealth legislative responsibility are met by existing legislation, such as the Customs Act 1901, the Proceeds of Crime Act 1987, the Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters Act 1987 and the Extradition Act 1988. As a consequence of article 4 of the convention, which deals with jurisdiction, new Commonwealth legislation was necessary. The Crimes (Traffic in Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances) Act 1990 gives effect to the extraterritorial jurisdiction prescribed in article 4. The States and Territories have responsibility for certain other obligations. Therefore, in order to preserve existing State-Territory and Commonwealth relations, and the State-Territory and Commonwealth balance of responsibilities in the drugs area, the Commonwealth has sought cooperation in enacting legislation to meet mandatory convention obligations. This contributes to preserving existing arrangements with respect to enforcement agencies such as drug squads, courts and prisons.

Three jurisdictions—Tasmania, Western Australia and the Northern Territory—are in the process of enacting legislation to meet the requirements of the convention. These areas of legislation include issues such as money laundering and the confiscation of the proceeds of crime. Nevertheless, the exigencies of the situation require this Bill to be passed as soon as possible if ratification of the convention by Australia is to become effective.

This Bill does not create any drug offences but defines various offences called `serious State drug offences' involving `dealing in drugs'. These are serious offences which are identified by the convention and which are also State-Territory offences. The phrase `dealing in drugs' is defined in clause 4, within the terms of the convention.

The Bill contains three new proposed sections, namely, 15A, 15B and 15C, which will make it a Commonwealth offence to launder money or other property known to be acquired or otherwise obtained from one of these `serious State drug offences'. These proposed new Commonwealth offences created in the sections are based on the drug trafficking convention and indeed follow its terminology closely, having regard to article 3.

Upon conviction of these offences, the provisions of the Commonwealth Proceeds of Crime Act 1987 will apply with respect to `tainted property'. This will ensure that those jurisdictions that do not yet have appropriate legislation with respect to the confiscation of proceeds of crime will now be able to rely upon the provisions of this Bill.

The Bill also provides for a new section 22. This will enable regulations to be made limiting the offence provisions relating to money laundering to States and Territories which are not prescribed. These prescribed jurisdictions are those where there is legislation making it an offence to launder money. This means that the legislation will apply only to those jurisdictions which have not enacted money laundering provisions. In view of the limited amount of time, I will close my remarks by complimenting the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock) on what was a very informative and learned speech.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duncan The Hon P.

TALKER.NAME: Mr DUNCAN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney-General)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—In closing the debate on the Crimes (Traffic in Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances) Amendment Bill, I want to thank all honourable members who have taken part, particularly the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock). I thought his contribution was sensitive and positive. Whilst I did not quite agree with some of the conclusions he made, I know that he made them with the best intention—that being, of course, that we get the best piece of legislation out of and through the Parliament.

PARA.TAB: The honourable member for Kooyong dealt with a number of issues in his contribution, particularly last evening, and I want to deal with those as he raised them. Firstly, there is the issue of Commonwealth-State responsibilities. The first point I want to make is that it was not the objective of this Bill to alter State, Territory and Commonwealth relations and balance of responsibilities in the drug area. The purpose of the Bill is to make the minimum necessary changes to the law that will enable Australia to ratify the 1988 United Nations Convention Against Illicit Traffic in Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances without further delay.

The Bill is, therefore, intended to apply only in those States and Territories which have not yet enacted legislation to make it an offence to launder money or property which is derived from drug trafficking. Of course, the provisions of the Bill will not apply in those States and Territories which have enacted money laundering legislation and, where it does apply, the Bill will cease to apply once jurisdictions have enacted legislation on money laundering.

Consultations with the States and the Northern Territory took place in December 1985, informing them of the proposals for negotiating a new drug convention. Those consultations have continued since February 1989, when Australia signed the new convention. That was more than three years ago and, although all States and Territories have expressed their willingness to enact appropriate legislation, some have not yet done so. All States have been consulted about the legislation before the House and, with one exception, there is no objection.

If a State or Territory wishes to do so—and we are speaking here of only three jurisdictions affected—the timetable would operate in this way: Australia's instrument of ratification will not be lodged until after the Bill now before the House is enacted; entry into force of the convention for Australia will not occur until 90 days from that lodgment. On the assumption that this Bill would pass both Houses during May, that leaves until some time in September at the earliest before supporting legislation would need to commence. If States and Territories can enact and bring into force their legislation by that date, I see no need for the Commonwealth legislation to become operative in relation to them at all. However, I do believe that we still need to press on with this Bill to cover the possibility that one or more jurisdictions will not have met the mandatory convention obligations in full by that date.

Clearly, it is neither the purpose nor the practical effect of the Bill to change the present balance of responsibilities between the States and Territories and the Commonwealth in the drugs area. I would simply repeat that all States have expressed their willingness to pass this legislation, but for various reasons three jurisdictions have not yet come into line.

I now want to turn to the issue of the threshold of 12 months. The 12-month threshold is necessary in the definition of `serious State drug offence' in order to catch all the relevant `drug offences' under State and Territory legislation and to bring them within the terms of the convention. An alternative approach would have been to ensure that all relevant drug offences were punishable by whatever higher penalty might be thought appropriate to attract the laundering offence, but that would involve an unnecessary change to existing penalty levels. So it was thought that the best way to do it was with a 12-month threshold.

I now want to turn to the issue of knowledge and purpose which was raised by the honourable member for Kooyong. This is an important issue which he has raised and one which I do not think can be rushed in our dealing with it. These words are used in the offence provisions of the Bill in sections 15A, 15B and 15C, which provide, for example:

SPEECH.PARA: Any person who, knowing that any property was derived from a serious State drug offence. . . converts that property to his or her own use. . . for the purpose of. . . concealing or disguising that the property was derived from the offence. . .
Those words are also used in the principal Act, for example in section 9:
A person who has in his or her possession, in Australia, any substance. . . knowing that the substance, equipment or materials are being used or are to be used in, or for, a dealing in drugs. . .

PARA.TAB: Firstly, the mental element does not alter the present common law. I will return to that in a moment. This legislation is intended to give effect to certain provisions of an international convention. It is being enacted under the external affairs power and, to avoid any doubts about it being within its power, should follow the language of the convention.

Paragraph (3), dealing with the elements of the specified offences, is an integral part of article 3 of the convention, which describes the conduct that is to be made the subject of the required offences. The inclusion of the language of paragraph (3) in the law creating the offences removes any argument that the statute, by describing the offences without reference to the particular wording of paragraph (3), intended to exclude the method of proof referred to in paragraph (3). The safest course in creating offences set out in the treaty is to follow the language of the treaty as fully as may be convenient. The Australian statute can be expected to be scrutinised in the course of the United Nations review of all national laws enacted to give effect to the convention and required by its article to be supplied to the United Nations.

The inclusion of proposed section 8A shows that, subject to Australian law, we have given effect to that provision of the convention that says that knowledge, intent or purpose in drug offences set out in the convention can be inferred from objective factual circumstances. It is clear that this provision has effect within the relevant principles of Australian criminal law.

I now turn to the suggestion that the offence provisions, as drafted within proposed section 8A, offend against existing principles of criminal liability by introducing an objective test instead of requiring actual knowledge or intent. This simply is not so. The court must be satisfied as to actual knowledge or intent on the part of the defendant. Under existing law, such knowledge or intention may be inferred from proven objective circumstances. This was made clear in the case of Pereira v. the Director of Public Prosecutions, to which the honourable member for Kooyong referred last evening. I entirely accept the considerations to be observed in making use of such evidence that were set out by the High Court in Pereira's case. I think there were three qualifications. I have no doubt that a court, in construing the proposed subsection 8A(1), would apply the test as set out in Pereira's case—that is, by using the words set out in the proposed subsection 8A(1), the law as stated in Pereira's case would then apply.

With reference to the fault elements, which were analysed by the Committee for the Review of Commonwealth Criminal Law, chaired by Sir Harry Gibbs, in relation to the various mens rea possibilities the Committee recommended the use of the concepts of knowingly, intentionally, recklessly and negligently. Each of those mental states is quite different from the others. We do not need to discuss when one or the other of them is appropriate. The provisions of the Bill before the House are directed to instances in which the fault elements are knowledge, intention or purpose. It deals with the method of proof and does not alter the existing law as to how those elements are to be proven. I commend the Bill to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
The Bill

TALK.START.PARA: —I simply note that the Opposition opposes clause 4A.

DEBATE.TITLE: CONSTRUCTION INDUSTRY REFORM AND DEVELOPMENT BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 25 March, on motion by Mr Beddall:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charles Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Construction Industry Reform and Development Bill 1992 is to establish the Construction Industry Development Council and the Construction Industry Development Agency as part of the Government's so-called construction industry reform strategy. The Council is intended to be an industry forum and to advise the Government on its so-called strategy. The agency which will be incorporated and have its own chief executive officer is to implement the strategy but the agency will have only a limited life, ceasing to exist on 30 June 1995.

PARA.TAB: Both the Council and the agency are part of an extravagant Government initiative called the building industry reform strategy, which the Government says is integral to its program of micro-economic reform. This highly structured tripartite exercise was announced by the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) in September 1990. It has involved several departments and Ministers, has generated a steady stream of documentation, committees and committee reports, draft codes, in-principle agreements, et cetera, and has been replete with seminars and prime ministerial launches. Twenty months later, the exercise has cost several million dollars and is expected to cost an additional $11m during the next three years. To date all it has generated is talk of reform and the creation of a bureaucracy to achieve it.

The coalition opposes this legislation and its intrusive mechanisms. It is clear that the Government is pre-empting the Gyles Royal Commission into Productivity in the Building Industry in New South Wales which may bring down recommendations which will make this legislation totally unnecessary. Moreover, the transfer of $1.5m worth of surplus funds from the Construction Employees Redundancy Trust to the Construction Industry Development Agency created by this Bill is of questionable legality. Certainly the Commissioner in the New South Wales inquiry, Mr Gyles, has been reported as saying that the transfer involved a very serious legal question as to whether or not it was an appropriate procedure.

Time and time again, Australians have been told that we have one of the world's most competitive housing industries. That same efficiency, however, does not translate to major building construction including offices, schools, hospitals, hotels and churches. One estimate is that full unionisation of medium density housing construction in Sydney will produce a cost of $1,100 per square metre compared with $600 per square metre for the non-unionised home building industry. The Housing Industry Association was reported today as stating:

SPEECH.PARA: Building companies which operate in unionised medium-density housing estimate that labour productivity is 40% below sub-contract labour in non-unionised housing sites. If labour costs were to increase by 40% on housing sites because of productivity losses the cost of an average $100,000 home would increase by $16,000. Some case studies show that extra costs of 35% are not uncommon where a housing site is unionised.

In the State of Victoria today a bricklayer will charge around 38c to lay one face brick for a house—remember that, 38c. If that same bricklayer were to lay the same brick for a factory, a school or a church he would receive around 73c for the same work. This massive difference of almost 100 per cent is that the major construction industry is unionised with prices controlled by cartels and with legislated and legalised restrictive work practices enhanced by the `no ticket, no start' rule.

PARA.TAB: On the other hand, the housing sector is dominated by small builders using independent subcontractors in a competitive environment. The royal commission in New South Wales commissioned a survey which revealed that building workers themselves wanted their trade unions to have less influence and inflict less interference. The workers viewed the building unions as a major impediment to labour reform and the smooth running of building sites.

It might prove helpful to honourable members for me to briefly review some of the statements made by the Minister in his second reading speech which he incorporated in the Senate on 19 December 1991. He said:
This Bill represents an important part of the Government's construction industry reform strategy.

SPEECH.PARA: On 3 December 1991 the then Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, in a speech launching the Government's industry reform strategy, said:

The construction industry reform strategy marks the beginning of a cooperative effort to solve some of the most intractable, I repeat intractable, issues in this vital industry and to nurture its considerable strengths. Costs for major projects are estimated to be up to 20 per cent higher than those of our major competitors.
That was from our ex-Prime Minister.

PARA.TAB: It is true in every sense of the word that Australia's major construction industry requires reform. A more inefficient, intractable, contrived and controlled industry would be difficult to find. Industrial relations mechanisms are archaic and the inefficiencies following from archaic and historical work practices are literally beyond belief.

I will leave for others to describe construction industry rorts, failings and inefficiencies with respect to the industry in New South Wales and Queensland. I will concentrate on my home State of Victoria. In a very real sense, I came to this Parliament out of frustration over my inability to help to effect reform in the construction industry in Victoria from within that industry. It was my spectacular lack of success in dealing with entrenched interests in the club that led to my candidacy for the seat of La Trobe at the election which was held on 24 March 1990. Anyone who read my maiden speech in this place would have no doubt that that was so.

Reform is the basis of this Bill. I confirm that the major construction industry in Australia is in desperate need of reform. We have no competition in an external sense for construction of major buildings. We cannot build 50-storey skyscrapers in downtown Melbourne and ship them to Hong Kong. Inefficiencies in our major construction industry cost the taxpayer in increased costs of construction for public works projects which run on into increased borrowings and costs to fund government Budget deficits. It is the Australian community, our society, which pays for construction industry rorts and malpractice through decreased standards of living for each and every one of us.

If we need a hospital or a school, there is no competition for the publicly owned hospital or for the publicly owned school in a real sense, so that cost inefficiencies and capital acquisition never face the searing heat of real competition. The Australian building and construction industry is a giant cartel supported and controlled by the industrial relations club. Giant vested interests will support this Bill and build the worst and most expensive of practices into a national code of conduct.

The Minister in his second reading speech said that the purpose of the Bill was to establish the Construction Industry Development Agency and the Construction Industry Development Council. The Minister said:

SPEECH.PARA: The in-principle agreement commits the parties to improve the performance of the industry to world-class practice and standards. It identifies specific areas where improved efficiency and productivity can be achieved.

The agency, the Council and the in-principle agreement commit the `club'—that is, major building contractors; building owners and managers; the major unions, being largely today the BWIU; the industry associations; State industrial relations departments; the Federal Industrial Relations Department; and, ultimately the grandaddy of them all, the Australian Industrial Relations Commission—to say nice things about each other and come to an agreement to further centralise wages and conditions of employment in Australia's construction industry.

PARA.TAB: Reform in terms of this exercise will undoubtedly mean the adoption of a national code of conduct for the industry which will pick the best, or the worst—depending on how one views the issues of the points—of the various State codes of conduct for building and construction. The current code of conduct in Victoria for the Department for Planning and Housing requires building contractors and all their subcontractors to adhere to the awards, to adhere to the national wage case, to prohibit all-in payments and to make certain that the Victorian Building Industry Agreement, which requires `no ticket, no start', is incorporated.

In so far as the reform strategy addresses building regulations, we on this side of the House have no quarrel with the established groups. But we have a great deal of difficulty in accepting and approving the `club' having any involvement in the reform of building industry industrial relations or practice. In order to implement the Government's plan for reform, a highly structured so-called tripartite organisation has been established which basically involves the making of another bureaucracy made up from a number of significant players in the industry.

As at December 1991 the parties to the agreement were the Commonwealth Government and the governments of Victoria, South Australia, the ACT and Western Australia—note Queensland and New South Wales are not included—the Australian Federation of Construction Contractors, the Master Builders Construction and Housing Association of Australia, the MTIA-National Construction Council, the Operative Painters and Decorators Union of Australia, the Metals and Engineering Workers Union, the Electrical Contractors Association of Australia, the Building Owners and Managers Association of Australia, the Building Industry Specialist Contractors Organisation of Australia, the Plumbers and Gasfitters Employees Union of Australia, the Building Workers Industrial Union, the Federated Engine Drivers and Firemen's Association of Australia, the Electrical Trades Union of Australia, the Australian Earthmovers and Road Contractors Federation, the Australian Workers Union and, last but not least, the Master Plumbers and Mechanical Services Association of Australia; a rather unwieldy group.

To date, the parties have agreed on a great number of motherhood-type statements, but all with the central design and purpose of producing uniformity throughout the industry under the banner of centralised agreement and control. The Iron Curtain may well have fallen in Germany, but we are now in the process of re-erecting that curtain around our island continent of Australia in so far as building construction is concerned. The in-principle agreement commits all parties to achieving specific objectives. It specifies performance standards for contractors, but not for employees. It agrees on commonality and uniformity—one would assume at the lowest common denominator. On the use of public works to enforce the in-principle agreement it states:

SPEECH.PARA: The industry parties note the express acknowledgment by Commonwealth, State and Territory Ministers of the need to use the purchasing power of government as a vehicle for implementation of the reform process.

In case anyone in this place is in any doubt as to the meaning of that statement, let me simply put to the House that it is the intent of the agreement to use publicly funded capital works projects to reduce the number of building contractors, reduce the number of employer organisations in the industry and achieve uniformity, undoubtedly at the expense of productivity, and a reduction in the number of projects we will be able to construct for the number of dollars we have available to spend.

PARA.TAB: It seems that no-one intends to ask the small or medium sized building contractors how they would apply their innovative solutions to building construction to achieve improved productivity and lower costs. These innovative small and medium sized companies will be not be asked their views of what constitutes a restrictive work practice, or how to eliminate it. This Bill is a recipe for disaster in terms of construction cost efficiency. One need only look at the very marked difference in cost efficiency between the largely subcontract oriented housing building sector and major construction to be immediately convinced of the error of continuing down the path of centralised regulation and control. This Bill is an ACTU Bill. It is a `club' Bill. It is not a user's Bill. It is not a taxpayer's Bill.

Government speakers in this debate will undoubtedly raise the charge of scaremongering with respect to those who claim that this Bill may provide a pathway for the BWIU to infiltrate the housing industry. The fact is that the Bill establishes a mechanism for regulation which will give the unions their desired foothold. I refer honourable members to Victoria where home building contractors, faced with a totally unionised roof tiling trade sector, switched to steel deck roofs, only to find that the regulatory authorities then decreed that only a licensed plumber with a union ticket would be able to fix a metal tray deck roof—compulsory union membership ipso facto.

The second leg of the Minister's efforts to destroy subcontracting will be contained in amendments to the Industrial Relations Act yet to be proclaimed which will allow the AIRC to meddle in contracts of employment or engagement with respect to contractors or subcontractors. The Minister's third mechanism will be amendments to section 45D of The Trade Practices Act, to water down sanctions against unions and allow them to take militant industrial action to force employers to hire employees, rather than contractors, and extend compulsory union membership into the housing sector.

The Victorian Building Industry Agreement is a model industry code of practice established by major contractors and major unions, and without competitive pressure. High holding costs associated with major construction and the fragmented nature of the industry have allowed the unions to pressure employers with demands which, under competitive situations, they might well have rejected. It is these demands which have resulted in inefficient and sometimes unconscionable work practices already entrenched in the industry which will be further set in concrete and cast in place should this Parliament support this legislation.

The Victorian Building Industry Agreement says in clause 6.4 that financial union membership is regulated by the agreement. A fundamental breach is where an employer—an employer only—is alleged to be in fundamental breach of the terms and conditions of the agreement, and the employees affected by that alleged breach may decline to work as directed in the area affected by the alleged breach. There is absolutely nothing about an employee's breach of contract.

The disputes board is a board set aside to determine the rationality of disputes within the construction industry. It shall determine whether an employer has committed a fundamental breach of the terms and conditions of the agreement, the terms of resolution of the dispute, and entitlements to payment where employees have declined to work as directed because of such a breach. Again there is no mention of a breach by employees. The next clause reads:

SPEECH.PARA: And provided further that in the event of a dispute over Union membership, the Board shall determine whether an employer has taken reasonable steps to implement the Union membership checking procedure, as per Clause 19.
All of the impetus of control and performance is upon the employer.

PARA.TAB: Clause 14 is entitled `Superannuation/Long Service Leave'. Clause 14.1 states:

SPEECH.PARA: All parties agree to cooperate and undertake the following responsibilities as appropriate for the purpose of seeking to ensure that the relevant approved Superannuation Scheme, the Construction Industry Long Service Leave Act, the Accident Compensation Act and the Redundancy Payment Central Fund Ltd. Scheme are observed.
The number of on-costs in the construction industry in Victoria as a result of this agreement are as long as one's arm. It continues:
The employee alleged not to have coverage for Superannuation, Long Service Leave, WorkCare or Redundancy, shall cease work.
So, if an employer has not covered a person for redundancy, he shall not work. Heaven forbid! Clause 15 is headed `All-in payments'. Clause 15.1 states:
It is acknowledged that the all-in method of payment to employees contravenes this Agreement.

15.1.1 All-in Payments means any system of payment that is hourly, weekly or daily, which is either in lieu of payment for overtime, or in lieu of one or more of the various Award conditions such as Annual Leave, Public Holiday payments, Inclement Weather . . .
That includes picnic days, et cetera. Clause 18 is headed `Rostered days off'. Clause 18.1 states:
The parties agree that, subject to Sub-Clause 18.2.1, the following prescribed rostered days off for 1990, 1991 and 1992 are programmed to ensure some fall together with Public Holidays . . .
That is so that we can have long weekends. Is that not cute? Clause 19.1 states:
The parties to this No Ticket-No Start Agreement, agree to abide by the following procedure with respect to financial Union membership.
Clause 22, which is headed `Pyramid Sub-contracting', states:

The parties to this Agreement have agreed that Pyramid Sub-Contracting is not acceptable in the Commercial and Industrial Building Industry and that reasonable steps shall be taken to prevent it from occurring.
Clause 22.2 states:

For the purpose of this Agreement, pyramid sub-contracting is defined as the practice of a sub-contractor to whom a labour-only contract was originally awarded, sub-letting that contract (or part thereof) to another sub-contractor . . .
And so it goes on. Mr Paul White, senior director of Concrete Constructions, in an address to the Construction 1992 seminar in Sydney last November, said:

Australian builders are poor performers because construction is the only industry in which behaviour of companies is not governed by customer's needs. For the construction industry, profit is not the difference between the sale price of a product and its cost but the bit that is added onto the cost—a very different thing, and not at all considerate of industry clients.
He went on to say:

In terms of performance our industry has, over time, created an expectation of delays of 10-40 per cent where only the amount of delay is discussed. The industry has come to accept low productivity where only 1 day in 2 is expected to be worked after we account for holidays, rostered days off, sick leave, weekends and wet weather.

In order to implement an agreement for a 38-hour week in Victoria, employers were forced to concede a rostered day off once every four weeks on a specified day, closing down all construction sites just so union organisers can make sure that employees take their rostered day off. It is an unbelievable nonsense that in 1992 an industry would shut down for 13 days a year for the convenience of a handful of union organisers. That cost is of benefit to no-one, with the exception of a few union officials. It is instructive that the in-principle agreement lists restrictive practices which should be addressed in order to improve industry efficiency and productivity, but nowhere is the issue of that restrictive work practice, a variable rostered day off—which would reduce construction costs, shorten construction time, increase the number of employees in the industry—even mentioned, much less addressed.

PARA.TAB: There is no doubt that reform of archaic work practices in the construction industry would proceed apace were voluntary union membership to apply. The ability of employers and employees to strike their own agreement on wages and conditions of employment would, undoubtedly, rid the industry of the two drops of rain on a cigarette paper syndrome, of uniform rostered days off, of triple time for Sundays, and so on.

I now refer to voluntary membership of association. Voluntary union membership is a concept which the ACTU, the union bureaucracy and Labor members opposite in this place time and time again maintain is practice in Australia. They contend that there is no compulsory union membership. I will read from the Victorian Building Industry Agreement 1989-1992. Clause 19 is entitled `Union Membership : no ticket-no start'. Clause 19.1 states:
The parties to this No Ticket-No Start Agreement, agree to abide by the following procedure with respect to financial Union Membership.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 19.2 defines the terms; clause 19.3.2 is headed `Employment of New Labour'; and clause 19.3.1 states:
When a prospective employee seeks employment, the employer is to ask the prospective employee to produce evidence of his/her financial Union membership as defined in clause 19.2.1 . . .
Clause 19.3.2 states:

If the employee is unable to produce evidence of financial Union membership, the employer shall then advise the prospective employee that he/she is required to produce such evidence from his/her union office before he/she can commence work.
Clause 19.5 is headed `Sub-Contractors'. Clause 19.5.1 states:
The principal contractor shall inform his/her sub-contractor/s in writing, prior to the acceptance of any tender, that non-unionists or unfinancial Union members are not permitted to work on site.
Clause 19.7 is headed `Industrial Relations'. Clause 19.7.1 states:

Notwithstanding anything elsewhere contained in this Agreement, it is recognised by all parties that it is the responsibility of all parties to ensure that employees are financial members of the appropriate Union.

Clearly compulsory union membership—no ticket, no start—is alive and well in Australia. In summary, the essence of this legislation is reform of a very major Australian captive industry. That industry at this time is in severe depression in several States from which it may not recover for many years, particularly in the case of Victoria.

PARA.TAB: The reform envisaged by this Bill or resulting from this Bill will have many negative aspects which I will reiterate as follows: first, the big stick approach will allow the Federal Government to force State governments and contractors to toe the line on codes of practice and, under threat of not being accepted, to tender for government financed projects. Second, this Bill will assist the ACTU to rid industry of individual contractors and sub-contractors—a major Kelty initiative.

Third, the Bill will entrench the worst and most expensive work practices and benefits to be found anywhere in Australia in the industry today. Fourth, implementation of the Bill will establish a new bureaucracy—a big brother over building and construction. Fifth, BWIU control of all building and construction will be substantially consolidated. Sixth, the Bill will entrench major contracting firms and squeeze out the innovative, small and medium sized contracting firms which have so much to offer.

Seventh, the Bill will extend the BWIU reach into housing construction, putting at risk current efficiency, productivity and high quality at an affordable price. Eighth, the Bill enhances the rhetoric of reform rather than substance which could obtain by deregulation, not by further control. Ninth, the codes of practice established by the parties to the in-principle agreement enabled by this Bill will lock out innovation rather than encourage new competitive practice. For all these reasons the Opposition comprehensively rejects this legislation and its projected outcomes.

TALK.START.PARA: —Every time that I believe I judge the Opposition too harshly, it proves that my expectations are correct. Every time there is a debate on industrial relations, it is quite clear that the mind set of those on the other side of the House lies stuck in the 1890s. Nothing has changed. It is pleasing to note that in the debates to come over the next 12 months we will see quite clearly that there has been no difference whatsoever in the challenges and the disagreements between those of us on this side of the House and those on the other side of the House in regard to special privilege, influence and directions.

PARA.TAB: The Construction Industry Reform and Development Bill is designed to express the clear commitment of the parties, which I will mention later, to achieve substantial measurable reforms in the building and construction industry over the next three years. I certainly commend the Bill.

As at December 1991 the parties to the reform are the Commonwealth Government; the governments of Victoria, South Australia, the Australian Capital Territory and Western Australia; the Australian Federation of Construction Contractors; the Master Builders Construction and Housing Association of Australia; the ACTU; the MTIA; the Operative Painters and Decorators Union of Australia; the Metal and Engineering Workers Union; the Electrical Contractors Association of Australia; the Building Owners and Managers Association of Australia; the Building Industry Specialist Contractors Organisation of Australia; the Plumbers and Gasfitters Employees Union of Australia; the Building Workers Industrial Union; the FED&FA of Australasia; the ETU; the Australian Earthmovers and Road Contractors Federation; the AWU; and the Master Plumbers and Mechanical Services Association of Victoria.

I think it is a great hallmark that so many people and so many organisations are committed to improvement in the construction industry. The previous speaker, the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Charles), said that it was a strange mixture. It may well be in some respects, but it demonstrates a commitment and a determination to work together for the betterment of Australia and the betterment of construction, and that is what all of us ought to be trying to achieve. I am surprised on that basis that the Opposition opposes something that is trying to draw Australia together for construction, for the benefit of this country and for working through recovery.

There are many objectives, but basically the principal objective of this agreement is to develop a reliable and internationally competitive industry through real and lasting improvements in efficiency and productivity, as well as providing more satisfying, stable and rewarding employment for workers in the industry.Several commitments have been made to achieve the objectives of the agreement. The most important of all, of course, is efficiency and productivity. That can only be achieved if there is goodwill and commonsense on all sides.

In regard to performance standards for contractors, the performance requirements expected of contractors and subcontractors to the public works market shall be developed by the Construction Industry Reform Agency in consultation with the industry, the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce and the States and Territories through the national public works conference. The parties agree to the development of commercially based and measurable performance standards for contractors, and that these will form the basis for registration of pre-qualified contractors for both private and government construction projects.

Probably one of the most important aspects of this Bill is in regard to labour market reform. Employers agree to rationalise the number of employer bodies in the industry and to work towards the formation within 12 months of single employer bargaining units for the major sectors of the industry.

In regard to the unions, they agree to rationalise the number of unions in the industry in accordance with ACTU policy and, further, they agree to form a single bargaining unit within 12 months for each major building project representing all principal and significant unions in the industry. I certainly believe that is a major breakthrough.

In regard to single industry awards, the parties agree to rationalise the number of existing awards and will commence discussions aimed at reaching agreement in principle on the nature and scope of the new national award or awards within 12 months of the commencement of this agreement. The parties also shall undertake within 12 months to identify all the agreements, formal or otherwise, with the industry and will develop a strategy for rationalisation of those agreements.

As to workplace reforms, the parties agree to seek agreement on specific measures to resolve each of the restrictive practices identified in the attachment to the agreement through discussions with the Construction Industry Reform Agency in the first six months of its life, and such measures will involve the adoption of more efficient work and management practices and, in particular, more flexible work patterns and arrangements.

On award restructuring and training, the parties have agreed to further pursue award restructuring over the next 12 months and, in particular, the implementation of a new classification structure and the introduction of skill related career paths and the development of nationally determined competency standards and related training measures.

In regard to health and safety, which I believe is fundamental and probably one of the most important requirements in respect of any industry, and certainly the construction industry, the parties agree to actively support the development and implementation of national health and safety standards in the industry through Worksafe Australia.

Further, the parties agree to promote equal employment opportunity principles, especially in implementing reforms under award restructuring and changes to work and management practices. The parties shall comply with all applicable equal employment opportunity and affirmative action legislation.

In regard to continuity of employment, the parties agree to introduce measures designed to improve opportunities for continuity of employment, and to this end the parties agree to develop measures to encourage a high incidence of direct contractor employment, broad banding of subcontractors and genuine supplementary labour.

As well, the Bill covers consultative arrangements. The parties agree to consult closely on key issues and developments. The parties agree to the establishment at each site of effective consultative committees representing management and workers. Issues to be addressed by such committees include award restructuring and training, occupational health and safety, industrial relations matters and the sharing of relevant information.

In regard to workplace bargaining, the parties have also agreed to encourage the development of workplace bargaining to further devolve industrial relations responsibilities, to implement award restructuring, to facilitate skills acquisition, improve occupational health and safety and enhance consultative and communication channels to achieve greater quality of working life and improved productivity and efficiency through reductions in lost time. Workplace bargaining shall be within the framework of existing awards and the operation of the Industrial Relations Act and the Australian Industrial Relations Commission.

Very briefly, that covers this Bill. One could speak for several hours on it because it is very thorough. The previous speaker covered many other aspects. As I have said, time does not allow us to go into all aspects of the Bill, but I would like to make the point that there is a difference and the Opposition is opposing the Bill. The difference is in regard to the way in which we handle industrial relations in this country. The Opposition is critical of central wage fixing; it is critical of unions; and it is critical because it says that its policies will work.

The only way we will get a fair analysis is to have some comparisons. While it is true that it is some nine years since the Opposition can be compared with the Government, as it is some nine years since the Opposition was on this side of the House, if one considers the actions and the behaviour of the Opposition when in government, one will find that inflation was running at 11 per cent, we had a wages blow-out and—

TALK.START.PARA: —Pushed by the unions.

—I am happy to debate that matter, too, with the honourable member. We had an attitude on the part of the Liberal Government of the time that the only way to deal with the trade union movement was to hit it on the head with a stick. So we had a wages blow-out; we had an inflation blow-out of 11 per cent; and we had the worst record of industrial disputation for many, many years. Unit labour costs went through the roof.

PARA.TAB: Since we came to office nine years ago we have seen, through working with the trade union movement and through treating the trade union movement, employers in this country, the National Farmers Federation, small business and every other relevant organisation fairly and equitably—and the proof is in the pudding—zero inflation this week, which must be really eating the Opposition's heart out. Inflation is running at 1.7 for the year and unit labour costs are down by some 8 to 10 per cent in real terms with the lowest level of industrial disputation that we have seen since the war. That speaks louder than words. The facts are there. One would pay tote odds on that.

It seems that it is a philosophical minefield, with regard to the Opposition, when it comes to union membership and the right of people to be in unions and to be protected. The freedom that the Opposition talks about is the freedom to starve and the freedom to have money taken out of people's pockets. The only reason why kids are not in coalmines today and the only reason why kids are not on scaffolds in wet weather and falling off and breaking their necks is that there happen to be some safety and health Acts within the construction industry and that we have a decent and strong union movement in this country.

The previous speaker can look to the United States as a classic example of where we do not have the same sort of background in the union movement. One can skite about low rates of pay while illegal immigrants from Mexico are encouraged to work for a dollar a day in the fruit and vegetable industry. The Americans skite about how good they are at efficiency in the agricultural industry while they hide behind corruptive trade practices. One can look at the meat industry where the Americans drag in Puerto Ricans and Mexicans who are prepared to work in conditions that no-one would, unless they were illegal immigrants. One can look at Florida where the Haitian immigrants are working in the same conditions—substandard conditions. That is the sort of freedom enjoyed under voluntary agreements. That is where the attitude on the other side of this House, which is nurtured in the H. R. Nicholls Society, comes from. As I have said, the only pleasing thing about these debates that will go on over the next 12 months is that they clearly distinguish between the philosophical background and the philosophical belief that those on the Opposition side of the House have and that those on our side of House have.

With regard to work and safety, the previous speaker complained about two drops on a cigarette paper. Let me tell him this: if there is one drop on a cigarette paper, it is enough to walk off steel scaffolding. Work and safety is the same in the coal industry. My great grandfather was stuck down a mine at seven years of age, and I am damn sure that I am not going to go see my grandchildren treated in the same way as he was treated. The only reason that did not happen and the only reason that it cannot happen is because of a trade union movement and a government that is not prepared to sell out the working men and women of this country. That is what this is all about. It is incredible that while this Bill is about reforming and restructuring construction the Opposition is so driven by this inherent belief in destroying the union movement that it is opposing it.

It is so incredible that the yuppies in the H. R. Nicholls Society are dominating the philosophy of those on the other side of the House. Let me tell Opposition members this when it comes to Fightback and let me tell them this when it comes to their philosophy: we are coming to get them from Cooktown to the steps of the Melbourne Club and the baggage of Fightback will be spread all over the landscape from Cooktown to the steps of the Melbourne Club, just like the German war machine was spread from the beaches of Normandy to Berlin. I tell Opposition members that the people of this country are not prepared to accept the philosophical driven, dry ideas from their side of the House.

With regard to the amount of effort that has been put into this Bill, I would like to compliment the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) and also the Minister for Small Business, Construction and Customs (Mr Beddall) who have shown a lot of innovation and a lot of vision in this regard. There is no doubt that there has been a need to improve the construction industry. That is what this Bill is all about. But it is not about improving it by taking away health and safety; it is not about improving it by taking away holiday leave loading and penalty rates; it is not about doing those sorts of things that will deprive workers in the industry of conditions. It is about achieving it by working together.

If one really wants to look at the so-called free enterprise, bright, new, dry vision of construction, one can see it in Hong Kong where they work on bamboo scaffolds. One can see it in Singapore. But that is not what we accept in Australia as the standards that we would like to have. While it is philosophically opposed by those on the other side of the House to have unionised labour in this country, it is incredible that I have never heard anyone on that side of the House wanting to break up the lawyers club and wanting to break up the AMA.

It was said by the previous speaker that the customers' needs are not necessarily met by having unionised workers. Let me tell Opposition members that it may not be the case that all the customers' needs are necessarily met by the club that runs the health system in this country; by that I mean the pathologists in the AMA. But I have never heard anyone on the other side of the House kick them in the shins. I have never heard anyone on the other side of the House kick the lawyers or the judges or anyone else who is on a high wage. But it is very easy to kick someone who wears a blue singlet, a pair of work boots and a pair of shorts. It is very easy to kick someone who does not have a degree and who lives in a leafy suburb. It is only those people on this side of the House who believe in organised labour, the union movement and that everyone deserves a fair go who will defend the very conditions that it has taken one hundred years to implement.

With regard to union labour, I fully agree and support the proposal that if anyone wants to work in this country, he has a moral responsibility to have a union ticket. The Opposition is prepared to sit back and accept the conditions that are gained through the money that union members pay and advocate through the Industrial Commission and anyone who does not buy a union ticket is having a free ride. To the two honourable members on the other side of the House who would disagree I would like to tell a story that was told to me by an 85 year-old man two years ago. He said to me, `I used to cut cane on your property when your grandfather was alive'. He said, `I never had to buy a union ticket in my life because he bought it for me and gave it to me when I walked through the gate'. The only reason he did it was that he knew what it was like to try get a job when he was 11 years of age. The jobs in those days were taken up by Kanakas or South Sea Islanders who were slaves.

For the information of the honourable member for La Trobe—I am sure that he does not need it—the sugar industry in Queensland was just as it existed in the old days in Virginia, Georgia, Alabama and South Carolina. That did not change because we waved a wand. It changed because young people of that age, my family included, formed a union, called the sugar workers union, that chucked out the third rate aristocrats from England that ran the plantation system in the sugar industry in Queensland, instituted award conditions, got rid of Kanaka labour and actually paid people a decent rate of pay. The Opposition's philosophy is about breaking down the very conditions that have brought people in the last one hundred years to where we are today.

The argument is that because things have been tough it is not the time to pay award wages and now is the time to dud people with the same argument that was used in 1890. Philosophy on the other side of the House has never changed. When we talk about work practices, why workers do not work longer and why workers should get holiday pay, I would like some of the honourable members on the other side of the House to go to the golf clubs and the bowls club on Wednesday afternoons to have a look at some of the efficient business people that are duding themselves by having that extra round of golf and having a game of bowls instead of being at the coalface in their own factories. These are the blokes that want to spend 250 grand on a Mercedes instead of putting that money back into machinery in their factories, which will make them more competitive. Those people who are doing that are leading the edge for this country. Those who want to bludge, wear an extra better yuppie suit and play an extra game of bowls are the blokes that are going broke and want to bludge by taking away the wage structure of the workers of this country. We are opposed to it. I support this Bill. If the Opposition had any commonsense, it would chuck away Fightback and it would change its attitude on industrial relations. It is the very thing that is going to cut its throat at the very next election.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prosser Mr G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Construction Industry Reform and Development Bill is one of the clearest examples of the differences between Australia's two main political parties. The Labor Government and the coalition are poles apart in many respects. In recent times most attention has focused on the differences in our economic policies, between the Government's so-called One Nation statement and the coalition's comprehensive Fightback package of reforms. On the one hand, we have the Government promising a fistful of dollars, without knowing where the money is coming from; on the other, we have Fightback, a package which is fully funded and a responsible strategy for combating the nation's structural and economic weaknesses.

PARA.TAB: There is, however, one policy area of massive importance that has largely been overlooked recently, and that is industrial relations. This is despite the fact that every single Australian is affected, either directly or indirectly, by what happens on the industrial relations front. Whether it is a demarcation dispute which results in power blackouts, a national wage case which results in flow-on wage increases, a dispute that results in travellers being held up for hours on end at airports, or a dispute on the wharves that will hold up containers, we are all affected.

Industrial relations is of paramount importance. Bad industrial relations often causes undue hardship for members of the community. It adds to the cost of everyday goods and services and it often results in fewer jobs. Good industrial relations means better productivity, a more competitive economy, higher standards of living and more jobs. I am an advocate of tax reform as a means of bolstering our economic stocks. I support reductions in government spending, along with other reforms, such as privatisation, deregulation and contracting out of public services, to generate greater efficiencies and improved competitiveness. I have no doubt whatsoever that if these matters had been addressed during the 1980s, Australia would have been well placed, well positioned, to avoid the recession and to emerge as a leader in world markets.These vital reforms are needed to straighten out our system of industrial relations. It is my belief that their importance is equal to, if not greater than, that of any other single area of economic reform. The construction industry must rank as a major priority in such reform.
Indeed, the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook), in his speech on the Bill, acknowledges the need for reform in the construction industry. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: It is an industry that we have sought to reform over the period of our government.

This says two things: firstly, it is an admission that there are serious problems in the industry—although that is no secret to anyone; secondly, it is an open admission of the Government's failure to reform the construction industry, despite having had nine years in office to do so.

PARA.TAB: Before Government members start bleating about deregistration of the BLF, let me openly acknowledge this measure, which, I might add, was commenced by a previous government. However, deregistering one militant union without stemming other union oriented problems is hardly what I would call large scale reform.But at least the Minister recognises the need for change in the construction industry. He also recognises the industry's importance within the overall economic framework. After all, we are talking about an industry with an annual expenditure exceeding $40 billion and generating over 60 per cent of Australia's gross fixed capital expenditure. Clearly if an industry of this magnitude is operating efficiently, as the Minister seems to accept, any improvements in efficiency must result in significant gains for the Australian economy and the Australian work force. The question is how best to go about achieving this task of reform.

It disappoints me that the Bill is the best the Government could come up with after nine years in office. Unfortunately, the Bill is totally inadequate. It is even counterproductive in some areas. In particular, it caters for only the big players in the construction industry, particularly the Building Workers Industrial Union. This fits with the Government's move towards bigger and more powerful unions with broader industrial coverage. The new mega-union, known as the Construction, Forestry and Mining Employees Union, already covers a massive 96,000 members and is tipped to expand much further, possibly to a membership as large as 200,000 within the next year.

The new union is an amalgamation of the BWIU, the timber workers and allied industries union and the Mineworkers Federation. As such, it is a collection of unions which historically have had very different interests. Furthermore, consideration has been given to two other unions which may join the new mega-union. One of them, the Plasterers Federation, has obvious ties with the construction industry; but the other, the Federated Engine Drivers and Firemen's Association, has far broader interests. Eventually the CFMEU, as it will become known, will possibly cover about 300,000 members. I have to question how a union of that size and that scope can possibly look after the interests of individual members working in a variety of trades in a range of enterprises and in vastly different locations.

Of course, what a union of that size can do is perfectly obvious, especially to those employers, subcontractors and employees who have fallen foul of the BWIU in the past. I do not pretend that the BWIU is in the same league as the BLF when it comes to industrial anarchy; however, anyone who has dealings with the various unions involved in the construction industry knows that the BWIU tactics used on site have often little to do with traditional workplace issues. Nowadays it is rare for a major construction project to be completed anywhere near on schedule or for the wages and conditions applicable at the outset of the project to be the same as those applying at the end of the project.

It is even rarer that a subcontractor or a company employee can so much as enter a major construction project without first joining at least one union. Even self-employed tradesmen who carry out subcontract work on the larger sites are forced to be union members, despite the fact that they may be technically ineligible to join the particular union involved. I am aware of cases where self-employed contractors have been forced to join three unions to avoid union harassment on site.

Big union muscle pays big dividends as well. For example, evidence to the Industry Commission last year revealed wages being paid to some crane drivers of up to $160,000 a year, with their dogmen earning up to $100,000. It has been estimated that overall restrictive work practices, overregulation and inefficient regulatory procedures in the construction industry cost about $1 billion every year.

This Bill will do little, if anything, to help resolve these problems. It is no wonder that the New South Wales Government has refused to participate in the Federal Government's grandstanding on this issue. It has the sense to wait until the Gyles Royal Commission into Productivity in the Building Industry in New South Wales has completed its investigations and made its own recommendations. I have to ask why the Federal Government could not be a little patient. After all, the Construction Industry Reform Agency, created by this legislation, will no doubt be going over the areas already canvassed by the royal commission. On its own, this duplication clearly is totally unwarranted.

Let us consider further that already we have had 22 separate inquiries into the industry over the past 15 years. It is abundantly clear that the Government should hold its horses and wait until the Gyles Royal Commission has finished its work before taking this legislation any further. But no, the Government has chosen instead to pre-empt the findings of the royal commission by pushing ahead with this Bill. Indeed, it has even gone one step further by making the necessary appointments to the Construction Industry Reform Agency.

The former Prime Minister announced in December that Mr Paul White, Group Construction Director of Concrete Constructions Group, had been appointed as chairman of the board. Most of the other board members are equally highly placed, being the executive directors or equivalent from Kinhill Engineers, Fletcher Construction Group, AMP Property Investments, Thiess Contractors, Hooker Cochram, the ACTU and the Building Workers Industrial Union.

Clearly, this Bill is a fait accompli, and the Government is asking us simply to rubber-stamp its legislation. This is a blatant abuse of the Parliament and demonstrates the Government's arrogance in taking action now and then seeking legislative authority later. However, there is another important reason why the Government should await the royal commission's findings, and that concerns the BWIU's decision to allocate $1.5m to the new Construction Industry Reform Agency. There might be nothing wrong with that in itself; but the fact that the union raided the construction employees redundancy trust to do this raises some serious questions about the legality of such action.

The trust was established specifically to meet redundancy payments to construction workers and I am pleased that the Gyles Royal Commission undertook to examine the matter in some detail. Already, Commissioner Roger Gyles has said that the actions of the BWIU in this regard seem to be:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . a most extraordinary step for a body such as this to take and, indeed, says much about the industry and the integrity of those involved in it.
What will this Bill do to improve these matters? After all, the Minister has said that this is not an industrial relations exercise, it is an industry exercise.

PARA.TAB: In fact, the functions of the Construction Industry Reform Agency are spelled out in only very general terms in this Bill. More detail is contained in the working party report and it seems that the legislation is meant to have far-reaching implications. Not only would the Agency involve itself in industrial relations matters, but also it could involve itself in broader issues such as overall industry efficiency and managerial competence in accordance with the in-principle agreement signed by the major industry groups.

Frankly, I do not believe that a bureaucratic body such as this, which is heavily influenced by a major organisation renowned for fostering inefficiency in the industry, can possibly achieve the goal of greater industry competitiveness. The coalition's outlook is far more realistic than this, and I will discuss this point later.

However, if there is one thing I can say in the Government's favour, it is that our loony friends in the Senate, the Australian Democrats, seem to think this Bill is nothing short of a magic potion and have suggested that more emphasis should be given to environmental considerations. Referring to such matters as energy efficient design practices, self-monitoring heating, and waste disposal practices, a Democrat spokesman said:

SPEECH.PARA: These are the sorts of issues which the Australian Democrats believe can be profitably pursued within the Construction Industry Development Council forum.

All I can say is that proponents of this legislation are either totally naive and do not understand the complexities of the workplace, where it might take several weeks to resolve a simple demarcation dispute; or they see this whole area as a political springboard enabling them to pursue their own ambitions. I am sure the BWIU holds the latter view. I suspect its idea of building industry reform is to pursue issues such as strike pay, higher employer-funded superannuation and even more in the way of redundancy payments.

PARA.TAB: Of course, the Government will say that this legislation has broad support but, as I said earlier, that is not the case because not all of the States are behind it. Furthermore, I sympathise with those business groups which feel obliged to support this approach openly through fear of what would happen to their position in the industry otherwise. Contrary to what members on the other side will say—and have said—the coalition is not anti-union, and my comments today regarding union militancy are not a reflection on the whole union movement. Although the Minister has said that we are in favour of eliminating the trade union movement from the construction industry, the truth is very different.

We certainly do recognise the valuable role which a properly democratic union movement can fulfil. However, we are not blind to the realities of industry relations in Australia today. The truth is that the existing system has failed dismally. Indeed, it is interesting that the Bill which is before us today deals only with the construction industry which, on the Minister's own admission, is fraught with problems.

Compared with the commercial construction industry, the home building trades are in a very different situation. Australia's housing industry, for example, is considered to be a world leader in terms of competitiveness and efficiency. The relatively low cost of home construction in Australia is the main reason why housing prices have not risen more in recent years. An indication of the degree of efficiency in our housing industry is the fact that costs have increased by far less than the prevailing rate of inflation.

In the five years to last December, the increase in house prices relative to inflation was as follows: Sydney house prices increased by 12.3 per cent and inflation over that period rose by 35.9 per cent; Melbourne house prices rose by 10.8 per cent, inflation by 35.5 per cent; Brisbane house prices went up 12.1 per cent, and inflation, 33 per cent; Adelaide, 6.9 per cent, and inflation, 34.4 per cent; Perth, 12.1 per cent, and inflation, 33.2 per cent; and Canberra, 6.4 per cent, and inflation, 32 per cent.

Why is it that the big construction sites are plagued with problems whereas the cottage industry operates so well? The first clue is that most employees in the cottage building industries are not union members. Of the 376,000 industry employees last recorded by the Bureau of Statistics, 205,300—or 54.6 per cent—were not union members.

We know that the construction industry has been almost totally unionised by the union movement's closed shop tactics, so it follows that employees in the building industry generally do not belong to unions. Indeed, from my experience this is certainly the case. Furthermore, the home building industry is also the bastion of the self-employed contractor who subcontracts his services and, more often than not, organises his own labour.

I put it to the House that this is the key to the whole matter and explains why we have an efficient housing industry whereas—as even the Minister concedes—the construction industry is in need of sweeping reforms. The housing industry illustrates the sort of decentralised and deregulated workplace which the coalition advocates as part of our industry relations policy.

By and large, Australian subcontractors work extremely efficiently. If one drives through any new suburb on any morning, one will see bricklayers, carpenters and electricians working efficiently on jobs to complete those contracts on time. If one drives past any major construction site, one will not see anywhere near the same level of activity. This is why the housing industry is pleased to have nothing to do with the Government's new legislation. It is also why it is totally opposed to the Minister's objective to include independent subcontractors in the centralised industrial relations system. Forcing subcontractors into the industrial relations system would spell disaster as it strikes at the very core of the Australian housing industry.

Just recently, the Housing Industry Association highlighted the additional costs arising from regulating the housing industry. The HIA maintains that home prices would increase by between 15 and 35 per cent, adding thousands of dollars to the price of every new home. Dr Ron Silverberg, national director of the HIA, went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: Housing subcontractors have abandoned the security of a company job and industrial awards for the satisfaction of relying on their own ability to succeed. Their earnings depend on establishing a reputation for quality and reliability. Subbies don't get paid for delays, rostered-days-off or wet weather so there is a strong incentive to get on with the job.

The coalition will not stand by and let this subcontract system be systematically destroyed in this way. Indeed, the reasons behind our support for the existing subcontract system are essentially the reasons why we cannot support this Bill before the House today.

PARA.TAB: Instead of creating a bureaucracy and feeding it millions of dollars of taxpayer and industry funds in a futile effort to reform the industry, the coalition believes in letting the industry reform itself. All that is needed is the right industrial relations framework. Abolishing compulsory unionism will not be easy, but it is essential if we are to rid the construction industry of the inefficiencies of union closed shop tactics. Combined with genuine secret ballots, we will see an end to those hurried on-site meetings where no-one dares to challenge the shop steward's authority.

In turn, subcontractors will play a more important role in the construction industry, bringing with them the same work practices which have helped make our housing industry so efficient by world standards. Subcontractors know that greater productivity means greater rewards and the coalition's enterprise agreements policy will extend the same incentives to employees in the industry. Employees will be able to enter into voluntary agreements with their employers, whether on their own or with union assistance, so that they can share in the spoils of a leaner, more efficient industry. If they choose not to do this, they will still have the security of the award system behind them.

The Bill will not solve anything. In fact, it has already created a serious legal situation which is set to reinforce some of the worst aspects of unionism. This is the sort of legislation that we have come to expect from this Government which takes its orders from Swanston Street. On the other hand, there is no reason why aspects of the housing industry should not be embraced by the construction industry so that the industry, and those working in it, will be better off. All it takes is the industrial relations framework proposed by the coalition in its Fightback policy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Catley Dr R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the Construction Industry Reform and Development Bill which is before the House. This Bill essentially presents the framework for a new organisational tripartite structure to be erected in the construction industry so that it may pursue its tasks more efficiently and more cooperatively with the different sectors involved. This is very important.

PARA.TAB: The construction industry in Australia is one of the largest sectors of industry. It runs at about 10 per cent of our GDP, something over $40 billion, subject to the state of the cycle. It employs about 7 per cent of the work force, or over half a million employees, and it lays down more than half our fixed capital expenditure. In other words, it is the major industry which lays down the infrastructure of sectors of our economy, particularly those which we hope in the 1990s will provide some of the basis for a rectification of our balance of payments imbalance which we found in the late 1980s.
