I refer particularly to mining; transportation, which services all industry; tourism, one of the fastest growing industrial sectors of the 1980s, and we hope it will repeat its performance into the 1990s; and the services sector, which is also going to require buildings from which to operate and which, I hope, we will be able to utilise to export services, particularly into the Asia-Pacific region.

Laying down this infrastructure is going to be very important for our national economy during the next decade. So while it is true that the construction industry has concentrated in the past on central business district construction—and this was particularly true in the 1980s, and notably in my seat of Adelaide where the skyline of the central business district was reconstructed—and CBDs throughout our country have at the present time surplus office space, that is not a situation that is going to last forever. It is also not a situation that means the construction industry is not important because, as I have just outlined, it has other roles to play into the 1990s.

So we need to look at the construction industry as a backbone for the economic development of the 1990s, laying down the modern infrastructure and the fixed capital of our economy. This was outlined and projected in the One Nation statement that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) gave in February. In that One Nation statement he laid down some direct infrastructure programs, particularly those related to the transport system of this country—rail, road and air—which the construction industry will undertake.

The Prime Minister also projected growth in service sectors and in tourism. Some taxation rearrangements were made to encourage the development of a tourism infrastructure, such that we can see the construction industry blossoming in different directions in the 1990s. This makes it very important that we undertake right now a micro-economic reform agenda in that sector which will provide a suitable vehicle for producing this infrastructure development.

We face a choice between two ways of doing this. One is to go back to the old kind of construction industry that we had in this country that developed during the 1950s, 1960s and 1970s when the central business districts of our cities were constructed; that is, one of militant, damaging and inefficient conflict between management and labour. The other way is construct a new form of construction industry in which there is a cooperative, tripartite drive by the public sector, organised labour and management for a more efficient construction method for the infrastructure that this country desperately needs to lay down over the next decade.

Essentially, I submit to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that the two sides of this House are offering alternative proposals as to how to lay down the basis for our construction industry which will construct that vital infrastructure during the coming decade. The passage of this Bill will ensure that we go in one direction. Its rejection would ensure that we take a few steps down the ultimate path into the past.

This construction industry reform strategy, as presently outlined in the Bill, was launched in the Great Hall by the then Prime Minister on 3 December last year. He noted then that our national costs for major projects were 20 per cent higher than our international competitors, our export performance among OECD countries was among the lowest, and our research and development expenditure in that sector was a mere $13m a year, which is an almost unrecognisable percentage of total turnover. He added, quite rightly, that our regulatory structure in the construction industry, springing as it does from an overlapping maze of rules by the various geographically dispersed and three-tiered stages of government, was a maze.

The then Prime Minister also announced that an in-principle reform and development agreement had been reached between peak employer, peak employee, and many State and Federal governments to conclude a code of practice in the industry which would incorporate a rating system for company performances, an industry development agenda to lift exports, research and development and quality practices, and a labour market reform process to lift flexibility, safety standards for workers, training standards for all those employed in the industry and the introduction of more flexible award restructuring. This agreement in principle would also seek to simplify and standardise the regulations that have been laid down by the various and multiple layers of government in this country.

To this end, the then Prime Minister announced that a comprehensive system of consultation in the industry would be set up. This Bill is the legislative form of that system of consultation. Notably, it would involve a Construction Industry Development Council, chaired by the Minister for Small Business, Construction and Customs and the Minister for Industrial Relations, and a Construction Industry Development Agency with a chief executive officer to implement the strategy.

I listened to two speeches against this process from the Opposition. I would just like to point out to people who may be listening to this debate or who may read it later—and, of course, to your good self, Mr Deputy Speaker—that people from the private sector who got behind this process were the top people in their field. One of the people, Mr Paul White, was quoted by the honourable member who led for the Opposition in this debate, the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Charles). Mr White was Group Construction Director of the Concrete Construction Group and has now become the Chief Executive Officer of the agency.

The people who have been nominated by private companies, by the union movement, by the responsible unions of the ACTU, together with officers from Commonwealth departments and the States, to serve on the Council represent those people who know the industry from the inside, who are aware of the problems that it faces and who have agreed in principle to a general reform process in which they will try to cooperate. I notice that one Council member is Mr Malcolm Kinnaird from the Kinhill group. He is a highly respected Adelaide developer with an export record which, in itself, demonstrates the capacity of this man and his thinking. The companies he represents go into the Asia-Pacific region to gain competitive contracts in one of the most competitive construction markets in the world. These people have come on board with this process.

Other members are very eminent, skilled and highly experienced people from the industry, the unions and various government departments, all of whom need to cooperate in the development of a more efficient, less trammelled and more cooperative construction industry. I do not intend to list them because the time available does not permit it. I should point out, however, that the construction industry reform strategy, which has been published by the Commonwealth Government Printer, lists the people involved.

We started this process against a background in the construction industry which, as I have already said, leaves much to be desired on all sides. It was an industry that developed quickly during the 1950s, 1960s, and 1970s when the structure of our present central business districts was laid down. The industry had a number of features. One was a management performance that was below that required by contemporary standards when the overall Australian economy was exposing itself to international competition much more severely. It had an extremely poor industrial relations record, caused in part by the extreme fragmentation of union organisation in the industry and the willingness of some of these fragmented unions to be extremely militant, against a background where labour in the industry, that is workers in the industry, had every ground to feel that they had been excluded from the boom of the fifties, sixties and seventies in terms of regular and safe employment, regular training, and access to the safety standards which became the norm elsewhere in our economy. This was such that they became, as was the expression, bloody-minded enough to introduce and sustain work practices which precluded the introduction of world best production methods.

Against the background of that industry it was hardly surprising that management would react with great frustration and would resort to old practices of, in turn, being vindictive towards their employees. As old projects closed down they were reluctant to hire the more militant of the workers on new projects. So there was continuing conflict between labour and capital that precluded the introduction of proper safety standards, training standards, remuneration and superannuation on the one side and regular and most productive practices of construction on the other. These mutual antagonisms grew and developed, until they had reached the peak in the 1970s and were inherited by this Government. Dealing with them then becomes the problem.

The in-principle agreement which was thrashed out last December was signed by most State governments, the peak employer bodies and the involved unions, with an agreement to the broad reform process that covered improvement in industry performance, management practice and working conditions for employees. There is something for everybody in that agreement, including the Australian economy as a whole.

As I have said, the details of this agreement are to be found in another publication by the Commonwealth Government which sets out the terms. I will not read them here, as they are far too lengthy, but they do get down to details which matter to workers in this industry, such as what happens when the weather is inclement and how is it judged. Is it enough to say two spots of rain on a cigarette paper? Or is there some better way to go? The agreement looks at the provision of toilets. When do we need adequate toilet facilities? When do we have to scrimp and scrape in order to improve efficiency? How flexible do we have to be on this issue? Who is responsible for the issuing of protective clothing, and under what circumstances and when is it adequate? What happens if a shop steward is dismissed? Do we lay down tools? How is that dealt with? All these things are vital day-to-day issues in the industry which, if not dealt with cooperatively, can hinder the introduction of efficient work practices, and have done for over a generation, thereby leaving a legacy which all of us, certainly on this side of the House, seek to eradicate.

This reform strategy cannot be imposed by this or any other government on this industry. We cannot impose a requirement that the parties cooperate with one another, as we would prefer that they do, and we cannot impose a demand that they compete ferociously all the time, as the Opposition cares to suggest. Reform has to grow out of industrial practice within the industry. We do not believe that, by setting up this agency and this council, we as a government will resolve the problem. We believe that we may be able to establish a framework within which the industry itself can cooperate to produce an outcome desirable for overall Australian economy's purpose of laying down a new capital infrastructure during the 1990s.

The Government has set up the Construction Industry Development Agency and the Construction Industry Development Council to get the process under way. There is a terminal point to the agency, which will be disbanded in mid-1995, by which time we ardently hope that this process of cooperation and the introduction of work practices comparable with the best in the world will have been finished. We believe that the coincidence of these reforms with the One Nation strategy, which kicks off, stimulates and exists alongside the upturn in the business cycle, will produce a laying down of a new bout of capital investment. This reform is appearing at the same time as that upturn in the business cycle occurs as a natural process of the eight-year cyclical movement.

I conclude by speculating as to why the Opposition has been so strongly opposed to what is a natural development in the industry of cooperating to seek greater productivity, one that has been encouraged by this Government and is in accord with the desires of both Labor and management within the industry. A number of objections have been raised. One is that the legislation does not cover the housing industry. It is suggested that the housing industry is a much better example, as in it productivity is higher and prices are lower. I believe that, on the one side, it is not possible to make those comparisons very easily, and I do not want to produce them here. I want to say, however, that anyone familiar with either the housing industry or the construction industry, just by driving past building sites, would quickly become aware that the housing industry is not based on large firms, large workplaces, large agglomerations of labour and capital working together over lengthy periods, during which they need to cooperate and eventually are in competition with the international market.

The proposition advanced by the Opposition is that the essential differences between those two industries are between a unionised sector and a non-unionised sector. Whatever conclusions those opposite draw from that, I would ask them to note that the big difference between the construction sector and the housing sector is not whether the labour is unionised in one and not in the other, but centres on the whole scale and size of the operations and the technology and the technological innovation that is involved. Those two industries are vastly different from those points of view, and they are the differences that are most important in looking at these industries.

In any case, the unions that occasioned the kind of disruption to the construction industry which the Opposition says does not occur in the cottage housing industry were chiefly those associated with the Builders Labourers Federation. I am sure that those opposite would be pleased to recognise that it was this Government that deregistered the Builders Labourers Federation for its involvement in disruptive activities in the construction industry.

The second objection that the Opposition has made is that the legislation was announced publicly in the Great Hall before it was announced in Parliament, thereby in some way usurping the Parliament's prerogative. I think that is a little unfair. The agreement was reached between the three most important parties in the industry and is about to be given legislative effect if it is accepted by this and the other House. In the other House the Australian Democrats have given their assent, so I presume it will eventually receive the assent of Parliament.

Thirdly, it is claimed that we require the findings of the Gyles Royal Commission in New South Wales before we can act. As the previous speaker pointed out, there have been 22 separate inquiries into the industry in the last 15 years. If we were to wait for the twenty-third, I am sure those opposite would be on our backs saying that we were again squibbing on micro-economic reform.

Finally, I note that in one of the debates in the other place someone pointed out that entering construction sites around Australia is basically like stepping into a communist nation, such as Cuba or an eastern European country. This is grossly unfair. Australian workers are merely seeking to protect their rights of safety and regulation within their industrial framework.

Much more important, I believe, is that underpinning the criticism of this agreement is the attack on the industrial relations club launched by the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Charles), who spoke first for the Opposition in this debate. The target is not the cooperative agreement that we are about to undertake within the construction industry, but a more radical policy which the Opposition is contemplating with respect to the industry relations system in general and which is reported in the Australian Financial Review this morning. In it an article states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Federal Opposition Leader, Dr Hewson, is driving a push within coalition ranks for a significant toughening of industrial relations policy which could commit a Hewson government to abolishing compulsory arbitration.
It goes on to say that he was impressed with the New Zealand model, having just visited New Zealand. It continues:

The key reforms . . . diluted the legal recognition of unions as the bargaining agents for workers, cancelled . . . industrial awards . . . and allowed employers and employees to negotiate new . . . contracts . . .

If we are to develop an industry which is cooperative, which seeks to use the world's best construction standards, which seeks to do a good job in laying down the new capital infrastructure that this country is going to require in the next decade, we do not want to return to a situation of extreme conflict that characterised this industry when the unions were under assault.

PARA.TAB: We now have moderate, temperate unions, looking to establish an ongoing industrial framework in which their members can have regular jobs, regular payment, regular superannuation and be safe at work, and where the employers recognise that going back to the conflict model would be inappropriate. This is what we are seeking to establish. We regard the Opposition's proposals as being contrary to the interests of the construction industry and seeking, ultimately, to snuff out the recovery phase of capital infrastructure development which this country is just entering into.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anderson Mr J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The visible and stated purpose of the Construction Industry Reform and Development Bill is to establish the Construction Industry Development Council and the Construction Industry Development Agency as a part of the Government's so-called construction industry reform strategy. That strategy is plainly devoted to the Government's program of micro-economic reform. I must acknowledge at the outset that nobody would argue with the need for that economic reform, in principle. Nonetheless, the Opposition takes a view that the mechanism being put before us will not prove adequate, appropriate, effective or, in the end, workable in achieving the stated objectives. Therefore, as the previous speaker, the honourable member for Adelaide (Dr Catley), acknowledged, we will be opposing this move.

PARA.TAB: The fact that the legislation will not achieve the stated objectives is, in our view, largely related to what might be called the unstated or not so visible objectives of the strategy which, regrettably, appear to have more to do with entrenching and enhancing union influence—which itself is a very major part of the problem—despite the observations made by the previous speaker, in Australia's construction industry. For him to pretend there is no relevant comparison between the performance of the building sector, the housing and cottage industries and the heavy commercial and industrial construction sectors, on the basis of one being unionised and one not being unionised, is to my way of thinking a nonsense. That comparison cannot be avoided and the need to draw conclusions from it can no longer be ignored either.

The problem with that extension of union influence and control, which is likely to carry over into the housing industry by virtue of the hidden agenda in this strategy, must not be overlooked or ignored. We must not pretend it is not real. The reality is that as a result of that we are likely to see a detrimental effect on the efficiency and economy of the home and cottage industries in this country. For those reasons alone, the Bill ought to be opposed.

Nobody doubts the importance of the building and construction industry in this country, although I suspect that few people really understand how its efficiency impacts on our economic performance, probably because they are not aware of its impact on our export performance and on our traded goods sectors. I will illustrate that in a moment.

The sector, as a whole, represents somewhere between 10 and 12 per cent of gross domestic product in Australia—in dollar terms, somewhere between $40 billion and $50 billion per year. It is obviously a very substantial industry, which employs more than 500,000 people. The housing and cottage sector of it clearly rates amongst the most highly efficient industries in this country, and probably anywhere in the world.

Largely untouched by excessive labour rigidities, restrictive work practices and idiotic demarcation disputes, it is to a great extent the domain of subcontractors who work largely without regard for the dictates of union officials, apparently with very good results in everything from economic and financial terms to efficiency and, of course, safety. They do so, to a great degree, irrespective of whether or not their employees are members of a union. The Troubleshooter brawl in Victoria, for example, had little or nothing to do with union membership, as such, but it appears that it did have a lot to do with the fact that subcontractors and those who work with them are difficult to organise and control. To a great extent, that is what this debate is all about.

It also seems that there are people in the labour movement who are keen to ensure that people are not made acquainted with the fact that if they can do better by entering freely into a workplace contract and can receive a higher degree of remuneration—and other things, such as job satisfaction—the efforts of union officials in the industrial relations club may begin to look a little irrelevant. Employees may want out of the centralised system, which is the option we fully intend to give them. Unfortunately, it appears that the labour movement, in its many varieties, is keen to do what it can to avoid letting ordinary working Australians either see the options or, having seen them, pursue them.

In this push to limit the role of subcontractors and almost certainly increase, by stealth, the degree of union coverage of and interference in the building industry, there will be losers, and they will not simply be home buyers and home purchasers. The introduction of restrictive construction industry type work practices, to the degree that it is allowed to take place, will increase the cost of housing, just as on the flip side of the coin the denial of the possibility of introducing these work patterns, these innovative ways of approaching construction and engineering problems in the commercial sector of the building industry, deprives it of the benefits of the efficiencies that apply currently in the housing and cottage industries.

The extension of the regulations governing the building industries has been referred to here tonight. Their extension would appear to be part and parcel of the reform strategy before us tonight. It would also appear that those regulations may be part of a vehicle for the extension of union coverage and the imposition of what might be regarded as desirable work practices by those unions.

As I understand it, the Housing Industry Association has estimated that simply the adoption of the Building Regulation Review Task Force's recommendations will add somewhere between $2,000 and $4,000 to the cost of the average Australian home or cottage. The effect of higher home prices presents a range of potentially detrimental effects. For one thing, Australians will drive themselves deeper into debt to buy a home. The great Australian dream will not be forsaken; it will just soak up more of our precious national savings.

As Senator Walsh pointed out some years ago, that trait in this nation is doing considerable damage. We are devoting too much of our scarce national capital to our housing. I think he observed that our obsession with the double garage and en suite is doing a great deal of damage in that regard. Furthermore, it will exacerbate the distortions already apparent in investment patterns in this country. Too much money is being directed towards the non-traded goods sector and not enough towards the export and import replacement tradeable goods sectors. On the other hand, a cynic might observe that the process will enhance our drift towards what one wit recently termed our future status as the best-housed Third World country in the world.

I now turn to our need to boost the traded goods sector, and investment in it, which is a very important part of this debate. It centres on the inefficiency and high cost of our construction sector. This is one of the major factors in the decline in capital investment in this country. Additional costs arising from those inefficiencies are added onto building owners' and users' costs and their cost structures. This saps our competitiveness and soaks up resources which would otherwise be available for productive use. Worse, as a result it has the potential to very seriously impact on our export performance—I suggest that it already has—with all that that implies in our present parlous trade imbalance situation.

I recently had a series of discussions concerning the meat industry. This industry is one of our major export trade performers. It is of immensely important economic significance—and potentially immensely more—in terms of our trade performance, yet investment in that industry has dried to a trickle. It is estimated that the industry pays out something like $250m a year in statutory government charges, of which over half goes to AQIS, which is in itself a story of industrial relations inefficiencies, and industry dues, such as AMLC and meat research dues. The interesting thing is that that $250m is probably more money than the industry has invested in capital works and new infrastructure in the last 10 years.

One major Australian meatworks, against the appalling backdrop of not being able to retain earnings out of its cash flow as a result of these government imposts and other cost imposts, needs to undertake major rebuilding of its plant over the next few years if it is to retain its various export licences. Here is the rub: the ballpark figure for the rebuilding of the essential part of the plant is around $30m on current indications. On the Government's own figures, it would appear that is about $6m or 20 per cent more than it ought to be. That is not just $6m or so more than it ought to be in terms of domestic costs, it is $6m or more than a comparable meatworks abroad might have to find to get this new infrastructure up to and running. That money may well be the difference between a decision to invest and a decision not to invest. We are talking about 500 jobs; we are talking about a multiplier effect right throughout the community; and we are talking about the loss of yet another export contributor.

The seriousness of these sorts of problems for our export sector must not be underestimated. Given the parlous state of our balance of trade and the alarming decline in capital investment in this country, one would have thought that there might have been urgent and effective attention paid to this matter. Despite earlier comments, there has not been too much urgency in this debate so far; in fact, the Bill before us has been something like 18 months in its gestation period. It has already cost several million dollars and has generated plenty of reports, plenty of meetings and plenty of in-principle agreements; yet out in the field it has not achieved anything yet. The first tangible outcome of it is the Bill before us tonight and, as I have said, there is, unfortunately, not likely to be a great deal of effectiveness either.

Despite the Government having created a statutory authority to continue the process of consultation between industry, governments and unions—a consultative process which has already been taking place anyway—not everyone seems to be convinced that much will happen or that this statutory authority will bring about much change. As I understand it, at least one reluctant participant in the process has indicated that the authority is very concerned and very sceptical about the whole strategy tackling the central issue which, in its view, is the extraordinarily difficult industrial relations problem that applies in the construction industry.

The only catalyst for urgency so far seems to have been the desire to have the process in train before the Gyles Royal Commission into Productivity in the Building Industry in New South Wales hands down its report. I understand that is due in the next couple of weeks. The New South Wales Government has in fact refused to pre-empt the findings of the Gyles Royal Commission which may well recommend a totally different approach to the one before us tonight. For that reason, the New South Wales Government has refused to participate.It points to the codes of conduct which have existed within the industry since 1986 and which arose out of concerns to ensure that there was adequate reinforcing of the deregistration of the BLF—the Federal, Victorian and New South Wales governments all participated—as well as claims that those measures have been largely ineffective. In addition, the Commission has had to consider the legality of an extraordinary transfer of $1.5m from the Construction Employees Redundancy Trust, CERT, to the Construction Industry Development Agency created by the Bill before us tonight.

CERT was set up as a charitable trust to receive weekly contributions of $40 per employee from employers to meet redundancy payments to building workers. Not surprisingly, this rather unusual transaction has raised a few eyebrows, not least amongst them Mr Gyles himself. He is quoted as saying that this:

SPEECH.PARA: `. . . involved very serious legal questions as to whether that is an appropriate procedure'.

PARA.TAB: He could `well imagine' that some contributors to CERT might be `appalled' by the payment and might want to legally contest whether the CERT trustees—

SPEECH.PARA: the trustees of a union redundancy scheme—
had the right to make such a decision—
He went on to say:

`All I can say at the moment is that without having heard argument on it, it seems a most extraordinary step for a body such as this to take and, indeed, says much about the industry and the integrity of those involved in it.
Furthermore, Mr Gyles said that he could not believe:

`. . . that the Commonwealth Government would have accepted this commitment as being a commitment on behalf of the industry when, in reality, all it is, is the distribution of income contributed in the main by sub-contractors and small building contractors, purportedly to deal with the redundancy of their workers and to pay the award provisions, and so on'.

PARA.TAB: `It is quite beyond me how any bona fide examination of the issues could have justified this payment,' Mr Gyles said.

SPEECH.PARA: That was not all the Gyles Commission uncovered. The sorts of rorts and rip-offs which make people gasp and say it has got to stop are evidenced aplenty in the media coverage of the Gyles Commission and its activities. To be fair, we need to acknowledge that it was not just the unions which were seen to be rorting the system, to be involved in these sorts of rip-offs.

PARA.TAB: The Australian Financial Review last August wrote a story of a daily litany of criminal, inefficient and idiotic practices. The same article referred to a study which showed that Australian construction costs were between 20 and 50 per cent higher than those abroad in similar countries, and that working days lost were up to 40 times higher than in comparable developed nations. We hear stories, for example, of the numbers of days lost to wet weather in CBDs around Australia being two, three and four times what they are in places such as London, which obviously raises some very serious issues. It seems that anything goes as long as one can pass on the cost and get the job done on time, although even that seems to present problems from time to time.
The media coverage makes some pretty interesting reading. An article in the Sydney Morning Herald headed `Job given due to fear of unions, QC told', states:

An insurance salesman who in 1989 was site delegate at the Travellers' Rest Hotel project in the Haymarket told the building royal commission that his father, who was construction manager, had agreed to re-employ a man because he was afraid of the trade unions.

SPEECH.PARA: Another article headed, `Building site was `smorgasbord' for thieves' states:
. . . project at Milsons Point . . . had produced a `smorgasbord' of materials, which were stolen with such frequency that police had to be called, the building royal commission heard yesterday.

PARA.TAB: The goods included a spa bath which was so heavy it would have needed a truck to shift it, about 300 lights, tiles, plumbing and electrical supplies, carpet, power tools and six coils of soundproofing material that would have needed more than one man to shift it.

SPEECH.PARA: When it was suggested that the cars of workers be searched, the unions vetoed the idea. Another article is headed, `Union reps paid $12,000 in secret, inquiry told'. It states:

PARA.TAB: Secret payments totalling $12,000 were made so that Building Workers Industrial Union (BWIU) representatives would make less stringent demands about the supposed asbestos contamination of bricks taken from a demolition site. . .

SPEECH.PARA: . . . indicated that if we could afford a site like this—
this is a Building Union representative speaking—
then we could afford to do the work.
The article continues:

They were claiming that the brickwork and timbers were now affected with asbestos particles and would have to be treated as asbestos material." Removal would cost about $60 per tonne, compared to the normal rate of between $7 and $9 per tonne.
A further article headed, `Union demands delayed building', states:

PARA.TAB: A lift driver who had a car accident and was off work "collected" wages at the troubled Premiers Apartments site at North Sydney even though he was off work for the whole period.

SPEECH.PARA: Then we had the amazing incident in 1989 where Industrial Equity Ltd advanced $950,000 to Girvan Corporation to buy a crane. When Girvan went bust, IEL discovered what a simple check of the paperwork would have shown if it had been carried out much earlier: the crane price was $850,000 and, anyway, Girvan had leased rather than bought it. `The rackets uncovered' is a heading in the Australian Financial Review. It states:

PARA.TAB: Builders on occasion appear to have been swayed by threats of union-inspired disruption to terminate certain sub-contracts.

SPEECH.PARA: `Site costs doubled, inquiry told' is another heading, and on it goes. The reality is that a balanced look at this cannot avoid the conclusion that the whole question of industrial relations does lie at the heart of the need to reform this industry.

PARA.TAB: It is clear that the first step in any attempt to reform industrial relations in the industry must be the proscribing of compulsory unionism, the proscribing of the `No ticket, no start' rule, which forces large firms into inappropriate alliances, prevents them from dealing directly with their employees and excludes non-unionised subcontractors from the industry. Until compulsory unionism is banned, the industry will not be able to move towards genuine enterprise based operations and the unions will continue to be able to hold the industry to ransom to force one or two firms to capitulate.

Clearly, the reform strategy is not about to proscribe compulsory unionism. Its funding may, in any case, be jeopardised if the Royal Commission finds that the $1.5m donation from CERT was unlawful and must be repaid by the agency. In these circumstances, the Opposition could not support the strategy, however commendable some of its other goals might be. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to follow the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Anderson). He puts a great deal of effort into the material he presents to this place, but his references to the Gyles Royal Commission this evening have been selective. I am surprised at the nature of some of them because in the course of that inquiry many improper practices have been revealed and investigated and cannot, under any circumstances, be talked away or justified. If there are improper practices, be they on the part of employers or employees, they have to be dealt with in the appropriate place and in the appropriate manner.

PARA.TAB: I say that because the honourable member has dwelt upon quotes, reports and matters that relate to the performance of employees in the building industry. We in this place are all mature and experienced enough to know that it takes two to tango. In many cases a number of us, in the course of our work in our electorates, come across instances where proprietors or management of firms have indulged, in one way or another, in the expenditure of companies' moneys or resources on projects that did not go to the benefit of employees, union members, but went to the benefit of executives.

Fortunately, in our scheme of things, we have a Public Accounts Committee that applies close scrutiny to public expenditure. In the private sector there is no method by which shareholders, or people who feel aggrieved at how company money is used, can take their case to a similar examination. One day we will have that kind of process in this country, not the farce of annual general meetings, where the shareholders can go along and say, `The executives and the board misused the assets of this company and I, the shareholder with my 1,500 shares from my superannuation, demand that justice be done'. We all know that that is a nonsense. We all know that the process of annual general meetings and the mythical examination of expenditure and use of resources by the private sector are a farce.
The honourable member, for whom I have a great deal of affection, would do himself and this House better service if he put a bit more balance into the whole process.

TALK.START.PARA: —He might have mentioned George Herscu.

—He could have mentioned George Herscu. There is a range of people he could have mentioned. This is not just relating to the peanuts in some of these cases that involve construction work. Let us look at what happens with the high-fliers, the entrepreneurs of the last decade. Now we are talking about money. But enough of that. One of the problems with those practices in that industry at times of a heated economy is that costs can be passed on so readily. If someone is at the end of the line and he is getting his 15 per cent on cost overruns or extras, why would he seek to reduce those extras? Why would he be opposed to that? If someone were supervising or monitoring the contract, I know what he would be doing. He would be sitting there and getting his 15 per cent, or his commission, on the tendered price or the contracted price, plus provision for extras. He would say, `Mr Proprietor, these are matters beyond our control. I have looked at them and examined them and I cannot see any way that you can avoid payment. My commission goes on as well'.

PARA.TAB: There is really an incentive in the system to encourage overruns. Some of these practices have been so easily done. But this country cannot afford those kinds of practice. There is a demonstrable inequity in those kinds of events. The great bulk of people in the trade union movement are Australian working men and women who give their best to see that this country grows and improves, and that there is a fairer society and a better standard of living. When people are able to rip off the system—whether they are executives or employees—they do it at the cost of their fellow Australians.

The honourable member, like his colleagues earlier in the debate and like his colleagues in the Senate, said, `Look, why don't we wait until the Gyles Royal Commission comes down with a report?'. The honourable member cannot have it both ways; earlier in his remarks he said, `Why has it taken the Government so long? This is an urgent matter. It needs to be resolved. Why has the Government taken more than 18 months to bring this legislation in here?'. But he concludes by saying, `We really ought to wait until the Gyles Royal Commission report comes down, and the New South Wales Government works out what it wants to do'.

The strategy we are enacting and passing through this House this evening is one that has been developed on a comprehensive basis aimed at reform and development of the industry, a major national industry. It has been developed over more than 18 months, and developed with the cooperation of key industry and union parties together with other governments. There is an urgency for reform processes to be implemented now, and particularly to support that $2.3 billion worth of infrastructure expenditure.

This country demands the best value we can get for that expenditure. This economy needs it. Therefore in these circumstances there is an urgency. There is no more time to wait. We cannot have it both ways. In any event, the strategy can take into account measures arising from the New South Wales royal commission that would supplement the wide range of proposals contained in this strategy.

I suggest also that, given the current paralytic state of the New South Wales Government, and given the performance of that Government in respect of former Minister Metherell, are we really saying that that is a model that we want to wait on and watch? I am damn sure I do not. I know most of my constituents do not want to be following the New South Wales Government model that is proceeding at the moment.

Honourable members opposite had a great deal to say earlier in the debate about unions. We are talking about fellow Australians, because unionists are fellow Australians; they are not some kind of alien beings; they are not some kind of strange or less than normal Australians. They are decent, honourable Australians trying to rear their families and trying to help to build this country. Sure there are exceptions, but for every exception those opposite can find in a trade unionist I will find one in an executive. Tally them up and I will show where we will find the biggest cost to this country. It will not be on the side of the individual unionist. We are working through a system of improving industrial relations, our skills, our reliability and our efficiency.

Earlier I sat listening to the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Charles) and I thought, `Subcontractors are really God's gift to any country. They are so good. Why doesn't the whole nation function as subcontractors?'. In the course of our inquiry into the efficiency and performance of the road industry, the submission of the New South Wales Road and Traffic Authority—which is a public document—had this to say about subcontractors on really major road building projects:

SPEECH.PARA: More recently, the Special Conditions of Contract have been modified to improve protection for all sub-contractors on RTA projects. The need for this protection arose from two recent examples on a Federally funded project where the RTA had made payments to its contractor and the main contractors had paid their sub-contractors. However, those sub-contractors had defaulted in their payment of further sub-contractors whom they had employed on the work.

Who in this chamber has not read reports of subcontractors welshing on their suppliers or welshing on other subcontractors, and then bobbing up under another name a few months later and doing it all over again and, with a bit of luck, bobbing up again under another company name and doing it all over once more. They are not trade unionists. They are not crooked union officials. They are businessmen out there earning a living and being entrepreneurial. So there is not right on one side or the other. There are defects and deficiencies on both sides. After a long period of consultation this legislation is about the process that this Government has pursued in industrial relations. It is a process of consultation. If we sit all those involved around a table and put the facts on the table, I believe there is sufficient commitment from most Australians in this country for them to find the right and best solution.

PARA.TAB: Do those opposite think that they can brand employees, Australian working men and women, members of unions—some with bitter memories from the formation of those unions and the circumstances under which they were formed and whose relatives still have not forgotten the harshness and brutality of the Depression when Australians were shot and beaten because they were unemployed? Do not let us forget the background to all of this; it is not mythology. Those opposite should read our history. Do they think they can blackguard those people and get the best economic results in this country by blackguarding them and saying, `Abolish all unions. Get rid of them.'? That is what they are really saying. It is the New Zealand disaster model—get rid of unions.

When the honourable member for Lyne (Mr Cowan) retires and is looking for a job because he wants to earn some income, he will go along to the manager of a middle sized company with about 10 or a dozen employees and say, `I am the former member for Lyne. I am a very good employee. I think I am worth, at best, $458 per week. Mr employer, you should employ me'. We know that sort of thing is not going to happen. We know that on a one to one basis employees have no bargaining power except when they have the skill which is in very short supply. Then they will exact the best price they can; they would be fools if they did not. If there is no other labour available they will again exact the best price they can because that is all they have to offer—only their labour and their skill. But the vast bulk of people will be just one of a number of people, particularly in a period of high unemployment, who are outside the gate.

My friend the honourable member for Lyne well remembers what happened in the late 1930s outside the gates of BHP in Newcastle—he has read about it and he has talked to his constituents about it and they have told him about it—when people tramped from one end of the State to the other to stand like fools outside the gates waiting because they might be noticed. Have those opposite forgotten what happened down on the waterfront? Why are we suffering today the difficulties we have had to go through in reforming the waterfront? It is because of the bitter memories of people who desperately needed work and to be employed so they could feed their families and rear their families. They were treated like animals—`Select the one you want'. That is really what the Opposition is saying.

I have said this many times and I continue to say it: does any mother listening to this debate or any woman in this building really believe that her daughter who is in a queue of 50 people after the one job that is available—and that is what the Opposition wants, those kinds of conditions, the New Zealand situation—is going to get a fair go; to get the going wage of any other competitive firm, or is that employer going to say, as we have seen recently, `Sorry, we have had you on for a fortnight. I'm sorry I cannot pay you but you did not perform well enough. Really, I would like to pay you more, but there are people here who will be happy to take 30 per cent less.'? Mothers know that will happen.

TALK.START.PARA: —I'd give the workers a good go.

—The honourable member for Lyne would give them a good go, but he would not get one himself as a worker in that kind of regime; that is the difference. There is confusion in the misnomer; it is not a building industry. Everybody calls it a building industry and thinks of it as an industry. But it is not one industry; it is many industries of differing sizes, differing products, differing awards, differing arrangements and differing locations. There is not just one panacea one can use right across it and then say, `Look how well it is functioning', because it is not one industry; it is many industries.

PARA.TAB: Let us take the residential industry. I heard cottage building talked about earlier. I am sure some of my colleagues in this place have also read how their constituents as subcontractors in the cottage industry were welshed upon. They did the work, but the contractor above them shot through and they were not paid. But that is the Opposition policy. It is not our policy.

The non-residential industry—offices, shops, hotels, factories, schools, hospitals, engineering construction, the construction of roads and dams and ports, power stations, heavy industry facilities—covers a range of industries and a range of different locations. I find it so repugnant to hear the comment coming from the other side of the House that there can be an arrangement one to one and to get rid of unions, as the honourable member for Barker (Mr McLachlan) says so often and says so plausibly, `We will talk about this'. How would they propose to do this for a three-week job stacking bricks or for a brick layers assistant? Sometimes it rains; sometimes it does not. Sometimes it is boggy underfoot; sometimes it is not. Are those opposite serious? Have they thought through what they are saying? They need to go out and have a look at the multiplicity of and variation in conditions and see how impossible are the proposals they are putting.

We live in a period where we have had nil inflation in the last quarter. We have the lowest interest rates in a period approaching 20 years. We have had a 10 per cent reduction in real unit labour costs. We have had a 60 per cent reduction in the rate of industrial disputation—the number of working days lost per 1,000 employees. The unfortunate element we have is a higher level of unemployment than any of us want, particularly those of us on this side of the chamber. On the other side of the chamber, for the proposal that they want to work, they have to have a higher level of unemployment—the New Zealand model. It has a figure of 17 per cent registered unemployed and we can add what we like to the unregistered figure. The proposals of those opposite means that an employer can grind down an employee. That is what one to one means. There has to be a high level of unemployment.

On this side of the House, in those circumstances I have described, there is an opportunity for this economy to lift off. It is lifting off, and this economy will bounce back stronger and better than it has ever been before. It will come out of the recession with more than a 10 per cent reduction in real unit labour costs. Are those opposite saying that they do not want it? Or would they rather it not be there? Would they rather have a higher rate of inflation? Sure! Earlier I heard the honourable member for Gwydir saying that the costs that relate to cottage building could be reduced if it could be more efficient. He did not mention that under the goods and services tax of the Opposition the cost of an average new home will go up by $2,856—this is as a result of the imposition of a goods and services tax. So do not pay too much heed to wanting to get costs down; that is not really fair dinkum.

In this set of economic circumstances we have a chance to lift off. The way to do that is for industry and for the unions involved—for all of the parties involved—to sit down and come to an agreement relating to a much more progressive means of dealing with problems and sorting them out. Let me give my two colleagues opposite an example—the honourable member for Lyne and the honourable member for Gwydir whom I keep mentioning—because they are involved with me in the same region—

TALK.START.PARA: —Thanks for the publicity.

—Yes. The honourable member needs some votes, I understand. They are not bad fellows. But in our region in the Hunter Valley in just over a decade we have had $10 billion worth of major projects completed through site agreements. They are major projects there which were on time, within budget and within schedule, not on this `catch and kill your own' that the Opposition is proposing, the one on one, screw down whoever you can. It is not on that basis. It is on site agreements between unions and companies. All of those projects came in within time, on schedule and within budget. There are projects such as the Eraring power station, the Bayswater power station, a number of open cut collieries, extensions to the Kooragang coal loader and $110m spent on the Williamtown air base—a wonderful job. How was that all done? That was the Hunter model and those site agreements show what can be achieved.

PARA.TAB: The figures are now growing well above $10 billion but I mention that this evening as an example of hard fact of what is available and what can be done. That model has been followed elsewhere in Australia. The Sydney Harbour tunnel is being built under the same model agreement. Those opposite came in here tonight with this proposal, repeating what their colleagues have said in the Senate. None of it has any realism to it. It does not recognise the real world. I have described this in my comments.

I want to conclude on these points: the tragedy of all of this is that we have got people sitting opposite—the conservative parties—who after so many years in government have learnt nothing. Really, what they are saying to people of this country is this, `We want to get trade unions out of the picture. We want to get awards out of the picture. Effectively, we want to disadvantage people who are powerless, who have little industrial power and turn the clock back to the nineteenth century where it all started at the end of the Industrial Revolution'. That was the reason for unions and industrial organisations beginning. The reasons for awards being established were all the abuses and the exploitation of people back in that century.

That is a great leap back into the nineteenth century for those who sit opposite. As an Australian, I just do not understand the obsession they have with bashing unions and virtually hating unionists. I ask honourable members opposite who have commonsense and some humanity to start thinking again. Opposition policies are irrelevant and are an obstruction to better industrial relations. It is the reason most business organisations and businesses are turning their backs on the Opposition. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —We did not hear very much from the honourable member for Shortland (Mr Peter Morris) on the Construction Industry Reform and Development Bill, so I assume this is a fairly wide-ranging debate on industrial relations. I understand the honourable member for Shortland is a former Minister for Industrial Relations, but here tonight he really struck me as attempting to defend the indefensible. I do not genuinely believe that the industrial relations system in this country can be defended. By any measure it has failed.

PARA.TAB: In my remarks tonight I want to demonstrate the extent of that failure. I want to say to the honourable member for Shortland who has just spoken that the industrial relations debate is not about fault—it is not about whether employees or employers are at fault. We are talking about the fact that this Government is at fault. This debate is about the performance or, more correctly, the non-performance of this Government in industrial relations.

I believe that the honourable member's defence of the role of trade unions, if we are to talk about that here, is hollow. I wonder whether he believes it. Maybe he does; maybe it has not yet dawned on him that we must change and that we must change quickly.

The honourable member talked about New Zealand, and I suppose we will hear quite a lot about New Zealand in the months ahead. Members of the Government may slowly become embarrassed when they become aware that New Zealand, being 10 years ahead of us in the process of reform, is beginning to see results. I do not suppose they want to know that, but it is. It is seeing very substantial productivity gains from the reforms that the Labour Party, to its credit, started in that country a number of years back. Those reforms have been continued by the present National Party Government in New Zealand. The result will be a more competitive economy in New Zealand with more jobs and prosperity. New Zealand will very quickly leave us behind unless we catch up. But we will not catch up under this Government because it is absolutely bound to an ideology that is outdated and irrelevant to the situation in Australia today.

What has this Government given us? What has this industrial relations system that we are labouring under now given us? It has given us huge debts, simply because it has enabled that to occur, and of course it has given us huge unemployment. Behind all of this we still have a plethora of deplorable work practices. The record of union abuses is a mile long. We really must move on. To use the words that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) used some time back, the caravan has moved on. The Labor Party, in an industrial relations sense, has been left way behind.

A building industry reform strategy—and that is what we are talking about in this Bill—is to be thrust upon us after years of abuses, rorts, violence and intimidation in that industry which have cost the Australian economy incalculable millions, if not billions, of dollars. Even now there is considerable suspicion about this so-called reform agenda with which we have been presented.

There is doubt in the minds of honourable members on this side that this is really reform at all. We suspect, like many of the other reforms in the industrial relations area that have been presented to us by this Government, that it is simply a Claytons reform like most, if not all, of the reforms this Government has talked about. The Government has been very big on rhetoric but very short indeed on results in reform in the workplace.

But our concerns go further than even doubt about whether we are talking about real reform here tonight. The Government's proposed reforms of the construction industry are of very doubtful value to the industry as a whole. It is a strategy to adopt and to entrench the BWIU agenda and to turn undesirable State practices and standards into national standards by extending the union's reach into the cottage sector of the building and construction industry.

The effect of this, quite clearly—and, I suspect, quite intentionally—is to lock out small specialist contractors such as skilled tradesmen and professionals, because the Government is all about big unions and centralisation of power which, of course, eliminates the small person in this industry. We on this side believe that is the real intention, and that is why we are opposed to this legislation.

In the Government's vocabulary this is reform, but it is designed to further entrench practices which are not really reforms at all but measures to further look after union mates. Is that not what industrial relations is all about from the Government's point of view? Ultimately it boils down to looking after union mates and, wherever possible, to increasing their powers and, coincidentally, to enabling and condoning abuses of those powers.

It is no wonder that when we look at this legislation we find that several small industry organisations have refused to be involved in the process. Quite clearly others have been pressured or coerced into doing so. Some of my colleagues on this side of the House tonight have indicated how many times there have been clear instances of coercion, intimidation and pressure applied to employers and employer organisations. The real intention here, the real agenda with this legislation—as is the case with most of the Government's legislation and so-called workplace reform—is to entrench compulsory unionism. This is the only way in which the power of the union can be maintained and union bureaucrats can hold down their cushy jobs.

Without `no ticket, no shop', probably no-one would join. Why would they join? At least under the sort of system we are talking about, where we will outlaw compulsory unionism, outlaw the closed shop, the unions will have to perform. They will have to be out there selling their services. We see a place for trade unionism within the system that we propose. We have no real problem with that. But what we do say is that workers will have a choice about whether they will or will not join. That choice has not been given to them in many industries in this country. They will choose to join a union where that union can demonstrate to its workers, to the people in an industry or in an enterprise, that it can deliver a service. That is fair, equitable and, to my mind, what the good old Australian fair go is all about.

We know that union membership in the private sector in particular has fallen to historically low levels, to somewhere about 30 per cent only of the private sector work force, and I think it would be considerably lower except for the fact that a small number of industries still have effective entrenched compulsory unionism. That is to be deplored. Incidentally, when we look at those industries—the motor vehicle industry in particular—we see that they are the ones that are heavily protected. That is where the argument about protection in recent times really comes home because we see that it is behind those high barriers that unions have absolutely thrived.

I am prepared to admit to the honourable member for Shortland, at least in respect of some of those industries, that management has acquiesced, often under pressure or intimidation, but behind those barriers unions have thrived. Coincidentally, many of those industries are the ones where we have effective compulsory unionism. Both of those things need to go: the protection and the compulsory unionism.

Unfortunately the history of trade unionism in this country is littered with cases of abuse of power. As I have already said tonight, I do not want to get into the argument of whether it is the fault of employers or employees. The real debate ultimately boils down to the performance of this Government. Nevertheless, it must be a great embarrassment to this Government and, indeed, to the Labor Party that there have been so many cases of huge abuses of union power.

We are talking about the building and construction industry tonight. We only have to think back to the Builders Labourers Federation. That is an embarrassment. The honourable member for Brisbane (Mr Bevis) is embarrassed. We talk about the BLF! What a terrific case history in the way that a union contributes to the workplace and to work practices. We look at the history of the BLF which was for so long a prominent player in the construction industry. The BLF has the distinction of being the only trade union which has been deregistered twice under the Federal industrial relations system. It exhibited consistently reprehensible conduct. There is reason to suspect that the BWIU, which is a party to the arrangements that we are talking about tonight, is not too far removed at all from the BLF. Some of the personalities are there; some of the same faces are there; and some of the same practices are there.

The Government's record on workplace reform could be described only as woeful. Australia has been a consistent economic under-performer for years, but particularly in the years since 1983. Productivity performance in this country has been poor by international standards. In terms of productivity growth on a per annum basis, we have lagged well behind the seven major industrial countries. The fact is that the Government, even if it had the will to move apace with real reform, is completely hamstrung by its relations with the union movement. The accord, on which almost all of its economic strategy is apparently based and upon which it claims great success, actually is very much to blame for the problems. The accord process has put the industrial relations power fairly and squarely in the hands of ACTU. The accord is at the heart of our structural problems and our macro-economic difficulties.

A unique relationship exists between the ALP and the union movement. Many unions are affiliated with the ALP. Unions contribute a percentage of union dues from their members to the ALP. Another thing that we want to outlaw is this mechanism by which employers collect—which may be by force or intimidation—union dues from their employees. The obnoxious thing about that is that many of the members of those unions do not even vote for the ALP. We are talking mainly about the union bureaucrats, but the average worker that I meet these days wants to get rid of the ALP; yet if they belong to unions, some of their union dues are actually finding their way into ALP funds. I think that is completely obnoxious.

They say, `He who pays the piper calls the tune'. That exactly sums up the relationship between the ALP and the union movement, and we only have to watch them in action. When Mr Kelty says, `Jump', Mr Keating's response is `How high?'. That is the relationship between the union movement and the ALP. The union movement calls the tune. The ACTU, incidentally, is rewarded consistently by the Government. It is represented on over 50 government boards and advisory committees including, of all things, the Reserve Bank. If there was ever a case of putting Dracula in charge of the blood bank, that is it.

When the trade union movement, the ACTU, got into business itself, it consistently went broke. It tried to get into the department store business and went down the tubes. Then it got into the service station business and it went broke. So it is pretty good at going broke itself. It has had a fair hand in many other businesses going broke as well where its practices have become entrenched.

The Labor Government will not countenance freer industrial relations between employers and their employees, which would lead to sensible work practices and increase productivity. This is because of the relationship between the union movement and the Labor Party; it is a relationship which leads to the abuses that we have been talking about.

Pacific Dunlop Ltd has been in the news in recent days. Some evidence that it has provided is actually very interesting. It shows us that 284 employees from a Pacific Dunlop subsidiary, Edgell and Birds Eye Foods, have lost their jobs because of the Keating-Kelty connection and because the Government will not allow them to get on with running their businesses. Martin Ferguson recently claimed that the ACTU was `in partnership with the ALP in government'. Trade unions are granted exemptions from paying tax and that confers all sorts of privileges on them. Over $30m has been provided in the form of grants to the union movement by the Hawke Government in the 1983 to 1989-90 period. In return, the union movement donates to the ALP. It is a very cosy arrangement, I am sure. It goes a long way in explaining why genuine workplace reform has been so slow and why we are so doubtful about the Government's bona fides in respect of this Bill that we are talking about tonight.

I think it really boils down to this in my view: the ALP cannot be trusted with reform of the workplace. That nexus that exists between the ALP and the union movement is so close and so cosy that it cannot deliver. It is completely hamstrung in respect of the delivery of reform. What we are talking about in this particular legislation is not reform.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member will get his go in a minute, and I will listen with interest to what he has to say. This is an excuse for reform. We, on this side of the House, are not fooled because we have seen too much evidence of the Government's approach to reform. It is painfully slow; it is inadequate; and, as I say, it is dominated by the Keating-Kelty connection. That is ultimately what it is all about.

PARA.TAB: The honourable member for Brisbane is here, so let me finish with a few gems for him to think about. It is to do with our own State of Queensland. The activities of the Federated Engine Drivers and Firemen's Association actually make the BLF look a bit respectable. It was no wonder that the Goss Government in Queensland could not get its hands quickly enough on Martin Cooke and shut him up. It wanted to close down the Cooke inquiry. It could not close it down quickly enough. When we look at activities of the FEDFA, as revealed in the Cooke inquiry, we find that $2m of FEDFA funds passed through 15 secret bank accounts held by ALP Vice-President, Ken Goodhew, and others. Ninety-four thousand dollars of this money was illegally transferred out of secret bank accounts to the ALP. Rank and file union members, it transpires, were being ripped off by the union bureaucrats. Their union dues were being used for the personal comforts and interestingly, as the Cooke inquiry found out, the sexual gratification of union bosses. This is quite incredible stuff. As I say, this makes Norm Gallagher look pretty good. Norm was not such a bad fellow at all when one puts him up against Ken Goodhew. Ken Goodhew then had the audacity to use $52,000 of union funds to buy himself a unit on the Gold Coast. He lived in my electorate for a while, but I am sure that he did not vote for me in any case. He certainly did not have permission to use that money.

The Opposition opposes this Bill because it, like all of the other workplace and industrial reforms that we have been presented with by this Government, is a con; it is Claytons reform. We challenge the Government to get serious about reform in the workplace; we will. We have a plan to make Australia competitive, to change the industrial relations system and the unions. Whilst they will have a role in it, they will not dominate. The Keating-Kelty connection will disappear out the door.
Debate interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., I propose the question:

PARA.TAB: That the House do now adjourn.

TALK.START.PARA: —I call the honourable member for Dunkley.

—Mr Speaker, this evening I wish to raise a number of important issues relating to war veterans and Australia's military achievements. I was called the honourable member for Ford today. Not too many people have their own electorate named after them.
—Not in their own lifetime anyway.

—That is right. At a recent State council meeting of the RSL, a number of resolutions were adopted. I believe that several are worthy of consideration by this House. The first relates to the question of free travel for the veterans of World War II. Some years ago the Victorian Government decided to give free travel to veterans of the Great War when they reached the age of 80 years. This travel concession was well received throughout the veterans community and widely supported in the general community.

PARA.TAB: It is my belief that this concession should also be extended to our World War II veterans when they reach the age of 80 years. With the exception of conscripts to the Pacific theatre of war from January 1943 onwards, all members of the Australian Imperial Force have been volunteers. Indeed, as anyone who has visited the Australian War Memorial would know, the commitment of the Australian people to their country in both the Great War and the 1939-45 war, to say the least, was overwhelming.

One need only read Michael McKernan's excellent work on Australia's participation in the Second World War to realise the extent to which citizens from all walks of life and backgrounds contributed to the war effort. In fact, the title All In! encapsulates Australia's response to that war.

Secondly, the RSL National Congress raised the issue of damage to the nation's war memorials and shrines of remembrance. It is, indeed, a sorry state of affairs that citizens might deliberately damage these memorials, many of which were paid for in the 1920s from the savings of ordinary Australians. I believe that the present penalties are not adequate to cope with these very sad crimes.

Thirdly, the RSL has suggested that schools should include Australia's involvement in war in the teaching of history. I fully support the RSL in its excellent recommendation. All young Australians have the right to know the achievements of their forebears. They have the right to know that the freedoms and privileges that they enjoy have been hard fought for, and often at great personal cost. Indeed, they should know, as the oppressed people of eastern Europe have known for decades, that democracy and democratic institutions are fundamental to freedom and a decent way of life. They should never be taken for granted. All young Australians have the right to know that the cemeteries of Gallipoli, the Western Front, Singapore, the Burma railway and New Guinea remain as a tribute to the sacrifices of the thousands of Australians who fought for a better world.

It is incredible that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has suddenly discovered that Australia has a military history and that Australians fought off the Japanese in the Pacific war. Perhaps he would support the proposition that I have just outlined.

At an Anzac Day ceremony last Saturday at Seaford in my electorate one speaker made what I believe were very telling comparisons between our wartime commitment and the current economic situation. In conflict, thousands of the nation's young men and women sacrificed their lives for something they believed in. They knew there was a great cause to fight for. They were prepared to defend their country and to fight for the freedoms in which they believed, and for the future.

Yet, in the 1990s we are sacrificing the future of 30 per cent of our young men and women for a failed political philosophy. They are being sacrificed on the altar of the Prime Minister's personal ambition, consigned to the scrap heap of unemployment or incarcerated in a secondary school or a Dawkins university. Their future looks pretty bleak.

The speaker at this Anzac Day ceremony suggested that we should conduct a war against the scourge of unemployment, against the lack of opportunity, against the vested interests of the individuals in the industrial relations club which has made full employment in Australia illegal. He did not realise that the campaign should start in this chamber, with both sides working out a solution to this self-imposed conflict. It would mean the scaling down of Canberra, of its institutions, of its excesses, and the resources directed to worthwhile and genuine long term employment opportunities. It would mean the abolition of the IR club and its grotesque disemployment of the nation's youth over the last 20 years. It would mean freedom of association, the deregulation of the labour market and the creation of genuine opportunities for our young people. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hollis Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tomorrow, 1 May, is May Day. This day had its origins in the industrial cities of nineteenth century America. In 1884 a conference of United States and Canadian trade unions set 1 May 1886 as the day on which to commence strike action in pursuit of their goal for an eight-hour working day. At that time many workers were working as many as 15 or 18 hours a day, from sunrise to sunset—a bit like present day Australian politicians.

PARA.TAB: In Australia, by comparison, we already had the eight-hour working day. This right had been won as early as 1855 by the Operative Stonemasons Society in Sydney and soon afterwards by similar building trade unions in Melbourne and Sydney. The right was not easily won. It came as a result of strike action and processions, followed by negotiation. Indeed, I might add that in the entire history of industrial relations only very rarely have important rights been won by workers through negotiation, where that negotiation was not first proceeded by some demonstration of worker strength and unity of purpose.

Honourable members might be interested in the words of the slogan used by the stonemasons in their struggle for the eight-hour day: eight hours to work, eight hours to play, eight hours to sleep and eight bob a day. This slogan became the basis of the American trade unionists' call for a just working day when they took up the fight towards the end of the nineteenth century. The main centre of the North American struggle was the industrial city of Chicago. Here, too, the struggle was not easily won.

On that first industrial workers day, May Day, in 1886, 25,000 workers took to the streets of that city. Employers and government were alarmed and called out the police. On 3 May the police attacked a meeting of striking workers outside the McCormick reaper works. Six workers were killed and many wounded. The following day another four workers and seven policemen were killed in Chicago's Haymarket Square. Eventually four labour leaders were arrested, tried and hanged. They became the union's martyred dead and symbols of the struggle.

The custom of holding workers demonstrations and celebrations on May Day quickly spread from America to Europe and Australia. May Day was first celebrated by Australian workers at Barcaldine in Queensland in 1891. The early 1890s were years of struggle between unions, which were determined to hang on to their hard won rights, and many employers, who spoke openly of their determination to crush the unions or else replace them with tame ones—similar to some of the words we have heard in this chamber tonight!

In 1891 the focus of this conflict shifted to Queensland. In Queensland the squatters were preparing to break the shearers union by bringing in non-union labour from the south. The Queensland Government sent out police and armed troops. The shearers were arrested and gaoled. At the same time in Brisbane, mindful that shearers were marching in the face of the troopers gun, Henry Lawson was writing Freedom on the Wallaby, with his famous lines:

SPEECH.PARA: So we must fly a rebel flag
As others did before us

It is a pity that we did not hear a little more about the rebel flag instead of seeing some of the flags that are cluttering this place. Sadly, the shearers' struggle was lost on that occasion and their leaders were gaoled. But the struggle for unionism and better working conditions has continued. Today the battle that Australian shearers have is with the scab labour from New Zealand. Today Australian workers face many of the same problems as those faced by the shearers of nineteenth century Queensland. There are many persons—employers and organisations, not the least being many of those sitting on the Opposition benches—that would seek to cripple the union movement and to replace unionists with scab labour. It may be dressed up in other words, but that is what it is: scab labour. We only had to listen to the speech delivered not 20 minutes ago by the honourable member for McPherson (Mr Bradford) to find proof of what I am saying. That is what those opposite are proposing—scab labour.

PARA.TAB: That is not the way ahead. This is a recipe for industrial and social disaster. There is another way to go. This way is based on greater union and worker participation in industry. Industrial relations today must be viewed within the context of today's world. The ways of the New Right and those opposite are the ways of the last century. It is time they were forsaken forever.
