Tomorrow night I will attend the Toast to May Day in my electorate and on Saturday I will proudly march through the streets of Wollongong with my union colleagues.

I will conclude by sounding a note of warning to those antiquarians who refuse to move out of the nineteenth century and learn their lessons from history. What the workers of the world are celebrating tomorrow and on each and every May Day is their strength, their unity of purpose and their firm resolve to struggle in the face of persecution and adversity. Time and again they have proved that they can be pushed just so far and no further. They will march tomorrow to celebrate just that—and long may they do so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McArthur Mr F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Olympic Games in Barcelona are but a few short months away. Cycling is one of the more interesting spectator sports held at every Olympics. Australia has produced some great cyclists over the years. Who could forget Sir Hubert Opperman, who was a world champion in his own right, and also represented the electorate of Corio in this House in such a fine manner for so many years?

PARA.TAB: In 1991-92 the Australian Cycling Federation will receive $1,395,000 in taxpayers' funds. The Federation has a duty to act in an accountable manner, not only to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories (Mrs Kelly) but also to the wider Australian community. I view with concern the activities of the selectors in the forthcoming final Olympic selection trials which will commence in France next Thursday with an acclimatisation race.

A constituent of mine, Donna Rae Szalinski, has alleged that the selectors have not performed their duties with the necessary care and responsibility that such a serious business as picking competitors, and hopefully medal chances, for the Olympics deserves. All of these female cyclists have applied total devotion to training for the squad and therefore are entitled to a fair evaluation of their ability.

Donna is a Canadian by birth and an Australian citizen. She has performed excellently in the preparatory training camps held by the Australian Institute of Sport in Adelaide under the direction of coach Gary West. In all items of physiological assessment, Donna has been measured in the top three. At the final camp which was held this month she came first in the individual time trial, had the second highest measure of oxygen consumption and, perhaps most importantly, managed to reach heights of achievement that had not been previously attained by female cyclists at the Australian Institute of Sport in Adelaide.

Today, in a telephone conversation with the chief selector, Alex Fulcher, Donna was apparently informed that this gentleman was unaware of her performance in the hill climbing sessions at the Adelaide camp up an escarpment known as Nortons Summit. The Olympic race of 80 kilometres will be on a hilly track, but with climbs of lesser duration than this Adelaide test. In Adelaide, Donna and her colleague Kathy Watt managed to break away from all other riders on one occasion, and on another occasion Donna was a clear leader.

The Olympic selectors assessed the female cyclists on only two occasions as to how they would go in a bunch sprint. On one occasion Donna finished ahead of three of the four who are presently to go to Europe for the final trials. The other race saw Donna beat one of the four others home. The selectors have stated to Donna that the camps in Adelaide were not the only measure of the cyclists' ability. Yet a minute from the AIS states clearly that the camps were:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . to be conducted at the AIS in Adelaide for the purpose of identifying three females to represent Australia at the Barcelona Olympic Games.
Has subjective opinion proved more important? The selectors did not attend the training camps or the races of the road squad. How much in taxpayers' funds has been effectively wasted in this charade?

PARA.TAB: Mr Martin Whitely, the executive director of the Australian Cycling Federation, has stated to Donna that the selectors have predicted that the Olympic road race will be a bunch finish and the four girls have been selected on that criterion. Donna having fulfilled all of the conditions laid down for selection and, on that basis, being in the top three of the squad, it is hard to understand why she has not been chosen to participate in the European squad seeking final Olympic selection.

The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories must sort out this mess quickly. Even if Donna cannot be on tomorrow's plane, it would be acceptable for her to be on Monday's flight in her bid to represent Australia. What is more, she is prepared to pay her own way if she is part of the official Australian team.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I would like to endorse the remarks of the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis) and recognise that this weekend we celebrate Labour Day with the trade union movement. Of course, in Queensland, it will be celebrated on Monday and, unfortunately, I will not be available to march in Gladstone because of requirements in the House.

PARA.TAB: The honourable member for Throsby mentioned the early struggles in the United States. One man I would like to mention is Joe Hill, who paid with his life in fighting for the rights and freedoms of the working men and women of this country. It is ironical that tonight during the adjournment debate the honourable member for McPherson (Mr Bradford) attacked the trade union movement and organised labour, as did other honourable members when speaking to the Construction Industry Reform and Development Bill, to which I also spoke.

It is interesting that the honourable member for McPherson, who represents the Gold Coast, which is a wonderful area, also represents from the side of privilege in the Liberal Party the spivs in the white shoe brigade, the blokes who came up in the Fitzgerald inquiry. It is interesting to note that the honourable member for McPherson criticised the Labor Party and the union movement on the basis of their being involved in business. The biggest business in this country is government, and this Government is the best government in the postwar period. The record stands and it will stand forever.

If we look at the performance of the Liberals in Queensland—the Liberals to whom the honourable member for McPherson belongs—we will see that for 26 out of 32 years they were part of the coalition Government in Queensland, a government wracked by corruption and incompetence. Of course, we saw three members of the Cabinet thrown into gaol and the chief law officer, Terry Lewis—a knight of the realm—was also thrown into gaol.

One other previous speaker tonight accused the Government of not doing enough for young unemployed people. I would like to point out the fallacy of the statement that 30 per cent of the young people in this country are unemployed. That is not true; the figure is 10 per cent. The majority of young people aged between 15 and 19 years are engaged in study at secondary institutions, tertiary institutions or at TAFE. The Government, seeing the need for reskilling and training, will contribute $750m over the next three years, in conjunction with State governments, to expand our facilities in TAFE.

That is in contrast to the Opposition, which makes the claim about the scrap heap. It is the Labor Party that is putting that money up front; it is the Labor Government that intends to ensure that universal health cover is maintained; it is the Labor Government that is prepared to ensure that adequate wages are maintained through award conditions; and it is the Labor Government that is defending the very institutions that give young people an opportunity. We are not interested in creating a scenario where we have cheap illegal Mexican labour. We are not interested in creating a scenario where award conditions are broken down. It is hypocritical for those people on the other side to talk about that.

It is also hypocritical for Opposition members to come in here, put our Australian flag on the desk and play the games they have played in the last week. It is the Opposition that has grovelled to the British for the last 50 years. It is the National Party in Queensland, in particular, that is more interested in knighthoods—and most knights in Queensland finish up behind iron bars. It is ironical that it is the National Party that is prepared to dud our farmers, farmers who cannot sell our produce because of the corruptive trade practices of the British and the Europeans. The National Party would rather grovel at the feet of the Europeans—particularly the British—instead of standing up and being proud to be Australian.

Those opposite can sit there with the Australian flag in front of them and talk about being proud of their country and proud of the flag; but when it really comes to a choice between sticking up for Australian farmers and selling out for knighthoods, the National Party in particular is more than happy to grovel at the feet of the aristocracy in Britain rather than stand up and fight for Australia.

The same applied during World War II. Any time the Opposition wants to bring it on, I would love to have an open debate for three or four hours about the history of World War II and what happened then. It is ironical that those on the other side of the House want to display all of these Australian flags and say how patriotic they are, but when it comes to telling the British where they get off, those opposite, instead of being proud to be Australian, would rather grovel and throw themselves at the feet of third-rate aristocrats in the House of Lords who are gout-ridden and full of whisky. It is ironical that members of the British aristocracy will cry when a horse breaks his sesamoid bone, but they will not blink an eye when two million Irish starve to death.

There is no way I will support that sort of hypocrisy and double standards by third-rate aristocrats from England. I would rather be proud to be an Australian. That is the difference between our side of the House and the Opposition side. Those opposite can grovel as much as they like. Menzies grovelled for years during the war, but it was Curtin who brought the Australian troops home. Let us have a full debate on that matter. (Time expired).

TALK.START.PARA: —I say to the former speaker, the honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Courtice), that I think we are all proud to be Australian. I want to make a few brief remarks tonight about the 7.30 Report, which I happened to be watching earlier in the evening. It related to the resource security legislation. There was a performance by the Minister for Resources (Mr Griffiths). I do not doubt that he has had a very difficult time with this piece of legislation. I know that he has had extensive negotiations with colleagues from my own State of Tasmania and, indeed, with my colleagues the shadow Minister for primary industry, the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd) and the shadow Minister for sustainable development and the environment, the honourable member for Pearce (Mr Chaney). He has also had extensive negotiations with the industry—the National Forests Industries Association, the Tasmanian Forest Industry Group and the Forest Industries Association of Tasmania, FIAT.

PARA.TAB: The amazing thing that has happened with regard to this piece of legislation is that it now appears that, in the face of a possible negotiated settlement which would have allowed this piece of legislation to pass, it may now not pass. But interestingly tonight, the Minister, when pressed particularly strongly by the interviewer, Mr Lyneham, appeared to back away and said that there would be the opportunity early next week for the situation to be salvaged. I would have hoped that would be the case.

From the point of view of a Tasmanian watching this issue over the last four or five months—I think it is nearly six months now—I have to express extreme disappointment with one of my Tasmanian colleagues the honourable member for Denison (Mr Kerr), because he has had the long time view that this legislation ought not to be amended to accommodate industry needs. We have got to the position in this place in the last couple of days where the views of industry had been accepted by the Government and there was to be a change of the Bill, a change in the title, to make it project specific. That would have meant that we may well have seen the legislation pass in the Senate to the benefit of all Australians. We would have seen the potential of a billion dollar investment in a pulp mill, adding value to that primary resource, meeting all those requirements and all the rhetoric that so many people in this place carry on with. All of a sudden, when the Minister went to the office of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) with his negotiated settlement with industry and the Opposition, he was told, as it was revealed tonight in the 7.30 Report, that he had to go and talk to the left wing of the Labor Party and to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories (Mrs Kelly) and get their concurrence to the changes that he was proposing. I have to say that the Opposition had given substantial ground in this matter, as had the industry, because we primarily want to get that mill up; we need that mill in this country. When the Minister for Resources went along with his negotiated in good faith agreement, he could not secure the support of the left wing or the Minister and he came back and said tonight on television that it would appear that the matter cannot proceed.

The interesting thing is that the Prime Minister has been sitting on his hands and has not said anything about this. He went into the prime ministership with the obvious support of some in the Left: perhaps he had the support of the honourable member for Denison, I do not know; perhaps he had the support of the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories, I do not know. But I have to say that this issue and this decision by the ALP over the last 24 hours have a smack of acute politics about them rather than any broader assessment of what is good public policy and what is good for job creation and industry development in this country.

I say tonight that I am ashamed that my Tasmanian colleague has not stood up for the development of industry in his State. I think he has sold out his State. I am dismayed, as are so many thinking people within both industry and finance right around this country, that the Government has got itself in this position. According to the Minister tonight, there is still time. There is still time. As I understand it, the Bill will be talked out tonight and there will be an opportunity on Monday to salvage the situation. I appeal for a bit of commonsense. Let us put growth first, let us put jobs first. Let us have balanced forestry policies in this country, and let us not let left wing politics dominate an outcome which will be disastrous for all of us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I want to talk about the wool industry because it is Australia's greatest industry; it is the most decentralised industry. Before I do, I just want to refer to the comments of my colleague the honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Courtice) who spoke earlier. I point out to him that Britain has offered Australia no sovereign threat for probably 40 years. It has no influence on our domestic policy or foreign policy and it seems rather late in the day to be tilting that particular windmill. I do not quite know why he went off on that tangent; I was quite enjoying his speech until it became inaccurate.

PARA.TAB: On the subject of wool, the Australian Wool Corporation has called its annual general meeting and the shareholders, the woolgrowers of Australia, are going to attend. There is a peculiar arrangement here in the voting pattern. If motions are put forward by the Australian Wool Corporation, they require only a third of the eligible votes for them to be passed. However, motions coming from the floor, from woolgrowers, require a two-thirds majority. I am told that this form of democracy also applies in the AMLC. I am not particularly interested in the AMLC at this stage, but I am vitally interested in the wool industry because of its importance to Australia. I just do not see how this situation can be allowed to continue.

I was debating today with Mr Jackson on radio the fact that this is a whole new AWC, which is now working entirely in the interests of growers and has their interests at heart. They are fine words, but it seems to me that the rhetoric does not match the actions. The AWC seems to me to be going down the same road that the previous AWC went down. Indeed, there are many people who are common to both the old and the new AWC.

One of the things that beset growers is the constant demand from these organisations that purport to speak on their behalf for extra money for promotion. That is something which needs to be analysed. If we look at the wool industry since 1970, we see that in 1970 there was 1,672,000 tonnes of wool sold. Sixteen years later, in 1986, there was 1,926,000 tonnes of wool sold—an increase of 15,302 tonnes per year. That is all. If we take the IWS figure of $100m, feed in the appropriate factors for inflation and what not, and attribute all the money spent to get those new sales, it works out that it was costing 14.84c a kilogram to get every extra kilogram of wool sold. These figures are very stark. If a person is paying three times as much to promote the sale of wool as he is getting for the wool he will simply go broke.

It would be interesting to compare that with cotton. In that same year, 1970, 11,950,000 tonnes of cotton was sold. Sixteen years later 16,960,000 tonnes was sold—an increase of over five million tonnes. On less than 10 per cent of the wool budget, cotton is able to get that sort of improvement in end use. That works out at something like 0.08c a kilogram. On this basis, I would be very wary of giving anybody—the IWS or the Australian Wool Corporation—any more money for promotion. In my view, the present budget is more than enough. It is hard to cut back. I would simply maintain the status quo. I would not increase it at all. It is quite clear that the Wool Realisation Commission does not need vast amounts of growers' money. The wool would probably sell now out of the stockpile without any loss, but to cover the growers for incompetence and other measures I am prepared to concede them 2c. We could reduce that wool tax to 5 per cent. A 5 per cent wool tax would give the wool industry a chance. It seems a nonsense to me to tax the wool

SPEECH.PARA: industry so heavily when it is on its knees, and to tax it as a precaution for something that may never happen when the real dilemma, the real problem with wool is now.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Land Transport, upon notice, on 26 February 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has his attention been drawn to an increase in recent years of the number of defective stamps and philatelic material being released by Australia Post.

(2) Has his attention been drawn to a submission concerning this matter which I made to the Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure during its inquiry into the administration of philatelic services.
(3) Did Australia Post advise that a revised set of procedures would remedy security problems arising during printing and issue of philatelic material.
(4) Has there been an increase in the incidence of defective philatelic material since the revised set of procedures was introduced; if so, why.
(5) Has his attention been drawn to the premium which attaches to errors in philatelic material and the resulting profits to be made by resellers.

(6) Will he ask for a full report on the security procedures which allow the occurrence of such defects as misprints, miscuts, perforation errors, double prints and overprinting of stained or blemished paper.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question, based on advice from Australia Post, is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Australia Post advises me that it is not aware of any increase in recent years in the amount of defective material being released on to the philatelic market.

Defects in stamps and philatelic material are a normal occurrence in the printing/production process, however, strict quality control and security procedures are in place to safeguard against defective material finding its way on to the market.

(2) I am aware of the submission on this matter which the honourable member made to the Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure during its inquiry into the administration of philatelic services by Australia Post.

(3) No. Australia Post advises me that it continuously monitors its stamp production and security procedures to ensure that they are adequate to identify any problems which may arise during the printing and issue of philatelic material.
(4) No. If the honourable member is aware of such material, I would appreciate it if he could provide me with full details so that the matter can be thoroughly investigated by Australia Post.

(5) I am aware of the potential profit to be made by the sale of defective philatelic material, however, I am advised by Australia Post that the release of such material has not been a problem in recent years. Australia Post advises me that it reviewed its security procedures for printing and is not aware of any material produced since 1988. Any material that is brought to the attention of Australia Post has been thoroughly investigated.

(6) No. Australia Post advises me that strict quality control and security procedures are in place to safeguard against defective material being released on to the market. In fact, the Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure inspected the current printing operation as part of its review and subsequently noted in this report that "it was very impressed with both the quality control and security arrangements in place for the printing of philatelic material." The Committee went on to note that "all possible steps have been taken to ensure that the quality of the stamps produced is both uniform and of high standard and safeguards against defective material being pilfered are more than adequate".

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Shipping and Aviation, upon notice, on 4 March 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Does the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) propose to reduce Search and Rescue (SAR) staffing levels from 5 March 1992.

(2) Has the Civil Air Operations Officers' Association expressed an intention to recommend to SAR mission co-ordinators not to accept duty where no rated assistant SAR mission co-ordinator is rostered on a shift; if so, would the recommended action impede the CAA in carrying out any of its SAR functions.
(3) Do the staffing decisions of the CAA compromise its SAR capabilities.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Shipping and Aviation has supplied the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) No; the CAA will maintain its current six Rescue Co-ordination Centres, staffed 24 hours a day by SAR mission co-ordinators and assistant SAR mission co-ordinators, pending the outcome of a current review of the SAR service.

(2) Yes; the Civil Air Operations Officers' Association has expressed this intention. However, the issue has been resolved with the Association and, as noted above, 24 hour coverage will be maintained pending the outcome of the review of the SAR service. If SAR mission co-ordinators were not to accept duty, this would impede the Authority in carrying out its SAR functions.
(3) No; the staffing decisions of the CAA have not compromised its SAR capabilities.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, upon notice, on 4 March 1992:

PARA.TAB: Is he able to provide the (a) titles, (b) dates and (c) essential provisions of legislation on Aboriginal rights in force in each State and Territory.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission has provided the following response to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: Up to date information concerning legislation on Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander rights in force in each State and Territory is contained within the publication entitled Halsbury's Laws of Australia, 1991 Volume 1, published by Butterworth's Pty Limited, ISBN 0 409 30437 9. As the publication is available in the Parliamentary Library, the Commission is not willing to authorise the staff resources required to reproduce or precis the information contained in this publication.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Australia Post: Slogan Postmarks on Envelopes

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Land Transport, upon notice, on 24 March 1992:

PARA.TAB: Is Australia Post using a slogan postmark on envelopes to advertise Coca Cola; if so, (a) when was the postmark first used, (b) what post offices or mail centres are using the postmark, (c) approximately how many postal articles receive the postmark each day, (d) what revenue is the postmark generating for Australia Post, (e) will other products, including alcohol and tobacco, and other companies be similarly advertised and (f) will the revenue generated through this form of advertising lead to lower prices for postal services.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question, based on advice from Australia Post, is as follows:

PARA.TAB: Yes. Australia Post has entered into a commercial agreement with Coca-Cola for the use of the postmarking slogan.
(a) Use of the postmarking slogan commenced on 1 December 1991.

(b) Five metropolitan Mail Centres in New South Wales are using the postmark—St Leonard's, Rushcutters Bay, Leightonfield, Turrella and Seven Hills. The postmark is used on Letter Processing Line machines only.
(c) Approximately 80 million letters per year are postmarked by these machines. This averages out to around 256,000 letters per day over a six day week.
(d) The details of Australia Post's agreement with Coca-Cola are commercial-in-confidence.
(e) Other products will be advertised, having due regard to Government regulation and community views.

(f) The revenue generated by this form of advertising will help offset operational costs thereby contributing to Australia Post's objective of keeping increases in the basic postage rate below increases in the general cost of living.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 25 March 1992:

PARA.TAB: Will the Government allocate funds under new initiatives pursuant to the Marriage Act or Family Law Act to family service organisations in 1992-93; if so, (a) what sum, (b) what criteria will apply to the allocation of funding to (i) marriage counselling, (ii) marriage education, (iii) family mediation and (iv) family skills training, (c) by what process will funds be allocated to (i) marriage counselling, (ii) marriage education, (iii) family mediation and (iv) family skills training and (d) to what extent will (i) Marriage Guidance Australia, (ii) the Australian Council of Marriage Counselling Organisations, (iii) Centacare Australia, (iv) the Australian Association for Marriage Education and (v) the Catholic Society for Marriage Education be involved in allocating funds.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that the answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: Yes. The Government will be allocating funds for initiatives pursuant to the Marriage Act and the Family Law Act to family service organisations in 1992-93.
(a) The total amount of funding available for new projects in 1992-93 is $2.4m plus a factor for price adjustment which will be finalised in the course of the Budget process.

(b) The criteria which will be applied to the allocation of funds to marriage counselling, marriage education family mediation and family skills training will be the same for each of the services. As in 1991-92, priority will be accorded to those proposals which address the provision of high quality services to areas of unmet need, particularly in outer metropolitan and rural Australia. Attention will also be focused upon the provision of services to areas of rapid urban growth.

In addition to these broad criteria, the Office of Legal Aid and Family Services has separately identified the need for marriage counselling services by geographical area and organisations have been asked to consider these priority areas in formulating their new project proposals.

(c) The process by which funds will be allocated to marriage counselling, marriage education and family mediation will be the same for each service in 1992-93. Applications for new project funding have been called for and were submitted by 24 April 1992. They are currently being assessed by officers of the Office of Legal Aid and Family Services and recommendations will be made to the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs. Funding for new projects will be available from 1 July 1992 and will be paid in quarterly instalments at the commencement of each quarter. Applications for family skills training will be called for separately, but will be subjected to the same process of assessment within the Department and will also be submitted to the Minister for his consideration.

(d) At the meeting held in Canberra on 27 February 1992 between officers of the Office of Legal Aid and Family Services and the representatives of five peak organisations funded under the Family Services Program, the representatives expressed their wish to be excluded from the process of ranking applications for new project funding. Although the peak organisations may liaise between their affiliates and the Department in providing any additional information which may be required to assess individual proposals, the Department will be responsible for assessing and recommending applications for funding.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, upon notice, on 25 March 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is defence force pilot training to be civilianised, ab initio, at facilities in Tamworth, NSW; if so, how many tenders were received for the project and will he provide details of the tenders.
(2) Who was the successful tenderer and was the successful tender the lowest in cost.
(3) Will other flying schools be allowed to benefit from the civilianisation, ab initio, of defence force pilot training.
(4) Were the Tamworth facilities built with Commonwealth subsidies; if so, what sum was involved.
(5) Which company owns the Tamworth facilities.
(6) Is he able to say (a) who are the directors of the company and (b) whether the company is a subsidiary of or is connected in any way with Ansett Airlines of Australia.
(7) Were the Tamworth facilities originally designed for training pilots from overseas.
(8) Was a tender for defence force pilot training received from a flying school based in Coolangatta, Queensland; if so, why was Tamworth chosen in preference to Coolangatta.
(9) Is he able to say whether Coolangatta is a more suitable location in view of its attractiveness as a place of residence to potential instructors.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bilney The Hon G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The restructure of ADF pilot training, which is managed for the three services by the RAAF, involves:

ANSWER.PARA: a.the commercialisation of Basic Flying Training (BFT) for the Australian Army (ARA) and the Papua New Guinea Defence Force (PNGDF);
b.the introduction of a commercial Flight Screening Program (FSP) for RAN and RAAF pilot candidates; and
c.new all-through basic flying training at No. 2 Flying Training School, RAAF Pearce for RAN and RAAF students.

PARA.TAB: ARA and PNGDF Basic Flying Training and RAN/RAAF Flight Screening will be carried out at a commercial facility in Tamworth, NSW.
Tenders for the BFT/FSP were received from five companies. The details of those tenders are the commercial property of the tenderers.
(2) The successful tenderer was the British Aerospace Ansett Flying College Pty Ltd. This company tendered the lowest price.

(3) No other flying schools are involved in the BFT/FSP contract; however, several flying schools in Canberra provide flying training to Private Pilot Licence standard for selected cadets at the Australian Defence Force Academy. Cadets who participate in this scheme are not required to undertake the FSP at Tamworth.
(4) No Commonwealth subsidies were involved in the construction of the Tamworth facilities.

(5) The Tamworth facilities are owned by British Aerospace Ansett Flying College Pty Ltd, an equal joint venture partnership between British Aerospace (Australia) Holdings Pty Ltd and Ansett Transport Industries Pty Ltd.

(6) The Directors of the College are Mr R. Somervaille, Mr I. Fraser, Mr J. Denny, Mr A. Krotly, Mr J. Bibo and Mr C. Jackson. The company is not a subsidiary of Ansett Airlines of Australia and is only connected with the airline to the extent that the college and the airline share a parent company.

(7) While a significant proportion of the college's business will come from overseas, the design of the facilities is directed at achieving excellence in flying training regardless of the source of the students. The facilities meet the requirements of the ADF in all respects.

(8) A tender was received from a Coolangatta based flying school. However, the tendered price was significantly higher than the winning tender and the facilities offered were of a lower standard than those at Tamworth.

(9) The possible attractiveness of Coolangatta as a place of residence for instructors does not make Coolangatta a more suitable location. In fact, the winning tenderer has many more applications for instructional positions than are available.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Land Transport, upon notice, on 25 March 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Does the draft report of the Eastern Rail Network Study conducted by Booz-Allen and Hamilton in July 1991 for the National Rail Freight Initiative state that the cost of standardisation of the line between Melbourne and Adelaide would be $154 million.
(2) Did the Prime Minister claim in the One Nation ministerial statement he made to the House on 26 February 1992 that the cost would be $115 million; if so, where will the cost reduction come from.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The draft report referred to addresses a number of options and provides a range of estimated costs. The figure of $154 million is quoted in the draft report as an estimate of one option.

(2) In his One Nation statement of 26 February 1992 the Prime Minister announced that the Government would be providing $115 million to fund the standardisation of the main rail link between Melbourne and Adelaide. This cost is lower than estimates appearing in the Booz-Allen and Hamilton report essentially because the latter includes a component for the conversion of spur lines.
The Government's focus in the Statement was on the interstate mainline rail network. Spur lines which service intrastate trade are a matter for State governments.

The Victorian Premier announced in her Economic Statement that the Victorian Government would provide $50 million to enable the Melbourne-Adelaide and associated freight lines and passenger links to be integrated. The Victorian Government is currently examining options in relation to the two wheat lines to Yaapeet and Hopetoun.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Finance, upon notice, on 30 March 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) What are the (a) number, (b) levels and (c) salaries of the officers in the Department/s and agencies for which the Minister has portfolio responsibility who are assigned to (i) full-time or (ii) part-time duties related to corporate plan, program evaluation plan and associated performance management activities.
(2) What is the estimated total cost for 1991-92 in terms of salaries and other payments, including those to consultants, of maintaining the activities referred to in part (1).
(3) How are corporate plans and associated performance activities monitored and evaluated in terms of cost benefits.
(4) How many additional positions have been created since 1989 to plan and co-ordinate the activities referred to in part (1) located.
(5) Where are the officers referred to in part (4) located.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Department of Finance's Corporate Plan provides guidance on broad values and objectives and is expected to provide a framework for Departmental activity for several years. It was prepared through a series of activities involving a large number of Departmental officers and over a period of several months, including work during and outside ordinary office hours. It also involved a working party of varying membership and whose work on the Corporate Plan was incidental to their other duties.

The Program Evaluation Plan results from input by a variety of officers from each of the Department's programs and is organised and produced as one of many projects undertaken in the Resource Policies and Management Branch of the Department. The performance of the evaluation within the Plan depends largely on the nature of the work and its timing.

Performance management in the Department is intrinsic to its overall operations and focuses on: detailed work plans that are prepared; work by internal and external audit; and a variety of staff appraisal mechanisms.

There are no officers in the Department whose full time or part time duties are solely related to the above. The activities are integrated in the broad variety of work conducted by all officers such that it is not possible to differentiate between the work done related to these activities and that required to meet the overall responsibilities of the Department.
(2) Consistent with the above, it is not possible to estimate the cost of salaries and other payments. No consultants have been engaged in relation to maintaining the activities referred to in (1).

(3) As mentioned above, the Corporate Plan consists of broad statements of values, objectives and intent and, as such, does not lend itself to the application of cost benefit techniques. Progress towards achievement of the Corporate Plan is addressed through ad-hoc meetings of a Corporate Plan Focus Group which, by drawing on activity and opinions obtained from throughout the Department, seeks to identify progress made. The minutes of this Group are provided to the Executive of the Department.
(4) Nil.
